annotations.lyric_fragment: [Bridge]

annotation.plain:
One of the earliest and most famous flute instrumental; interlude in rock/pop history.

To be precise, the instrument that mimicked the flute was Musitron, played bythe song’s cowriter Max Crook.

There is only one Musitron. It’s a three-octave keyboard I built from a Clavioline. That’s the basic box. I added pots and resistors and echo and reverb effects.



Another remarkable one is heard in The Mamas and the Papas' “California Dreamin'”.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And the sound of children’s
 Laughter fills the air (Oh, oh yeah)

annotation.plain: “Christmas is for Children” is a Yule-time standard.  Similarly, Bing Crosby’s “Silver Bells” sings of children laughing, and those sentiments ring through to Mariah’s classic: the ambiance of Christmas isn’t complete without happy children somewhere in the tableau.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And everyone is singing (Oh yeah)
 I hear those sleigh bells ringing (Oh)

annotation.plain:
Sleigh bells were once considered a symbol of status and wealth. A matter of safety, they used to warn pedestrians of an approaching vehicle.

In Christmas, they represent that Santa Claus is communicating with the reindeer. They serve as a tool for the festive animals to pull as a team—synchronizing their movements in order to keep balance.

Conclusively, the sleigh bells are a signature trait of Christmas that prevails through time and helps us realize that Santa is near.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Oh, I won’t ask for much this Christmas
 I won’t even wish for snow (And I)

annotation.plain:
“White Christmas” is a seasonal event-and in many country very rare- where it is snowing on Christmas Day. The very beautiful phenomenon,  is so important that it is closely monitored through forecasts.

And yet, Mariah Carey would rather spend time with her lover than hope to see this happen.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I don’t need to hang my stocking
 There upon the fireplace (Ah)

annotation.plain:
Hanging stockings on the fireplace references the tradition when St. Nicholas put money in three poor sister’s stockings while they were hung there to dry. Adding on to the theme that she doesn’t want a lot for Christmas, Mariah says that she doesn’t need to hang up her stockings for more gifts.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I won’t make a list and send it
 To the North Pole for Saint Nick (Ah)
 I won’t even stay awake to
 Hear those magic reindeer click

annotation.plain:
During Christmas, it is custom to make a list of what you want and send it to Saint Nick. Santa Claus, although detractors deny his existence, is known for traveling the world on his magic reindeer to give presents in one night. Many children stay awake at night in an attempt to see Santa or hear the clicking of his reindeers' hooves as they run.

Mariah says she won’t be participating in any of these Christmas traditions because she is so focused on being with her significant other.

annotation.plain: Fun fact: the high note that Mariah sings here is a G5, or treble G. That’s quite high, but not as high as her highest note. According to Bustle, she hits a G#7 in “Emotions,” which is over two octaves higher than this note!

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’m just gonna keep on waiting
 Underneath the mistletoe

annotation.plain: It is a holiday tradition to kiss under the mistletoe during the Christmas holiday. Since this song about how Mariah wants her lover to be with her during Christmas, it would make sense why she would be waiting underneath this seemingly magical plant.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Oh, all the lights are shining
 So brightly everywhere (So brightly, baby)

annotation.plain:
It’s a standard tradition to display Christmas lights outside one’s home for the holiday of Christmas. According to author Antonia Felix, the practice started with early German Christians, and originally represented Jesus:

German families brought a small tree into the home at Christmas time as a symbol of the Christ child, and decorated the boughs with cutout paper flowers, bright foil, apples, sweets, and other fancy treats. Another feature of Christmas that took a uniquely American turn in the nineteenth century is the tradition of Christmas lights. Candles were traditionally placed on the Christmas tree to symbolize Jesus as the light of the world.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I don’t want a lot for Christmas
 There is just one thing I need
 I don’t care about the presents
 Underneath the Christmas tree
 I just want you for my own
 More than you could ever know
 Make my wish come true
 All I want for Christmas is you, yeah

annotation.plain:
Many people think that consumerism is destroying Christmas. People are focused solely on buying and receiving more things instead of the true meaning of Christmas: family, or if you’re Christian, Jesus. Even the UK number one single during the week of Christmas is a big deal in today’s society.

But Mariah doesn’t care about any of that. Ironically, this song is her best selling in the UK, but her wish isn’t for consumer goods or objects. It’s for her lover to be with her on Christmas.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Suddenly
 I’m not half the man I used to be
 There’s a shadow hanging over me
 Oh, yesterday came suddenly

annotation.plain:
The speaker expresses feeling diminished compared to their former self, using the metaphor of being “half the man.”

There’s an implication of a looming presence or problem, described as a “shadow hanging over me.” The final line suggests this change occurred unexpectedly and rapidly, with a connection drawn to the past (“yesterday”).

The repetition of “suddenly” at the beginning and end emphasizes the theme of swift, unexpected transformation.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Mmm-mmm-mmm-mmm-mmm, hmm-hmm

annotation.plain:
This section is most likely inspired by Bobby Day’s 1957 song, “Little Bitty Pretty One.”



He is perhaps best known for writing October 1958’s “Rockin Robin,” which has been covered multiple times.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Yesterday
 Love was such an easy game to play
 Now I need a place to hide away
 Oh, I believe in yesterday

annotation.plain:
In the October 1997 Paul McCartney biography, Many Years From Now by Barry Miles, McCartney was said to have finalized the lyrics during a trip to Portugal in May 1965:


I remember mulling over the tune ‘Yesterday’, and suddenly getting these little one-word openings to the verse. I started to develop the idea … da-da da, yes-ter-day, sud-den-ly, fun-il-ly, mer-il-ly and Yes-ter-day, that’s good. All my troubles seemed so far away.

It’s easy to rhyme those a’s: say, nay, today, away, play, stay, there’s a lot of rhymes and those fall in quite easily, so I gradually pieced it together from that journey. Sud-den-ly, and ‘b’ again, another easy rhyme: e, me, tree, flea, we, and I had the basis of it.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Why she had to go
 I don’t know, she wouldn’t say
 I said something wrong
 Now I long for yesterday

annotation.plain:
In a biography about Paul McCartney, it was theorized that this song was actually an homage to his late mother, Mary–rather than a lost girlfriend or spouse; which is almost a little more depressing.

McCartney himself confirmed the true meaning of the song to be about his mother, when in February 2024, he revealed on his “A life in lyrics” podcast that the song is indeed about his grief for his mother and regret towards one conversation he had with his mother not long before she passed away, in which he mocked her for sounding posh- which he not much later after regretted doing so, and especially after his mother died.

Paul wrote the song while he was still in a committed relationship with Jane Asher  in 1964, though this partnership would dissolve four years later, in 1968.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Yesterday
 All my troubles seemed so far away
 Now it looks as though they’re here to stay
 Oh, I believe in yesterday

annotation.plain:
This song, composed entirely by Paul McCartney, came to him in a dream. He awoke one night while staying in a London attic for the filming of Help!:

I got out of bed, sat at the piano, found G, found F sharp minor 7th – and that leads you through then to B to E minor, and finally back to E. It all leads forward logically. I liked the melody a lot, but because I’d dreamed it, I couldn’t believe I’d written it. I thought, ‘No, I’ve never written anything like this before.’ But I had the tune, which was the most magic thing!

The melody came to McCartney much quicker than lyrical inspiration. In order to arrange the song, he quickly scribbled out placeholder lyrics. Thus, “Yesterday” originally had the working title “Scrambled Eggs,” and opened with:

Scrambled eggs
Oh my baby, how I love your legs

McCartney would subsequently write “Yellow Submarine” in bed, and John Lennon would also stumble upon “Nowhere Man” and “Across The Universe” in dreams. McCartney would later observe:

When you’re trying to write a song, there are certain times when you get the essence, it’s all there. It’s like an egg being laid – not a crack or a flaw in it.

songs.lyrics:

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Piano Intro]

annotation.plain:
Vanessa explained to MTV that after struggling with writing this song, she set it aside for six months, and in the summer of 1998, she was playing around on the piano and ended up using what she played as this well-known intro.

I was frustrated with writer’s block, so I put the song aside for six months. Later that year I was doodling on the piano and I played the beginning of what we now call ‘A Thousand Miles’ for a producer. He stopped me in the middle of the song and asked me what it was. I said, ‘Nothing.’ He said, ‘You have to finish that.’ So I finished the song that Saturday night in an hour.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And I need you
 And I miss you
 And now I wonder

annotation.plain: The uncertainty is centered on living without this person and how missing him or her is consuming her thoughts. She’s not just confused as she trudges along in life but moving along with a piece missing, and important piece that’s really preoccupying her mind.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
If I could fall into the sky
 Do you think time would pass me by?

annotation.plain: This is easily one of the most puzzling lines in Pop Music history and some still speculate to what this actually means. However, the most common theories are when free falling or skydiving it feels like everything around you stops, so does time stop too? Since we can now fall into the sky everything is backwards, does that mean time moves backwards too?

annotations.lyric_fragment:
’Cause you know I’d walk a thousand miles
 If I could just see you tonight

annotation.plain:
The only constant at this point is the one she’s trying to get to in the middle of all of the confusion. Vanessa would do anything just to see and to be with the person she loves as soon as possible.

No matter what lengths.



Walking a thousand miles is not an uncommon theme among love songs. Artists use this hypothetical endeavor to show the drastic measures they would take to be with the one they love. Tyga did it in “Far Away,” and the Proclaimers did it in “I’m Gonna Be(500 Miles).”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Makin’ my way downtown
 Walkin’ fast, faces pass and I’m homebound

annotation.plain:
There’s tons of drama in life. In fact, probably every single person downtown has at least one problem.

Vanessa has hers too, but she’s just trying to get back to the one she loves.

Also, note being “home-bound.” If being home is being with a loved one, then she has just started her 1000-mile journey.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Yeah, you hear my boy
 Soundin’ like a zillion bucks on the track
 I got whatever on my boy, whatever

annotation.plain:
Nitt supporting his boy Fetty.

A zillion is a fictitious number—with a zillion bucks you could buy a bajillion Lambos.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Put your money where your mouth is
 Money on the wood make the game go good

annotation.plain:
If you put your money where your mouth is, and “money on the wood make the game go good”… is Nitt saying that your mouth is on the wood?

A little oral sex wordplay.

But here’s the double meaning: “wood” refers to “hardwood”, the basketball court surface: to say “money on the wood make the game go good” means that a team of high-paid players does well. Nitt’s bankrolling the best team in the game.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Remy Boyz got the stamp though

annotation.plain:
The Remy Boyz’s name refers to the Remy Martin 1738 brand liquor which has a distinctive stamp on the bottle to show authenticity. Also, in East Coast areas like New York, Philly, and the Remy Boyz native New Jersey, heroin is sold in glassine containers called stamp bags. The name comes from their legitimate use by postage stamp collectors, but also for the distinctive graphics “stamped” onto them for branding purposes.

In this sense, the Remy Boyz are the real deal and have the stamp of high-quality product that all the fiends are searching for.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
It’s big ZooWap from the bando
 Remind me where I can’t go

annotation.plain:
ZooWap is a nickname that combines Zoo, another of Fetty’s nicknames, with the part of his name that he adopted from Gucci Mane’s alias Guwap.

Fetty is from 12th and 22nd in Paterson, NJ, an area known for its drug activity. Bandos or abandoned houses are ideal places to sell drugs from since they are off the grid and can be abandoned again if the cops come knocking.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Verse 2]

annotation.plain: This is used as the second verse for the mixtape and some radio versions of this song, most likely because it’s catchier and easier to memorize than Fetty Wap’s rapped verse.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Money out of sight cause fights
 Put up or shut up, huh?

annotation.plain: When people owe someone money but don’t have it, they often stay behind the scene or out of sight. If you don’t get their money you obviously want to fight. Put up with the issue or shut up.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Nitt Da Gritt, huh, RGF Productions

annotation.plain:
Nitt Da Gritt is the head of RGF Productions. Fetty got introduced to him in 2009 by Monty. Nitt provided funds for Fetty early in his career. He also directed the “Trap Queen” music video and drops a verse here and there on occasion.



Left to right: Fetty, Kanye, and Nitt

Remy Boyz, also known as Remy Boyz 1738, is the name of the Paterson, NJ squad consisting of Fetty Wap, Montana Bucks and P-Dice. The name originates from Rémy Martin’s 1738 premium cognac.

He’s pledging allegiance to his crew. He’s saying he would never ride with any other crew other than his current one, Remy Boyz. He’s a loyal member.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I can’t get her out of my mind

annotation.plain: Simply put, you just can’t stop thinking about them because of how much you care for them. And you probably should act on this desire, so long as you’re sure you’re not coercing them into doing things against their wishes.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Getting paid is her forte

annotation.plain:
What does it mean when someone says something is their forte?
a person’s strong suit, or most highly developed characteristic, talent, or skill; something that one excels in: So she excels in getting paid.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I like the playettes
 No diggity, no doubt, uh
 Play on, playette
 Play on, playette

annotation.plain:
The word “Playettes” here, refers to a female version of the word Player, something the Urban Dictionary refers to as “Usually a boy who makes you feel special.  He makes you feel like the only girl in his life, when really you are just one of 100.”

A shoutout to playettes foreshadows some of what the song is about a little later on

annotations.lyric_fragment: Attracting honeys like a magnet

annotation.plain:
While there is no shortage of rap lyrics about men attracting women (or, indeed, music in general), Dr. Dre had a particular reputation as being charming, which got him into trouble in a number of incidents, as he also has had a problematic history of violence against women.

https://www.nme.com/news/music/dr-dre-discusses-abuse-women-fucking-mind-2108142

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Verse 4: Queen Pen]

annotation.plain:
Queen Pen had been performing around New York (she’s from Brooklyn) for years before Teddy Riley plucked her from relative obscurity and put her on this track. Days later, he signed her to his label Lil Man Records, and went on to produce her solo debut album My Melody. In an interview with the New York Times, she said:

Ten years of paying my dues and one night in the studio with Teddy Riley, I got my record deal.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Verse 1: Dr. Dre]

annotation.plain:
Getting Dre on this track wasn’t easy. He was still on Death Row records (he left the label in 1996, when this track came out), lead up by the notorious Suge Knight. Dre wanted to be in the video for this track. Teddy Riley convinced him to just drop a verse. He told Vibe:

And I’m telling him, ‘Well, Dre can’t be in my video unless he raps on the song.’ Because I had been trying to get a Death Row artist on one of my songs for a long time. But Suge Knight (former notorious Death Row head) would not let a Death Row artists be on my album unless we paid him $50,000 and joined his label. And that’s how Dre got on ‘No Diggity.’ He even got a piece of the publishing. ‘No Diggity’ turned out to be the biggest record I’ve ever been associated with as a singer.

Originally, Blackstreet founder Teddy Riley didn’t want any rappers on the album, but decided this would be an exception.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Cover much grounds, got game by the pound

annotation.plain: Teddy Riley’s cowriter and coproducer on this track—William Stewart—came up with this line.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Shorty get down, good Lord

annotation.plain:
Teddy Riley told Vibe:

I wanted the song to start with ‘Shorty get down…’ And then I thought, ‘Well, can we add the words Good Lord to the track?’ I’m like, ‘Man, it’s sounding like a gospel record.’ [laughs] So we came up with, ‘Shorty get down, good Lord, she got it working all over town…’

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I like the way you work it
 No diggity,

annotation.plain:
This began as an older song—“I Like the Way You Work It,” a cut off their self-titled debut album. Riley tapped LL Cool J to come remix that original song, and he was the one to inadvertently to come up with the lyric “no diggity, no doubt.”

Teddy Riley told the story on Lorna’s Corner:

We got the single from a song that we did called “I Like the Way You Work” which was on the last album. We wanted to just take it to another level—because we felt like there was just something that wasn’t there. But it was a great hook. So we add on “no diggity, I got to bag it up.” It was also part of a remix we were supposed to do for “I Like the Way You Work” and it was done with LL Cool J. He was saying “I like the way you work, kid, no diggity”—you know, as a rap. We just said ‘we wanna make this into a song.’ And we did that.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Zn1kKBatkE8

annotations.lyric_fragment:
But it’s just the price I pay
 Destiny is calling me

annotation.plain:
The price he pays is the feeling of losing her more and more as time flies by. This brings in jealousy, to the point his feelings are so hazy, he chokes on his words. This ‘price’ he talks about feels like destiny to him. He feels like this was meant to happen, perhaps because she felt like he wasn’t enough, hence the need to cheat on him.

The price could also mean that he didn’t probably pay too much attention to the situation because it was “only a kiss” and now he doesn’t know how it ended up this way. He calls that his ‘destiny’, showing that maybe he trusted her so much, he never felt that the suspicion he had was valid and real. He tries to cope with her disloyalty by blaming himself and says that it’s just the price he pays for being too trusting.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Gotta, gotta be down because I want it all

annotation.plain: Just like the earlier lyrics. He needs to be ready, knowing if he isn’t, he can’t do what he puts his mind to

This ‘price’ he talks about feels like destiny to him. He feels like this was meant to happen, perhaps because she felt like he wasn’t enough, hence the need to cheat on him.

The price could also mean that he didn’t probably pay too much attention to the situation because it was “only a kiss” and now he doesn’t know how it ended up this way. He calls that his ‘destiny’, showing that maybe he trusted her so much, he never felt that the suspicion he had was valid and real. He tries to cope with her disloyalty by blaming himself and says that it’s just the price he pays for being too trusting.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Let me go
 And I just can’t look, it’s killing me
 They’re taking control

annotation.plain: Our narrator has already tried once to control the image in his mind’s eye, making an R-rated scene more PG, but now he’s failing again. He wants the jealous, fantasized images to stop, but he finds he cannot – they [the images] are taking control of what he sees, thinks, and feels.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Verse 2]

annotation.plain:
Lead singer and lyricist Brandon Flowers told NME,

I remember being in the studio, recording the demo but still writing the lyrics. I was procrastinating, and that’s why the second verse is the same as the first one, but it just stuck. What strikes me about it is how powerful that song still is, and the second verse is still as powerful as the first one, every night. There’s just something about it. It’s a moment.

The repetition of verses is a significant reason for the song being so memorable and why so many know the lyrics. But most of the credit is justifiably given to the fact that it is a great song.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Interlude]

annotation.plain:
There’s a brief instrumental here – only about 4 bars long – that is notable as being the best place to spot the source of the melody for “Mr. Brightside” – Beethoven’s “Ode to Joy.”

https://youtu.be/qjG7TqoQog4

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I never
 I never
 I never
 I never

annotation.plain:
This outro is about regrets. In the beginning of the song the woman leaves off in a cab to meet another man with his cigarette. Flowers is saying that he was not to blame. It’s too late now for him to go back though, because she found someone else. It repeats itself to emphasize the point. He never expected her to cheat and leave him this way, reinforcing the line “It started out with a kiss, how did it end up like this?”

The repetition of the phrase is also sung with a variety of emotions, following the pattern of the stages of grief: Shock/Denial, Pain/Guilt/Anger, Depression/Reflection, and finally Acceptance. Another interpretation about the different feelings involved in the singing may be related to just two varieties: a more calm one (twice, identical) and a more angry one (twice, identical).

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Open up my eager eyes
 ’Cause I’m Mr. Brightside

annotation.plain:
“Mr Brightside” is being used ironically to name himself because he is assuming the worst of his lover.

He is “Mr Brightside” because he always looks on the bright side of things. But someone (“destiny”, probably himself looking into the future) is telling to open his “eager” (doesn’t want to believe the truth) eyes to the fact that he is being cheated on.

Calling himself Mr.Brightside is alluding more to him knowing she is cheating (hence, open up my eager eyes). In other words, I do not believe it is an empty suspicion, as stated above. He is able to look at the dismissal of his relationship as destiny, and an opportunity to advance as a person. I agree the irony in calling himself Mr.Brightside when he is assuming the worst (when he has only seen a kiss) is probable as well, but it should be noted that he is actually looking at the bright side of the end of his relationship with a girl. So though it is ironic that he calls himself Mr.Brightside when he is assuming the furthest extent of cheating, he is in actuality Mr.Brightside because he can understand that this relationship has run its course (destiny is calling me).

annotations.lyric_fragment: And she’s calling a cab

annotation.plain:
He’s imagining his lover calling a cab, out somewhere at the end of the night without him. This could also possibly be her finally making the decision to leave/cheat on him.

David Bowie was a major influence on the Killers, and his song “Queen Bitch” contains the lines:

Now I’m phoning a cab
Cause my stomach feels small

Along with the rest of the lyrics to “Queen Bitch”, this is an interesting and likely intentional (on the Killers’ part, of course) parallel to “Mr. Brightside”.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I know that living with you, baby, was sometimes hard

annotation.plain: In her memoir, “Rememberings,” O'Connor explains that her mother was physically, verbally and emotionally abusive towards her. Though she still missed her and thought of her often.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
’Cause nothing compares
 Nothing compares to you

annotation.plain: Is in love with a concrete person, unique and irreplaceable. No one else and nothing else can fill the void of the absence of the beloved person.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I could put my arms around every boy I see
 But they’d only remind me of you

annotation.plain:
O'Connor hypothesizes whether being with other men would help her deal with the void left by her absent lover, but even here she finds the idea of promiscuous overcompensation lacking in comparison to the relationship she had before: being physically involved with other men would only bring her to mind the memory of the more complete, more fulfilling relationship she had with her lover (until he left, of course). Even the idea of such a fleeting connection can’t compare with the memory of her previous one.

This situation evokes a psychological/neurological term called involuntary memory, defined as a specific type of memory where a sensory or emotional stimulus in the present causes someone to remember a person or situation from their past without prior effort.

In literature, this concept is best and most famously represented by Marcel Proust’s memory-trigging madeleines from his magnum opus In Search of Lost Time, but it is an idea evoked in many different forms of popular culture, including music.

One recent musical example is Sam Smith’s “Reminds Me Of You”, which seems to act as a real life experience of the scenario that O'Connor (through Prince’s lyrics) left only in the realm of hypotheticals:

And God knows I try
Looking for lovers at night
But each time I do
It only reminds me of you
It only reminds me of you

annotations.lyric_fragment:
It’s been seven hours and fifteen days
 Since you took your love away

annotation.plain:
Sinéad O'Connor is stating that the breakup happened exactly 15 days, 7 hours prior.

Usually when someone experience a breakup they have a hard time getting over it.  Sinéad evens know how many hours it’s been since the breakup – it’s as if the world stopped for her, and this is a new era in her life.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
All the flowers that you planted, mama, in the backyard
 All died when you went away

annotation.plain:
In the video, this is the line that makes O'Connor cry (though the tears don’t fall until the next chorus.) In interviews, she has said she was struck by thoughts of her deceased mother when she sang this line during the video shoot:

“It’s always the same thing and it always works… I always think of my mother… which is why I had the little tear in the video. My mother died when I was 17 and it wasn’t long after that that I was making the video.”

 Na, na-na-na, na-na
 Na, na-na-na, na-na-na, na, na

annotation.plain:
Na na na’s are a common vocalization in One Direction’s debut album. It is used in the intro and interlude of “I Wish” and it’s also the title of the B-side of “What Makes You Beautiful:”

We’re like na na na
Then we’re like yeah yeah yeah
Always like na na na
Then we’re like yeah yeah yeah
No we can’t make up our minds
‘Cause when we think we’ve got it right
We go na na na
Na na na

The boyband also uses na na na’s in many other songs throughout their discography, i.e. November 2012’s “Kiss You” and July 2013’s “Best Song Ever.”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You don’t know, oh-oh, you don’t know you’re beautiful, oh-oh
 That’s what makes you beautiful

annotation.plain:
Those lyrics were criticized because one possible interpretation is that the boys are attracted to this girl because of her low self-esteem, as pointed out by Chloe Angyal of Feministing.

Comedian Stephen Colbert argued that those lines are not only prone to problematic interpretations, but also might have a logical flaw!

First of all: great dating advice. Remember girls, low self esteem – very attractive to men. Guys always go for the low hanging fruit, easy pickings. Second: the lyrics are incredibly complex! You see, the boys are singing ‘You don’t know you’re beautiful, that’s what makes you beautiful.’ But they’ve just told the girl she’s beautiful. So since she now knows it, she’s no longer beautiful! But – stick with me, stick with me, oh it goes deeper! – but she’s listening to the song, too. So she knows she’s not beautiful. Therefore, following the syllogism of the song, she’s instantly beautiful again!

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Written By Savan Kotecha]

annotation.plain:
Savan Kotecha wrote the lyrics about his wife, Anna… while on the toilet. (No, really.)

I was literally taking a shit at the Royal Garden hotel in London. My wife was on the other side of the wall and she was having one of those ‘I feel so ugly’ days. I shouted ‘you’re not’ and in my mind I was thinking ‘wow, that’s one of the great things about you is that you don’t know how beautiful you are and that’s what makes you beautiful’. I literally wrote down the phrase and then I went to the studio with Rami [Yacoub] and Carl [Falk]. I had the melody of “baby you light up my world like nobody else” in my head and then everything connected.



Regarding the popularity of the song, Kotecha told Pop Justice that the song isn’t as perfect as One Direction fans claim:

[…] I’ve had artists come up to me and say ‘dude, ‘What Make You Beautiful’ is the perfect song’. I knew that the math was right, but I guess when it’s all together and the voices are on it and it’s mixed it worked out. […] At the last second I changed a couple of lines, like the ‘flip your hair, get you overwhelmed’ bit wasn’t there. That was a juicy line.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Don’t try to change it now sayin’ you gotta bounce
 When two seconds ago said you just got in the house

annotation.plain:
Sensing trouble from Beyoncé bringing her friends over to his house, the boyfriend tries to to keep her from coming to his house by saying he’s about to leave.

To Beyoncé, this sounds suspicious. He just stated that he just made it home, but now he’s all of a sudden about to leave again, so she believes that he’s just making up an excuse so she doesn’t come over and find that another woman is there.

annotations.lyric_fragment: (Darkchild ’99)

annotation.plain: When this first came out, and even now, people think that he says, “Darkchild, na na.” In October 2018, he clarified this.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Intro: Rodney “Darkchild” Jerkins]

annotation.plain: Producer of “Say My Name” Rodney Jerkins is heard in the intro of the song, using one of his trademark producer tags, “Darkchild 99”.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Where you’re sayin’ everything to me times two

annotation.plain: Stuttering can be a sign of nervousness, especially when someone is attempting to make up a lie on the spot. This behaviour makes Beyonce further suspicious that their partner is cheating.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I know you say that I am assuming things

annotation.plain:
The individual she is referring to is being questioned about their behaviour – she suspects they are cheating, so they employ a simple gaslighting technique. By making the girl question herself (“Am I just making assumptions?”), he is able to shift away from the accusations and merely imply that she’s making it all up.

In an interview with Terrell, LeToya mentioned that this line was inspired by one of her ex-boyfriends who would tell her that she was always assuming stuff:

I ain’t gon' say no names, but I wanna thank you for this line. He would always say that I was assuming stuff. I’m not dumb, I’m not making an assumption, I actually saw. Your girl called me, sweet cakes. She got my number, she called my phone and she told me what your head on, okay? So it wasn’t an assumption. She called me with the facts. But thank you for the line, anyway.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Any other day I would call, you would say
 “Baby, how’s your day?” But today, it ain’t the same
 Every other word is “Uh-huh, yeah, okay”
 Could it be that you are at the crib with another lady?
 If you took it there, first of all, let me say
 I am not the one to sit around and be played
 So prove yourself to me if I’m the girl that you claim
 Why don’t you say the things that you said to me yesterday?

annotation.plain:
When you call your partner and you say things that really sound like you care about them, such as “Baby, how’s your day going?”, that makes them think the relationship is going good and that you care.

However, saying phrases such as “uh-huh”, “yeah” or “ok” make one appear disinterested, and that they are in-fact not listening or caring about the conversation with their supposed lover.

But she can see through this façade, and ponders on whether or not her partner is actually cheating on her. Why act loving one day, but disinterested the next?

annotation.plain:
This is likely a reference to Henry Glover’s blues standard “Drown in My Own Tears,” popularized by Ray Charles—one of Stevie Wonder’s idols. The song is about mourning a lost love:

It brings a tear
Into my eyes
When I begin
To realize
I’ve cried so much
Since you’ve been gone
I guess I’m drowning in my own tears

annotation.plain:
In 2021, Sulley told The Guardian:

I’ve spent 40 years telling people I never worked in a cocktail bar.

Oakley also shared:

The first verse came more or less wholesale from a photo romance magazine I was reading. The first line was: “You were working as a waitress in a cocktail bar.”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I picked you out, I shook you up, and turned you around
 Turned you into someone new

annotation.plain:
The lyrics were originally inspired after lead singer Philip Oakey read a photo-story in a teen-girl’s magazine.

Oakley is stating that as their relationship blossomed, he helped Sulley/the other female vocalist and member of the Human League. Alternatively known as the cocktail waitress out the rut of being in the job.

Oakley is claiming that he is the one to be praised for helping her, additonally suggesting that she should be thankful to him for that.

By standards and general consensus in the modern day – 2019- this is viewed as creepy and concerning as even if a relationship is over, you do not try to manipulate the other and praise yourself for their growth.
If anything, Oakley should be happy that he helped her and look back on the good 5 year they had, instead of being bitter.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
But even then, I knew I’d find a much better place
 Either with or without you

annotation.plain: Sulley is stating that at the time Phillip met her she still thought she could do better than the low (of being a waitress) she was at. This verse is probably due to their relationship ending therefore she is saying this is hindsight to hurt Phillip’s feelings.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
But don’t forget, it’s me who put you where you are now
 And I can put you back down too

annotation.plain: He is taking credit for her success and threatening to ruin her if she doesn’t stay in a romantic relationship with him. By today’s standards he is obviously a sexual predator, but in the 80’s we didn’t notice stuff like that.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Ever since I left the city—

annotation.plain:
By ending with this line from the top of the first two verses, it seems like Drake has an infinite list of things that’ve changed with this girl since he blew up.

The longing for the old times with his girl before he was famous and she got interested in other guys/traveling the world/etc doesn’t stop at the end of the song. It’s almost as if the song is meant to be played on repeat, which in fact it was, for 12 minutes, when Drake premiered it on the the second episode of the OVO Sound show on Beats1 radio on July 25, 2015 (starts around 1:09:35).

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Why you never alone?
 Why you always touchin’ road?
 Used to always stay at home
 Be a good girl, you was in the zone
 Yeah, you should just be yourself
 Right now, you’re someone else

annotation.plain:
“Touch road” is Jamaican slang commonly used in Toronto to mean going out. Drake’s girl seems to be doing this more often than he remembers—he remembers her as a stay-at-home girl who he could get in the zone with whenever they got the chance.

The girl he once knew is gone, and even though he knows it is this new place that has changed her, he has a difficult time accepting that and pleads she should be herself.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Produced by Nineteen85]

annotation.plain:
“Hotline Bling” samples the drum machine loop and jazzy Hammond organ from the Timmy Thomas soul song “Why Can’t We Live Together.”

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cFU-FJzPE80

“Why Can’t We Live Together” was previously covered by Sade on her 1984 debut album. If Drake doesn’t already know about this connection, he would probably be very pleased:



Lots of people think it samples D.R.A.M.’s “Cha Cha”, which is why D.R.A.M. feels jacked:

https://twitter.com/ONLY1DRAM/status/656311192198082561

When the song premiered on Beats 1 Radio, the service called out the connection on Twitter:

https://twitter.com/Beats1/status/625082033002319873

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Doing things I taught you, gettin’ nasty for someone else
 You don’t need no one else
 You don’t need nobody else, no

annotation.plain:
Drake has tricks up his sleeve to hit all the right spots, so it’s no surprise his girl learned a thing or two from him.



This line is reminiscent of Kanye’s skit at the end of “Blame Game”, where Yeezy taught his girl how to get sexy for another man.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
These days, all I do is
 Wonder if you’re bendin’ over backwards for someone else
 Wonder if you’re rollin’ up a Backwoods for someone else

annotation.plain:
Filled with regret, Drizzy’s got an ex on his mind. Is she sleeping with someone else? Is she rolling blunts for someone else?

“Backwoods” are a cheap brand of cigar. While it’s common practice to empty out the tobacco and re-fill it with weed to create a blunt, it also sounds like Drake says “backwards.” Is this girl pleasing someone else in the bedroom? He used a similar line on “Shot For Me”.



“Bending over backwards” has a double meaning as an idiom for putting a lot of effort into helping someone. As well as the more literal sexual meaning. So this can be read as the narrator not just missing the sexual side of the relationship but the emotional closeness, with them putting a lot of effort into making someone else happy, but not him anymore.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Ever since I left the city, you, you, you
 You and me, we just don’t get along
 You make me feel like I did you wrong
 Goin’ places where you don’t belong
 Ever since I left the city, you
 You got exactly what you asked for
 Runnin’ out of pages in your passport
 Hangin’ with some girls I’ve never seen before

annotation.plain:
In 2009, it was reported Drake was seeing fashion designer, Nebby. Yet once he blew up and left Toronto, it seems like the relationship ended and Drake doesn’t know why.



Did she want to leave with him and he said no? It’s possible, her Tumblr and Instagram see her roaming the world, running out of pages in her passport. Nowadays a lot of “Instagram models” get flown out to exotic countries by wealthy men. Could she be doing the same thing? Sure seems like it.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And I know when that hotline bling
 That can only mean one thing
 I know when that hotline bling
 That can only mean one thing

annotation.plain:
Drake knows that at this time of night, there’s only one person who’ll call him. He also knows that the only thing she’ll want is to come over and have sex. By describing his cell phone as a hotline, he’s referencing phone sex hotlines that people call “for a good time.”

Notably, Drake is using “bling” as the sound of his phone ringing. Drake’s mentor Lil Wayne originally coined the ideophone “bling bling” as a sound that could adequately express the flash of jewelry. Also worth noting that rings are jewelry, cellphone ring = bling. Wow!

Slate wrote about Drake’s love-hate relationship with communications technology and even said “he’s claimed the laurels of the 21st-century bard of telephony.”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Ever since I left the city, you
 Got a reputation for yourself now
 Everybody knows and I feel left out
 Girl, you got me down, you got me stressed out
 ’Cause ever since I left the city, you
 Started wearin’ less and goin’ out more
 Glasses of champagne out on the dance floor
 Hangin’ with some girls I never seen before

annotation.plain:
Similar to the way he did on “Club Paradise,” Drake reflects on how the girls he used to kick it with in Toronto have changed. Drizzy presumably acted as a mentor, and without his guidance, these girls have gone down a route of selling themselves short to attain money and fame.

The subject seems to be his old flame from ‘09, Nebby. Her Instagram showcases her wild adventures around the world whilst at times wearing very little clothing. Drake is no stranger to dedicating entire tracks to women, as both Cece and Bria have served as muses for his songs with the similar sentiment of long distance and regret.

They say that all your old girls got somebody new

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You used to call me on my
 You used to, you used to
 Yeah

annotation.plain:
Before his rise to fame, Drake was just an average guy living in the suburban part of Toronto. Back then he had a girl that adored him, but his stardom slowly tarnished their relationship as she no longer gives him any attention.

This girl is most likely his former Canadian flame Nebby whom he has mentioned in songs such as “Look What You’ve Done” and “Best I Ever Had.” Regardless of what she needed, Drake would drop everything when she’d call, especially if it was at night.

Drake stops and starts in the intro, perhaps choking up with sadness at the loss he’s experiencing. Also, in the third line of the chorus, Drake omits the “you used to…” anacrusis, turning the nostalgic, regretful tone into a more demanding one, with an imperative.

annotations.lyric_fragment: My locs

annotation.plain:
Locs were a style of darkly tinted sunglasses that were popular within hip-hop culture in the late 1980s and early 1990s.



“The Ray Ban Wayfarer-esque sunglasses known as “Locs” have been a part of West Coast hip-hop culture since the days of N.W.A. Allegedly, the name is derived from the Spanish word “loco” and was originally worn by Cholos before Los Angeles gangsters started wearing them. Perhaps the best way to understand the origin of these frames is to listen to that fake radio ad for locs on Above The Law’s 1990 track “Livin' Like Hustlers.””

https://www.complex.com/style/iconic-hip-hop-sunglasses

annotation.plain: “Baby Girl” is the nickname Timbo the King had for Aaliyah. Eventually most people took this nickname on. And of course, he is originally from Virginia Beach, Virginia.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You don’t even have to do too much

annotation.plain: Abel may be talking about opiate withdrawal. During opiate withdrawal, your body is extremely sensitive. Because of this, even the slightest touch could turn him on.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You can turn me on with just a touch, baby

annotation.plain:
Abel expresses his great sensitivity towards the girl he’s with to show he’s really in love with her, or that he clings to every sign of affection, following what he says in the verse.

Also, even if that mustn’t be the same person he’s talking about in this track, Abel is not unfamiliar with this kind of touch. That could imply a reminiscence of feelings he had in his (fictional) past life, and the fact that he’s very sensitive towards women, and has always been.

This idea is somewhat confirmed in the chorus.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’m running out of time
 ’Cause I can see the sun light up the sky

annotation.plain:
This line has several meanings:

First, he alludes to Las Vegas again. As mentioned in the pre-chorus of the song, Abel has a special emotional connection to the city. He recalls it here and automatically combines it with the chorus:

No, I can’t sleep until I feel your touch

Furthermore, Vegas is a city, known for being “alive” at night. Another reason this song’s story, or the whole album takes place in Vegas are Abel’s
repeated references of it, adding to the fact, that he feels at home there.

Abel fears, that he won’t be able to sleep, because he lost his loved one and needs to get her back to finally get sleep. At the end of his journey, he recalls this line. On “Final Lullaby”, the last track off the deluxe version of his album After Hours, Abel tries to accept the fact that he won’t find his love back in that night.

I’m running out of time
And you’ll always be on my mind

Another explanation could be his habit to be awake late at night, as already mentioned in “Alone Again”:

I’m falling only for the night

A possible reason for him being stressed during the day is his fame and popularity. During the day, Abel is blinded by the lights of police cars, but also by flashing camera lights, representing fame. Therefore, he likes to escape into the night, just like in his record “Snowchild”:

Leaving, leaving into the night
Now a nigga leaving, leaving
Leaving into the night, oh

annotations.lyric_fragment: I’m goin’ through withdrawals

annotation.plain:
A “withdrawal” can both mean the behavior in which one prefers to be alone or also the physical and mental effects experienced when a person stops using a drug. Considering Abel’s historic of drug abuse, which is largely mentioned in his songs, the second one is more likely.

Moreover, in a 2016 interview with The Guardian he referred to the subject:

When I had nothing to do but make music, it was very heavy. Drugs were a crutch for me.

annotations.lyric_fragment: So I hit the road in overdrive, baby, oh

annotation.plain:
Here, Abel alludes to his habit of driving over the speed limit, which he has mentioned in several songs in the past, such as on “Heartless,”“ featured on his fourth studio album, After Hours:

I’ve been dodgin' death in the six-speed

Abel also admits his love for dangerous speeding on his September 2016 single “Starboy”

100 on the dash get me close to God

“Blinding Lights” was also originally teased in a German Mercedes-Benz commercial, where The Weeknd is shown driving an electric car while the song plays in the background.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=97eZHGbaGZQ

annotations.lyric_fragment: I’ve been tryna call

annotation.plain:
The first line of this song represents Abel’s vulnerability. A theme explored throughout the rest of this song. On the song “Coming Down,” Abel expresses very similar feelings:

Pick up your phone
The party’s finished and I want you to know
I’m all alone

Without drugs, Abel feels a sense of loneliness. This is perhaps Abel’s truest and most authentic self.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I said, ooh, I’m blinded by the lights
 No, I can’t sleep until I feel your touch
 I said, ooh, I’m drowning in the night
 Oh, when I’m like this, you’re the one I trust
 Hey, hey, hey

annotation.plain:
This song directly follows the outro of “Faith,” where The Weeknd speaks about being in the back of a police car presumably after an overdose:

I ended up in the back of a flashing car
With the city shining on my face
The lights are blinding me again

The “lights” here not only represent the lights from the police car or the city but also the fame Abel’s enjoyed for his recording career. From stage lights to paparazzi camera flashes, he’s been “blinded” by many examples of a wealthy and successful life, and he doesn’t plan on stopping anytime soon. However, his celebrity life often overshadows his deep personal life. On his 2018 song “Privilege,” Abel discusses how many fans and media sources didn’t believe that he could have a real and genuine relationship with a partner because of his status in fame:

They said our love is just a game, I don’t care what they say

Nevertheless, his relationship seems to be real and sound, as he claims that it is the only thing that can keep him peacefully inserted in this lifestyle.

Abel also uses a similar line on “Snowchild,” the fifth track from After Hours:

Leaving, leaving into the night
Now a nigga leaving, leaving
Leaving into the night, oh

annotations.lyric_fragment: I’ve been on my own for long enough

annotation.plain:
Abel’s been on his own since around the age of 17 when he dropped out of high school and left home to never come back. This is referenced on many of his songs, like “Rolling Stone,” from his mixtape Thursday, where he said:

‘Cause I’ve been on these streets way too long, too long, too long
Baby, I’ve been on this too long

He’s also implying that he has been single for quite some time now and has forgotten how to love. From 2015 to 2019 Abel and model Bella Hadid had an on and off relationship, and after spending a few months apart, Abel seems to have lost his ability to love.

To add on, throughout After Hours, Abel plays with the idea of being “alone together” or simply “alone” on songs like “Save Your Tears”, “Faith,” and the opening track “Alone Again:”

‘Cause I don’t know if I can be alone again
I don’t know if I can be alone again

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I look around and
 Sin City’s cold and empty (Oh)
 No one’s around to judge me (Oh)
 I can’t see clearly when you’re gone

annotation.plain:
Las Vegas is nicknamed “Sin City” due to the city’s overwhelming presence of crime, drugs, and sexual promiscuity—all important themes throughout The Weeknd’s career. He also explores hedonism on his August 2011 song “Heaven or Las Vegas.”

Abel experienced emptiness and heartbreak when he was briefly separated from Bella Hadid in 2019. The two have since reunited and emotionally completed The Weeknd.

Abel previously touched upon his need for Bella on his November 2019 single, “Heartless”:

You just came back in my life
You never gave up on me (Why don’t you?)
I’ll never know what you see (Why won’t you?)
I don’t do well when alone (Oh yeah)

annotations.lyric_fragment: He moves in space with minimum waste and maximum joy

annotation.plain:
Here, along with the line about “street-car desire” places an imagery of a modern man that lives an urban life.
The act of moving with minimum waste and with maximum joy can intend that the man of the song finds pleasure in driving cars, as well as that he effortlessly exudes confidence in the way he carries himself.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Coast-to-coast, L.A. to Chicago, western male

annotation.plain: A famous, or possibly infamous, geographical puzzle, since although Los Angeles is indeed on the West Coast of the USA, Chicago is noticeably NOT on the East (or West) coast of the USA, raising the question of how such a journey can be described as being ‘coast-to-coast’. One option is that the coast-to-coast part is just one step of the journey, with the second step being the journey from the East Coast to Chicago. The second option is that the coast being referred to is the coast of Lake Michigan, which is Chicago does indeed lie upon. This does seem a bit strange though. Then again, Lake Michigan and Lake Huron are both in fact hydrologically part of Lake Michigan-Huron, which, treated as a single lake, is the world’s largest freshwater lake, and second largest lake after the Caspian Sea. In other words, describing Chicago as a ‘coastal’ city is maybe not quite such a crazy stretch as it seems. Then again, the third option is that Sade Adu simply needed a city with a name that rhymed (in her British accent) with ‘Key Largo’, and that ‘Chicago’ does that.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Face-to-face, each classic case
 We shadowbox and double-cross
 Yet need the chase

annotation.plain:
Shadowboxing can be defined as ‘fighting an imaginary opponent by hitting the air’ but it can also mean ‘arguing or dealing with smaller problems to evade the main one’. The first case suggests both parties are in a psychological battle or conflict, along with deceit and betrayal. The second definition implies they were metaphorically not face-to-face to begin with, contradicting the first line.

…yet the pursuit continues.
The beauty of a paradoxical (and probably toxic) relationship, perhaps.

annotations.lyric_fragment: When you require streetcar desire for higher heights

annotation.plain:
Referance to 1947 play, ‘A Streetcar Named Desire’ by Tennessee Williams. An American classic which touches on themes of desire, truth, and the idea of ‘new vs old America’. Our protagonist, the aging Southern belle, Blanche, comes from her families estate to visit her sister in multicultural New Orleans. After arriving in a red streetcar, literally named desire, she is appalled by her sister’s poor living quarters and the coarseness of her brother-in-law, Stanley, who Blanche jokes to her sister about flirting with. She stars a relationship with his friend Mitch, though this is cut short as through the course of the play Stanley works to uncover the dark secrets of Blances past, and expose her “loose morels”. The play is likened to a card game, as one of the first scenes, and also the last scene features one of Stanleys ‘poker nights’. The final line reads “This game is seven-card stud”.

Marlon Brando’s portrayal of a muscled, sweaty Stanley Kowalski in the film adaptation, perpetually clad in a tight-fitting tank top or in the process of taking it off, made him a sex symbol. This line likely intends to compare the “smooth operator” to Stanley, whose primordial passions Blanche describes thus:

Thousands and thousands of years have passed him right by, and there he is – Stanley Kowalski – survivor of the Stone Age! Bearing the raw meat home from the kill in the jungle! And you – you here – waiting for him! Maybe he’ll strike you or maybe grunt and kiss you!

annotations.lyric_fragment:
A license to love, insurance to hold
 Melts all your memories and change into gold
 His eyes are like angels; his heart is cold

annotation.plain:
“Smooth Operator” is a seductive and atmospheric track that showcases Sade’s unique blend of jazz, R&B, and pop. The lyrics tell a story of a Western male who is loved in seven languages and is the subject of the narrator’s desire. The song’s setup establishes a lively and cosmopolitan atmosphere, with references to diamond life, city lights, and business nights. The character desires a relationship with this man that will bring them “minimum waste and maximum joy,” which may be interpreted as a sexual reference.

The confrontation section of the song introduces a license to love and insurance to hold, which could be seen as a desire for a committed and official relationship. The lyrics then state that this license “melts all your memories and change into gold,” which may be interpreted as the character’s orgasmic experience with the man. The song’s resolution acknowledges the character’s desire for the man but ultimately concludes that their request cannot be granted by someone with a cold heart.

Overall, “Smooth Operator” is a beautifully crafted song with poetic and atmospheric lyrics that create a vivid narrative. The combination of Sade’s smooth vocals and the song’s seductive instrumental backing creates an alluring and captivating listening experience.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Smoother than a fresh jar of Skippy

annotation.plain:
Bruno e la sua crew sono più smoother (lisci) di un barattolo di arachidi.

In italiano questa frase non ha assolutamente senso. Secondo Urban Dictionary la parola Smooth sta ad intendere un difficilissimo lavoro fatto passare come semplice.

In questo caso Bruno ha voluto giocare sui due significati della parola, dicendo che ciò che hanno fatto (suonare live) è stato facile (anche se in realtà non lo è) ed è stato più liscio di un barattolo di arachidi.

annotation.plain:
Ragazze urlate il vostro Hallelujah! (Woo!)
Perché il Funk dei Quartieri alti sta per darvelo (il piacere)

Il termine “Hallelujah” non ha bisogno di spiegazioni, è un'espressione attraverso la quale si prega Dio. In questo caso alle ragazze viene chiesto di pregare la canzone (la cui risposta è indicata dal Woo!).

Ci sono delle allusioni sessuali all'interno delle parole: la musica procura piacere e le fa sentire bene.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And a Britney song was on
 And a Britney song was on
 And a Britney song was on

annotation.plain:
It couldn’t have been “Hold It Against Me” because that wasn’t out yet – maybe “Slave For You”?

Miley recorded this song in 2008. It is also a possibility that the song was “Gimme More” or “Piece of Me.” If the song was recorded late 2008, it could have been “Circus,” “Womanizer,” or “If U Seek Amy.”

annotations.lyric_fragment: They’re playin’ my song, the butterflies fly away

annotation.plain:
These butterflies are the ones in your stomach. The song makes her feel at home and she relaxes.

In a weird coincidence, on the hit Disney TV show, Hannah Montana, Miley Cyrus and her father, Billy Ray Cyrus, sang a song called “Butterfly Fly Away". However, this line was actually written before Miley Cyrus was attached to the song – it appears in Jessie J’s original demo version. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KrL8ndJRgcQ

annotations.lyric_fragment: Look to my right, and I see the Hollywood sign

annotation.plain: It’s interesting to note that if Miley Cyrus were to come straight from LAX, the infamous Hollywood sign would actually be to her left, and not her right. Of course, she could be looking out the back of the cab, which would place the sign on her right.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I hopped off the plane at LAX
 With a dream and my cardigan
 Welcome to the land of fame excess (Woah)
 Am I gonna fit in?

annotation.plain: LAX is the airport code for Los Angeles' International Airport. Hollywood, a Los Angeles neighborhood, is home to many people who hope to make their dreams come true. The use of “cardigan” suggests that she’s there with just the clothes on her back—clothes not even meant for the dry Los Angeles climate.

annotation.plain:
It is rumored that she was talking about Jay-Z’s 2009 hit “Empire State of Mind”.

However, this song was released before “Empire State of Mind” was. Along with the fact that Miley claims she’s never heard Jay-Z, as she wasn’t credit as a writer for this song, but Jessie J was.

The song in question could be Jay’s 2001 hit “Izzo (H.O.V.A.).” Cyrus references putting her hands up in this song’s chorus, so does “Izzo”:

H to the Izz-O, V to the Izz-A
That’s the anthem, get'cha damn hands up!

I’d rather live in his world (Live in his world)

annotation.plain:
Travis Morrison sings about this in the Ice of Boston.

https://genius.com/10267142

annotations.lyric_fragment: (A superstar, but he didn’t get far)

annotation.plain:
According to Wikipedia, Jim Weatherly penned this line in particular as a reaction to a conversation he was having with Farah Fawcett, who was dating Lee Majors at the time and whom was speaking to Weatherly via Majors' telephone, as he was a bit confused as why she was opting to take “the midnight plane to Houston” from L.A.
I guess the implication is that he did not understand why Fawcett was leaving Majors' home in the middle of the night.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’d rather live in his world (Live in his world)
 Than live without him in mine (Her world is his, his and hers alone)

annotation.plain: She’s in love with this man. She’s thriving in LA (her world), but he isn’t. He leaves to go back to Georgia (his world) and she has to make the decision of if she loves him enough to leave “her world” to be with him in “his world”.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Mm, L.A
 Proved too much for the man (Too much for the man, he couldn’t make it)
 So he’s leavin’ the life
 He’s come to know, ooh

annotation.plain:
This song was inspired by starlet Farrah Fawcett of all people as Weatherly explained:

the song actually came about after a phone call I had with Farrah Fawcett. Lee Majors was a friend of mine. We’d played in the Flag Football League together in L.A. He had just started dating Farrah. One day I called Lee and Farrah answered the phone. We were just talking and she said she was packing. She was gonna take the midnight plane to Houston to visit her folks. So, it just stayed with me. After I got off the phone, I sat down and wrote the song probably in about 30 to 45 minutes. Something like that. Didn’t take me long at all, ‘cause I actually used Farrah and Lee as kind of like characters I guess. A girl that comes to L.A. to make it and doesn’t make it and leaves to go back home. The guy goes back with her. Pretty simple little story, but it felt real to me.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I ain’t got seventy days

annotation.plain: An average stay in rehab is 28 days, while a long-term inpatient treatment is usually 60 to 90 days. Winehouse seems to have split the middle with seventy. She might be slyly indicating some awareness of her condition, in that she recognizes that if she did go to rehab, she’s in bad enough shape to be kept for the full term.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I didn’t get a lot in class

annotation.plain:
By her own admission, Amy was a less-than-ideal student. At the age of twelve her rebellious attitude and nose piercing got her expelled from the Sylvia Young Theater School.

Describing Amy’s troubles with school in a 2007 interview with The Daily Mail, her mother Janis said “she was very bright but she was always messing around.”

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Chorus]

annotation.plain: When Amy won the Grammy, it was 4 or 5 in the morning in the UK. She couldn’t get into the country. That was one of the first times that the Grammy’s had beamed a satellite for a Grammy acceptance. That was something I will never, ever forget. Being there, and being involved in it, and then seeing it happen…It was a proud moment. I remember saying to her afterwards, “Amy it’s amazing, you just won five Grammys!” and she was like “Eh.” And that was it.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’m gonna, I’m gonna lose my baby
 So I always keep a bottle near

annotation.plain: I didn’t know how bad her drinking or drug use was. She was traveling a lot publicizing the record. She was away when everything started to explode. However bad it was at the time, I couldn’t say. But it was something waiting to happen.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Produced by Mark Ronson]

annotation.plain:
I remember Guy Moot called me one day saying that he had just got Mark Ronson and that he thought he and Amy should meet. Amy wasn’t convinced initially. But then they met and disappeared to New York for a few weeks to see if they could make something. She was playing Mark all the records that she was listening to and they started writing. I came by four weeks later to hear the songs. I went to his studio in SoHo and sat down to hear the first four tracks. It was a total “where were you” moment. When they played me “Rehab” I remember saying “rewind it, rewind it!” I was in awe. The rest of the album came shortly thereafter.

Later on Amy sent me the track list for Back to Black and I called her and said “There’s only ten songs on here??” She said “I’ve written the record, it’s 10 tracks, that’s what it is. Now fuck off.” Amy always knew what it was.

annotations.lyric_fragment: They tried to make me go to rehab, but I said, “No, no, no”

annotation.plain:
In between recording “Frank” and “Back to Black” Amy and I maintained contact because I wanted to keep her engaged and make sure she didn’t get away from the studio and the creative process for too long. One day I was in Primrose Hill and I remember hearing what sounded like Amy’s voice behind me. I turned around and that was the first time I had seen her without the beehive, looking a lot thinner, with a lot of tattoos. It was honestly a change with where she was stylistically. It wasn’t long after that that we started the recording process.

When “Rehab” dropped it was just like a newspaper being lit. I wasn’t expecting this song to be the one that did it. We wanted to come in with a cool angle. We thought putting Ghostface Killa on “You Know I’m No Good” would be the big hit. It wasn’t until people heard “Rehab” that they really got it.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Yes, I’ve been black, but when I come back, you’ll know, know, know

annotation.plain:
Amy plays on the phrase “once you go black you don’t go back,” and also references the title song of the album, “Back to Black,” with the use of the color in the latter symbolizing depression. She went through a very dark time involving tumultuous relationships and drug abuse.



She is telling her audience that she knows she has a problem with depression but believes she can fix it on her own and shut everyone’s mouth.

As we all know, however, she was tragically found dead in her London home in 2011 due to alcohol poisoning.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
It’s not just my pride
 It’s just till these tears have dried

annotation.plain:
She says she’ll go and keeps pushing it off. Referencing the title of another Back to Black single, “Tears Dry on Their Own”, Winehouse suggests that her substance abuse is not an ongoing problem, but rather a temporary response to personal difficulties. This sentiment was echoed in interviews surrounding the album’s release. As Amy stated:

I do drink a lot. I think it’s symptomatic of my depression … I’m manic depressive, I’m not an alcoholic, which sounds like an alcoholic in denial.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
The man said “Why do you think you here?”
 I said, “I got no idea”

annotation.plain:
The doctor at the rehabilitation center asks Amy why she thinks she’s here, to which she responds she has no idea. This demonstrates the confusion and lack of help available to her if she tries to look for it.

This is the typical experience with counseling and things you go to to seek help in the UK, anyone that’s been through it complains because it’s almost the opposite of what you want.

Amy saying she has no idea why she’s here (talking to the counselor) demonstrates her ambivalence to work towards sobriety. The question is leading (she knows something about why she’s there) and she regresses, focusing on her irritation instead of accepting her vulnerability and telling what she knows about why she is there. Tragically, the inclusion of the lyric in the song suggests she has some insight into the importance that her non-participation plays in that conversation.

annotations.lyric_fragment:

 So I always keep a bottle near

annotation.plain: I didn’t know how bad her drinking or drug use was. She was traveling a lot publicizing the record. She was away when everything started to explode. However bad it was at the time, I couldn’t say. But it was something waiting to happen.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Outro]

annotation.plain: The repeat of the chorus' last line ends the song on a literal different note, as Olivia changes the resolved major chord on “street” to an unresolved minor chord. This gives the song the feeling of being unfinished, almost like it never really ended in the first place. That effect ties into the wider song’s theme of breaking up with someone you really care about. Olivia is left slightly dazed- Bassett was one day everything to her, and now he is nothing to her. However, feelings don’t shift that rapidly, and as her relationship draws to a close, she is left to pick up the pieces with words still left unsaid, hence the unfinished energy of the outro.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Yeah, today, I drove through the suburbs
 And pictured I was driving home to you

annotation.plain:
On Olivia’s 2022 project for Disney+, Olivia Rodrigo: driving home 2 u (a SOUR film), she explained:

That line can very literally be, like, I was driving home to your house or whatever, but I remember, at that time, I was really reconciling with the fact that sometimes, when you love a person so much and you spend so much time with them, that’s who you feel the most at home with. And I remember listening to that song, even when I hadn’t put it out, when I just had a demo on my phone and I’d drive around and listen to it. Every time that came on, my stomach would drop, just because I felt like it was so acutely how I was feeling.

annotations.lyric_fragment: ’Cause you said forever, now I drive alone past your street

annotation.plain:
This line alludes to breakups, the theme of the song as Rodrigo has stated, and reminiscing on memories. As the song is presumably about Joshua Bassett and Olivia promising to obtain a driver’s license, — as stated in the song bio — the line also supports her fulfilling the promise.

In addition, this specific line was heavily popularized on the social media platform, TikTok, where most most of the short videos using this audio involved relationships and melancholic settings.

annotations.lyric_fragment: And I just can’t imagine how you could be so okay now that I’m gone

annotation.plain:
This line is yet another confirmation of the theory that Joshua Bassett is the subject of Rodrigo’s multi-platinum debut single.

Around the release of the track, rumors were swirling that Bassett and other Disney star Sabrina Carpenter were dating. Though not confirmed by either party, it would explain why Rodrigo would be upset that Bassett moved on so quickly without her.

Sabrina Carpenter’s song “Skin” was released in apparent response to “drivers license.” Some of the lines in the scathing track appear to be directly pointing to Bassett:

You can try
To get under my, under my, under my skin
While he’s on mine

While nothing is confirmed regarding who the songs are directed to, it appears to be a painful shot at Bassett for starting up a new relationship with Carpenter while Rodrigo was still getting over their relationship.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
To finally drive up to your house
 But today, I drove through the suburbs
 Crying ’cause you weren’t around

annotation.plain: Olivia Rodrigo was born in Temecula, California, a city of about 114,000 people though currently, she resides in Los Angeles. Joshua Bassett, who the song is rumored to be based off of, is from Oceanside, California which a population of about 167,000. Both stars currently reside in LA, where the song can be assumed to take place. The suburbs of a city are smaller communities adjacent to a city. Los Angeles has the most suburban cities in the United States with 15.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I got my driver’s license last week

annotation.plain:
As Rodrigo told the New York Times, this lyric was originally an excerpt from a diary entry. She elaborated on this during a Vogue interview:

I was aimlessly driving around my neighborhood, listening to sad music, and bringing up these emotions I hadn’t felt in a while. I’d just got my license, so I was relishing my freedom. When I got home, I sat down at the piano — and I love songs that feel like a diary entry and are confessional — so I took some lyrics from my diary and went from there.



A parody of Rodrigo’s driver’s license, as printed on her offical merch.

annotations.lyric_fragment: ‘Cause I still fuckin’ love you, babe (Ooh, ooh-ooh, ooh, ooh-ooh)

annotation.plain:
Olivia talked about writing this line with producer Dan Nigro and the decision to swear, in The New York Times series “Diary of a Song”:

https://youtu.be/hWq_ma9ZDxk?t=425

Dan was like, “What if we say, ‘I still fuckin’ love you,‘” and I’m like, “That’s brilliant. Let’s do it.” […] And I think it’s actually really cool that I did swear in my first song. I guess it’s a nice, like, "Ah, look, I’m an adult. I can say—” I’m not an adult, I’m like, seventeen, haha.

In the clean version and in certain live performances, these lines are changed to:

[‘Cause/But] you know I still love you, babe

annotations.lyric_fragment: Red lights, stop signs

annotation.plain:
In keeping with the ideology of driving through the song, Rodrigo points to two symbols of stopping: traffic lights and stop signs, symbolizing the ending of her relationship.

Olivia posted these lines to her Instagram accompanied by a red picture of her, in line with the songs.



This line is the first of three colored lyrics in the bridge, the other two colors being white and blue.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Just like we always talked about
 ’Cause you were so excited for me

annotation.plain:
Joshua Bassett, who the song is rumored to be about, helped teach Olivia how to drive. In an Instagram Story from January 2020, Olivia talked about getting her first driving experience with Joshua, after they learned that the song they wrote together, “Just for a Moment.” would be used in High School Musical: The Musical: The Series:

We celebrated and we went to In-N-Out, and I couldn’t drive actually. I was sixteen, but I didn’t have my permit, and so he took me in his car, and we drove around the In-N-Out parking lot. That was my first time driving, so I’ll always remember that.

Olivia has also referenced driving on her unreleased track “Gross”:

And driving in your car, I feel all grown up

annotations.lyric_fragment: God, I’m so blue, know we’re through

annotation.plain:
“Feeling blue” is a phrase meaning to feel depressed or disappointed. The color blue is often associated with being sad, with a genre of music even being named after these emotions.

The music video for “drivers license” contains darker colors, tinting Olivia’s skin tone. In scenes within the video, she is cast in a blue shade. This is a clever nod to this line, as well as a unique rendering of her emotions throughout the song.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Down in the hollow
 Playin’ a new game

annotation.plain:
The Hollow, is in East Belfast just off the Beersbridge Road. The once-shabby and run down grove behind Abetta Parade is where the youthful Van Morrison and his friends used to play. It’s recently been refurbished as part of the £40m Connswater Community Greenway project.
It is also on the self-guided Van Morrison Trail in Belfast.
http://www.connswatergreenway.co.uk/vanmorrisontrail/hollow

annotations.lyric_fragment:
My brown-eyed girl
 You, my brown-eyed girl

annotation.plain:
Per the Belfast Telegraph, the song was originally titled “Brown Skinned Girl”.


Morrison changed the name to “Brown Eyed Girl” when he had finished recording it.

Remarking on the original title, he said: “That was just a mistake. It was a kind of Jamaican song… Calypso.

“It just slipped my mind. I changed the title.”

He continued: “After we’d recorded it, I looked at the tape box and didn’t even notice that I’d changed the title. I looked at the box where I’d lain it down with my guitar and it said “Brown Eyed Girl” on the tape box.


If this is to be believed, it sounds like the song’s lyrics were always “brown-eyed girl”, and only the title changed. If this explanation feels flimsy, it becomes easy to interpret the song as being about an interracial relationship, and the title (and lyrics) were really changed because interracial relationships were pretty controversial back in 1967.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Behind the stadium
 
 [Refrain]
 With you

annotation.plain:
Via the Belfast Telegraph:


The song may have been about a Belfast girl, but Stuart Bailie of the Oh Yeah Centre thinks the singer may have been using poetic licence.

“I’d like to think it’s about Belfast and that the stadium he refers to may have been The Oval in east Belfast.

“Although it could have been the Shankill Stadium as well.” Radio Ulster’s Ralph McLean said: “Morrison’s songs are best when full of intrigue.”

annotations.lyric_fragment: With a transistor radio

annotation.plain:
The transistor was invented in 1947, leading to the enormously popular transistor radio in 1954. It dominated popular music consumption in the 1960s and 70s (“Brown Eyed Girl” was first recorded in March 1967) before being replaced by portable CD players and other higher-fidelity devices.



A Sanyo transistor radio from 1959. Image via Wikimedia Commons.

Many transistor radios were portable– allowing Van to take one as the young couple went down to an old mine. The transistor radio was a wonderful thing for its time, but has now rarely used; it fits in with the nostalgic mood of the song nicely.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Laughin’ and a-runnin’, hey, hey
 Skippin’ and a jumpin’
 In the misty morning fog with
 Our, our hearts a thumpin’

annotation.plain: This song was released in June of 1967 which was also the time of the “Summer of Love” hippy movement. The song “Brown Eyed Girl” became a hippy anthem due to its themes of young love and sexual freedom. Van Morrison himself was not a hippy and did not intend for his song to be associated with the hippy movement.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Sometimes I’m overcome thinking about
 Making love in the green grass

annotation.plain: The line “making love in the green grass behind the stadium” was changed to make the single radio-playable.  The lyrics were considered too suggestive at the time.  Shortly after initial release, Bang Records released a radio-edit of the song, replacing that phrase with “laughin and a-runnin, hey hey” from a previous verse. The original line appears in the album version of the song.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Slipping and sliding
 All along the waterfall
 
 [Refrain]
 With you

annotation.plain:
As heroin is brown, it could be inferred that this is a song about someone’s ‘slipping and sliding’ relationship with drugs.

However, the song is about an interracial relationship and was originally called ‘Brown Skinned Girl’. The name change seems to have mostly been a mistake:


“That was just a mistake… It just slipped my mind. I changed the title.”
- from Inarticulate Speech Of The Heart by John Collis

“After we’d recorded it, I looked at the tape box and didn’t even notice that I’d changed the title. I looked at the box where I’d lain it down with my guitar and it said ‘Brown Eyed Girl’ on the tape box. It’s just one of those things that happen.”
- from Van Morrison: No Surrender by Johnny Rogan
