annotations.lyric_fragment:
Open up the dirty window
 Let the sun illuminate the words that you cannot find

annotation.plain:
The writer is singing about how getting a new perspective can allow you to learn and grow.
If we keep living in our shells, we’ll never realise the potential we have; opening a ‘dirty window' symbolises taking a chance and going for our goals.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Drench yourself in words unspoken

annotation.plain: The line “Drench yourself in words unspoken” metaphorically suggests immersing oneself in unexpressed thoughts or feelings. It encourages a deep engagement with the unsaid aspects of one’s inner self, urging individuals to embrace unspoken truths and be open to the uncharted facets of their own personality. This compact interpretation underscores the call for authenticity and self-discovery.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Open up the dirty window
 Let the sun illuminate the words that you cannot find
 Reaching for something in the distance
 So close you can almost taste it
 Release your inhibitions

annotation.plain: The bridge repeats the idea of opening the “dirty window” and freeing oneself from limitations. The notion of reaching for something in the distance, so close you can almost taste it, could signify the tangible possibility of achieving personal goals.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Live your life with arms wide open
Release your inhibitions

annotation.plain: Shake off the stress that hinders you from feeling Joy, and start to live your best life!

We’ve been conditioned
 To not make mistakes
 But I can’t live that way, no, oh

annotation.plain: She is saying that everyone has always been taught that you shouldn’t make mistakes, and it is wrong to make them. She is stating that it’s ok to make mistakes and it’s not possible to not live without them.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Live your life with arms wide open

annotation.plain: don’t be afriad to try something new and enjoy that new something

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I break tradition
 Sometimes my tries
 Are outside the lines, yeah, yeah

annotation.plain:
A “try” is to rugby what a “touchdown” is to football, so when she says “sometimes my tries are outside the lines”, it’s like saying she goes out of bounds.

This may seem far-fetched, but she is British and having “tries outside the lines” doesn’t actually make sense in any other context.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Today is where your book begins
 The rest is still unwritten

annotation.plain: This line seems to suggest that our futures are not determined. Nothing is set out for us and we should ultimately be the ones who decide what we want to do with the rest of our lives.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Staring at the blank page before you

annotation.plain: The “blank page” refers to your life.  Bedingfield’s life seemed to be “empty” and without meaning. Until she decided to have a new beginning.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Ain’t enough lime here for you to shine here

annotation.plain:
Limelight is a word used for “spotlight” also meaning to be the center of attention.

Puff is saying that no matter how much limelight there might be, it won’t be enough for someone else to be the center of attention if he’s around.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Step on stage, the girls boo too much
 I guess it’s ‘cause you run with lame dudes too much

annotation.plain:
It would be impossible to prove, but Biggie might be referring to an incident at the 1995 Source awards.

“With his chest puffed out, Suge took the stage to accept his label’s award for best soundtrack, for Above the Rim. Giving a stink eye to the audience, he digressed, throwing a pointed barb at Sean "Puffy” Combs, the head of Bad Boy, Biggie Smalls’s label. Alluding to Puffy’s tendency to insert himself in his performers' works, Suge said: “Any artist out there wanna be an artist, and wanna stay a star, and don’t have to worry about the executive producer trying to be all in the videos, all on the records, dancing—come to Death Row. The venue erupted in boos.”

https://www.vice.com/en/article/gqkqz3/tupac-biggie-friends-to-foes

annotations.lyric_fragment: My team supreme, stay clean

annotation.plain: Supreme Team was a famous and highly respected drug operation in Brooklyn, led by Kenneth “Supreme” McGriff. Supreme Team “stayed clean” in two ways: 1) Their appearances, i.e cars, clothes, jewelry, haircuts, shoes etc. and 2) They managed to maintain clean criminal records for a relatively long time, given how much crime they committed. Biggie is claiming Supreme Team, and its reputation, as his own here.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I know you thinking now, “When all the ballin’ stops?”

annotation.plain:
By the time this song was released in 1997, Diddy, Biggie, and the rest of the Bad Boy crew had dropped hit after hit. The Notorious B.I.G. had released his successful singles “Juicy” and “Big Poppa” in August of ‘94, Craig Mack dropped “Flava In Ya Ear” in June of the same year, and only about a month earlier, Diddy released his collaboration with Ma$e, “Can’t Nobody Hold Me Down,” which peaked at #1 on the Billboard Hot 100.

This succession of dominance over the rap game would lead Bad Boy’s rivals, which included those on the West Coast who they had been feuding with, to have negative feelings towards them. Biggie’s former friend turned mortal enemy, 2Pac had died in 1996 a year before this album came out and tensions were high, but nevertheless Bad Boy stayed on top.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Nigga never home, gotta call me on the yacht

annotation.plain:
Owning a yacht with a cellular phone was a major flex when this was recorded in 1996. Puff really did spend a lot of time on the water—in 1998, he did the entire interview for an Observer article over his yacht phone.

In his 2017 Genius Level interview, DJ Premier remembered how outlandish Puff’s boat phone seemed back then:

I remember Puff calling, like, ‘Yo, here’s all my numbers—my house phone, my cell phone, my car phone, my boat phone.’ And we said, ‘He got a boat phone??’ We was like, ‘Puff is huge!!’

Puffy and Biggie famously filmed the “Hypotize” video aboard a yacht in Malibu, CA.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I don’t know what they want from me
 It’s like the more money we come across
 The more problems we see

annotation.plain:
This song popularized the phrase “more money, more problems,” but the idea was already common, perhaps inspired by the famous Biblical proverb “the love of money is the root of all evil.” (1 Timothy 6:10)

In 1984, a newly famous Madonna made a similar observation in an interview with Record Mirror magazine:

The more money you have the more problems you have. I went from making no money to making comparatively a lot and all I’ve had is problems. Life was simpler when I had no money, when I just barely survived

In 1996, 2Pac rapped on “Hold Ya Head”:

And mo' money mean litigatin', mo' playa hatin'

It’s likely that the “Mo' Money, Mo' Problems” chorus, sung by Kelly Price, was written by the song’s co-producer, Stevie J., perhaps with Puffy’s involvement. This trio—Price, Puffy, and Stevie J—also worked together on SWV’s 1997 hit “Can We.”

The phrase “mo' money” had become very popular thanks to the 1992 Damon Wayans comedy Mo' Money. AZ and Nas' 1995 song “Mo' Money, Mo' Murder, Mo' Homicide” may have also been an influence on the song’s title.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I’m the young Harlem nigga with the Goldie sound

annotation.plain:
Ma$e compares his music to “Goldie,” the main character in the 1973 blaxploitation film The Mack.



Goldie was a pimp known for his flashy style, smooth demeanor, and slick talk. This lyric connects to the “true pimp niggas” line later in Ma$e’s verse.

It’s likely that this line inspired young Harlem rapper A$AP Rocky to name his debut single “Goldie.”

Ma$e referenced Goldie again on his 1999 song “If You Wanna Party”:

Young kid’ll live by Goldie advices
Pimp hoes that come across so righteous

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Stay humble, stay low, blow like Hootie
 True pimp niggas spend no dough on the booty

annotation.plain:
This cryptic line was finally explained by Darius Rucker, the lead singer for the 1990s band Hootie & the Blowfish. True players don’t have to pay for sex:

We were at the Grammys, and some really hot girl walks by. One of [Biggie’s] boys was like, ‘I’ll pay her,’ just as a joke. I go. ‘Man, I’m not paying for it.’ We laughed and then his next record, he’s got a line that goes. ‘Stay humble, stay low, blow like Hootie/True pimp niggas spend no dough on the booty.’ Great line.

annotations.lyric_fragment: We don’t play around, it’s a bet, lay it down

annotation.plain:
Double entendre!


Ma$e and crew are always serious and you can bet they aren’t messing around. If you mess with them, they’ll ‘lay you down’ in your coffin.
‘Lay it down’ is a reference to betting in casino games. Ma$e doesn’t play for fun, but rather for cash. To place a bet in a casino, you have to lay your cash down. Also “lay it down” as in recording a verse

annotations.lyric_fragment: My succotash wish

annotation.plain: Succotash is a sweetcorn and lima bean based recipe. It is most commonly known in wider culture through the Warner Brothers cartoon character Sylvester The Cat’s catchphrase, “sufferin' succotash” and so, alongside other lyrical references like Horton Hears A Who and the dancing heads of Tip and Miss Kier in the video, this helps to play into the generally cartoonish vibe of the track and concept

annotations.lyric_fragment: Q-Tip,

annotation.plain: Q-Tip provides a great rap verse on this song. He is known for being a member of the rap group “A Tribe Called Quest” with Phife Dawg which was popular. So adding him made this song even more popular.

annotations.lyric_fragment: No walls, only the bridge

annotation.plain:
Walls (suggesting enclosure and limitations) are the opposite of a bridge (representing openness and sharing). However, “bridge” also refers to a common part of song structure).

It’s also worth remembering that when this song was being written, the Berlin Wall was on a lot of people’s minds. It was torn down, symbolizing the reunification of Germany.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Flowin’, glowin’ with electric eyes (eyes)

annotation.plain: The reference to electric eyes is almost certainly a reference to MJ’s “Human Nature”, which could also be interpreted as a reference to an intoxicant.

annotations.lyric_fragment:

 No, I couldn’t ask for another

annotation.plain:
The tamborine throughout “Groove is in the Heart” comes from Vernon Burch’s 1979 groove, “Get Up.”  If it was ONLY the tamborine, though, it might have been hard for anyone to figure out where DJ Towa Tei and DJ Dmitry got the sample from.  So what does Deee-Lite do to give credit where credit’s due?  Include the part of “Get Up” that no one ever forgets: the slide whistle.

annotations.lyric_fragment: It isn’t silly, love isn’t silly, love isn’t silly at all, yeah, yeah

annotation.plain: “Silly” is more like “stupid” in British English. He’s dismissing the cynicism of “sentimental” love ballads, because it’s easy to be critical from the outside, but when it happens to you, it feels different.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I can’t explain, the feeling’s plain to me

annotation.plain: This song takes a lot of jabs at music critics for the way they criticised and described Paul’s songs as ‘silly love songs’. Music critics love to criticise vagueness in a song. Lines like ‘I can’t explain’ are prevalent when it comes to love songs, and music critics hate vagueness. If the writer can’t explain, what can he write about? Paul fires back by using these same tropes, sending messages that it doesn’t matter if his lines are vague, his songs are great anyways.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I love you (Ah, he gave me more, he gave it all to me, say, can’t you see?)
 I love you (I can’t explain, the feeling’s plain to me
 Say, can’t you see?)
 {How can I tell you about my loved one?}
 I love you (Ah, he gave me more, he gave it all to me
 Say, can’t you see?)
 How can I tell you about my loved one?
 I love you
 I can’t explain, the feeling’s plain to me
 (Say, can’t you see?)
 How can I tell you about my loved one?
 I love you
 Ah, he gave me more, he gave it all to me
 (Say, can’t you see?)
 How can I tell you about my loved one?

annotation.plain:
Paul’s digging into some deep meta-analysis here.  One of the things that annoys music critics about the generic love song is that the singer, either to make the song more relatable or out of a lack of ideas, will fail to specify why they’re in love.  For instance, why do so many love songs say “I can’t explain”?  If you can’t explain, why are you writing?
Paul answers his critics by committing the same foul, intentionally, in a song that’s not about being in love, but about writing about being in love.  So lines like “I can’t explain” get turned on their head – Paul is explaining that his lack of precision is the precise thing that makes his love songs great.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You’d think that people would’ve had enough of silly love songs
 I look around me, and I see it isn’t so

annotation.plain:
Paul is saying that, despite the cynicism and dismissiveness of his critics, people like to listen to ‘silly’ love songs and always have. As he said in 2001:


But over the years people have said, “Aw, he sings love songs, he writes love songs, he’s so soppy at times.” I thought, Well, I know what they mean, but, people have been doing love songs forever. I like ‘em, other people like 'em, and there’s a lot of people I love – I’m lucky enough to have that in my life. So the idea was that “you” may call them silly, but what’s wrong with that?

The song was, in a way, to answer people who just accuse me of being soppy. The nice payoff now is that a lot of the people I meet who are at the age where they’ve just got a couple of kids and have grown up a bit, settling down, they’ll say to me, “I thought you were really soppy for years, but I get it now! I see what you were doing!”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Love doesn’t come in a minute
 Sometimes it doesn’t come at all

annotation.plain: Love doesn’t just happen all of a sudden, you have to grow to love that person, and you can’t force love. And sometimes, love between two people just doesn’t happen at all.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I’d like to know, ’cause here I go again

annotation.plain: This is a great ironic line by McCartney. He’s taunting John for accusing him of writing “silly love songs,” and now he’s writing another one, the chorus of which is “I love you,” so here he goes again. Brilliant and cute.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I love you
 I love you
 I love you
 I love you

annotation.plain: Paul is singing this not just to his audience but to John Lennon.  He’s defiantly saying he loves John even though John had been slagging him off in the press post-Beatles.  And because Paul knows John so well, he knows that being so sappy like this will annoy John to no end – but also that John will begrudgingly respect his skilled songwriting.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Some people want to fill the world with silly love songs
 
 [Refrain: Paul McCartney]
 And what’s wrong with that?

annotation.plain: This is Paul’s response to John Lennon’s comment in an interview that post-Beatles, Paul only wrote “silly love songs.” So Paul asks in response (in this song), “What’s wrong with that?”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
One taught me love
 One taught me patience
 And one taught me pain
 Now, I’m so amazing
 Say I’ve loved and I’ve lost
 But that’s not what I see
 So, look what I got
 Look what you taught me
 And for that, I say

annotation.plain:
Ariana could be saying she learned love from Big Sean, who was her first notable boyfriend. However, it should also be noted that before Sean, she was in relationships with Graham Phillips, Jai Brooks and Ricky Alvarez—who was name-dropped in the first verse.

She could be saying she learned patience from Pete Davidson as they were both criticized for rushing into a relationship. In the second verse, she acknowledges that she “moves on too fast” and now, she’s putting herself first.

Lastly, she could be saying she learned pain from Mac Miller, who was dealing with drug addiction during their relationship and whose death was hard on her. After Miller’s May 2018 DUI charge, a fan blamed Ariana for breaking his heart, in which she responded how their relationship was “toxic” and how it was overwhelming for both of them.

Following the release of the song, these lines became a meme, in which three objects are placed together with this lyric as its caption. For example:

https://twitter.com/ayoedebiri/status/1059446249961730049

annotations.lyric_fragment:
One day I’ll walk down the aisle
 Holding hands with my mama
 I’ll be thanking my dad
 ’Cause she grew from the drama
 Only wanna do it once, real bad
 Gon’ make that shit last
 God forbid something happens
 Least this song is a smash (Song is a smash)

annotation.plain:
Ariana and Pete Davidson got engaged after about a month of dating, but now, she realizes she doesn’t want to rush into marriage.

Ariana also applies the theme of gratitude to her own father, Edward Butera, who divorced her mother, Joan Grande, when Ariana herself was 9 years old.

The “God forbid” line could be a nod to Pete’s bit on Saturday Night Live in September 2018 when he kept prefacing jokes about them breaking up with “God forbid.”

https://youtu.be/asdR4gIT2vU?t=101

The “song is a smash” line could be Ariana predicting the song would be a hit, which it was: “thank u, next” debuted and stayed at #1 on the Billboard Hot 100 for 7 weeks.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Wish I could say, “Thank you” to Malcolm
 ’Cause he was an angel

annotation.plain:
Ariana and Mac Miller (real name Malcolm James McCormick) started dating in August 2016 and broke up in May 2018. Even after breaking up, they decided to stay friends.

Following Mac’s DUI charge in May 2018, a fan posted on Twitter, blaming Ariana for breaking his heart, to which she responded how her relationship with Mac was “toxic” and how his addictions were overwhelming for both of them.

Mac Miller died on September 7, 2018, from an accidental overdose of fentanyl and cocaine. Five days following his death, Ariana posted a tribute to Mac via Instagram, with the caption:

i adored you from the day i met you when i was nineteen and i always will. i can’t believe you aren’t here anymore. i really can’t wrap my head around it. we talked about this. so many times. i’m so mad, i’m so sad i don’t know what to do. you were my dearest friend. for so long. above anything else. i’m so sorry i couldn’t fix or take your pain away. i really wanted to. the kindest, sweetest soul with demons he never deserved. i hope you’re okay now. rest.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Plus, I met someone else
 We havin’ better discussions
 I know they say I move on too fast
 But this one gon’ last
 ’Cause her name is Ari
 And I’m so good with that (So good with that)

annotation.plain:
The “better discussions” reflect Ariana’s increasingly positive mental state. On her August 2018 album, Sweetener, she confronts her emotions following the May 2017 bombing at her Manchester concert. In her July 2018 ELLE cover story, Ariana described how she felt:

There were a couple months straight where I felt so upside down.

Apple Music originally had the lyric “her name is Ari” transcribed as “her name is Aubrey,” which caused a bit of controversy with fans who wondered if Ariana had a new lover or if she was talking about Drake, whose given name is Aubrey Graham. Apple later apologized for the incident and Grande confirmed the lyric was "Ari,” as in herself, “Ariana.”

https://twitter.com/ArianaGrande/status/1058717538505252865

In the official music video, the mix-up was joked about, which Troye Sivan said:

I heard she’s a lesbian now and dating some chick named Aubrey. It’s fuckin' sick.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Wrote some songs about Ricky
 Now I listen and laugh

annotation.plain:
Ariana and Ricky Alvarez first became involved in April 2014 after he became a backup dancer for her.

They first kissed publicly in June 2015 during Ariana’s performance at 2015 PRIDE. They were also seen kissing during Ariana’s infamous doughnut shop incident–where she licked a doughnut that she did not purchase–confirming their relationship. They broke up in July 2016.

Ariana’s December 2015 song, “True Love” and May 2016 track, “Moonlight” were written about Ricky. Fans have also speculated that the tracks, “Into You” and “Forever Boy”, are about him, since the tracks were released while they were dating.



The phrase “listen and laugh” could mean she’s reflecting on the good times or the bad times with him.

Less than a week after the song’s release, Alvares posted a five-second video of his reaction to the shout-out on his Instagram Story:
https://youtu.be/jy3NIyEd9OM
Ari ended up apologizing to Ricky for giving him “the worst line,” noting that she meant it with love:

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Thought I’d end up with Sean
 But he wasn’t a match

annotation.plain:
Ariana and Big Sean started dating in August 2014 and broke up in April 2015, due to both of them having conflicting tour schedules.  However, it was also rumored that they had broken up over Sean’s lyrics on his 2015 song “Stay Down”:

I ain’t even gonna lie, I got a million dollar chick
With a billion dollar pussy
Every time I cum, I swear to God I feel like I be rich

The two collaborated on multiple songs, like Grande’s 2013 song “Right There,” 2014’s “Best Mistake,” “Problem,” and Sean’s 2015 song “Research.”



Big Sean went on to reference “thank u, next” during his verse on “Thank You,” a track on DJ Khaled’s May 2019 record Father of Asahd:

Plus I gotta thank my exes on some “thank u, next” shit
And all the old times that gave me new perspectives

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Even almost got married
 And for Pete, I’m so thankful

annotation.plain:
On May 23, 2018, Ariana and Pete Davidson were spotted sporting matching tattoos, which confirmed they were dating.

Fans were surprised since Ariana and Mac Miller had just broken up on May 10, 2018, and Pete Davidson had also announced his relationship with Cazzie David was over on May 16, 2018.

On a June 21, 2018 episode of The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon, Pete Davidson confirmed that the two were engaged:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OwAL5TetOdI

Ariana named a song after Pete on her August 2018 album Sweetener. On August 23, 2018, Ariana stated that the couple would get married soon. However, the couple split in October 2018.

annotation.plain:
Ariana is thankful for all of her failed relationships and how they helped her grow as a person.

In the wake of Ariana and Pete Davidson’s breakup in October 2018, Pete joked about their split during a Saturday Night Live clip. Ariana expressed her aversion on a since-deleted tweet that stated:

for somebody who claims to hate relevancy u sure love clinging to it huh

She followed that up with a tweet of the song’s title.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Oh, daddy dear, you know you’re still number one

annotation.plain: Often times, dad’s are terrified to let their daughters grow up. They don’t wish to see their little girl all grown. The daughter here is reassuring her father that he is still the number one guy in her life. How cute :)

annotations.lyric_fragment:
The phone rings in the middle of the night
 My father yells, “What you gonna do with your life?”

annotation.plain:
The house phone rings in the “middle of the night”, and it wakes up her father. The caller might be a girlfriend of hers or her boyfriend.
Being parallel to what her mother said earlier, the dad is irked that his daughter hasn’t gotten her life together, and asks what will she do after her partying life.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Oh, mama dear, we’re not the fortunate ones

annotation.plain:
The girl is trying to justify her actions to her mother, claiming they don’t have the good life, so why not live it up?

Possibly an allusion to “Fortunate Son”.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I come home in the mornin’ light
 My mother says, “When you gonna live your life right?”

annotation.plain:
A girl (and possibly her girlfriends as well) have finally came home after being out the entire night. They come in the morning when the sun is out.
The girl’s mother is aggravated that girl was out all night, probably partying, and feels the girl needs to get her life together.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And girls, they wanna have fun
 Oh, girls just wanna have fun

annotation.plain: Written by Robert Hazard, this song was originally sung from a man’s perspective. The “girls who want to have fun” are the women he’s out sleeping with every night. Luckily, Lauper got permission to make some minor adjustments to the lyrics, and it became a signature 80’s pop hit.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Intro]

annotation.plain:
The intro starts with the song’s signature bass pattern. It’s importance is underlined by co-writer Mike Stoller:

Jerry [Wexler, an Atlantic Records producer] always said that bassline made the song. And it’s true that, whenever the record starts, or a band plays it at a wedding, you know what’s coming just through those first bars. source

This iconic rhythm has appeared in many other pop songs, such as the Zombies' “Time Of The Season”.

When you’re down and troubled
And you need some loving care

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Oh, stand by me
 Woah, just stand now
 Oh, stand, stand by me

annotation.plain:
The phrase To stand by usually means “help me”, “support me"loyal” to me“.

Here, the use takes a hundred and eighty degree turn. The lyricist provides the comfort and safety, rather than requesting some.

Still, the underlying message is perhaps the mutuality in the act – by helping others, one helps himself, as h"detailed" in the first verse.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
When the night has come
 And the land is dark
 And the moon is the only light we’ll see

annotation.plain: This sets the mood for the song, explaining that there could be literal darkness or that this girl is going through a time where it seems she’s shrouded in mental darkness, moonlight will be the only thing shining through.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
If the sky that we look upon
 Should tumble and fall
 Or the mountains should crumble to the sea
 I won’t cry, I won’t cry
 No, I won’t shed a tear
 Just as long as you stand, stand by me

annotation.plain:
Even physical desolation (“mountains should crumble”) shan’t eclipse the profound love and affection King feels for this woman. So long as she remains by him he won’t be susceptible or vulnerable.

This line can also be interpreted with religious connotation, as it references the Bible’s book of Psalms, specifically Chapter 46, verse 2:

Therefore will not we fear, though the earth be removed, and though the mountains be carried into the midst of the sea;

In this light, the singer’s fervent devotion to his subject reflects the love of holy worship. Some could even argue the song is more religious than romantic.

The phrase “the sky that we look upon”, has the accent on the “on” of upon, and the line has become a rock classic.  In actuality we look up on to the sky, because to look upon, we’d have to either be considering the sky in an abstract manner or we’d have to be looking down from a position on high – a position where from this day forward, Mr. Ben E. King may very well have a good view.

annotation.plain:
These lyrics were almost excluded from the final film version of this song:

… [David] Foster went to a record store and bought the Linda Ronstadt version so Whitney could learn the song. When he called Dolly Parton to let her know they were using her song, Dolly told him something very important: the Ronstadt version leaves out the last verse (“I wish you joy and happiness”), which changes the tone of the song. Parton gave him the lyrics and Whitney recorded the full version. Foster had to tell the film’s director, Mick Jackson, that he needed an extra 40 seconds of screen time, as it had been placed in the film minus the last verse.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Pretty woman, look my way

annotation.plain:
The song has inspired many parodies. Arguably the most famous and notorious one is 2 Live Crew’s on their album “As Clean as You They Wanna Be”, using the riff and the same structure ,but with

[Big hairy woman] You need to shave that stuff
[Big hairy woman] You know, I bet it’s tough
[Big hairy woman] All that hair, it ain’t legi-i-it
[Cause you look like Cousin I-I-I-I-It]
[Big hairy woman]

The group was sued by Roy Orbison’s publishers for copyright infringement – Cambbell v. Acuff-Rose Music, Inc. The case went all the way to the Supreme Court, where in a precedent establishing ruling, the SCOTUS ruled in favor of 2 Live Crew, greatly expanding protections of parodies created for profit.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=65GQ70Rf_8Y

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Pretty woman, stop a while
 Pretty woman, talk a while

annotation.plain:
This is the “story” part of the song – the lyricist’s wishful thinking – per New Musical Express(NME)

http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=rr1AZTbNtwA

There’s a ballad in the mid-section of it there: he’s very sure of getting the girl when he first sees her, and then he’s not so sure, and then he gets desperate, and then he says forget it, and then she comes back. It’s quite complicated, but it’s probably in the presentation…

annotations.lyric_fragment: Oh, oh, pretty woman

annotation.plain: The pretty woman, his wife Claudette, cheated on him. He divorced her only to re-marry her in 1966. Two month later she was killed in a motorcycle crash.

A great inspirational phrase – from none others than the Beatles' She Loves You

During his 1963 tour in Great Britain, the Beatles were his opening act.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Are you lonely just like me?

annotation.plain: A hint to his personal struggle – his long time away from home on tours apparently drove his wife to having an affair with a contractor building the same dream house about which he is writing in a letter to UK pop magazine Rave in 1964.

who died tragically in a motorcycle accident in 1966.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Chorus]

annotation.plain:
Former G-Unit member Bang Em Smurf said that 50 Cent got this chorus from a Lloyd Banks song
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QglrdNQFvz8&t=125s

Sha Money XL, who was one of the executive producers of the Get Rich Or Die Tryin' album, also said that 50 Cent took this chorus from one of Lloyd Banks’s songs.

Truth be told Lloyd Banks wrote that hook. That whole part was a verse in one of Banks’ songs. “Find me in the club, bottle full of Bubb…” Fifty heard it and knew how to make it a hook and make it hot.

Interestingly enough 50 Cent had rapped this chorus in a freestyle G-Unit did on Hot 97 in 2002

annotations.lyric_fragment: If the roof on fire, let the motherfucker burn

annotation.plain:
This is a direct reference to the iconic moment in the old school 1984 hip hop track “The Roof Is On Fire” by Rock Master Scott & the Dynamic Three.

The roof, the roof, the roof is on fire
(We don’t need no water, let the motherfucker burn)
(Burn, motherfucker, burn)

Interestingly, given 50 Cent and Eminem’s close ties – particularly at the time when 50 was signed to Shady Records – it’s worth mentioning that just 3 months prior to the release of this track, Eminem’s semi-autobiographical film 8 Mile also referenced this segment of the original track during a scene in which an abandoned house was burnt down by the main characters. It is possibly that 50’s reference was additionally inspired by this.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Intro: Justin, All]

annotation.plain: The song starts with a synthesized string orchestra. In the video, the stage is shown and at the bottom of it reads the Latin word Libertas, which translates to Freedom, which is exactly what this song is about; getting free from a dwindling relationship.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I loved you endlessly
 And you weren’t there for me
 So now, it’s time to leave
 And make it alone

annotation.plain: There’s a nice distinction between emotional and temporal ends here. Though the depth of his love was endless, she wasn’t able to match that support and connection, and so now their relationship will have an end in time.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I, I’m doin’ this tonight
 You’re probably gonna start a fight
 I know this can’t be right
 Hey, baby, come on

annotation.plain:
Although the song is seemingly about a break up with a girl, there’s a lot of underlying meaning to this allusion.

‘N Sync, while under Sony BMG, sued Lou Pearlman for reaping all of their profits, while under his management. No Strings Attached was released under Jive Records. This song can be seen as a record label break-up, between the group and its label/managers.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Don’t wanna be a fool for you
 Just another player in your game for two

annotation.plain:
She’s been toying with his emotions, similar to how a puppet master would pull the strings of a puppet. Needless to say, he wants out of the relationship.



  


A long-speculated double meaning here alludes to their former manager Lou Pearlman, who has been sued by several of the bands that he once oversaw. Pearlman was due to be released from serving a 25-year prison sentence, but ultimately passed away while serving due to suffering a stroke.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Yeah, Spyderman and Freeze in full effect

annotation.plain:
Spyderman (aka Ross Sloane) is an uncredited co-producer on “Poison.” Dr. Freeze (aka Elliot Straite) is the credited producer and writer of the track. Thus, they were in full effect.

The song was originally for Al B. Sure. Check out this documentary about the song:

https://youtu.be/c7xZ7cbpc5w?t=2m56s

annotation.plain: There had been a rumor for years that the actual lyrics are “Rob Moore, you’re dead.” Rob Moore was a wide receiver at Syracuse University, drafted in 1990 to the New York Jets. Rumor had it that Rob Moore stole Bivins’s girlfriend at Syracuse; this is why Biv is wearing Syracuse gear in the video. This story is apocryphal at best.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And I’m lookin’ in the mirror all the time
 Wonderin’ what she don’t see in me
 I’ve been funny; I’ve been cool with the lines
 Ain’t that the way love’s supposed to be?

annotation.plain: Looking in the mirror is a common metaphor for introspection, as one faces up to reality when confronted with one’s reflection. He wonders what it is she sees in Jessie that he doesn’t have, and then asks himself why she hasn’t taken notice of him when he’s been charming and has kept his distance in spite of his feelings. In a weird sort of logic, he’s blaming her for taking his basic decency of not meddling with her relationship as just that, instead of his actual intention of winning her over — not having to risk his neck admitting his feelings to her upfront all the while.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’ll play along with this charade
 That doesn’t seem to be a reason to change
 You know I feel so dirty when they start talking cute
 I wanna tell her that I love her, but the point is probably moot

annotation.plain: Even though he’s in love with Jessie’s girlfriend, he tries to pretend everything’s fine and that he’s happy for them. Doing this means being dishonest to Jessie, though, which makes him ashamed, and craving the girlfriend’s affections doesn’t help — after all, coveting your friend’s significant other is not generally approved of. He wants to admit his feelings to her but he fears it won’t change the situation, as she might say no anyway.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You know I wish that I had Jessie’s girl
 I wish that I had Jessie’s girl
 Where can I find a woman like that?

annotation.plain: He deeply wishes that Jessie’s girlfriend was his. By its own definition, though, wishes are hard to make come true, so it’s not likely to happen. He feels Jessie’s girlfriend is unique and asks desperately where he might find someone as great as her.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And she’s watching him with those eyes
 And she’s lovin’ him with that body
 I just know it
 And he’s holding her in his arms late, late at night

annotation.plain:
This is what he thinks Jessie and his girlfriend are doing, which is average for a couple. Thing is, he’s envious of Jessie, and just imagining how loving they’re being makes him feel terrible, as unrequited love is wont to do. This part might remind one of “Mr. Brightside”:

Now they’re going to bed
And my stomach is sick
And it’s all in my head, but she’s touching his
Chest now
He takes off her dress now
Let me go
I just can’t look, it’s killing me
And taking control

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Jessie is a friend
 Yeah, I know, he’s been a good friend of mine
 But lately something’s changed that ain’t hard to define
 Jessie’s got himself a girl, and I wanna make her mine

annotation.plain: Jessie and the narrator are friends. Quite good friends in fact but there is a problem: he’s in love with Jessie’s girlfriend and all he wants is to be with her. Love triangles and unrequited love are very common tropes in art, and “Jessie’s Girl” is a prime example.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
So excuse me forgettin’
 But these things I do
 You see, I’ve forgotten
 If they’re green or they’re blue
 Anyway, the thing is
 What I really mean
 Yours are the sweetest eyes I’ve ever seen

annotation.plain: Colors often have symbolic meanings. Green and blue are commonly associated with tranquility, nature, and calmness. The confusion between the two might imply that the exact detail is less important than the overall impact of the beloved’s eyes on him.

annotations.lyric_fragment: My gift is my song and this one’s for you

annotation.plain: From an early age, John was talented at the piano, and he attended the Royal Academy Of Music as a teen. One possible interpretation of this line is that he is “gifted” in music (i.e. a child prodigy), so his song is his gift. His music also got him through hard times emotionally, even helping him process his journey as a gay man when he was closeted, so he could also be saying the ability to create music is a “gift” to him.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I sat on the roof

annotation.plain: The writer of the lyrics, Bernie Taupin, allegedly wrote the song’s lyrics after breakfast one morning on the roof of 20 Denmark Street, London, where John worked for a music publishing firm as an office boy.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Well, a few of the verses

annotation.plain:
Made him feel “cross”?

According to an interview with Cameron Crowe in The Uncool, Elton said:

I remember writing it at my parents’ apartment in North London, and Bernie giving me the lyrics, sitting down at the piano and looking at it and going, ‘Oh, my God, this is such a great lyric, I can’t fuck this one up.’ It came out in about 20 minutes, and when I was done, I called him in and we both knew. I was 22, and he was 19, and it gave us so much confidence.

annotations.lyric_fragment: If I was a sculptor, heh

annotation.plain:
If he was a sculptor, he’d give his love a breathtaking sculpture. If he made potions, he’d give his love one. Sadly, he isn’t any of these and instead of fancy gifts (sculptures or potions) he gives his love a song.

Of course, as we now know, Bernie Taupin’s gift for writing songs, and Elton John’s gift for singing songs, have given them the money to buy pretty much anything they want.

annotations.lyric_fragment: But the sun’s been quite kind

annotation.plain:
Fortunately, he has a pleasantly sunny day as he’s writing.

The person he’s writing about keeps the sun “turned on” for him — the sunshine in his life.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
It’s gettin’ late to give you up
 I took a sip from my devil’s cup
 Slowly, it’s takin’ over me

annotation.plain:
The main character states that “it’s getting late”, possibly making implication that the rendezvous between the two has gone on for too long at this point, and that she now tires of him/her. Despite this, the main character states that she “took a sip from (her) Devil Cup”, which would relate to basic mythology wherein Satan rewards foul behavior with pleasures.



This implies that, though the main character has moral issues with her actions, she has no plans to repent, and will continue her tryst with her newfound lover.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
With a taste of your lips, I’m on a ride
 You’re toxic, I’m slippin’ under
 With a taste of a poison paradise
 I’m addicted to you
 Don’t you know that you’re toxic?
 And I love what you do
 Don’t you know that you’re toxic?

annotation.plain: The chorus itself continues to hammer the point home of the love interest being both “dangerous” (stating that he/she is like a “poison”) and like a drug, adding that she is “addicted” to him/her.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Too high, can’t come down
 Losing my head, spinnin’ round and round
 Do you feel me now?

annotation.plain: This reflects that earlier notion of a more carnal state of the complexity of “love”. Basically a simple sexual attraction and little else is had between these two personalities.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Baby, can’t you see I’m callin’?
 A guy like you should wear a warnin’
 It’s dangerous, I’m fallin’
 There’s no escape, I can’t wait
 I need a hit, baby, give me it
 You’re dangerous, I’m lovin’ it

annotation.plain:
Britney starts off the song with an innocuous plead for her lover to notice her. However, it turns more mature quickly, as she starts to compare her lover with a drug—she “needs a hit” of their love, and that’s why she’s calling.

Drugs can be dangerous, bad for you, and frequently come with warnings, but people use them because drugs make them feel good. B’s lover is the same—maybe dangerous, even toxic to her, but she’ll go through whatever side effects she needs to get this love.

In fact, romantic love does literally affect your brain like a drug would, so Britney’s not far off here.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Verse 1]

annotation.plain: Before making the video of “Cry Me a River”, Justin Timberlake, Britney’s ex,  called Britney to let her know that she would have been in the video. Once she saw the video, Britney was angry about how he represented her. This verse, and the following one, can be read as Spears' dig back at JT.

annotation.plain: The band ‘The Wrecking Crew’ sang the backup vocals.

annotations.lyric_fragment: On a winter’s day (On a winter’s day)

annotation.plain: Michelle Phillips was living with John Phillips in New York City in 1963 during a cold winter which made her miss the nice weather in California.

annotations.lyric_fragment: (Preacher liked the cold)

annotation.plain: The narrator has gone into the church only to get in out of the cold. That’s why the preacher likes the cold – it fills the pews. And now that he’s there, maybe the narrator feels pressure to act like he is there as a believer.

annotations.lyric_fragment: He knows I’m gonna stay (Knows I’m gonna stay)

annotation.plain: The preacher likes the cold because he knows that it causes more people to walk through his church’s doors and stay for a while to warm up, during which time he can preach to them.

annotations.lyric_fragment: (If I was in L.A.)

annotation.plain:
Many of the “Hippy”, “restless”, “Flower Children” left their home and migrated west, peaking in the 1967 Summer of Love, of which these and many other songs (e.g. San Francisco) became anthems.

It had also been very popular for the soldiers in Vietnam, expressing their homesickness from the war (cold, brown, gray) in contrast to home  - “safe and warm”.

annotations.lyric_fragment:

 If I was in L.A.

annotation.plain:
A picture is worth a thousand words (Temperatures are in Celsius) –



and if this is not convincing enough – this will…

annotations.lyric_fragment:
If I didn’t tell her (If I didn’t tell her)
 I could leave today (I could leave today)

annotation.plain:
In contrast for the somehow positive optimistic nature of the previous lines, this may be a reference to the discourse and impending separation of Michelle and John Phillips.

Their separation was the subject of their follow-up (and highest charting) hit, “Monday, Monday”, and another follow-up, “I Saw Her Again.”

Michelle had an affair with band member Denny Doherty invoking this poetic reaction.

annotation.plain: Apparently, the Phillipse’s visited St. Patrick Cathedral in Manhattan a few days before writing the song, and it had been the inspiration for this line.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Streetlights, people

annotation.plain:
Lead singer Steve Perry wrote this line to describe people walking around late at night who are illuminated by the streetlights above them.

In an interview with Vulture, Perry says that he came up with this line while looking out of a hotel window in Detroit at 2 a.m.

‘I was digging the idea of how the lights were facing down, so that you couldn’t see anything,’ he says, recalling the night. ‘All of a sudden I’d see people walking out of the dark, and into the light. And the term “streetlight people” came to me.’

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Some will win, some will lose
 Some are born to sing the blues

annotation.plain: In the game of life, there will always be winners and losers. But some people were just born to sing the blues, most likely because all they ever do is lose. As Steely Dan famously said, “They got a name for the winners in the world, I want a name when I lose…..Call Me Deacon Blues”.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
But I don’t wanna live that way
 Reading into every word you say

annotation.plain:
PROPOSED SUGGESTION:

She suggests he’s used to turn things around on her, forcing her to find other meanings to what he says when he was wrong and to blame herself even when she was right.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Outro: Gotye, Gotye & Kimbra]

annotation.plain: The singing in the outro is made to sound like it’s fading out, symbolizing both the relationship and repercussions of the breakup are finally dissolving after many arguments.

annotations.lyric_fragment: But you didn’t have to cut me off

annotation.plain:
This line comes in immediately after Kimbra finishes her verse, almost cutting her off. Well done. But it just shows how even after she is completely reasonable and methodical with why she broke up with him, the second she’s done with that he’s still going to regard her as the bitch that won’t talk to him anymore.

There is more than one side to this story, which is why this song is a pretty accurate representation of your average break up. Not just the typical “I fucked up, I’ll do anything to get you back”, or “She fucked me over the whole time” type of song.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You said that you could let it go
 And I wouldn’t catch you hung up on somebody that you used to know

annotation.plain:
Now we see a different usage of “somebody that I used to know”. It’s possible it isn’t just a phrase for just this particular girl, it’s possible he uses it for all the girls he broke up with. When he was with his most recent girl, he kept assuring her that his former girlfriend was just someone he used to know; until she caught him going back to her.

The other possibility is that the somebody he used to know is still referring to her. She hears him going on about how she wronged him so badly and he’s so done with her, and she heard him say he didn’t care about the breakup. But now he’s clearly emotionally distraught and shows he still has feeling for her.

Either meaning indicates that he isn’t done with her forever like he claims, and also that it wasn’t like this girl was the only one at fault during all this.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Now and then, I think of all the times you screwed me over
 But had me believing it was always something that I’d done

annotation.plain:
We see a different side of the relationship; she reveals that in fact, she was wronged in the relationship. Kimbra is taking on the role of the girl in this relationship that dumped Gotye.

She doesn’t see their breakup the way he does. He believes it was just an example of the two of them realizing they weren’t going to be together forever and drifting away. But she felt like she was being emotionally abused the whole time. Everything that he did wrong, he was able to put the blame on her. And she even believed it for a while, but when she saw through it she called it off.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Now and then, I think of when we were together
 Like when you said you felt so happy, you could die
 I told myself that you were right for me
 But felt so lonely in your company
 But that was love and it’s an ache I still remember

annotation.plain:
The song begins with the artist reminiscing about their relationship and how happy she was and how he merely was able to lie to himself and tell himself he was happy too.

The phrase “so happy you could die” could be interpreted two ways. The first is merely the notion that should die happy and peacefully, and thus in their relationship she would be able to die at the happiest time of her life. The second interpretation is an idea of Love-Death, or Liebestod (in German). This idea is captured wonderfully in Richard Wagner’s Tristan and Isolde. It is the idea that “love” is fully realized only in death, and thus after reaching a certain point in the relationship, death would be the consummation of the love between the two individuals.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You can get addicted to a certain kind of sadness
 Like resignation to the end, always the end
 So when we found that we could not make sense
 Well, you said that we would still be friends
 But I’ll admit that I was glad it was over

annotation.plain:
In the depths of a terrible relationship, it is hard to break up with the other person. This may be from a feeling of guilt that prevents you from freeing yourself from an unhealthy relationship or it may be from a feeling of comfort of being with someone you know (but don’t necessarily cherish). In any case, the relationship is painful and most likely becomes an on-again, off-again relationship. (See: Of Montreal’s “Our Love is Senile”.)

You can become so used to this pain that you would rather stay depressed and cut off from the world than have to face the daunting prospect of creating happiness.

This idea is captured in Belgian Frog’s “Loveless Way”:

I’d rather stay trapped in a loveless way than try to make the pain go
I dishonor myself by the way that I string you along

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Make out like it never happened and that we were nothing (Ah)
 And I don’t even need your love (Ooh)
 But you treat me like a stranger and that feels so rough (Ah)
 No, you didn’t have to stoop so low (Ooh)
 Have your friends collect your records and then change your number (Ah)
 I guess that I don’t need that, though (Ooh)
 Now you’re just somebody that I used to know

annotation.plain:
Gotye sums up the whole angst and meaning of the song with:

It wasn’t a nasty break-up, but it was messy in the sense that we hurt each other more than we needed to because it wasn’t a clean break… We both realized we had to move on and we haven’t seen each other since.

annotations.lyric_fragment:

annotation.plain: He knows he doesn’t need or deserve the treatment. He’s acknowledging that his ex and the relationship is in the past. He doesn’t even refer to her as an ex, he just refers to her as somebody. It’s like everything they went through was for nothing.

annotation.plain: Rather than keep a friendship with him, she has completely rid him from her life, going so far as to send her friends in to pick up her things. Though he couldn’t be with her, he still cares about her as a person; he didn’t want to completely end the friendship because the good times they shared were good.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
There are many things that I would like to say to you
 But I don’t know how

annotation.plain:
“There are many things that I would like to say to you” expresses a strong desire for communication and connection. It suggests that the speaker has something important they want to share with the person they’re addressing.

“But I don’t know how” highlights the speaker’s struggle in finding the appropriate means of expression. It could indicate their emotional vulnerability or the complexity of their thoughts, making it challenging to articulate their feelings.

He is talking retrospectively now, that the day (which he mentioned earlier in song) is wasted now. He didn’t grab the opportunity and didn’t tell her whatever he wanted to say.

And by now he should have realized what he should not do – like he dont be shy or dont waste further time etc.

annotation.plain:
He says that there is gossip in the town that enthusiasm for love in her heart is gone now (because of the heartbreak she had).

Altough she had heard confessions from someone about the love earlier , but this time she might have doubts about  authenticity/ genuineness of such emotions.

She never had such doubts earlier as she never embraced such a heartbreak.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Today is gonna be the day that they’re gonna throw it back to you

annotation.plain: At an Oasis gig, a woman pressed a ‘wishing stone’ into Noel’s hand therefore “Wishing Stone” was the original title of the song. This line could symbolise Noel giving the wishing stone back to the woman, likely to be acquaintance Melissa Lim. He may have given the stone back when he re-joined Oasis after his cooling off period.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Outro]

annotation.plain: Listen carefully, and you’ll hear five seconds of the riff to “Supersonic” being played on an acoustic guitar at the very end of the song.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I don’t believe that anybody feels the way I do about you now

annotation.plain:
In the first break the narrator believes that nobody else in the world could possibly have stronger feelings toward this person at this exact moment in time.

The meaning changes slightly in the second break. The person has failed and has no chances left, yet the narrator still feels strongly towards this person. Basically saying that even though everyone is against you, I still feel the same about you as I did before.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And all the roads we have to walk are winding
 And all the lights that lead us there are blinding

annotation.plain:
A straight road lets you see what’s ahead. The road of life is winding, meaning you can’t see what’s ahead, and, on top of that, the lights that you follow are blinding you. You just have to keep walking and hope for the best.

Getting to a better place in life is not easy; there will be lots of ups and downs and you won’t always see reason behind life’s events until you’re older and able to look back.

The first line alludes to The Beatles‘ song “The Long And Winding Road.”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Because maybe
 You’re gonna be the one that saves me
 And after all
 You’re my wonderwall

annotation.plain:
According to Noel Gallagher, a “Wonderwall” describes, “an imaginary friend who’s gonna come and save you from yourself.” However, Liam Gallagher said that, “It’s just a beautiful word.”

Sometimes, you may need to lay down some hard truths to great friends to save them from whatever trouble they’ve gotten themselves into. This may be the only way of saving them from themselves.

I'm the one you're using, please don't push me aside
We could've made it cruising, yeah

Soon turned out to be a pain in the ass
Seemed like the real thing only to find
Mucho mistrust, love's gone behind

annotations.lyric_fragment: We could’ve made it cruising, yeah

annotation.plain: “made it” could be referring  to marriage or a physical retirement cruise.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
In between, what I find is pleasing and I’m feeling fine
 Love is so confusing, there’s no peace of mind

annotation.plain:
Many relationships start out well only to turn sour later on down the road. A person in one may feel uncomfortable due to actions of something that the opposing partner is suggesting. Thus the “What I find is pleasing and I’m feeling fine” suggests, a person being unsure of what they enjoy and what makes them feel uneasy in a relationship.

Love is a mixture of many feelings and as a result makes someone feel unsure of what they want.  “Loving is so confusing there’s no peace of mind” can be explained by the psychology of people.

Human beings want to be in a permanent relationship with another person, yet at the same time they don’t want to lose their individuality.

This results in the mind unsure of what it wants: to spend lots of time with someone that makes them happy or enjoying the time spent being by themselves. The best way to solve this problem is to balance it equally.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Once I had a love and it was divine

annotation.plain:
Divine means “of a god or like a god”.  Another (informal) meaning of it can also be “very pleasing or delightful.”

What Debbie could be experiencing could also be seen as “puppy love,” when a couple is new and all they ever want to do is be with each other forever. Eventually, this feeling will go away.

“Divine” makes us feel the love is really something that will be good ever, and no one will realize it may hurt you until it hurts you.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Yeah, riding high on love’s true bluish light

annotation.plain:
‘Riding high’ is a variable idiom used to express doing well in many senses. ‘High’ also refers to being intoxicated, or the intoxication felt by some influence, often drugs, and many would argue love is the most powerful drug.

While light and love are often compared or connected in art and literature, the idea of love’s light being blue is unique. Could this refer to the phrase ‘true blue’ to denote something extremely loyal or orthodox?

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Once I had a love and it was a gas
 Soon turned out had a heart of glass

annotation.plain:
Saying something is “a gas” is a phrase synonymous with saying something is “a lot of fun”. She was just living in the moment in this relationship, but then it all suddenly ended when the person shattered her heart.

“Originally, Debbie’s second line of the song was, “Soon turned out, he was a pain in the ass.” Mike thought that might not play well on the radio, so I threw out a phrase, “heart of glass,” which everyone liked. Debbie worked it in as “Soon turned out, had a heart of glass.” That’s the title we used on the song.” – Mr. Stein,  Anatomy of a Song, How Blondie Created ‘Heart of Glass’, Wall Street Journal, 3 March 2015

annotations.lyric_fragment: Soon turned out to be a pain in the ass

annotation.plain: The BBC Radio edit changed this line to “Soon turned out had a heart of glass”.

Once I ran to you (I ran)
 Now, I’ll run from you

annotation.plain:
Two possible meanings:

literal meaning – The narrator avoids making any sort of contact with his ex in public.

Deeper meaning – The narrator’s love for his significant other existed until the break-up which faded away.

annotations.lyric_fragment: From the pain you drive into the heart of me

annotation.plain:
A loaded statement:

Usually pain emanates from the heart – at least in literature.

While anything “driven” into the heart will cause pain (and likely death) –



it is just as much an opposite image – as Cupid drives his arrow into the heart to create love.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Run away, I’ve got to

annotation.plain: The song has an irregular cadence with pauses between prepositions to verbs, accentuating the lyrics message – as if choking up with tears mentioned in the chorus.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Take my tears and that’s not nearly all

annotation.plain:
While not out of male’s realm, some would agree that such a line would more likely be written for a female singer, especially earlier on, as was the case with the original Gloria Jones version.

The previous line indicates that the tears given were a “bonus”, after all he (she) has already given, physically and emotionally.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I give you all a boy could give you

annotation.plain:
The original recording was in 1964 by Gloria Jones, as a B-side to another flop – “My Bad Boy’s Coming Home”.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_detailpage&v=NSehtaY6k1U

Obviously, this line read “I give you all a girl could give you”

Gloria Jones was in the ‘70s a backup singer for T-Rex, and was the girlfriend of their lead singer, Marc Bolan (killed in a car accident in 1977  - a car driven by Gloria Jones).

Marc bolan was idolized by Soft Cell’s Marc Almond, who spelled his name “MARC” to mimic Bolan’s name.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Tainted love, oh,

annotation.plain:
Marc Almond, the singer among the duo, is gay, and that let to speculation that the song was revived to warn about, or at least make people aware of the AIDS epidemic that had recently started.

That was very unlikely as the lyrics were written in 1964, and in 1981, when the cover was recorded,  the HIV virus was just discovered, and AIDS was still far from a mainstream concern or a subject of great advocacy.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Oh, tainted love

annotation.plain: A simple, but true metaphor. Love is an abstract, so being tainted is product of the imagination – smearing paint over whatever one portrays as love.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
The love we share
 Seems to go nowhere

annotation.plain:
The song is obviously about unfulfilled love – a couple at a dead end in their relationship, at least according to the narrator.

It was initially recorded in combination with another cover – of The Supremes' “Where Did Our Love Go” – another song about “lost” love.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AHUQdDtRaDI

“Where Did Our Love Go” starts ~5:00

They eventually decided to separate the tracks and use the latter for the B-side.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And you think love is to pray
 But I’m sorry, I don’t pray that way

annotation.plain:
Nice “play” on the sound similarities of “pray” and “play”.

While the latter would make more sense (and that’s what one hears in the original Gloria Jones version), the use of “pray” may be a way to demonstrate dependency and/or worshipping, which the narrator cannot accept.

Or – maybe the original intention was to use “to prey”, or combination of prey and pray.

The only musical – “non lyrical” part of the song –  played with synthesizers and rhythm machines establishing the riff that accompanies all the verses.

The first two notes – “toot – toot” like, reminds many of the tram in San Francisco…



Per Marc Almond – in 1000 UK#1 Hits

(the song is) A mixture of cold electronics with an over-passionate, over-exuberant, slightly out of key vocal.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Give me the microphone first, so I can bust like a bubble

annotation.plain: Snoop Dogg is eager to start rapping, confident that he will perform impressively once he gets the mic. The metaphor “bust like a bubble” refers to quickly making an impact, like how a bubble bursts suddenly and noticeably. It implies that once he’s given the mic, he’ll deliver something explosive or memorable, reflecting his confidence and skill.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Ain’t no pussy good enough to get burnt while I’m up in it (Yeah)

annotation.plain: “Burnt” is slang for contracting a sexually transmitted disease. Snoop emphasizes that no matter how enticing a sexual encounter may be, none are worth the risk of getting an STD, underscoring the importance of wearing contraception to maintain his sexual health. This pragmatic approach stands out within the song’s celebration of the carefree and rebellious lifestyle of gangsta rap, adding a layer of realism and wisdom to Snoop’s persona. By addressing the consequences of risky behavior, Snoop subtly promotes responsibility amidst the bravado of the genre.

This is a shout-out to the legendary boxer Evander Holyfield. Holyfield earned the nickname “The Real Deal” due to how great he was in the ring. Around this time, Holyfield was considered one of the most elite heavyweight boxers in the game.

Check out Evander’s reaction to Snoop name dropping him in this hit:

annotations.lyric_fragment: Two loced out niggas goin’ crazy

annotation.plain:
“Locced out” originates from the word “loc,” which is shorthand for “loco” (Spanish for “crazy”). In gang culture, particularly among the Crips, being “locced out” signifies being deeply involved or immersed in the gang lifestyle, often indicating toughness, fearlessness, or wild behavior. By using this term, Snoop is flexing his affiliation with the Crips and asserting his street credibility.

In the broader context of the song, Snoop and Dre are presenting themselves as iconic, hardcore figures in the gangsta rap scene, embodying the rebellious and bold spirit of West Coast hip-hop culture in the early 1990s. This line not only reinforces their authenticity and connection to the streets, but also highlights their dominance and influence in the genre.

Snoop repping Crip attire

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’m sittin’ on the dock of the bay
 Watching the tide roll away
 Ooh, I’m just sittin’ on the dock of the bay
 Wastin’ time

annotation.plain:
To find some rest after having performed at Fillmore West in San Francisco, California, Otis Redding stayed at a boathouse in Sausalito, located in the San Francisco Bay Area. There, Redding had some time to reflect on his life. During that time he was at the height of his popularity, as roughly two moths before, he had performed at the legendary Monterey Pop Festival (1967). The docks in Sausalito eventually inspired Redding to write this song, which became his biggest hit.

When Otis played the song for producer Steve Cropper, he told him that if a ship rolls, it will take on water and sink. Otis replied, “Hell, Crop, that’s what I want,” and the line stood.



Allegedly, the houseboat Redding stayed in still exists, even though slight changes have happened throughout the years. It is located at the Liberty Dock in Sausalito. It’s not open for public, though some have noted that the residents at the dock are often kind enough to give you some extra information and an outside look at the houseboat.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
’Cause I’ve had nothing to live for
 And look like nothin’s gonna come my way

annotation.plain:
Some months before he wrote this song, he had performed at the legendary 1967 Monterey Pop Festival, which marked the height of his popularity. While this meant that he actually had a lot that was about to come his way, it might’ve seemed insignificant to Redding.

Co-writer and guitarist Steve Cropper has noted that the song is “about many things”. The difficulty of coping with fame and being approximately 2000 miles away from his wife and kids might’ve been a factor. Redding also had problems with his voice during the time he conceptualized this song. Eventually, Redding recovered better than expected after the surgery was done. Shortly thereafter, he began writing extra lines and recording the song.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Verse 1]

annotation.plain: When the song was first recorded, producers worried that the sound would be too pop for Redding. They made plans to have a gospel act sing in the background of the song, but that never ended up happening.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I left my home in Georgia
 Headed for the ’Frisco bay

annotation.plain:
Otis Redding was born and raised in Georgia, a state of the United States of America. He and his wife, Zulma Atwood, also chose to raise their four children there.



A statue of Otis Redding can be found in Macon, Georgia, where Redding grew up and started a family with his wife.

Because of his career as a musician, Redding was often on the road, leaving his family behind in Georgia. In 1967, he rented a houseboat in the San Francisco (“‘Frisco”) Bay Area, California, while on the break of his King & Queen tour. During that time, Redding had some time to reflect on his career, and life in general. His time there became the inspiration of this song.

annotations.lyric_fragment: *Whistling*

annotation.plain:
Otis Redding was well-known for improvising at the end of his songs. When Otis recorded this song at Stax Studios in Memphis, Tennessee, he and co-writer Steve Cropper didn’t have a last verse written yet, so Redding just whistled the ending.

He planned to return to the studio to replace the whistling with a new verse after performing in Madison, Wisconsin. While near the destination of Madison, the plane he was in crashed probably due to poor weather on December 10, 1967. Redding died on impact at the young age of 26.

Cropper left eventually the whistling in, as it fit the song’s vibe quite well.

While most people accredit sideman Sam “Bluzman” Taylor for the whistling, Cropper has debunked this myth by stating that the released studio outtakes confirm that it was, in fact, Redding who did the whistling.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Sittin’ in the mornin’ sun
 I’ll be sittin’ when the evenin’ come
 Watching the ships roll in
 And then I watch ’em roll away again, yeah

annotation.plain:
Otis Redding only wrote the first verse of “(Sittin' On) The Dock of the Bay”. His session band’s guitarist Steve Cropper finished the rest of the lyrics. Cropper reflected on a conversation he had with Redding:

I was at the studio when Otis Redding called me from the Memphis airport.
Usually when Otis came to town, he waited until he checked into the Holiday Inn before calling me to work with him on songs in his room. This time he couldn’t wait. He said, “Crop, I’ve got a hit. I’m coming right over.”
When Otis walked in, he said, “Crop, get your gut-tar.” I always kept a Gibson B-29 around. He grabbed it, tuned it to an open E-chord, which made the guitar easier to play slide. Then Otis played and sang [this] verse he had written.
I said, “Otis, hold on. If a ship rolls, it will take on water and sink.” He said, “That’s what I want, Crop.” So we let it go and worked on the rest of the song.

annotations.lyric_fragment: It’s two thousand miles I roamed

annotation.plain: The distance from Georgia to San Francisco is approximately 2000 miles.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Verse]

annotation.plain:
“Last Dance” is famous for having a slow piano-ballad intro before erupting into a dance number. Donna Summer told NPR that it was a compromise for wanting to score a hit with a slow song.

… I don’t know if it was Neil [Bogart] or Giorgio [Moroder] who came up with the idea of why not start the song slow and then break out into it so people can start together, and then they can swing themselves out and start dancing, you know, the way they dance. And it was a format that worked for us very well.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You’re on the phone with your girlfriend, she’s upset

annotation.plain: Taylor said that she saw a close friend arguing with his girlfriend. Later, she started humming a little tune that went “You’re on the phone with your girlfriend, she’s upset.” That’s how this song came to be!

annotations.lyric_fragment: And you’ve got a smile that can light up this whole town

annotation.plain:
Swift has sung about her lover’s smile a lot of times throughout her career. On “Jump Then Fall”, she sings:

Every time you smile, I smile
And every time you shine, I’ll shine for you

On “Superstar”:

You smile that beautiful smile and all the girls in the front row
Scream your name

And “Today Was a Fairytale”:

You’ve got a smile
That takes me to another planet

The theme persisted and, on 2019’s “I Think He Knows”, a similar line is also sang:

Lyrical smile, indigo eyes, hand on my thigh
We could follow the sparks, I’ll drive

annotations.lyric_fragment:
’Cause she wears short skirts, I wear T-shirts
 She’s Cheer Captain and I’m on the bleachers

annotation.plain:
Swift told The New Yorker in 2011 that the pre-chorus and chorus were the first parts she wrote, saying:

I just came in and played the pre-chorus and the first half of the chorus for Liz [Rose]. ‘She wears short skirts, I wear T-shirts,’ and she goes, ‘Something about bleachers!’

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’m in my room, it’s a typical Tuesday night
 I’m listening to the kind of music she doesn’t like

annotation.plain:
In the music video, Taylor is in her room reading, and later gets up and dances to (presumably) music the infamous “she” doesn’t like. The next day is a school day, and she’s not doing anything special.



The use of the word “typical” emphasizes that this has been the status quo for a long time, and their fighting is nothing new.

Taylor has made mention to this specific day of the week before, on “Forever & Always.”

Once upon a time, I believe it was a Tuesday when I caught your eye

Taylor has said in interviews that the “Junior Jewels” t-shirt was borrowed from a member of her tour band, who had it from band camp in her youth.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Standing by and waiting at your back door

annotation.plain:
He means so much to her, that she will literally stand and wait for him outside of his house for as long as it takes him to come out and run to her.



She uses a similar line to this in “Hey Stephen,” where she talks about waiting out in the cold:

Of all the girls tossing rocks at your window
I’ll be the one waiting there even when it’s cold

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Oh, I remember you driving to my house
 In the middle of the night
 I’m the one who makes you laugh
 When you know you’re ’bout to cry
 I know your favorite songs
 And you tell me ’bout your dreams

annotation.plain:
Swift has shwown similar feelings to this on another Fearless track, “Jump Then Fall”:

The time is gonna come when you’re so mad you could cry
But I’ll hold you through the night until you smile




This is Swift recounting all the memories she and this guy share and how she makes him feel good when he’s down (instead of freaking out when he made a joke); how they know each other so well, which just points to the fact that they’d be a way better couple than the guy and the “cheer captain”.



The part in the official video when the two use the notebooks to write notes shown through their windows is another sign that they’re meant-to-be. Taylor writing “You okay?” shows that she knows this guy well enough to be able to tell that he’s not okay from his body language.

Glitter on the mattress
 Glitter on the highway

annotation.plain: In this case, the glitter is something like the singer’s nostalgia or conception of the Love Shack. Everything about it glitters to her. The highway (path) creates anticipation. Glitter is happiness, giddiness, anticipatory joy.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Well, it’s set way back in the middle of a field
 Just a funky old shack and I gotta get back

annotation.plain:
The Love Shack isn’t necessarily the most luxurious, or in the most central location. In fact, it’s hard to find. It’s just kind of in the middle of a field, at the end of the Atlanta Highway. However, it’s not fun because of those- it’s fun because of the people, music, and lovin' that happens in it’s walls. Kate is talking about how it’s just small and in the middle of nowhere, but she wants to go back regardless.
Also, since the Love Shack, as a place, was meant partially as a metaphor for some of the more energetic and fun venues that the B-52’s performed at, this is recognizing that they, at least in the beginning, were just a small band that was hard to notice, but once you did you loved them.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Your what?
 Tin roof, rusted

annotation.plain:
The lyric “Tin roof, rusted” has no specific meaning, but that hasn’t stopped listeners from trying to define it. Pierson told the A.V. Club: “There are all sorts of interpretations, but one of the most popular is that it means you’re pregnant. I have no idea how people got that idea. I’ve never heard that particular expression, and I don’t even know how it came up, but I hear it all the time now!”

A 1990 Spin article offers some insight into how the line first worked its way into “Love Shack”:

At one point while they were jamming, Keith Strickland stopped playing. Cindy kept singing. She screamed, ’T-i-i-i-n roof!“ thinking the music was still going. Then she looked around and realized everything had stopped, and just said, "Rusted.” The band worked it into “Love Shack”’s final mix.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Made of finest silver from the north of Spain

annotation.plain:
The reference to the north of Spain likely evokes the historic image as the world’s greatest seafaring power. It is possible that “north of Spain” might not allude to a specific city, but just be poetic.

That said, Spain is fairly well known for it’s silver mines, from Roman times. In the north there were the mines of Gijon.

In addition to its silver mines, northern Spain is a very popular pilgrimage destination in the Christian world – The Camino de Santiago route, which concludes at the tomb of St. James in the cathedral of Santiago de Compostela in Galicia, is still walked by foot in many cases. Brandy’s locket carries added significance due to its place of origin, a site of spiritual devotion and long journeys that mirrors her pining for her sailor, far away.

annotations.lyric_fragment: But my life, my love, and my lady is the sea

annotation.plain: The sailor, while tempted to settle down and live a life of ease alongside Brandy, confesses to her that “But my life, my love, and my lady is the sea”. When the sailor says this, he means that the sea is his calling, that it will always tempt him, and he will always be drawn to it, to go on adventures.

annotations.lyric_fragment: And Brandy does her best to understand

annotation.plain:
Every other sailor says that “her eyes could steal a sailor from the sea,” but clearly her eyes cannot. So are they not honest men? Are they not true sailors? How can a man choose such a lonely calling over a life with the perfect woman? The sea is beautiful and vast, but also dangerous, cold, and uncaring!

Brandy might also struggle to understand why she and the sea are mutually exclusive, but it is not clear that she does so. It is likely to be a given that Brandy cannot join him in sailing because she is a woman, as every sailor in the story is a man.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
They say, “Brandy, fetch another round”
 She serves them whiskey and wine

annotation.plain:
These two lines, through unspoken wordplay, reinforce the ensuing narrative: the sailors keep asking (“another”) for Brandy, but brandy (the drink)/Brandy (the lady) is not for them to have.

It’s funny that her name is Brandy, but she serves whiskey and wine. The difference between brandy and whisky is that brandy is made from grapes and is basically distilled wine, but whiskey is made from grain. We can conclude that water, aka the sailor, was removed from brandy which fundamentally altered her. Now all these other sailors admire her, but you can’t add water back to brandy.
