annotations.lyric_fragment:
But today the way I play the game has got to change oh yeah (Oh, yeah)
 Now I’m gonna get myself happy

annotation.plain:
George is rejecting the roadmap that the music industry is once again expecting him to play in order to make him more mentally stable.

Michael admitted that the rollout of Faith made him feel exhausted, lonely, and frustrated in the end after a large tour, numerous music videos, and constant promotion. For his second solo album, he decided not to do the same rollout of his first album by refusing to promote the album as well as appear in music videos in order to make himself more mentally stable.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I won’t let you down
 I will not give you up

annotation.plain: An early shotout to his fans that despite his change in musical direction and style, he still tries to provide joy for his fandom.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I just hope you understand
 Sometimes the clothes do not make the man

annotation.plain: Making it known that he is more than bubble gum pop music persona that launched his career.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Heaven knows we sure had some fun, boy
 What a kick, just a buddy and me
 (What a kick, just a buddy and me)
 We had every big-shot goodtime band on the run, boy
 We were living in a fantasy

annotation.plain:
George refers to his band-mate from Wham!, Andrew Ridgeley.

Of their early days together, Michael has said:

For a while it was just magical. With your best mate, playing out your fantasies. It was just a dream. I was supremely confident I was writing pop classics but I was also supremely aware that if I left the imagery a little bit more to Andrew, kids loved it. Then we were massively successful and I went from being Andrew’s shadow as a sexually confident being to being the centre of attention. At that level I lost all my confidence. I suddenly felt like a fake, so the whole thing turned me into somebody who felt the camera was my enemy.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Posing for another picture
 Everybody’s got to sell
 But when you shake your ass
 They notice fast
 And some mistakes were built to last

annotation.plain: This is a direct reference to the crazy success of the Faith album, specifically his dancing in the video for the “Faith” single (“when you shake your ass”). George is not proud of his past image and finds it very hard to shake it off (“some mistakes were built to last”). This point is further made by the Faith-era artifacts—the leather jacket, the guitar, the Wurlitzer jukebox—being destroyed in the video for “Freedom! ‘90” (and also by his decision to not appear in the video).

annotations.lyric_fragment:
May not be what you want from me
 Just the way it’s got to be
 Lose the face now
 I’ve got to live

annotation.plain: George is at last living for himself and he does not care what other people think. He is finally liberated.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
That’s what you get, that’s what you get, that’s what you get
 I say that’s what you get
 I say that’s what you get
 That’s what you get for changing your mind

annotation.plain:
The lyrics point out George’s dissatisfaction for his prior image and how jaded he’d become with the industry.

The lines can also be seen as a harbinger of his later, very public spat with his record company, Sony Columbia, which he left after this album.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
When I knew which side my bread was buttered
 I took the knife as well

annotation.plain: George knows what is necessary to keep himself at an advantage, given he’s a great songwriter. So he’s taking full control of his career, not being what the higher-ups want him to be.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Well it looks like the road to heaven
 But it feels like the road to hell

annotation.plain:
This part of the song represents a journey into George’s mind. This is evident in the abrupt chord progression from a potent C major to a mellow, funky C minor.

When looking around him, it appears George has the perfect life; however, this is not the way George lives his life. He feels he is on the road to hell while others may feel he is a “superstar” and on the road to heaven and a superb legacy.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
We won the race, got out of the place
 Went back home, got a brand new face for the boys on MTV

annotation.plain:
As one-half of Wham!, George was one of the most successful artists of all time. He’s won numerous awards, which he refers to as a “race.” This win made his record company and those around him very proud, and the band was able to break up at the top of their game.

“Brand new face” refers to the new hairstyle and facial hair he wore to promote Faith. He looked very different from when he was in Wham!.

annotation.plain:
The first flush of love changes everything, as it did for Perry in 2010 when she married Russell Brand.

Valentine’s Day was clearly important for her: Reports circulated that she bought Brand a customized $340,000 dollar Bentley Brooklands for a surprise Valentine’s Day gift in 2010. The couple divorced in 2011.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You make me feel like I’m livin’ a
 Teenage dream, the way you turn me on
 I can’t sleep, let’s run away
 And don’t ever look back, don’t ever look back
 My heart stops when you look at me
 Just one touch, now, baby, I believe
 This is real, so take a chance
 And don’t ever look back, don’t ever look back

annotation.plain:
While discussing “Teenage Dream,” Katy said that the song is about recapturing the dizzying, thrilling feeling of first love.

When you’re growing up and you’re falling in love for the first time, it’s such an amazing feeling that sometimes you can’t recycle again later on in your life. For me, being in love again now, it’s kind of the same feeling.

At the same time, her image has always been wrapped up in a stylized sexuality, inspired by the image of a pinup model. Many of her videos feature a blend of girlish innocence and adult sexuality, the sort of transition of desire associated with teenage years:

I want people in a way to think of me as that pinup poster in their room, that I can invade their dreams, be their teenage dream."

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Chorus]

annotation.plain:
Perry originally co-wrote numerous songs with youthful themes in mind, but they were rejected by Benny Blanco and Max Martin. Blanco was the one who came up with the idea of being in love as a teenager.

The production has influences of rock and disco, but can be put under the category of power pop.

According to Steve Leffridge of Pop Matters:

The title track and second single is even better [than the previous one] with Katy’s lusty belting on the chorus, which soars over a filthy grind of industrial-pop programming.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I know you get me, so I let my walls come down, down

annotation.plain:
The “walls” that Katy sings about could possibly refer to her mental barriers. After being scarred by previous boyfriends, Katy believes that she can recognize true love.

In addition, as Katy claims that she lets her “walls come down”, she submits herself to her lover. This could also lead to a sexual reference.

It is worth taking note of the fact that she goes on to say:

Got a motel and
Built a fort out of sheets

This could be a usage of either an extended metaphor or wordplay.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Ain’t no mountain high, ain’t no valley low
 Ain’t no river wide enough, baby

annotation.plain: “Ain’t No Mountain High Enough” is about so much more than a simple love story, it’s a story of self empowerment and never giving up. The song was originally written by the husband and wife hit songwriting duo of Nickolas Ashford and Valerie Simpson. Nick Ashford came from Willow Run in 1964 with a dream of making it in NY. Before he got to that dream he spent months in Bryant park–homeless. The lyrics, “Ain’t no mountain high, Ain’t no valley low, Ain’t no river wide enough, baby,”  symbolizes how Ashford felt about his troubles. “Simpson recalls how he said he was walking by the large buildings in the district of Central Park West and thought, ‘The buildings looked like mountains.” Ashford was determined to make it and not let his obstacles deter him.

annotation.plain:
Marvin and Tammi have done multiple songs and even compiled an album together. While their relationship was nothing more than friends, even somewhat of a [brother-and-sister dynamic], they still were very tight.

Marvin Gaye and Tammi Terrell… remained friends; they had a brother and sister type of relationship. Tammi was dating David Ruffin, lead singer of the Temptations.

annotation.plain: The post-chorus amplifies the song’s physicality with the command “slam your body down and wind it all around.” This section encourages listeners to engage physically with the music, reflecting the song’s energetic and dynamic spirit.

annotations.lyric_fragment: If you wanna be my lover

annotation.plain: The outro succinctly ties back to the central theme with the line “If you wanna be my lover,” leaving the listener with a lasting impression of the song’s playful yet meaningful message about love and friendship.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Oh, what you think about that
 Now you know how I feel
 Say you could handle my love
 Are you for real? (Are you for real?)
 I won’t be hasty
 I’ll give you a try

annotation.plain: In the second verse, the lyrics challenge the listener to prove their sincerity and capability of handling the singer’s love. The line “Are you for real?” questions the authenticity of the potential partner. The verse also highlights the willingness to give someone a chance but with a clear boundary: If the partner fails to meet expectations, they will be dismissed (“then I’ll say goodbye”).

annotations.lyric_fragment:
If you wanna get with me
 Better make it fast
 Now, don’t go wasting
 My precious time

annotation.plain: In the first verse, the lyrics advise a potential partner to focus on the present and future rather than past mistakes. This verse highlights the need for efficiency and seriousness in relationships, as indicated by “Better make it fast” and “Don’t go wasting my precious time.” The underlying message is about valuing time and taking immediate action to build a strong connection.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Yo, I’ll tell you what I want
 What I really, really want
 So tell me what you want
 What you really, really want
 I’ll tell you what I want
 What I really, really want
 So tell me what you want
 What you really, really want
 I wanna (Hey!), I wanna (Hey!)
 I wanna (Hey!), I wanna (Hey!)

annotation.plain: The refrain is a back-and-forth dialogue that establishes the central theme of the song: desire and communication. The repetition of “I’ll tell you what I want, what I really, really want” underscores the importance of expressing one’s true desires clearly. The energetic interjections (“Hey!”) further emphasize the urgency and excitement behind their message. The phrase “zig-a-zig, ah” is a whimsical expression, adding a playful and memorable hook.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Ha-ha-ha-ha-ha

annotation.plain: The playful laughter in the intro sets a fun and carefree tone for the song. It immediately engages the listener with a sense of joy and spontaneity.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
If you wanna be my lover
 You gotta get with my friends

annotation.plain: Basically, she’s saying she wants him to fornicate with all of her friends (one by one) before she will even consider dating him. Each friend in the group considers each of the other friends to now be a part of themselves (like how you take up the mannerisms of close friends), so if he can please the other “parts” of herself then he can please her.

annotations.lyric_fragment: If you really bug me, then I’ll say goodbye

annotation.plain: A lukewarm invitation to anybody who wishes to date Geri.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
So here’s a story from A to Z
 You wanna get with me, you gotta listen carefully

annotation.plain: This verse provides a breakdown of the group members through a clever alphabetical story (“A to Z”). It offers insights into their personalities and preferences, making it clear that understanding and accepting each member’s individuality is crucial. The playful lines like “Easy V doesn’t come for free, she’s a real lady” blend humor with the overall message of respect and understanding.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
If you want my future
 Forget my past

annotation.plain:
Here, the Spice Girls are addressing the possibility that future men may be deterred by the extensive dating and sexual history.

The ladies are, in effect, asking suitors to ignore all the men they have slept with in the past.

These lyrics suggests moving forward in a relationship or any aspect of life, it is necessary to let go of any negative or limiting beliefs associated with the past – such as the female’s body count.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’d like to know that your love
 Is love I can be sure of
 So tell me now, and I won’t ask again
 Will you still love me tomorrow?

annotation.plain:
Whether or not the singer realizes it, the assurance that “I won’t ask again” is plainly false. Perhaps we believe in not needing to ask again—or hope we won’t need to—yet the question repeats at least twice more.

The lack of a certain answer is inevitable. Much as I may ask you to state your love, and truthfully as you may reply, there will always be the requirement that I trust you.



But since I’d so courteously like (rather than insist to need) a “love I can be sure of,” understand me if tomorrow I ask: will you still love me tomorrow?

annotations.lyric_fragment: You had my heart inside of your hand

annotation.plain: In this line “You had m heart inside of your hand”, Adele is using a metaphor to present the anger she is feeling presumably because she was going through a bad relationship.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You had my heart inside of your hand

annotation.plain:
Cause she gave it to you. And then you betrayed her. That’s like rule number one to never do. What kind of person does this.

I suppose only a sad little life. Probably a man. They are always sad.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Thinkin’ that we almost had it all

annotation.plain:
here, she doesn’t mean “We almost had all that love”.
“having it all” – as google says – means: “ having all the things life has to offer, having all the things”. and here she means: “we almost had everything we could ever ask for”. She means we were on our way to have all those.

annotations.lyric_fragment: They keep me thinkin’ that we almost had it all

annotation.plain:
here, she doesn’t mean “We almost had all that love”.
“having it all” -as google says – means: “ having all the things life has to offer, having all the things”. and here she means: “we almost had everything we could ever ask for”. She means we were on our way to have all those.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Count your blessings to find what you look for (Woah)

annotation.plain:
Adele is subtly boosting her own ego here.

To count your blessings means to be grateful for what you have. Therefore, Adele is suggesting that in order to find the happiness he wants in a relationship, her ex should stop looking elsewhere and appreciate what he already had–a perfect woman in her.

annotations.lyric_fragment: And you played it to the beat

annotation.plain:
Adele felt that she could trust her lover, she let him into her (notoriously private) life. Unfortunately, he wasn’t all nice; he ended up hurting her and using her for what he wanted. “Beat” could reference a heartbeat, since it’s her heart she says just before he had in his hand. Also, specifically “playing it to the beat” alludes to music, which may be Adele suggesting  that based upon her musical track record at the time he knew and took pride in the fact she’d deal with her pain by writing songs like this about him and their relationship once it finally fell apart.

It’s a cruel world out there.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
But you played it, you played it, you played it
 You played it to the beat

annotation.plain: Relating it back to the chorus, Adele’s lover had her heart in his hands—he was caring for her. Unfortunately, Adele’s lover wasn’t all nice; he ended up playing her and using her for what he wanted. Adele claims he played it to the beat of a song, which may suggest it was his plan from the start and he knew what he was doing. It’s a cruel world out there.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Think of me in the depths of your despair
 Make a home down there, as mine sure won’t be shared

annotation.plain:
Continuing with the threats from the first verse, Adele hopes that her ex-lover feels pain. It’s common to feel animosity toward’s one’s ex, but Adele takes it further than just hating your old love. “Depths of your despair” also refers to hell (or, sticking with the ocean theme, the dark depths of the deep sea). Adele hopes he goes there and stays there; a worthy fee for the suffering he caused her.



Basically, Adele hopes the breakup will make him miserable while she prospers. Nice for her, that’s exactly what happened. Adele went on and had a child with her new boyfriend in 2012, while we haven’t heard anything about this guy since.

annotations.lyric_fragment: The scars of your love remind me of us

annotation.plain: When you have an injury, you see the scar and you remember of the pain you felt in that moment. Adele feels the same way about her emotional injury. She’ll be able to look back at her ‘emotional scars’ in the upcoming years and it’ll remind her of him. This makes it tough to get over someone as you’ll be constantly reminded of that person. Adele uses “scars” as a metaphor for “memories”, claiming she’ll always have the memory—positive or negative—of their relationship. Just like scars, the memories won’t ever leave her.

annotations.lyric_fragment: (You’re gonna wish you never had met me)

annotation.plain:
As stated in verse 1:

Go ahead and sell me out, and I’ll lay your ship [shit] bare
See how I’ll leave with every piece of you
Don’t underestimate the things that I will do

At least Adele’s kind enough to warn him. After she’s done with him, either by revealing all of the stuff she had to put up with in their relationship or any secrets between the two, he will wish he never had met her. Don’t underestimate what she can do, especially with her newfound fame. 21 was what many would deem an onslaught of verbal attacks on Adele’s old flame, and as it sold over 30 million copies as of November 2015, that’s a lot of people hearing Adele embarrass her ex-lover. She’s already made him look like a fool, and chances are, he wishes they’d never met. Mission accomplished



Music theorists have noticed that when this line is delivered in the chorus, it used an A♮, which is odd, and Adam Neely made a 12-minute video all about this one note:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IUfJZJofdj8

annotations.lyric_fragment: Everybody wants to rule the—

annotation.plain: This is a fragment of a row without the word “world”

annotations.lyric_fragment: One headline, why believe it?

annotation.plain:
One way of interpreting this is if only one source is saying something, why would you believe it?

The other way I think to interpret it is if everybody believes one thing, but you don’t, pursue what you do believe.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Nothing ever lasts forever

annotation.plain: i like it

annotations.lyric_fragment: Say that you’ll never, never, never, never need it

annotation.plain: This is likely in reference to many countries saying that they’ll never need their nukes, they’re only making them as a precaution.

annotations.lyric_fragment: All for freedom and for pleasure

annotation.plain: I interpreted this as a very patriotic American message.

annotations.lyric_fragment: So glad we’ve almost made it

annotation.plain: This could be interpreted as the two powers, the US and USSR, expressing how close they were to gaining victory over each other.

annotations.lyric_fragment: When they do, I’ll be right behind you

annotation.plain: Likely referring to the retaliation policy of “mutually assured destruction” that was applied in the event that either side of the Cold War conflict fired a nuclear missile at the other. In that way, the preceding lines are essentially a statement to the other side: “If you fire at me and destroy my property and my people, I WILL fire back”

annotations.lyric_fragment: Help me to decide

annotation.plain: Could be referencing the democratic political system that the US is built around, allowing its citizens some ability to decide the future of the nation. It may also be referencing the openly diplomatic foreign policy of the US, and it’s tendency to, as it did by creating both the League of Nations and the United Nations, call on other countries to help work together through diplomacy. Following this thread, it may be a plea to the USSR to cooperate with them to help calm the tensions created between themselves.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Help me make the

annotation.plain: As with the previous verse, this seems to be a fragment of a complete sentence finished in the first part of the chorus: “Help me make the most of freedom and of pleasure”. This, combined with the previous lines, further reinforces this is in fact the US talking about itself. It asks that the listener, (unidentified, perhaps citizens of the US or perhaps a plea with the Soviet Union), to help them to make the most of the “freedom and pleasure” that their democratic and heavily capitalistic society grants them, which is now being threatened by the possibility of nuclear war.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Bridge]

annotation.plain: In keeping with the implied “back and forth” conversation with these personifications of the US and USSR, the bridge appears to be both of them shouting in unison, as insinuated by the “chorus” effect used by the singers. Who is talking to who is unclear; perhaps they are shouting to each other, or perhaps to onlookers.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’ll be gone
 In a day or two

annotation.plain: The singer will only be here for a short while, so it’s important that they make the most of the time they have together.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Say after me

annotation.plain: “Si etter meg,” which is Norwegian for “repeat after me,” directly translates to “say after me,” so it was meant to be “repeat after me.”

annotations.lyric_fragment: “It’s no better to be safe than sorry”

annotation.plain: The idiom “better safe than sorry” emphasises not taking risks to avoid potential negative outcomes or regrets. “It’s no better to be safe than sorry” seems to a variation of this, and instead suggests that not taking risks does not guarantee a more positive outcome. So maybe it’s better to tell you how I feel just in case you feel the same?

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Take on me (Take on me)
 Take me on (Take on me)

annotation.plain:
There’s an intimate level to this text, as well–“Take on me” literally translated to Norwegian (a-ha’s native language, though they perform in English) as “Ta på meg.” This is how you say “Touch me” in Norwegian.

“Take me on” / “Ta meg på” means “put me on” (like clothing).

The bilingual nature of the first line offers dual meanings: “Give me a chance!” and “Touch me,” in the first; and “Take me on,” (colloquially meaning, “I’ll fight you,” or “I’ll accept your challenge,”) and “Wear me.”

Considering the Norwegian lyrics as subtext rather than a pretext, and considering the coy and non-committal nature of the verses, there is quite a battle within our protagonist and narrative. At once, he wants to love fully and genuinely, as he feels a lot for this person, but he is going away, and he senses mutual reticence. The sexual attraction, though not necessarily confirmed is culpable as he “stumbles away, slowly learning” some semblance of self-confidence.

The two challenge each other as well as being skeptically in love with each other.

annotations.lyric_fragment: (Oh, my-my, what a sensation)

annotation.plain: Sensory distortions are a component of LSD trips.  Many users experience synesthesia, where two separate senses are associated.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I don’t know where but she sends me there

annotation.plain: He is so head over heels for her that every time he thinks of or sees her, he enters some sort of paradise. This could also be an underlying drug reference.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Close my eyes, she’s somehow closer now
 Softly smile, I know she must be kind
 When I look in her eyes
 She goes with me to a blossom world

annotation.plain:
The girl is so perfect and gives off such good vibes, that she may only be his dream girl. This is further proven when he “looks in her eyes” and they go off to a “blossom world” which is undoubtedly equating his wild love for her to a psychedelic (drug) experience.

It was revealed on the SMiLE Documentary, the lyric was originally written as: “she goes with me to a blossom world we find”. Producer/Songwriter Brian Wilson removed “we find” so that the bassline leading to the “Good Vibrations” hook is heard more prominently, thought nowadays sometimes singer Mike Love adds the line back during live perfomances.

Note:
Brian Wilson was known for his use of LSD and other drugs, which was fitting as “Good Vibrations” became a cornerstone of psychedelic music.

At a modern glance we may see them as psychedelic pioneers; but in the sixties they were seen as all-American boys with a clean-cut look.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’m pickin’ up good vibrations
 She’s giving me excitations (Oom-bop-bop)

annotation.plain:
Definition of ‘excitation’ according to Merriam-Webster:

the disturbed or altered condition resulting from stimulation of an individual, organ, tissue, or cell.

She turns him on. And she’s good at it.

Also, the electrotheremin played on this track illustrates the good vibrations through sound. It was played by its inventor, Paul Tanner. The instrument is played without touching it. The weird noise produced by this instrument was a major contributor to the song’s success, as it provided a psychedelic effect.

Brian came over to me and sang such and such a thing, and I said “Well, write it down and I’ll play it,” and he said “Write it down? We don’t write anything down.”
- Paul Tanner, Strange Sounds: Offbeat Instruments and Sonic Experiments in Pop by Mark Brend.

annotation.plain: She’s attracted to the darker aspects of relationships. While most people wouldn’t want to deal with drama, she willingly takes it on, either because she find drama exciting or because she wants to experience this love to the full extent.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Oh, caught in a bad romance
 Oh, caught in a bad romance

annotation.plain:
Lady Gaga has said these lyrics are quite literal: caught in a bad romance revers to being in love with someone you’re not suppose to be in love with. Gaga confirmed in an interview with Grazia that the song is about being in love with your best friend.

She also stated it’s also more general; her attraction to unhealthy romantic relationships.

Hence it’s a bad romance.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I want your ugly, I want your disease
 I want your everything as long as it’s free
 I want your love

annotation.plain:
Even if it’s ugly, even if it’s contaminated with diseases, she wants it all. The good ánd the bad.

During an interview with Fuse TV, Gaga said about these lyrics:

[…] I want your ugly, I want your disease, all of those things that I’m saying, it’s like when you love someone so much and your fear of losing someone is so so deep, that you’re [like] I want your psycho, I want your ugly, I want all the most disgusting parts of you that you think nobody will ever love. I love all of those things. The song’s about being in love with your best friend. Whether that’s a literal situation in your life or just you maybe wanted to tell someone that you love them but you couldn’t. It’s a bad romance.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Gaga, ooh, la, la

annotation.plain:
Lady Gaga name drops herself in the pre-chorus, followed up by the phrase “Ooh La La”, which is a phrase used to express excitement or admiration.

“Ooh La La” is also French in origin, which lines up well given that the song has a few verses in French

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Ra, ra, ah-ah-ah
 Roma, roma-ma

annotation.plain:
In October 2016, Gaga explained to James Corden that she repeats these initial syllables in the song’s hook simply because they begin to sound out the word “romance.”

https://youtu.be/X5Cfi7U4eL4?t=180

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I want your love and I want your revenge
 You and me could write a bad romance (Oh)
 I want your love and all your lover’s revenge
 You and me could write a bad romance
 Oh, caught in a bad romance
 Oh, caught in a bad romance

annotation.plain:
Lady Gaga revealed her mindset when writing this chorus during an interview with Grazia in 2010:

I kind of wanted to leave the ‘80s a little bit, so the chorus is a '90s melody, which is what the inspiration was. There was certainly some whisky involved in the writing of the record. It’s about being in love with your best friend.

What she quite bluntly states throughout this hook is her desire for intimate relations with a person she’s not quite meant to be with (i.e., as she told Grazia, a best friend). “Bad Romance” means not that a romance has dissatisfied her, but the idea of it turns her on, even though it’s against moral rules.

“I want your love and all your lover’s revenge” reinforces that, showing that Gaga is thinking recklessly and not seriously caring or contemplating the extent of how damaging a naughty tryst would be!

annotations.lyric_fragment: I want your leather-studded kiss in the sand

annotation.plain:
She wants her lover to be delicate (just like a kiss in the sand), but at the same time she wants it rough (leather-studded possibly refers to BDSM.)



Of course this could be figuratively speaking of show business and what it takes to be part of it, in which case she’s ready to face it all.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I want your horror, I want your design
 ’Cause you’re a criminal as long as you’re mine
 I want your love
 Love, love, love, I want your love
 I want your psycho, your vertigo schtick (Hey)
 Want you in my rear window, baby, you’re sick

annotation.plain:
Gaga has stated in interviews that these lines are indeed a callback to the movies Psycho, Vertigo, and Rear Window all movies directed by Alfred Hitchcock. Hitchcock films tend to focus on people’s descent into madness, and thus fit well with the rest of the song.

“I want your horror,” in a metaphorical sense, refers to these Hitchcock “horror films.” Furthermore, in light of discovering these dark secrets that her lover harbors, she accepts him for all he is, seeing him as some kind of bad boy “criminal”.

“I want your psycho” implies that Gaga craves her lover’s wild side. In addition, she wishes for her lover to behave like the characters from the movie Vertigo to fulfill her power fantasy. After all, in the film, the lead female Judy (played by Kim Novak) manipulates the lead male John Fergurson (played by James Stewart). Lastly, “want you in my rear window” implies a desire for anal sex, as Gaga desires pleasure from her “rear”.



Although the official lyric is “shtick”, Gaga makes no qualms in pronouncing it a bit more like “stick”. Thus, her lover’s “vertigo stick” is also referring to his genitalia. This could also be a reference to her earlier-released song “Lovegame” where the speaker expresses a desire to “take a ride on” her lover’s “disco stick.”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Walk, walk, fashion, baby
 Work it, move that bitch crazy
 Walk, walk, fashion, baby
 Work it, move that bitch crazy
 Walk, walk, fashion, baby
 Work it, move that bitch crazy
 Walk, walk, passion, baby
 Work it, I’m a free bitch, baby

annotation.plain:
This song debuted on the catwalk during Paris Fashion Week. Gaga and McQueen were close friends while he was still alive, so much so that she includes his style in the “Bad Romance” music video when she sings these lines.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qrO4YZeyl0I&feature=youtu.be&t=207

The line “move that bitch crazy” describes the “passion” with which this fictional model walks, but it also reflects the song’s greater meaning. In her “bad romance”, Gaga could be referring to her relationship as her “bitch,” to which she ardently dedicates herself.

annotation.plain:
“Oh baby, give me one more chance (To show that I love you). Won’t you please let me (Back in your heart).”
— Despite the fact that his ex is dating someone else, Michael still begs her to become his girlfriend (thus breaking up with her current boyfriend)

“Oh darlin', I was blind to let you go (Let you go baby). But now since I see you in his arms (I want you back).”
— You never know what you had until it’s gone. He realizes that he took her love for granted when he sees all the fun she is having with her new boyfriend.

annotation.plain:
“But someone picked you from the bunch, one glance was all it took.”
— Another guy started to date the girl Michael broke up with. This other guy saw something that was unique about her that Michael didn’t recognize before. And that’s when Michael regrets his decision to end the relationship.

“Now it’s much too late for me to take a second look”
— She’s already dating someone else so it’s too late for Michael to ask her out again.

annotation.plain: Just as Big Pun rapped on “Still not a Player” that “I don’t discriminate, I regulate every shade of the ass,” when it comes to the fellas, Missy Elliot shares Pun’s egalitarian ideals of horniness.

 Not on the bed, lay me on your sofa

annotation.plain: Maybe because it was just the night

annotations.lyric_fragment: I love your braids

annotation.plain: As of 2018, Hip-hop rapper Missy Elliot has let her hair grow out to longer-length.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Is it worth it? Let me work it

annotation.plain:
The first line of the chorus sets the insecurities of a female artist in hip hop into full view. The hard work it takes to make a name for oneself, along with her divergent work ethic, one which doesn’t involve sexualizing herself for success. This angle may also alienate her from other female rappers, as well as the entire industry for breaking status quo.

She has taken a step back to reflect on this pressure, before reinforcing the fact that she has made it thus far.

annotations.lyric_fragment: When I come out, you won’t even matter (Ugh)

annotation.plain:
“Work It” dropped as a single a little over two months prior to the release of the full album, Under Construction. At the end of this blazing track, Missy puts her industry peers on notice; you ain’t hear nothing yet, this is merely an appetizer. Wait until the album drops.

One of the more effective examples of this particular type of lyrical boast can be found in Large Professor’s verse on A Tribe Called Quest’s “Keep It Rollin'.” He never got the opportunity to drop the album until 2009, however.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Picture Blacks saying, “Oh yes-a, massa”

annotation.plain:
Missy is saying that she has no plans to adopt a regressive ‘slave mentality’ and dilute her image/lyrics for the appeasement of the powers that might seek to hinder her.



The “NO!” that is heard in the background of the  track indicates that a black person who is willingly subservient to whites in this day and age is not cool with Missy.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Minute man, Big Red could outlast ya

annotation.plain: Missy is using Minute Man (service) and Big Red (short lasting-flavored chewing gum) as metaphors to what could “outlast” her opponents in the rap game.

annotations.lyric_fragment: This is a Missy Elliott one-time exclusive (C’mon)

annotation.plain: Missy wasn’t lying: the track reached the number two position on the U.S. Billboard Hot 100 on the issue dated November 16, 2002 for ten weeks, becoming Missy Elliott’s most successful single to date.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
To my ladies (Woo)
 You sure know how to work that

annotation.plain:
Timbaland ends the song with a different beat when Missy Elliott recites this line. It creates an evocative image of what the musical style throughout this song represents (particularly breaks and golden age hip-hop).

This sample is a portion of Bob James’s cover of “Take Me to the Mardi Gras”, which was popularized in the late 80s after Run-D.M.C. came out with “Peter Piper”.

annotation.plain: Aretha is playing with these lines from the original song: “Do me wrong, honey, if you wanna / You can do me wrong, honey, while I’m gone.”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Ooh, your kisses, sweeter than honey
 And guess what? So is my money

annotation.plain:
Aretha is riffing on these lines from the Otis original: “Hey, little girl, you’re so sweeter than honey / And I’m about to just give you all of my money.”

Basically, her financial independence is just as special as her partner’s affection.

annotations.lyric_fragment: (Just a little bit) You’re runnin’ out of fools

annotation.plain: This is a self-referential ad-lib calling back to Aretha’s hit song and album “Running Out of Fools” from three years before in 1964, as well as her same year’s hit “Chain of Fools,” both songs involving women who wise up in their dealings with emotionally manipulative men.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
What you want, baby, I got it
 What you need, do you know I got it?

annotation.plain:
In Otis' version, these lines were both “you got it” (not “I got it”). It’s a subtle difference, but while Otis is telling his wife to be satisfied with what she has, Aretha is complimenting herself.

Aretha talked about the line in a 2016 interview:

As women, we do have it. We have the power. We are very resourceful. Women absolutely deserve respect. I think women and children and older people are the three least-respected groups in our society."

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Written by Otis Redding]

annotation.plain: Aretha’s version is the one that blew up. I used to wonder about it, as a kid. My grandfather would say, “Oh, I feel like Otis right now, I just need respect.” All I could think about was my mom playing Aretha. I didn’t know what he was talking about. That wasn’t even a guy’s song! It wasn’t until I was nineteen that I figured out that it was Otis Redding’s song, that he wrote and recorded it first.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Is to give me my propers when you get home

annotation.plain:
“Propers” is a 60s term, now shortened to “Props”.

This line was added in the Franklin version, and not in the original Otis Redding  version.

annotations.lyric_fragment: R-E-S-P-E-C-T, take care of T-C-B

annotation.plain:
TCB is an acronym for “Take Care of Business”.

A common misheard lyric is “take out TCP”, which might confuse some as that would result in “RESE”.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Got me looking so crazy right now
 Your love’s got me looking so crazy right now (Your love)
 Got me looking so crazy right now
 Your touch got me looking so crazy right now (Your touch)

annotation.plain:
Falling in love tends to make people do all type of crazy things. However, the inspiration behind the chorus came up after Beyoncé looked at herself in the mirror in the studio and thought she was looking physically crazy:

We just couldn’t figure out what to write with it. I was looking crazy with my clothes. And I kept saying, “I’m looking crazy right now.” I wanted to go out and buy Kelly a birthday present but I didn’t want to leave the studio because I was scared that people were going to take pictures of me. Things weren’t matching, my hair wasn’t combed, just looking crazy! And he said, “That’s the hook!” And I’m like, “Yeah, right.” Then he starts singing, “I’m looking so crazy right now,” and I’m like, “That’s hot!”

— Beyoncé via The Guardian

annotations.lyric_fragment: History in the making

annotation.plain:
A prophetic statement from Jay. “Crazy In Love” was an instant success, topping the charts in America and England, winning two Grammy awards, and also being widely considered by critics to be the best song of 2003, the year it was released.

But not only that, in retrospect it has also garnered quite a legacy, with critics widely considering the song to be one of, if not the best song of the 2000s decade, while also being considered one of the greatest songs of all time. It’s safe to say “Crazy In Love” has cemented its place in the history books as one of the greatest moments music has ever seen.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Part two

annotation.plain:
“Part Two” refers to the fact this was Beyoncé and Jay-Z’s second collaboration. Part One came a year earlier when Beyoncé featured on Jay’s song “‘03 Bonnie & Clyde”.

  Beyoncé (left) and Jay-Z (right) in the “‘03 Bonnie & Clyde” music video.

However, this was far from the last Beyoncé and Jay-Z collaboration. 13 collaborative songs, 2018’s critically-acclaimed collaboration album EVERYTHING IS LOVE, three children, and a marriage later, it’s safe to say the pair are quite the duo.

annotation.plain:
The bridge from “Crazy In Love”, was written by Beyoncé. She and Rich Harrison, who is the main producer of the track, came up with the concept of the song from Bey looking at herself in the mirror and noticing her clothes were unmatched and her hair was untidy. She kept repeating “I’m looking so crazy right now” which gave an idea to Harrison:

Things weren’t matching, my hair wasn’t combed, just looking crazy! And he said, “That’s the hook!” And I’m like, “Yeah, right.” Then he starts singing, “I’m looking so crazy right now,” and I’m like, “That’s hot!”

They needed a simple but catchy hook and she had just the right one.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Intro: JAY-Z & Beyoncé]

annotation.plain:
Beyoncé kicked off her first solo album rollout with a sample of “Are You My Woman? (Tell Me So)” by the Chicago R&B quartet, The Chi-Lites. The song is part of their 1970 album I Like Your Lovin' (Do You Like Mine?).

The song was discovered and sampled by Rich Harrison, the producer behind “Crazy In Love”. Harrison shared that when he first played the song for his friends, they weren’t immediately convinced of the sound:

I remember when I first did the beat, I played it for a lot of my buddies, as I normally do, and they couldn’t dig it. But that’s when I knew I had something special. Sometimes people need to hear the whole record.

In that same interview with MTV, he admits that even Beyoncé had reservations about the song, since she believed it was “too retro” and that “no one used horn riffs, in the 21st century”.

From her face, she was kind of like, ‘I don’t know, but I'mma ride with you anyway’. I knew I was going to have to sell it a little bit, because when it comes on it doesn’t sound like anything that was being done at the time.

Anyway, Harrison managed to convince her that this was the right one, and the end result was a sample that went on to become one of the most iconic in pop music.

annotations.lyric_fragment: And the R-O-C, uh-oh (Oh, no)

annotation.plain: R-O-C refers to Jay’s now defunct record label, Roc-A-Fella Records, which he founded in 1995 along with Damon “Dame” Dash, and Kareem “Biggs” Burke.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Got me hoping you’ll page me right now

annotation.plain:
A pager (also known as “beeper”) is a wireless device used for communication, with which you could only send or receive a short text or audio message. It was very popular in the ‘80s but lost its space for the cellphones in the '90s and practically disappeared in the 21st century.



It’s interesting that Beyoncé hoped to receive a pager message when almost no one used pagers in 2003. Maybe that’s the crazy thing she hoped the boy did for her.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Young Hov, y’all know when the flow is loco (No, no)
 Young B

annotation.plain:
Jay-Z starts his rap with one of his nicknames (Young Hov). Hov is short for J-Hova, a name Jay-Z gave himself in reference to the God Jehovah, making him the god of rap. According to this article explaining Jay-Z’s different nicknames according to this age, the first time he called himself J-Hova he was 30. This shows he considers himself young in his thirties, which he also demonstrates in 30 Something by saying “30 is the new 20”.

He then refers to Beyonce as “Young B”, effectively using his own nickname style to name her.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I shake phonies, man, you can’t get next to

annotation.plain:
The word “phony” in popular culture is often a reference to J.D. Salinger’s novel The Catcher in the Rye.

An example of Holden Caulfield calling out phonies:

You never saw so many phonies in all your life, everybody smoking their ears off and talking about the play so that everybody could hear and know how sharp they were.”

In Jay-Z’s book “Decoded” he explains how he liked Catcher in the Rye in high school:

I loved Catcher In The Rye in high school—I always related to young Holden Caulfield, especially his curiosity about where the ducks in Central Park go during the winter. I still don’t know, but The Black Album was such a big 4th quarter release, I felt like people should tell the ducks about it before they skated off for the season. I move birds like an Oriole fitted, son.

In this quote, when he says “people should tell the ducks”, he refers to this line in “Change Clothes”:

Then run and tell them ducks you heard Hovi new shit"

annotations.lyric_fragment:
It’s only me who wants to
 Wrap around your dreams

annotation.plain:
She is stating that it is only her that really wants to get in his mind, because deep down she wants their relationship to last.

Stevie named the song “Dreams”.

Songwriters often name a song after a line (or two) that is particularly significant or poignant to the meaning of the song. This line is the key to interpreting the metaphor and her state of mind when writing the song. Specifically, she identifies herself as the only one who wants to wrap around (or share) Lindsay’s dreams as opposed to other potential suitors who are likely to be chasing him owing to his fame and current popularity.  Her love for him is based on something deeper than his stage persona.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Like a heartbeat drives you mad (Heartbeat)
 In the stillness of rememberin’ (Stillness)

annotation.plain:
Loneliness strikes you in a heartbeat. In a heartbeat you can realizes how lonely you feel, it can make you sad, sometimes it can drive you mad, and being lonely will force you to reminisce those times you weren’t, and how happy you were with you lost love.

His dreams become maddening  nightmares of loneliness, which is ironic because this only happens when the storm subsides “in the stillness of remembering.”

annotations.lyric_fragment: I keep my visions to myself

annotation.plain: She doesn’t tell him that she can imagine a life with him because she knows that he will not listen, nor will he change his ways.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Players only love you when they’re playing

annotation.plain:
There is a double entendre in this line. At first one’s mind thinks of a “player” in its slang meaning (a man who has relations with multiple women), which works with this line. The second meaning is the more literal meaning of the word as in a “player” of an instrument, or a musician. This connotation particularly makes sense in this line considering the profession of the person this song was written for (Lindsey Buckingham the guitarist). With the latter meaning it can be assumed that Stevie felt that Lindsey only “loved” her on stage and on tour but that outside of the realm of music he felt nothing for her.

Actors are also referred to as players. And they love you when they are “on”. Seems to resonate with the public persona vs private, or perhaps speaks to acting the women in the next line might do to get next to a famous musician.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
In the stillness of rememberin’ (Stillness)
 What you had and what you lost (Lonely, ooh)
 And what you had and what you lost (Ooh, ooh)

annotation.plain: When all the dust has settled and you’re sitting all alone, your lonely heartbeat will constantly drive you crazy, reminding you of the person you had and how you let them go. The repetition of the last phrase emphasizes the the loss that you will feel.

annotations.lyric_fragment: And have you any dreams you’d like to sell?

annotation.plain:
Selling Dreams is basically lying – deceiving intentionally. In real life it’s lottery, fortune tellers, love potions and other snake charming methods.

She uses the verb in relations to his (possible) dreams. He doubts that he has any, and if he does say he has – is he telling the truth?



This appears to be biting sarcasm.  Stevie is bitter that he is forgoing the long-term potential of their relationship built on a lifetime of dreams for more recent opportunities afforded by their commercial success.  In many ways, it is the biggest insult to a true artist to suggest their dreams are for sale. She is implying that he will indulge in the temporary perks of fame (like the adulation of other women) and abandon (sell) the dreams they had together.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
What you had and what you lost (Lonely, ooh)
 Oh, what you had, oh, what you lost (Ooh, ah)

annotation.plain: The repetitiveness emphasizes the enormity of the step and its effect – loneliness, obviously, and it is also a warning massage of a recurring cyclical process.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Dreams of loneliness

annotation.plain:
Wearing the heart on a sleeve was not exclusive for Nicks; in the same album, Lindsey Buckingham addressed the loneliness from his side in Go Your Own Way, directed to Stevie –

You can go your own way (go your own way)
You can call it another lonely day

annotations.lyric_fragment:
It’s only right that you should
 Play the way you feel it
 But listen carefully to the sound
 Of your loneliness

annotation.plain:
Stevie Nicks is likely speaking to guitarist Lindsey Buckingham upon their previous relationship. She is telling him to play the song as a metaphor for their relationship, cautioning him to listen to his lonely heart when he leaves her. At the end of each phrase, we hear the (almost weeping) response of Lindsey’s guitar.

In the live version she adds “You know what you lost”, further articulating her message to Lindsey. He may never find another woman like her.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Now, here I go again
 I see the crystal visions

annotation.plain:
Stevie Nicks’s' lyrics switch to first person to assure us that it is not an “all your fault” type message.

“Crystal Gazing” – “a form of divination” –  via a crystal ball – an allusion to magic, attempts at foresight, that can also be reached when in trance – either through meditation, or chemical “tripping”.

Later (2007), “Crystal Visions” became the name of Stevie Nicks’s “Best of…” album.

annotations.lyric_fragment: As we danced in the night, remember

annotation.plain:
The theme of memory, prevalent in this song, is reminiscent of the poem “September” by Helen Hunt Jackson, an American poet of the 19th century. Published in 1892 in Poems, she writes in the final lines:


But none of all this beauty
Which floods the earth and air
Is unto me the secret
 Which makes September fair.

’T is a thing which I remember;
To name it thrills me yet:
One day of one September
 I never can forget.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Hey, hey, hey
 Ba-dee-ya
 Say, do you remember?
 Ba-dee-ya
 Dancin’ in September
 Ba-dee-ya
 Never was a cloudy day

annotation.plain:
In an interview with SongFacts, Allee Willis (one of the songwriters of “September”) gave a personal story about how she initially didn’t like this three-syllable series of classic phonetic compilation:

I absolutely could not deal with lyrics that were nonsensical, or lines that weren’t complete sentences. And I’m exceedingly happy that I lost that attitude. I went, “You cannot leave bada-ya in the chorus, that has to mean something.” [Maurice White] said, “No, that feels great. That’s what people are going to remember. We’re leaving it.” We did try other stuff, and it always sounded clunky – thank God.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Do you remember
 The twenty-first night of September?

annotation.plain:
The fall equinox typically falls on the 22nd or 23rd of September, so the evening of the 21st is right at the end of summer.

However, songwriter Allee Willis says the seasons have little to do with the date of choice here:


We went through all the dates: ‘Do you remember the first, the second, the third, the fourth … ’ and the one that just felt the best was the 21st. I constantly have people coming up to me and they get so excited to know what the significance was. And there is no significance beyond it just sang better than any of the other dates.

I learned my greatest lesson in songwriting: Never let the lyric get in the way of the groove. So … sorry!

These lyrics are sampled from the first sung couplet on Tom Tom Club’s hit “Genius of Love”, which is also sampled for the instrumental and interpolated in other vocal parts in the remix to this song. The lyrics are a combination of the first three and last lines of the couplet as shown below.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Now, we gon’ break this thing down in just a few seconds
 Now, don’t have me break this thing down for nothing
 Now, I want to see y’all on your baddest behavior

annotation.plain: “Break down” is a double entendre here, as Andre is both talking about the breakdown of the song, and saying he wants people to furiously dance to it, in a sexy and suggestive manner, and also talking about going through a relationship breakdown, breaking up with the person and therefore wanting to be on one’s “baddest behavior”, to have all those sexual experiences a monogamous relationship renders impossible.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
All right, all right, all right, all right, all right, all right, all right, all right
 All right, all right, all right, all right, all right, all right

annotation.plain:
This is a reference to the intro of “Gasoline Dreams"–the second track of Outkast’s previous album Stankonia, where Andre repeats in the intro,

Alright, alright, alright, alright
Alright, alright, alright, alright
Alright, alright, alright, alright

This part of this song has become subject to meme culture over the years, usually used to describe what it’s like to have a dragged out conversation with a parent on the phone.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
My baby don’t mess around
 Because she loves me so, and this I know for sure (Uh)
 But does she really wanna
 But can’t stand to see me walk out the door? (Ah)

annotation.plain: Andre starts off this track with an affirmation of his relationship but then shows the true nature of this track by stating that he’s worried his girlfriend/wife might only be faithful because she’s afraid of being alone rather than actual feelings of attraction or love. This is echoed in the line about mom and dad sticking together, and the insecurity in modern relationships.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
So why oh, why oh, why oh, why oh, why oh
 Are we so in denial when we know we’re not happy here?

annotation.plain:
Andre is wondering if his he and his partner are ignoring their real feelings simply out of fear of being alone to the point where they are sacrificing their own happiness and making their lives worse. This can happen a lot when couples do things like “stay together for the kids” or move in with each other and getting married simply because they’ve been dating for long enough. Things like this often end up making both people unhappier than if they just broke up, because they are now involved in a relationship based off of obligation instead of actual feelings.
The beat cuts off after this line, leading us to believe that the relationship may actually be over for a brief second, but the denial in the relationship continues on the form of a second chorus.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
If what they say is, “Nothing is forever”
 Then what makes, then what makes, then what makes
 Then what makes, what makes, what makes love the exception?

annotation.plain: A lot of people subscribe to the idea that love is something that is everlasting, especially when it comes to things like marriage. André here desperately wants someone to explain to him how this can be true when people will also say “nothing is forever” especially in times of prosperity to keep people from being stupid with things like money, friendships, or even relationships.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Don’t want to meet your daddy
 Hey ya! (Uh-oh)
 Just want you in my Caddy (Uh-oh)
 Hey ya! (Uh-oh)
 Don’t want to meet your mama (Uh-oh)
 Hey ya! (Uh-oh)
 Just want to make you cum-a’ (Uh-oh)
 Hey ya! (Uh-oh)
 I’m, I’m, I’m just being honest (Uh-oh)
 Hey ya!
 I’m just being honest

annotation.plain: André is being very upfront about what he wants with this girl–he’s not working for a serious relationship, meeting parents, etc. All he wants is a shawty he can have sex with and spend some casual time with.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Lend me some sugar, I am your neighbor

annotation.plain:
André 3000 references the practice, rarely done anymore, of asking your neighbor for a cup of sugar.  It would occur when someone was cooking or baking food, and they were out of sugar, but it also extends to other ingredients such as salt.

This stopped being a concept because most people have become isolationist regarding talking to those that live in their neighborhood. Another reason is technology has allowed supermarkets to flourish and thus people only need to drive there to get all their goods.

This is, of course, simply a metaphor though – “sugar” is slang for lovin'.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Y’all don’t wanna hear me, you just wanna dance

annotation.plain:
This line ended up being pretty accurate–as many people see this song as a happy dance number and have used it to express eternal love when the actual lyrics express someone who is very uncertain about love and relationships.

Although the happy tone in Andre’s voice and poppy beat make this a very danceable song; this line is even buried in the mix of the song making it hard to hear over the chorus, adding to the effect of ignoring the true nature of this song.

The message is similar to people saying they don’t want to hear lyrical rap songs in the club, especially if they’re not dance-friendly since most people aren’t looking to engage in deep thinking on the dance floor.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Thank God for Mom and Dad
 For sticking two together ’cause we don’t know how (C’mon)

annotation.plain:
André 3000 said the following about the overall theme of the song, which relates to these lines:

‘Hey Ya!’ is pretty much about the state of relationships in the 2000s. It’s about some people who stay together in relationships because of tradition, because somebody told them, ‘You guys are supposed to stay together.’ But you pretty much end up being unhappy for the rest of your life.

He’s not talking about his own parents but speaking universally, as many in the older generation born around the early 1900s traditionally were known to get married young and stay married for decades despite rising divorce rates, while many millennials aren’t getting married at all. André is thanking his forebears for showing him that a successful long-term relationship can work and providing the knowledge on how to make it work.

In a 2013 interview with The Huffington Post, André 3000 revealed that “Thank God for Mom and Dad” was a possible early title for what became “Hey Ya!”:

The song went through several working titles, that was one of them. That song was actually the oldest one on the album because I had started writing it during the Stankonia tour.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Okay now, ladies (Yeah?)

annotation.plain: Fun Fact: The voice of the “ladies” is just one lady, Rabeka Tuinei, who was an assistant to the audio engineer of the song.

annotation.plain:
She’s addicted to her lover, and he’s the only reason she’s alive.

In 2003, 5 years after “…Baby One More Time,” Britney released a song called “Breathe on Me,” where breathing has less to do with survival and more to do with sex.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Give me a sign
 Hit me, baby, one more time

annotation.plain:
The line, “Hit me baby one more time” caused a little bit of controversy, particularly in the United States.

In an interview with Rolling Stone in 1999, Britney clarifies:

It doesn’t mean physically hit me. It means just give me a sign, basically. I think it’s kind of funny that people would actually think that’s what it meant.

Additionally, in a 2015 article, it was revealed that Max Martin and Rami Yacoub (both Swedish) thought that “hit” was slang for call.

annotations.lyric_fragment: My love will be your food

annotation.plain: The connection between food and sex is eternal, both sensually stimulating, both contemplating a devouring, both satisfying needs.  He hurtles right past a comparison and offers his partner a serving of love a la Prince.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Women, not girls, rule my world, I said they rule my world

annotation.plain: Prince likes mature women who act like adults, rather than people who act like little girls and don’t act their age.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You got to not talk dirty, baby, if you wanna impress me
 You can’t be too flirty, mama, I know how to undress me

annotation.plain: Prince isn’t into the typical conventions of romance and sex. Instead of talking up a storm about what they can and will do in bed, he wants to break away from the usual and have an unconventional experience that suits his needs.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Act your age, mama, not your shoe size, maybe we could do the twirl

annotation.plain: An old saying, basically stating that he wants her to act more mature, and not her shoe size. Shoe sizes are usually a lot smaller than the persons age, essentially shes acting like a kid. The twirl is slang for giving a blow job, usually from a prostitute. Although in this scenario, it’s from the woman Prince is with.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I just need your body, baby, from dusk ’til dawn

annotation.plain: Prince simply wants the woman’s body for as long as possible.  It’s not about her beauty, which is an inherent characteristic that she can’t change.  It’s about her stamina and willingness – can she keep up with Prince all night long?

annotations.lyric_fragment: I want to be your fantasy, maybe you could be mine

annotation.plain: These lines were famously sung years later during the bathtub scene of the 1990 film Pretty Woman.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Ain’t no particular sign I’m more compatible with
 I just want your extra time and your kiss

annotation.plain: Prince is basically saying that the Zodiac signs, such as Cancer, Gemini, etc., don’t matter to him because all he wants is this particular girl by his side.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Yes, oh, I think I wanna dance, uh

annotation.plain: The indication for the start of the bridge and guitar solo, and Prince’s subsequent dance moves.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Little Girl Wendy’s Parade

annotation.plain: “Little Girl Wendy’s Parade” was the early version of the song “Christopher Tracy’s Parade,” also from the album Parade. This “little girl Wendy” is of course Wendy Melvoin, the guitarist for Prince’s band at the time, the Revolution (while Christopher Tracy is the name of the character Prince plays in the 1986 film Under the Cherry Moon, to which Parade served as the soundtrack).

annotations.lyric_fragment: You don’t have to watch “Dynasty” to have an attitude

annotation.plain:
A popular soap opera from the 80s that aired on ABC. The women on the show were catty, bitchy, and full of attitude.



Since Dynasty was cancelled in 1989, Prince continually updated the reference when he played “Kiss” in concert, replacing the dated reference with a more contemporary one. (He used both Sex and the City and Real Housewives, for example.)

annotations.lyric_fragment:

 You’ll let me be your man
 And please, say to me
 You’ll let me hold your hand

annotation.plain: At times John Lennon realized that the crowds the Beatles played to were so loud that they really couldn’t hear them sing, so sometimes instead of saying “I want to hold your hand,” John would say, “I want to hold your gland” as a reference to women’s breasts.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And when I touch you
 I feel happy inside
 It’s such a feeling that, my love
 I can’t hide
 I can’t hide
 I can’t hide

annotation.plain:
Perhaps we can thank these lyrics for the Beatles' introduction to cannabis (and their ensuing drug-inspired music!).

None other than Bob Dylan – and arguably his mishearing of this lyric – was responsible:

Hanging with the Beatles at the Hotel Delmonico in NYC (now a condo building owned by Donald Trump) on 28 August 1964, Dylan suggested the group smoke some pot.


Brian [Epstein] and the Beatles looked at each other apprehensively. “We’ve never smoked marijuana before,” Brian finally admitted.

Dylan looked disbelievingly from face to face. “But what about your song?” he asked. “The one about getting high?”

The Beatles were stupefied. “Which song?” John managed to ask.

Dylan said, “You know…” and then he sang, “and when I touch you I get high, I get high…”

John flushed with embarrassment. “Those aren’t the words,” he admitted. “The words are, ‘I can’t hide, I can’t hide, I can’t hide…’”


And the rest is history…

annotations.lyric_fragment: Let me serenade the streets of L.A

annotation.plain:
A serenade is a “musical composition or performance delivered in honor of someone or something”. The word comes from Italian “sera "evening,” from Latin sera, fem. of serus “late.” (Wikipedia)
Often serenades are of romantic nature.

So here Pac continues the romantic  theme from “Bumping and Grinding like a slow jam”, but also depicts the streets of L.A. at night as his love interest

annotations.lyric_fragment: Bumpin’ and grindin’ like a slow jam

annotation.plain:
A possible reference to R Kelly’s 1994 hit Bump n' Grind

Bumping and Grinding is a type of dance frequently seen in night clubs, where (typically) men and women grind their hips and private parts against one another. Usually the woman is standing with her back to the man, so she can grind on him with her behind. See the picture.

Bumping and grinding can be done to various types of music, to different emotional effects. Bumping and grinding to slow jam music would usually be very sensual, like R Kelly’s Bump N Grind suggests.

Slow Jams are usually slow RnB or Soul songs, often focused on love making.

Examples:

Bump n' Grind by R Kelly
Let’s Get It On by Marvin Gaye
Sexual Healing by Marvin Gaye
The Lady In My Life by Michael Jackson
If Ever You’re In My Arms Again by Peabo Bryson

So Pac might be saying that he is getting it on with ladies. Pac was indeed known as a ladies man.

Examples:
Madonna
Heather Hunter
Nina Hartley
Many more rumoured such as Whitney Houston

annotations.lyric_fragment: It’s all good, from Diego to the Bay

annotation.plain:
While San Diego is the largest city in southern California, close to Mexico, the Bay Area is rather located in the north. Despite it is not too near to the border of Oregon, it is the greatest northern metropolitan region. In particular, the Bay Area describes the region around the San Francisco and San Pablo Bay, to name a few examples. It includes cities such as Oakland, Vallejo, the capital Sacramento and of course San Francisco.

The Bay Area is known as the home of famous rappers such as The Click, i.e., E-40, B-Legit, D-Shot, Suga T. Other notable representatives are Too $hort, Spice 1, C-Bo and Richie Rich. 2Pac had many guest appearances on their albums, whence it is not surprising that there is also a collabo track on All Eyez On Me, which is “Ain’t Hard 2 Find”.



Check out this rare photo of 2Pac with a fan in front and, from left to right, E-40, C-Bo, B-Legit and D-Shot in the back.

annotations.lyric_fragment: The track hits your eardrum like a slug to your chest

annotation.plain:
A slug, in this context, is a punch. So, Dre essentially says here that this shit is pretty hard-hitting.

Slugs are also a type of shotgun shell that is built to give maximum damage, like this song.

annotations.lyric_fragment: We in that sunshine state where the bomb-ass hemp be

annotation.plain:
Officially, the Sunshine State is Florida’s nickname, whereas California’s is The Golden State.

Despite Dre’s misnomer, California as a state gets the most daily sunshine in the country as measured by the average kilojoules of solar radiation per square meter.



California, of course, is a major marijuana hub. In 2017, the state produced 13.5 million pounds of cannabis (including hemp) — and consumed over 2.5 million pounds of that good ol' Chronic.

annotations.lyric_fragment: In L.A. we wearin’ Chucks, not Ballys (Yeah, that’s right)

annotation.plain:
Chucks is slang for Chuck Taylor otherwise known as Converse, which is a shoe company owned by Nike. Ballys are a higher end shoe company with some shoe prices going over $1,000. Pac still rocks Converse even though they’re cheaper.

Converse:



Bally:

annotations.lyric_fragment: Sacramento, Sacramento where you at?

annotation.plain: Despite being California’s capital, Sacramento doesn’t get as much attention as some of California’s other cities and has a lower population compared to San Francisco and L.A. but for the love of the Golden State, Dre gives its capitol a shout out to make sure they’re celebrated as well.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Verse 2: 2Pac & Dr. Dre]

annotation.plain:
This was originally supposed to be a Dr. Dre song.

Dr. Dre had recorded the entire song with three verses by himself at first. 2Pac heard it over at Dre’s house one day and Dr. Dre let him get a guest verse on it.

Even though it was Dr. Dre’s song, Suge Knight wanted to sell it as a 2Pac song for increased marketability.



Dre, fed up with Death Row’s questionable business practices, immediately left the label after filming the music video.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Even Hollywood tryin’ to get a piece, baby

annotation.plain: Hollywood is in California.  It has a glitzy reputation because of the movie & TV business, but most celebrities don’t live in the actual neighborhood of Hollywood.  Hollywood itself is actually a very poor working-class neighborhood that used to be heavily Black, and is now heavily Latino.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I took no time with the fall

annotation.plain: This means that she fell in love immediately, referencing love at first sight.

annotations.lyric_fragment: It’s hard to look right at you, baby

annotation.plain:
Every time Carly sings this line, she takes a short pause after singing:

It’s so hard to look right

At this point, most first-time listeners understand this as falling in line with the trope of a girl trying to look pretty so she can catch a guy’s attention and attraction. The male gaze is pervasive in our culture, so we have all seen countless examples of this in popular media.

However, within seconds, Carly subverts the expectation:

at you, baby

It is she who is gazing at him. The fact that it’s so hard for Carly to look at him underscores the fact that she is not used to being on this side of the story; she’s self-conscious of the fact that she’s staring at and objectifying him. This is also part of the reason why giving out her phone number feels so crazy to her—she is used to the guy doing the chasing.

And all the other boys try to chase me
But here’s my number, so call me, maybe

annotations.lyric_fragment: At first sight, and it’s real

annotation.plain:
This is an allusion to the concept of “love at first sight”—a romantic notion that is at the heart of this song. Asking someone who “just met you” out on a date seems “crazy” because this kind of love is purely emotional rather than rational. In a vertified annotation to her track “Party for One”, Carly elaborated:

I do think of love in this very fantastical kind of child-like way. I think like the epitome of new love is something that I focused a lot on in my last album even if it was just sort of what it is to have butterflies, what it is to feel nervousness. But I think- I think that that’s sort of is shortsighted for what real, real love comes down to. And I’m learning that more and more, and exploring that more with this next album. But, I will say that at the beginning of anything I’m always still truly, unfortunately addicted to that first rush.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Verse 1]

annotation.plain:
Carly Rae Jepsen has described the understanding of love she had when she wrote “Call Me Maybe” as “child-like.” The song’s chorus epitomizes the “first rush” that Carly believes she is still “addicted to.”  In a vertified annotation to her track “Party for One”, she elaborated:

I do think of love in this very fantastical kind of child-like way. I think like the epitome of new love is something that I focused a lot on in my last album even if it was just sort of what it is to have butterflies, what it is to feel nervousness. But I think- I think that that’s sort of is shortsighted for what real, real love comes down to. And I’m learning that more and more, and exploring that more with this next album. But, I will say that at the beginning of anything I’m always still truly, unfortunately addicted to that first rush.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Your stare was holdin’

annotation.plain: Carly is describing a moment of intense eye contact between her and someone she is attracted to. The present participle “holdin'” emphasizes the continuous and captivating nature of the gaze. The lyric reflects the sudden and intense feelings of infatuation that can occur in a fleeting moment of connection.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Hey, I just met you, and this is crazy
 But here’s my number, so call me maybe
 It’s hard to look right at you, baby
 But here’s my number, so call me maybe
 Hey, I just met you, and this is crazy
 But here’s my number, so call me maybe
 And all the other boys try to chase me
 But here’s my number, so call me maybe

annotation.plain:
At first glance, the narrator’s actions seems reckless and wild. The act of giving someone your number is basically asking the other one out. Carly Rae Jepsen later remarks on this line during an interview with THR:

I think it’s just my type of, the way I would talk about it. I’m not overly confident in love. I’d probably be more coy about it, I guess, just like, ‘call me, maybe? If you want to?'

Additionally, this chorus was deemed the most famous chorus of the 21st century by Billboard.

Interestingly, according to Jepsen, these lines were almost not written into the chorus:

We had a verse, we had a completely different chorus, and I thought that what I was singing at the time – ‘Hey, I just met you, and this is crazy’ – was just, like, filler lyrics. I mentioned to [co-writer] Tavish [Crowe] that we would fix them later, and he said, ‘No, I think they’re kind of quirky and light-hearted and fun. I think we should keep those.'

According to Jepsen, the next day the two took the song to Josh Ramsay, the leader of Marianas Trench, who suggested that they turn the song’s pre-chorus into its proper chorus. Ramsay later ended up producing the song that made Jepsen famous.
