annotations.lyric_fragment: She told my baby we’d danced ’til three, then she looked at me

annotation.plain: M.J recalls ‘Billie Jean’ telling his current girl that they had been up late dancing, which could either be a literal tale or a metaphor for having sex until the early hours. Either way Billie Jean is painting an image for Jackson’s  girl, seemingly to tarnish their relationship.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Then showed a photo of a baby cryin’, his eyes were like mine (Oh, no)

annotation.plain: The “oh no” signifies MJ’s horror at the similarity between their eyes, as it lends credence to Billie Jean’s claim that he fathered her baby.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Billie Jean is not my lover, uh
 She’s just a girl who claims that I am the one (Oh, baby)
 But the kid is not my son (Hoo)
 She says I am the one (Oh, baby)
 But the kid is not my son (Hee-hee-hee, no-no, hee-hee-hee, hoo)

annotation.plain:
The general theme the chorus revolves around the idea of “groupies,” or crazed fans. MJ and the Jackson 5 encountered many of these throughout their career. In a 1996 interview in Thailand, MJ said:

They would hang around backstage doors, and any band that would come to town they would have a relationship with, and I think I wrote this out of experience with my brothers when I was little. There were a lot of Billie Jeans out there. Every girl claimed that their son was related to one of my brothers.

J. Randy Taraborrelli, the author of MJ’s biography The Magic & The Madness, wrote that the Billie Jean character was derived from a young woman who alleged MJ was the father of her child. While this is possible, MJ shrugged the claim in his autobiography Moonwalk:

There never was a real Billie Jean. The girl in the song is a composite of people my brothers have been plagued with over the years. I could never understand how these girls could say they were carrying someone’s child when it wasn’t true.

As a single that sold exceptionally well upon release, on the best selling album of all time, this is one of the most famous choruses in existence.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Verse 1]

annotation.plain:
The song has an atypically long intro, something the song’s producer Quincy Jones explained in an interview, saying:

The intro was so long you could shave during it. I said we had to get to the melody sooner, but Michael said that was what made him want to dance, it was the song’s ‘jelly’. And when Michael Jackson says something makes him want to dance, you don’t argue, so he won.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Who will dance on the floor in the round

annotation.plain: In this repetition of the line, Michael realizes that everyone is watching him and has accepted him as ‘the one'—the lucky guy Billie Jean chooses to groove with.

annotations.lyric_fragment: For forty days and for forty nights,

But she came and stood right by me
 Just the smell of sweet perfume (Ha-oh)
 This happened much too soon (Ha-oh, ha-ooh)
 She called me to her room (Ha-oh, hoo), hey-ey

annotation.plain:
The ironic implication is that Michael ends up getting seduced by Billie Jean, despite the situation. This is a sort of “surprise ending”. One would likely predict an ending with Michael pleading with his girl (“my baby”) to believe him, or something similar.

However, this ironic ending makes the story that much more interesting–although not less tragic, as expressed by Michael’s repetition of the lamenting chorus.

However, it may not necessarily be an ending. It could be a flashback to the night they “danced”… after all, the baby looks an awful lot like him.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
The law was on her side
 But who can stand when she’s in demand?

annotation.plain: Billie Jean went to the courts and tried to get money from MJ, appearing as the one who was correct. MJ learns here that his mother was right: “… the lie becomes the truth.”

annotations.lyric_fragment: ’Cause we danced on the floor in the round, baby (Ooh, hee-hee-hee)

annotation.plain:
The line could either be literal or a metaphor.

Literally, the dancing was the cause that lead into the action (sex) that ended with the consequence (Baby)

Metaphorically, “We danced on the floor” is in itself the action, a euphemism/metaphor for having sex.

annotations.lyric_fragment:

 Just remember to always think twice
 (Don’t think twice) Do think twice! (A-hoo!)

annotation.plain:
Take his strong advice and think clearly before you get involved with someone.

This is also a case of the ‘devil versus angel’ trying to give someone advice. The “don’t think twice” echo obviously represents the devil/bad choice and the “do think twice” is the advice MJ chooses to take from the angel.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I close my eyes
 Heaven, help me

annotation.plain: The end of the first verse continues the dual-level lyrics maintained throughout the song.  For a religious prayer, this couplet literally describes the song’s title: people traditionally close their eyes when praying, and ask for help from Heaven above.  As a sexual connotation, she’s going to give in to ecstasy and asks here for forgiveness instead of rescue.  Depictions of ecstasy often straddle the line between religious fervor and sexual fervor, a line Madonna is happy to blur.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I have no choice
 I hear your voice
 Feels like flying

annotation.plain:
This is about being drawn to someone, and not being willing to stop the encounter with them rather than not being able to.

A callback to the angelic voice, and the euphoria of flying confounds religious fervor and sex.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Now I’m dancing

annotation.plain: Dancing is an oft-used biblical metaphor for joy and for worship.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You’re here with me

annotation.plain: Given that the second verse is explicitly about “the child,” it’s possible that the speaker is referencing here the idea of “God With Us,” the English translation of “Emmanuel,” another common appellation for Christ–the person of God who has most literally been “with us.”

annotations.lyric_fragment: No end and no beginning

annotation.plain: Here the speaker references God’s existence outside of time: a being with no end and no beginning, the Alpha (beginning) and the Omega (ending).

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Like a child
 You whisper softly to me
 You’re in control
 Just like a child

annotation.plain: In Christianity, God believes that children are pure, innocent and that God favors them. This could be Madonna’s way of interpreting that God is “like a child”.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I close my eyes
 Oh God, I think I’m falling
 Out of the sky

annotation.plain: Sexual pleasure has long been described in terms of floating, flight, or falling…but in the context of spirituality, there is the unspoken notion of “a fall from grace.” Man was considered to have “fallen” after original sin (often associate with sex or loss of innocence) as well as the “fallen angel” Lucifer, who fell from the kingdom of God. Sex is associated with a spiritual connection, but also seemingly contradicts religious tenets that reserve such spiritual expressions for the divine. Is it possible that the two expressions, worship and sexuality, are one and the same?

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Just like a muse to me
 You are a mystery
 Just like a dream
 You are not what you seem

annotation.plain:
The Muses were the inspirational goddesses of literature, science, and the arts in Greek mythology. They were considered the source of the knowledge embodied in the poetry, lyric songs, and myths that were related orally for centuries in these ancient cultures.



In current English usage, “muse” can refer in general to a person who inspires an artist, musician, or writer.

She suggests the subject is a mysterious guy and that that is what she finds most attractive to him. As she gets to know him better and learn more things about him she realizes he isn’t what he looks.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Intro]

annotation.plain:
The distorted guitar which opens the track is from a longer (unused) guitar solo by Prince.

Producer Patrick Leonard recalls:

What happened is, [Madonna] sent him something to play on and he played on it and sent it back. And we didn’t feel that what he did served it. But that piece, that beginning, is him.

More of that unused guitar work appears in the extended remixes found on the “Like a Prayer” single.

Prince appears later on the album, most prominently on the duet “Love Song” (which he co-wrote and co-produced) and he provides more uncredited guitar work on “Keep It Together” and “Act of Contrition.”

annotations.lyric_fragment: Let the choir sing

annotation.plain: The choir in question was assembled and conducted by the estimable Andrae Crouch. He arranged and recorded the choir parts away from Madonna and Patrick Leonard; when they received the choir tapes, they pulled back the song’s latin elements (mainly bongos and other latin percussion) to more smoothly integrate and spotlight the vocals.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’ve got sunshine on a cloudy day
 When it’s cold outside, I’ve got the month of May

annotation.plain:
Ruffin is experiencing a sunny day, even though there’s nothing but clouds in the sky.



In May, the weather starts to get warmer. Despite it being cold outside, he’s feeling warm.

In other words, he’s expressing how it feels to be in love – he’s happy and has a warm feeling inside.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I’ve got all the riches, baby, one man can claim

annotation.plain: Ruffin doesn’t need money, fortune, or fame to be rich because his girl is worth more than that and she’s all he needs.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Outro]

annotation.plain: The ad-libbed vocal outro, restating some of the song’s prior lyrics, was yet another Motown staple

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Verse 3]

annotation.plain: Going into this verse, the song changes key, rising from C to D

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Verse 1]

annotation.plain:
This was the first Tempts song to feature David Ruffin singing lead, something that was actually Smokey’s idea:


 Eddie Kendricks sang lead on a number of the group’s early hits. But Smokey Robinson sensed that if he wrote a song, the right song, for heartthrob David Ruffin, he’d be launching a new star.

 “David Ruffin, I knew, was like this sleeping giant in this group because he had this—it’s sort of like a mellow gruff-sounding voice. And all I needed was the right song for his voice and I felt like I would have a smash hit record. So I sat down at the piano to write a song for David Ruffin’s voice. So I wanted to make it something that he could belt out, but yet make it melodic and sweet.”

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Instrumental Intro]

annotation.plain:
Motown was famous for their instrumental introductions to songs.  Even given that, this combo of bass, guitar, and fingersnaps is a star amongst stars

The 2002 film Standing in the Shadows of Motown had a heartbreaking scene where guitarist Robert White talked about hearing “My Girl” in a restaurant and wanting to be able to say, “I wrote that,” but realizing that the anonymity of Motown’s amazing house band, The Funk Brothers ensured that no one would believe him.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You can dance, you can jive
 Having the time of your life
 Ooh, see that girl, watch that scene
 Digging the dancing queen

annotation.plain:
To “jive” means to dance lively, characterized by high amounts of energetic and exaggerated movements, specifically swinging and spinning.



You can dance simply to music, immerse yourself in it and allow your body move freely to the rhythm, or you could sit back and simply “dig the dancing queen”.

At a disco party, you can do anything you want and enjoy yourself in any way you choose.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You are the dancing queen
 Young and sweet, only seventeen
 Dancing queen

annotation.plain:
The song centers around a teenage girl, presumably 17 years old, heading out to a disco party on Friday night.

The “dramatic chorus that ascends to heart-tugging high notes” display her ongoing search for a partner, both for dancing and potentially more.

She’s the “dancing queen”, displaying a sense of liberation and excitement while on the dance floor.

Although other theories and interpretations of the suggest a deeper, possibly even darker message. ABBA’s intention was reportedly much simpler, aiming to “simply [be] an account of a night out”.

The protagonist is in search of a man—a “king” that will help her enjoy her night even more.

There are so many guys at the party, that any of them could be the one, she simply has to keep searching.

annotation.plain: Music has always been a powerful coping/escape mechanism for people. It allows us to escape the problems and stresses of everyday life and to enjoy ourselves and truly unwind. Even if it’s just for one night.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Verse 2]

annotation.plain:
Similar to “I Do, I Do, I Do, I Do, I Do” from their previous album, “Dancing Queen” originally had more lyrics during the demoing process. The following lines can be heard in a recording session and would have ultimately made the second verse equal in length to the first:

Baby, baby, you’re out of sight
Hey, you’re looking alright tonight
When you come to the party, listen to the guys
They’ve got the look in their eyes

While these lines don’t appear in the English recording, the Spanish rerecording includes this lengthening of the verse, though the words are not a translation of the above.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Night is young and the music’s high

annotation.plain: Many fans misinterpret this lyric, thinking it’s about music making you high—but in ABBA’s native Sweden, “high” means “loud.”

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Outro]

annotation.plain: This outro riff was later used as the main riff for the song “On Top of the World”.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You got to roll with the punches to get to what’s real

annotation.plain: In order to achieve what you want, you have to go through some struggles first. “Rolling with the punches” is a boxing term, a way to adapt to one’s opponent’s strikes to lessen the impact. It has become an idiom meaning “to change the way you do things so that you are not seriously affected by difficulties you experience”.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Oh, can’t you see me standing here?
 I got my back against the record machine

annotation.plain:
He’s there for the taking, even if the lady is somehow ignoring. (and no, it’s not “wrecking machine”)



For younger audiences, record machines or jukeboxes were stereos in public places such as restaurants where you put in a coin, chose a song, and it would play out loud. They’re much less common nowadays with TVs becoming mainstays and personal devices, though some restaurants, especially ones that keep a retro look may have one.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Guitar Solo]

annotation.plain: Eddie Van Halen says this solo is “the best one I never wrote”, given the producer spliced parts of two different takes to create the one heard in the song.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Verse 1]

annotation.plain: The song is preceded by an synthesizer instrumental called “1984”, which then segues into “Jump”’s own synth intro. The track was always being postponed by the fact that David Lee Roth and producer Ted Templeman didn’t want keyboards in Van Halen’s music. Then Eddie Van Halen built his own studio and was able to record the “Jump” demo, and the team couldn’t refuse it.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Ah, might as well jump (Jump!)
 Might as well jump
 Go ahead and jump (Jump!)
 Go ahead and jump

annotation.plain: Inspired by the occasional onlookers who tell those attempting suicide to “go ahead and jump,” Roth compares that to earning the courage to attempt something with the girl – in a fitting metaphor, a leap of faith.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
So can’t you see me standing here?
 I’ve got my back against the record machine
 I ain’t the worst that you’ve seen
 Oh, can’t you see what I mean?

annotation.plain:
He’s standing there, and and repeats his offer for the woman to jump at the opportunity, and leaving behind what isn’t essential.

And no, the lyrics aren’t “wrecking machine”.

annotations.lyric_fragment:

annotation.plain: He’s still trying to work her (or you – the listener) out of her shell and into a good time. She seems to be hesitant, but still a little interested, because you get the feeling she said something along the lines of: “I don’t know how I am, it hasn’t been good. I can’t tell you how I’m feeling, what are you suggesting?”

I ain’t the worst that you’ve seen

annotation.plain: Here, Roth (the lead singer) is telling the woman that he can read her and see that she’s had problems and troubles to overcome. He is also saying that she’s not the only one he’s seen like this, and therefore not alone.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You thought that it was special, special
 But it was just the sex, though, the sex, though

annotation.plain:
Post makes clear the type of love he’s portraying, which is lust. Although his significant other feels more than that, Post on the other hand does not. He has made similar references in the past on his April 2018 track, “Rich & Sad”:

Plenty sluts grabbin' on my nuts
Might have fucked, it was only lust

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Run away, but we’re running in circles
 Run away, run away

annotation.plain:
Post and his significant other are “running in circles,” meaning that they repeat the same actions without any change.

Post described similar grief for returning to the same situation time and time again on April 2018’s “Otherside”:

Feel like I’m circlin' a drain, all I see is the remains of an ugly truth (Of an ugly truth)

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Seasons change and our love went cold
 Feed the flame ’cause we can’t let go

annotation.plain:
To “feed the flame” means to make a situation worse. To “feed the flame ‘cause we can’t let it go” references how they’d rather keep the failing relationship going even if that isn’t mentally healthy for both of them.

Post used the “flame” metaphor before on April 2018’s “Otherside” where he recognizes that a relationship won’t be the same if the two reconcile after their conflict:

We’re no strangers to the flame
We will never be the same if we make it through (And we can make it through)

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I dare you to do something
 I’m waiting on you again, so I don’t take the blame

annotation.plain:
These lines are a callback to Post’s April 2018 song “Otherside” where he says:

I been waitin', wide awake for the waves to come and take
Take me right to you

This time around, Post is not taking the blame for nothing happening, something he’s done before, which he makes very clear in the chorus of “Blame It On Me”:

That you can’t blame it on me (Ayy)
It’s not my fault, it’s not my fault, it’s not my fault
Blame it on me (Ayy)

annotations.lyric_fragment: Smell like I sound,

annotation.plain: We are mainly receiving Le Bon sonically; that is, through his vocals. Given the band’s success, it is no doubt that many regard his singing as excellent. With that, he could be alluding (more intimately and primally), that he smells as good as he sounds.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Burning the ground, I break from the crowd

annotation.plain: Similar to the way hunters burn out forests or tall grasslands to draw prey into the open, the ‘wolf’ breaks from the pack to hunt a solitary objective.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Darken the city, night is a wire

annotation.plain:
Wire could reference a live wire, an electric surge through the streets that’s powerful and exciting.
The line can be interpreted in many ways, but it somehow manages to convey the feeling of a bustling underground city that feels alive.

annotations.lyric_fragment: And I’m hungry like the wolf

annotation.plain:
Wolves appear in many fairy tales and fables as antagonists who want to eat the protagonists when they’re hungry.

Some examples of this are The three little pigs and Little Red Riding Hood. The last one was indeed the story which inspired this song.



Wolves are thought to be smart, determined and ravening creatures, attributes that the singer would like to describe himself.

Bettelheim has theorized that the wolf was a representation of the sexual. Being hungry like the wolf is therefore a metaphore expressing sexual attraction.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Steam in the subway, Earth is afire

annotation.plain: Classic scene of steam rising from the subway beneath the streets, we are so consistently in motion that it may seem like the world is on FIRE!

annotations.lyric_fragment: Mouth is alive with juices like wine

annotation.plain:
One can only imagine what “juices” Simon is singing about here.  Intoxicating like wine, yes, but brother, I don’t think we’re talking about wine…if you get my drift.

If you don’t get my drift, perhaps this exceptionally clinical Wikipedia article about vaginal lubrication will help get the point across.

More likely, this indicates he is depressed, not that he wakes up in the middle of the night.

annotations.lyric_fragment:

 When I hear that old song they used to play (More than a feeling)

annotation.plain: It’s impossible to describe the emotion that is evoked when he hears the song that reminds him of Marianne.  It takes him back to a special time, all he can use to describe the situation is “it’s more than a feeling”.  There’s a certain magic that surrounds not being able to pinpoint exactly what it is.

And I begin dreaming (More than a feeling)
 ’Til I see Marianne walk away
 
 [Post-Chorus]
 I see my Marianne walkin’ away

annotation.plain: The old memory (of a song) spurs a daydream for our narrator that brings a rush which exceeds any single one of the senses. Yet, as the classic tune invariably peters out, so must his moment of reminiscence; when the dreamer remembers Marianne leaving his life, his daydream fades away.

annotation.plain: A common and annoying stereotype about women is that they are nothing more than a pretty face is a dress, that they can’t think for themselves

annotations.lyric_fragment: Oh, I’ve had it up to here

annotation.plain: She’s tired and done with people treating her like she’s only a little girl. Especially considering that by the time this song was written, she was around her mid-20s, which is a more-than-high enough age for her to take care of herself.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Oh, I’m just a girl, guess I’m some kind of freak
 ’Cause they all sit and stare with their eyes
 Oh, I’m just a girl, take a good look at me

annotation.plain: Girls are commonly objectified and stared at. Maybe for their bodies, face, outfit, and it can feel like you’re being treated like a doll rather than a human

annotations.lyric_fragment: ’Cause I’m just a girl, I’d rather not be

annotation.plain: Being a girl is hard, and sometimes, you’d rather be a boy.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Just your typical prototype

annotation.plain:
The term “typical prototype” can be broken down.

“Prototype” may refer to how some treat women as objects, objects that can be replaced and discarded once an improvement is found.

“Typical” may be referring to how many women are objectified and treat like prototypes, Stefani is not alone in being treat in an objectifying manner nor is it an uncommon occurrence.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Oh, I’m just a girl, my apologies
 What I’ve become is so burdensome

annotation.plain: When you’re raised as a girl, you often end up feeling like a burden or that you need to apologize for just about everything.

annotations.lyric_fragment: What I’ve succumbed to is making me numb

annotation.plain: Eventually, we start ignoring misogynistic encounters because we’ve run into so many that we are numb to them.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Oh, am I making myself clear?

annotation.plain: This could be a reference to the way that girls and those raised as girls are taught from a young age to tone ourselves down – we often end our points with things such as “if that makes sense” “I don’t know, just a thought”, etc.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
’Cause I’m just a girl, oh, little old me
 Well, don’t let me out of your sight
 Oh, I’m just a girl, all pretty and petite
 So don’t let me have any rights

annotation.plain: This continues the tongue-in-cheek tone of the song by mocking the perspective of those who view women as delicate and defenseless.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Take this pink ribbon off my eyes
 I’m exposed, and it’s no big surprise
 Don’t you think I know exactly where I stand?
 This world is forcing me to hold your hand

annotation.plain:
Gwen uses symbolism to show how the lives of women are all lies. Using the ‘pink ribbon’ as a deceiving object which covers up the real truth of womanhood with pretty things and lacy frills, she talks about how women are kept from seeing the world for what it truly is. The pink ribbon is also used to show that the color pink is stereotypically attributed to girls. Women are supposed to suppress their awareness of their challenges while society is tries to shape them into things they don’t want.

Gwen, however, takes this blindfold off and lets the audience know that she is well aware of the disadvantages and the limits society has placed on her because of her status as a woman.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Pour myself a cup of ambition

annotation.plain: Getting a big fat cup full of morning brown is a typical start to the average workers day.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Want to move ahead but the boss won’t seem to let me

annotation.plain:
Idea that ‘the rich get richer’.

Workers that fall for the idea of ‘trickle-down economics’ are buying into a scam made by the bosses and CEOs of the world, who want to keep their wealth and will not allow the workers under them to ‘move ahead’. Dolly is beginning to see this and getting frustrated.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I swear sometimes that man is out to get me

annotation.plain: The feminist message of this song is largely from its historical context as the theme song to the movie “9to5” but it is subtly supported in the lyrics. In this verse, they set up a conflict between the female singer and her male “boss man”. Parton could have chosen to keep the gender of the boss neutral, as in the first verse when a genderless “they” use her mind without credit. Instead, she repeatedly mentions a male boss antagonizing her.

annotations.lyric_fragment: And yawn and stretch and try to come to life

annotation.plain: When waking up early in the morning, you stretch and yawn to get oxygen into the bloodstream as your body feels lifeless and lethargic, especially when preparing yourself for work in the morning.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Verse 3]

annotation.plain: Pagliacci is a play that premiered in Milan, Italy in 1892. The prologue has the character Tonio, who is dressed as a clown, tell the audience that a clown is also a man who feels sorrow and pity, as Smokey displays in the theme of this song.

annotations.lyric_fragment: The tears of a clown

annotation.plain: One of pop music’s greatest tricks is the reversal.  In this case, a clown, who appears perpetually happy, is actually sad.  The late George Jones was a master at these kinds of songs, with numbers such as “Accidentally on Purpose” and “He Stopped Loving Her Today” (spoiler – because “he” died)

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Just like Pagliacci did (The great pretender)
 I try to keep my sadness hid

annotation.plain:
Pagliacci is an Italian opera about an acting troupe where the lead actor is driven to murder his actress wife and her lover. The lead man is dressed as a clown in the play that goes on in the opera (kind of a play within a play). For much of the opera, the clown is forced to cover up his misery.



Just like all great artists, Smokey steals from the best – in this case, himself! He used these exact lines six years before in the song “My Smile Is Just A Frown (Turned Upside Down),” which he wrote for Carolyn Crawford:

Just like Pagliacci did
I’ll keep my sadness hid

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Intro]

annotation.plain:
This opening theme is played on a calliope, and Smokey thought it “sounded like a circus,” which inspired his lyrics



The bassoon on this song, most notable in the introduction, was played by Charles R. Sirard

annotation.plain: Likely refering to a date of the singer, that he is trying to have sex with. Since they have no future and no past, the singer is only seeing this as an one-night stand and in the third line is basically asking them to enjoy the moment. “Built to last”  refers to the pair lasting long during sex, but could also be interpreted to mean the divided city.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Faces on posters, too many choices

annotation.plain: Continuing the theme of affluence juxtaposed with destitution the unspecified ‘faces on posters’ may be famous musicians and actors, or possibly wanted posters for criminals, or even missing persons posters. Too many choices, too many possibilities, could the next move lead to riches or ruin?

annotations.lyric_fragment: The East End boys and West End girls

annotation.plain:
The East End of London is stereotypically associated with poor, immiganant, or lower class communities, as opposed to the more posh West End.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_End_of_London

The line is referencing the intersect between the common, working class East End boys, with the posh, privileged West End girls.

On a night out, East End boys will be trying to pick up West End girls.

Pulp’s Common People touches on the theme

In interviews, Tennant has also added that East End boys was a reference to criminal activity (like the Krays) and that it seemed fascinating that West End girls, the sort that frequented the theatres etc, would end up with crime-related East End boys. Lowe that added there was a seedy connotation.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You’ve got a heart of glass or a heart of stone

annotation.plain: Reference to the popular Blondie hit “Heart of Glass”, it could also possibly mean that you have a fragile heart. Also refers to Rolling Stones song ‘heart of stone’.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
How much have you got?
 Have you got it, do you get it, if so, how often?
 And which do you choose, a hard or soft option?

annotation.plain:
An ambiguous question – either discussing how much you earn (an important question in the money-obsessed London of the 1980s) or how much sex you get. Perhaps it’s hinting that high earners get more…

These verses are about the seedy parts of the West End of London where drugs and sex were available. “if when why what, how much have you got” are questions for a drug deal. While “faces on posters, too many choices” refers to all the pictures of the performer posters, who you can see if you enter one of the sex clubs. There’s “too many choices.”  And “Which do you choose a hard or soft option” is asking if you’d prefer a hard (male) option or a soft (female) one in a genderfluid world with east end boys and west end boys.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Running down underground to a dive bar

annotation.plain:
“A well-worn, unglamorous bar, often serving a cheap, simple selection of drinks to a regular clientele.” – Urban Dictionary

According to their website, the “dive bar” here was an actual bar that the Boys visited in their pre-fame days in the early 1980s.

annotations.lyric_fragment: In a restaurant in a West End town

annotation.plain:
“The West End of London (more commonly referred to as simply the West End) is an area of Central London containing many of the city’s major tourist attractions, shops, businesses, government buildings and entertainment venues” -Wikipedia

The connotation for 80s “West End” is not only somewhat upper class, but also chic, fashionable, desirable.

annotation.plain: The whole song has been believed to be one long sexual innuendo – not explicit – but not difficult to reach such a conclusion. Apparently not considered as such by the radio stations, and it did not join the long list of boycotted songs.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Crimson and clover

annotation.plain:
A case where the song was composed to fit a phrase that popped up one morning in Tommy James’s mind combining his favorite color and flower.



From a Songfacts interview

they were just two of my favorite words that came together. Actually, it was one morning as I was getting up – this is a true story – I was getting up out of bed, and it just came to me, those two words. And it sounded so poetic. I had no idea what it meant, or if it meant anything. They were just two of my favorite words. And Mike Vale and I – bass player – actually wrote another song called “Crimson and Clover,” and it just wasn’t quite there. I ended up writing “Crimson and Clover” with my drummer, Pete Lucia…

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Ah, now I don’t hardly know her
 But I think I could love her

annotation.plain:
Not an impressive start grammatically. Pedants will turn their noses up at the double negative. Interpreted literally, “I don’t hardly know her” means “I know her quite well”. However, double negatives can also reinforce a negative – he really doesn’t know her at all well. Call it poetic licence, or just call it rock and roll.

Like double negatives, love at first sight is common in pop music, and particularly hippyish pop music of the 60s. As Ringo said in “With A Little Help From My Friends”, it happens all the time.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Instrumental Bridge]

annotation.plain:
A long (over 2 minutes) instrumental part, repetitive tune, but building up with all instruments joining in and dominated by the lead guitar’s wah-wah sound, with tremolo – the trembling effect – that extends into the chorus.

This interlude is much shorter in the single version, making the song an “acceptable” 3 minutes+  - the standard length of a single at that time – rather than the almost 6 minutes album version.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Instrumental Interlude]

annotation.plain:
A short instrumental interval led in by the bass.

The bands was one of the early ones to use vocoders and phasers in music.



At the ed Sullivan show (after which the song hit no. 1).

I guess in a situation, you will know you’re a better one if you’ll be well off without that person whoever the fuck they may be. You know they from the struggle or they don’t see your worth type shit until it’s too late. I kind of figured out that I probably don’t know what real love is.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Who knew evil girls had the prettiest face?

annotation.plain: That’s a false statement, I’ve come to find out. I feel like maybe in TV it’s somewhat real, ‘cause you know how in the movies where the high school bully girls, they be all like, dumb blondes. Everybody be trying to get with them at school, and they be like, “Get the fuck out my face,” you know what I’m saying? But I think in real life, that’s not necessarily true.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I should’ve listened to my friends

You’re the one that’s in the shit, they can see all the faults, ‘cause I feel like, when you feel a certain type of way about someone, or something, you don’t see anything wrong with it.

annotations.lyric_fragment:

annotation.plain: Sleep paralysis. I have it, to this day. If somethings bothering me, I have it, if I’m going through stress and shit, I have it. It’s still the same feeling as it was when it first started, still the same amount of fear, it does not get old. It’s scary, you can be laying right next to somebody and if they not paying attention, they won’t even know you having it. Some people have it together, that’s crazy. It’s a documentary on Netflix where the husband was having it, he saw a cat sitting on his wife’s chest, and when she was having it, she saw something leaning over him, they was crying when they was talking about it, but it was scary as fuck.

Any help that was given by that was very temporary, wasn’t anything, it didn’t permanently fix anything, it was very temporary, like four or five hours of feeling like shit was gonna be okay, and after that, your deeper than the hole you were before, and then you gotta take more ‘cause your tolerance is built up, and now you on twice, three times, four times, and before you know it, your like dead. Some people have an old lady that sits on their chest, they call it “The Old Hag” and it’s weird, ‘cause like a hundred million people probably have sleep paralysis and a lot of them see the same old lady sitting on they’re chest. That shit’s crazy. But the shadows, that’s pretty much talking about sleep paralysis.

“It’s to the point where I love and I hate you"–that’s one of the craziest things, I feel like a lot more people go through it than people think. ‘Cause I mean, you could be attached to somebody that’s no good, and you can’t help your feeling at the end of the day. It’s like, you know that they’re not good. And that goes for anything, even outside of a boyfriend or girlfriend relationship. That goes with friendships in the family, all types of shit. People gotta love their family at the end of the day, but some people got some no good ass family members. So I feel like you can reach that point on any aspect.

annotation.plain:
Serious heartbreak can often bring on feelings of emasculation and suicide. Suicide can seem much easier than enduring the emotional roller coaster of rejection, depression, and anger. Juice WRLD has mentioned the idea of suicide in relation to a broken relationship on his track “End of the Road”:

This the end of the rope
The other end at her throat
It’s suicidal she wrote

Furthermore, Juice may be experiencing an adverse effect of Xanax–the prescription meds likely referenced earlier in the verse–which is the risk of suicide due to depression.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Strike a pose
 Strike a pose

annotation.plain: This song takes its name from the dance move called “voguing,” which was originated by gay, black men in Harlem, New York. First born in ballroom culture, the basis of “voguing” is striking a pose, usually framing one’s face with their hands as if for a beauty shot on the cover of a magazine.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Rita Hayworth gave good face

annotation.plain:
Rita Hayworth was an American actress who was one of the biggest film stars of the 1940s.



She was the top pin-up girl for G.I.s during World War II as well.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Ginger Rogers dance on air

annotation.plain:
Ginger Rogers was an American actress, dancer and singer who appeared with the aforementioned Fred Astaire in numerous musical films during the 1930s. She also won an Oscar for the 1940 film Kitty Foyle.



Rogers was one of the few stars mentioned in this verse who was still alive when “Vogue” came out.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Jimmy Dean

annotation.plain:
James Dean made only three films in his brief career — Rebel Without a Cause (1955), East of Eden (1955) and Giant (1956) — yet he had already become a force in Hollywood. Through his characters' brooding ways and estranged dispositions, Dean became a symbol of his generation, but he’d never have an opportunity to further explore his artistic gifts. When Dean wasn’t acting, he was a professional racecar driver. At just 24, his life was cut short in a high-speed car accident off a California highway, when a Cal Poly student collided with Dean’s vehicle. Dean was killed immediately.



Dean was openly bisexual, saying in a 1955 interview,

No, I am not a homosexual. But, I’m also not going to go through life with one hand tied behind my back.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Marlon Brando

annotation.plain:
Marlon Brando may have been known for his strikingly good looks in his youth and later, for his personal self-indulgence, but his professional status as one of the greatest actors of the 20th century remains solidly intact. His roles in such memorable films as A Streetcar Named Desire (1951), On the Waterfront (1954) and The Godfather (1972) — the last two of which he received Academy Awards for — changed the cultural landscape of cinema. With additional blockbuster hits like Last Tango in Paris (1972) and Apocalypse Now (1979), Brando secured his place as one of the highest paid actors of his era and a master of his craft.



Maintaining references to homosexuality, Brando himself was open about having had homosexual experiences:

Like a large number of men, I, too, have had homosexual experiences, and I am not ashamed. I have never paid much attention to what people think about me. But if there is someone who is convinced that Jack Nicholson and I are lovers, may they continue to do so. I find it amusing.

annotations.lyric_fragment: DiMaggio

annotation.plain: Jo DiMaggio was a record setting American professional baseball player, who spent his entire 13 year career with the New York Yankees.  DiMaggio married Marilyn Monroe in 1954.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
When all else fails and you long to be
 Something better than you are today
 I know a place where you can get away
 It’s called a dance floor
 And here’s what it’s for, so

annotation.plain:
You can say Madonna is describing herself and her life in these four lines. Madonna is the definition of the American Dream.



She had tough childhood, it all began from the death of her mother. At the age of 20, she moved to NYC for a better life. She had only $35 in her pocket, she worked as a waitress at Dunkin' Donuts and she was eating out of garbage cans:

It was the first time I’d ever taken a plane, the first time I’d ever gotten a taxi cab. I came here with $35 in my pocket. It was the bravest thing I’d ever done.

But her love for dancing was strong and she started to work as a backup dancer for other established artists. In 1981, she with her former boyfriend Stephen Bray as drummer, formed the band Emmy. Their music impressed producer Mark Kamins and that’s how she managed to release her first album.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Vogue (Vogue, vogue)
 Vogue (Vogue, vogue)

annotation.plain:
Vogue has a double meaning to the song

First of all, ‘vogue’ or ‘voguing’ is a dance characterized by striking poses. Originated in the “ball culture” of gay black men in Harlem, which is now present in every major city of the U.S. and internationally thanks to Madonna.



Secondly, using the word ‘vogue’, you can describe something that is popular, cool and fashionable.

annotation.plain:
Grace Kelly was an American actress. She has won two Golden Globes for Best Actress and an Academy Award.
She retired from acting at the age of 26 and one year later, in 1956, she married Prince Rainier III and became the Princess of Monaco.

annotation.plain:
Fred Astaire was an American dancer, actor and singer. He’s one of the most influential dancers in the history of film. He starred in more than 10 Broadway and London musicals and made 31 musical films during a 76 year career.

Gene Kelly, another famous dancer Madonna mentions in the song, said:

The history of dance on film begins with Fred Astaire.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Say, Candy and Ronnie, have you seen them yet?

annotation.plain:
The chorus starts with a teenager who has succumbed to the hype and asks Candy and Ronnie if they have seen them. Candy or Ronnie replied in the negative: “(No), but they are so spaced out”. In response, the original teenager then gives their reasons why: weird, great, Bennie is really cool, electric boots, mohair suits etc.

Candy and Ronnie are fictional characters. They should represent teenage boppers following the band.

annotations.lyric_fragment: B-B-B-Bennie and the Jets

annotation.plain:
Bennie is a female who Elton describes as a “sci-fi rock goddess”. Bennie and the Jets is an imaginary band that from Elton and Bernie Taupin’s perspective is a prototypical female rock ‘n’ roll band out of science fiction.

The B-B-B was not originally in the lyrics written by Bernie Taupin. Elton John came up with this idea to portray that science fiction image and make it work well with the futuristic and robotic theme of the lyrics, as well as to add a certain flair to the glam rock/R&B crossover genre.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Hey kids, plug into the faithless
 Maybe they’re blinded, but Bennie makes them ageless

annotation.plain:
Elton asks the younger generations to get into the music of past generations and states that even though their parents and grandparents can’t get into the newer music, “Bennie” makes the music of their parents generations ageless. Or, alternatively, the “faithless” could refer to the kids’ parents, who have no faith in modern music and are blinded to how good it actually is; Bennie and the Jets is the exception, for their music reaches everyone regardless of age.

The lyrical hero calls the new generation (kids) to join the ranks of nonbelievers stating that Bennie shall be the source of eternal life for them, not God.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You’re gonna hear electric music

annotation.plain: This song was made at the beginning of Electronic music, and it was still a curious novelty of the time. Bands had begun using synthesizers like Kraftwerk and vocoders like Electric Light Orchestra. This song paints a picture of this band “Bennie and the Jets” as one of many acts of the time who were using electronic instruments in that time period

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Hey kids, shake it loose together
 The spotlight’s hittin’ somethin’
 That’s been known to change the weather

annotation.plain:
The singer is taking the perspective of one of The Jets' utterly uncritical fans.  Songwriter Bernie Taupin has said that this song is a satire of the music industry in the ‘70s.

Here, the fan is excited about the concert, not because of the music, but because of the then-new technology of turning spotlights upside-down to hit clouds.  It might do nothing for the music, but who cares, it looks cool.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Where we fight our parents out in the streets
 To find who’s right and who’s wrong

annotation.plain:
The ‘60s and '70s were a time of huge generational struggles, where kids rebelled against their parents. This came not just in countercultural activities, drugs, and free love, but also in kids liking new music and defending its value to their parents.

In a more literal sense, it could refer to the Vietnam War and other issues of the day that pitted the younger generation against the older in protests on the street.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Solid walls of sound

annotation.plain:
A musical production technique pioneered by Phil Spector in the 1960s and gained popularity in the 1970s.

Spector created a dense, layered, reverberant sound that came across well on AM radio and jukeboxes popular in the era. He created this sound by having a number of electric and acoustic guitarists perform the same parts in unison, adding musical arrangements for large groups of musicians up to the size of orchestras, then recording the sound using an echo chamber.

Famous examples of the Wall of Sound technique would be  Ike and Tina Turner’s “River Deep, Mountain High”, The Ronettes' “Sleigh Ride” and The Beatles' Let it Be album, particularly  “The Long and Winding Road”, “I Me Mine”, and “Across the Universe.”



This line has also been sampled in the A Tribe Called Quest song ‘Solid Wall of Sound’ as the main hook.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You know, I read it in a magazine, oh-oh

annotation.plain: This line slyly points out that some fans seem far more interested in a singer’s looks, and in what others think about her, than in her actual music (which of course you can’t hear in a magazine).  Billy Joel makes the same critique in “It’s Still Rock and Roll to Me”, although as usual, Joel is blunter than John/Taupin.

annotations.lyric_fragment: We’ll kill the fatted calf tonight, so stick around

annotation.plain: The idiom “kill the fatted calf” dates back  2000 years to a story that Jesus made up, The Parable of the Prodigal Son.  In the story, the father kills the fatted calf so that they can have a big celebration and eat tasty, tasty veal.

annotation.plain:
The Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals concluded that Juvenile’s use of this “poetic four-word phrase” did not infringe the copyright of DJ Jubilee.

Jubilee was a fellow New Orleans-based rapper who had recorded his own track called “Back That Ass Up” in November 1997. You can hear the clean version of the track here:

https://youtu.be/oDAxtgk5EJw?t=5

Highlights from the case include Juvenile’s lawyers arguing:

[T]he phrase “back that ass up” cannot be copyrighted. […T]he phrase is not original and […] the merger doctrine precludes extending protection to a phrase that is necessary to describe a particular thing--in this case, a dance move.

This appearance by Lil Wayne was, at the time, his biggest brush with stardom.  Although he was a member of Cash Money, he was nowhere near the star that Juvenile was at the time.

annotations.lyric_fragment: She’ll push and pull you down

annotation.plain:
When someone is drowning in a large body of water, it’s very dangerous for a rescuer to swim out to save them without any flotation devices, as the person who is drowning will instinctively latch onto anything nearby to pull down on and try to breathe. In some cases, this has caused the rescuer to drown instead.

She’ll pull you into her chaotic life for her own benefit, and whether you survive (metaphorically or not) is of no concern to her.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
She’s into superstitions
 Black cats and voodoo dolls

annotation.plain:
PROPOSED SUGGESTION:

The superstitions listed reflect the woman’s nature. Black cats are seen as an omen of bad luck, whereas voodoo dolls can be used to curse or harm someone without being near them.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
In a funky cheap hotel
 She took my heart and she took my money
 She must’ve slipped me a sleeping pill

annotation.plain: New York City or Manhattan is a giant city full of landmarks. If he woke up there without remembering what he was there, he was most likely drugged or drunk (Probably drugged as the sleeping pill is mentioned) and then he was dumped into a relatively cheat hotel (as cheap as a hotel in a giant city can get) and then stole his money and ran while he was still asleep.

‘livin la vida loca’ is Spanish for ‘living the crazy life’,
which from the previous lyrics means that she lives a bit untraditionally.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
She never drinks the water
 Makes you order French champagne

annotation.plain: Tap water is usually served as a free drink in most American restaurants regardless of whether it is ordered or not as a refresher. However, the girl shows herself to be extremely snooty by not just refusing the water, but forcing her date to order (real) French champagne, a very expensive type of sparkling wine.

annotation.plain: Red is often associated with love, happiness, and passion, but also danger, sexuality, and sin. All of these are also associated with the girl.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Ain’t no sunshine when she’s gone
 It’s not warm when she’s away
 Ain’t no sunshine when she’s gone
 And she’s always gone too long
 Anytime she goes away

annotation.plain:
The use of the phrases “this time” and “anytime” imply that this isn’t the first time Bill Withers' love interest has withdrawn. He’s coming to the realization that he might be losing her forever.

Notice the paradoxical juxtaposition between “gone to stay” and “this house just ain’t no home”—this highlights the nuance between these words' various connotations; the house is now missing the warmth, memories, comfort, and familial connection that it once had.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And I know, I know, I know, I know
 I know, I know, I know, I know
 I know, I know, I know, I know
 I know, I know, I know, I know
 I know, I know, I know, I know
 I know, I know, I know, I know
 I know, I know

annotation.plain:
Bill Withers had originally planned to write a third verse for the song, but the other musicians recommended that he didn’t, hence the repetition of “I know” twenty-six times instead.

He spoke on this in a 2004 interview with songfacts.com:

They were all these people with all this experience and all these reputations, and I was this factory worker in here just sort of puttering around. So when their general feeling was, ‘leave it like that,’ I left it like that.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You grabbin’ me hard ’cause you know what you found
 It’s biscuits, it’s gravy, babe

annotation.plain:
Biscuits and gravy is a classic comfort food.

The line could have multiple meanings:

Lacy’s romantic interest is attracted to him not for the reasons most singers or rappers write about, such as money or bravado. They like Lacy because he is sincere and makes them feel comfortable.

Additionally, Lacy had been shy and insecure before finally gaining the courage to approach this person. Now that he has taken that leap, and they have reciprocated his feelings, the world is at peace. They both feel as comfortable with each other as they do having a nice meal.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Please say to me (Please just say to me)
 If you still want it
 I wish you wouldn’t play with me
 I wanna know (I wanna know)

annotation.plain:
Adding on to the sense of doubt and insecurity from the beginning of the song, Steve is waiting for clear confirmation from his love interest that they are attracted to to him before he makes his move.

However, there is a slight change of tone: before, he was wallowing in regret that he missed his chance to be with this person, but now, he is confronting them directly so that he can get the motivation to ask them out, albeit in a somewhat begging manner.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Thought you were too good for me, my dear
 Never gave me time of day, my dear
 It’s okay, things happen for
 Reasons that I think are sure, yeah

annotation.plain:
Steve offers an explanation for why he tends to not shoot his shot at those that are interested in him—insecurity.

Feelings of inferiority to a romantic interest will cause one to be oblivious to any signs that would otherwise be obvious that there is an attraction.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Kinda mad that I didn’t take a stab at it

annotation.plain: Steve here adds on the “bite the tongue” expression use, as he appears to be frustrated afterward about something he was willing to say, but unfortunately held back because of this “habit”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I wish I knew
 I wish I knew you wanted me (I wish I knew)
 I wish I knew (Oh)
 I wish I knew you wanted me
 I wish I knew (Yeah)
 I wish I knew you wanted me (Oh)
 I wish I knew
 I wish I knew you wanted me

annotation.plain: The song’s central premise is Lacy’s reflection on how he regrets not expressing his feelings to someone. Now, he is stuck thinking about the “what ifs” as he is wishfully thinking about what would have happened if he did confess his feelings and that maybe they’d like him back. He’s desperately trying to grapple with the regret. The repetition of the line could also imply the constant guilt and the continuous thoughts he might be thinking of his missed chance.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I bite my tongue, it’s a bad habit

annotation.plain:
Steve uses this line as a double meaning. The first meaning being more literal of actually biting your tongue and fidgeting. The deeper meaning is using the expression of “biting your tongue” and second guessing yourself.

In the second chorus, Steve asks to bite the tongue of the person who the song is addressed to–essentially asking to kiss them. There, the meaning changes from regretting not having said anything to trying to make a move on the person after all.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Produced by Daft Punk]

annotation.plain:
The masters of dance returned with this radio-magnetic ballad about letting your favourite song play one more time.

As claimed by Guy-Manuel de Homem-Christo:

We thought the funkiness of [Romanthony’s] voice fit the funkiness of the music."

The song’s vocal features heavy processing and auto-tuning. When questioned on the effects, Thomas Bangalter stated:

A lot of people complain about musicians using Auto-Tune. It reminds me of the late ‘70s when musicians in France tried to ban the synthesizer… What they didn’t see was that you could use those tools in a new way instead of just for replacing the instruments that came before."

In terms of samples, it takes its horns from Eddie Johns' More Spell On You however, Bangalter reportedly denied using any samples for the song, take a listen below and make your own judgement.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=53p7ogqJqqs&t=2m23s

annotations.lyric_fragment: Here comes the shame, here comes the shame

annotation.plain:
PROPOSED SUGGESTION:

Referring to the “running” in the previous sentence: the feeling of shame is starting to overwhelm you, you’ve metaphorically ran a mile, but you’re too slow… shame is catching up with you.

You’re unable to suppress the memories of the night before: what you have done, what you’ve said and even what you’ve thought. Maybe you went into the night with some great intentions, which you all failed to live up to and now you start to feel ashamed.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Party girls don’t get hurt

annotation.plain:
Sia begins the song with almost a dubious invincibility, a concept she introduced on her 2008 album Some People Have Real Problems. The alcohol shield / IDGAF-barrier makes the party girl immune to feeling anything real… or at least until it wears off.

Alcohol actually does have a numbing effect on the body, and was often used as an anesthetic in the past because it depresses the central nervous system.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Chorus]

annotation.plain: From Jesse Shatkin: “Sia and I wrote "Chandelier” on a break from recording her record, in Greg Kurstin’s live room.  It was originally a Marimba and Piano jam session, which turned into an iPhone voice note, which turned into a demo i made at my house, which turned into the final version with Greg’s production that you hear today."

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Verse 1]

annotation.plain: From Greg Kurstin: “‘Chandelier’ was written by Sia and Jesse Shatkin.  Sia brought it in for me to work on and tie into the other songs on the record.  I added some acoustic piano, Mellotron and live drums over the track. I left most of Jesse’s production; which was awesome.”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
We are not thugs, we don’t use drugs, but you assume on your own
 They offer coke and lots of dope, but we just leave it alone

annotation.plain:
In 1986, Run DMC was pushing an anti-drug message, not only in their lyrics but in public appearances. That year, Run told Rolling Stone:

If only one kid turns away from gangs or drugs, we’ve been successful … Life is hard enough without drugs or joining gangs … We offer kids alternatives. We tell them they can go play ball, go to school. There are lots of other things you can do besides taking drugs or joining gangs … We are not thugs. We don’t use drugs. People try to stereotype us.

In the same interview, manager Russel Simmons added:

The guys sing about staying in school, going to church, respecting your mother, don’t take drugs.

But years later, DMC admitted:

Yeah we was getting high as hell. I was a cocaine man, Run was a weed head, and Jay was weed and 40s. The coke in the ‘80s was the best coke ever!

 It’s tricky, tricky, tricky, tricky
 It’s tricky to rock a rhyme, to rock a rhyme that’s right on time, it’s tricky
 Tr-tr-tr-tricky, tricky, tricky

annotation.plain:
People may think rapping is easy. After all, it’s just rhyming, right? Even Doctor Seuss can do it. Wrong. It takes a lot of talent to come up with a sick rhyme, especially when on the spot.

This also served as a response to critics of old-school rappers that dismissed their flow and rhyme style as not complex enough.

They use the simple back and forth, the same, old rhythm
That a baby can pick up, and join, right with them

Note that the cadence of this chorus is directly lifted from Toni Basil’s 1982 chart-topper “Mickey”.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Say so

annotation.plain:
The whole point of the song is:
Doja Cat teases the love interest, but he, himself, doesn’t have the courage to front with it. Doja Cat tells him to not resist it and “say so”, but he never does. Afterwards, Doja Cat moves on and tells him he should have said so

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And we can dance all day around it
 If you frontin’, I’ll be bouncing

annotation.plain:
A few definitions for those that don’t understand the language here.

“Dancing around it” is a common English expression that means to avoid discussing something or avoid dealing with it directly.

“Frontin'” refers to putting up a façade, to be faking it.

To be “bouncin'” / to “bounce” in this situation means to leave the room/area.

The entire first verse is Doja admitting she’s into this guy to herself, whilst knowing he’s into her too. But the guy hasn’t made a move yet. Doja likes him, but if he’s faking it, she’s not gonna deal with it. She has no time for playing games.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Come on, Eileen

annotation.plain:
Producer Clive Langer shared what the original lyric here was:

We recorded it as “James, Van and Me” – James Brown, Van Morrison, and Kevin [Rowland]. That was the original chorus, singing about people who influenced him to write the song – like he mentions Johnny Ray. And then [Kevin Rowland] came in one day and said I want to change the lyric completely, it’s a working lyric. And we actually liked “James, Van and Me!” Because we’d been working with it and got used to it.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Oh, believe me, if all those endearing young charms
 That I gaze on so fondly today
 Were to suddenly leave you or fly in the night
 Just like fairy gifts gone in the sky

annotation.plain:
“Believe Me, if All Those Endearing Young Charms” is a popular song written in 1808 by Irish poet Thomas Moore using a traditional Irish air.

This a capella appears on the album version but not the single or music video versions of the song.

“Believe Me, if All Those Endearing Young Charms” is about how the narrator will stay with and still love the object of his affection would still be adored even after her beauty fades – not about how they will leave at any moment. The next few lyrics reveal this:

Thou wouldst still be ador’d as this moment thou art,
Let thy loveliness fade as it will;
And, around the dear ruin, each wish of my heart
Would entwine itself verdantly still!

The narrator of “Come on Eileen” is telling Eileen that their relationship is not just a fling while they’re young; he’s promising to stay with her as they grow older and lose their youthful charms.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Fiddle Tune]

annotation.plain:
An interpretation of Thomas Moore’s Irish folk song “Believe Me, if All Those Endearing Young Charms”

If you don’t believe it, just listen to the vocal melody here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_detailpage&v=B6BKIxbDB4Q#t=30

(It’s also well known to fans of Merrie Melodies/Looney Tunes as the song that is inevitably played on a piano with dynamite under the last key.)

The album version removes the initial fiddling and adds directly a shortened, a capella version of “Believe Me, if All Those Endearing Young Charms” after the song is over. The fiddle tune is heard on the music video and single versions.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Sounded sad upon the radio
 Moved a million hearts in mono

annotation.plain:
Johnny Ray’s sad songs weren’t heard in the highest-fidelity format, but their meanings still came through.  (“Mono” is the opposite of “stereo”: the left and right speakers get the same signal.)

As a metaphor, since “mono” means “one” in Greek, this part could also mean “a million hearts became one”.

He was also known for the sad ones: his biggest hits were “Cry” and “Walking in the Rain”.

annotations.lyric_fragment: How you feel

annotation.plain: He’s trying to convince Eileen that he feels the same way she does, mainly to connect with her and position himself to have sex with her later on.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Eileen, I’ll hum this tune forever

annotation.plain:
It is common for people to become attached to songs they hear when they’re young and to listen to them repeatedly as they get older.  Eileen will most likely end up humming the lullaby tune “too-ra-loo-ra” a lot as she gets older (most likely to her children, but also to herself), illustrating how most people’s tastes get stuck in their youth.

This line forms a parallel with “and we can sing just like our fathers,” which holds the same position in the previous verse. Taken together, it’s a potentially pessimistic vision of joys becoming routines and eventually ruts.

annotation.plain:
She is sexually mature and is showing it in an obvious way.

There’s also a possibility that what is “showing” is her pregnancy, thanks perhaps to a spring and summer of taking off dresses together.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Intro chords]

annotation.plain:
This basic three-chord intro is one of the most famous openings in rock. The New York Daily News has called the song “a three-chord, garage-band classic anybody could play soon after picking up an electric guitar.”

In the film Mr. Holland’s Opus (1995), Mr. Holland uses the song as an example of why there’s “a lot more to music than notes on a page,” explaining that The Kingsmen “can’t sing, they have absolutely no harmonic sense, and they’re playing the same three chords over and over again–and I love it.”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Me sailed that ship all alone
 Me never think I’ll make it home

annotation.plain:
The lyrics here are reminiscent of at least one authentic Caribbean folk song, the Bahamian shanty originally called “The John B. Sails”:


So hoist up the John B. sails,
See how the mainsail set,
Send for the captain ashore—let me go home,
Let me go home, let me go home,
I feel so break-up, I vant to go home.

(As transcribed by Richard Le Gallienne, 1916)


This song was later recorded as “The Wreck of the John B” and “Sloop John B” in famous versions by The Kingston Trio and The Beach Boys:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q8NVY0INJFk

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HW5yLvoJMD4

annotations.lyric_fragment: Louie Louie, oh baby, take me where ya gotta go

annotation.plain:
According to Richard Berry, who wrote the original lyrics to this cover song, the titular “Louie” is a bartender to which our protagonist and singer of this sea shanty is professing tales of his woe and loneliness.

The original (1957) version:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z-2CKsaq5r8

annotations.lyric_fragment: Fuck!

annotation.plain:
For all the rumored dirtiness of the song, there is only one actual curse word in The Kingsmen’s “Louie Louie.” At around 0:53, drummer Lynn Easton shouts “Fuck!” after missing a cue–apparently, he fumbled a drumstick.

Compare the legendary “Fucking hell” in the background of The Beatles’s “Hey Jude”.

annotation.plain: “They” (teachers, cops, politicians, religious leaders, society in general, take your pick) say that Coolio – a stand-in for all gang bangers who turned to a life of crime after being failed by the system since the moment they were born – needs to learn to lead a legitimate life as a productive, law-abiding citizen, but if they don’t understand the circumstances he was born into, raised in, and still lives in, how can they possibly help him, let alone expect him to do so himself?

annotations.lyric_fragment: And my homies is down, so don’t arouse my anger, fool

annotation.plain:
This could mean one of two things, given the context:

1) His homies have all been killed, and Coolio has developed a nihilistic outlook on life as a result that has lead him to be extremely quick to turn to violence if even slightly provoked.

or

2) His fellow Crips are down to engage in violence if Coolio calls upon them to, so one would be wise to not provoke Coolio, lest he tell his homies to go kill you.

annotations.lyric_fragment: As they croak, I see myself in the pistol smoke

annotation.plain:
Coolio is alluding to his own personal connection to these violent acts; he sees himself to be as much a part of the systemic violence as the physical properties of the crime.

Focus on the smoke specifically may be a reference to the temporal nature of his existence, comparing his circumstances to the smoke which vanishes after a short time.

Coolio sees himself in the smoke because he knows his time is coming sooner or later, just like the guy he just offed.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You better watch how ya talkin’ and where you walkin’
 Or you and your homies might be lined in chalk

annotation.plain:
When a criminal kills someone, and the dead body is found, the police get informed, and they come to the “scene of the crime” as they say, and try to find out who did it. They do a number of things to try and find out what happened, depending on the case. It is not clear to the general public how they operate, but this is one thing specifically that they do in a time like this.

And that is the iconic “draw a line of chalk or special tape around the entire body”. They use chalk if the body is on the street, concrete, or something similar to that. And tape if the body is on the ground, grass or something like that. The outline of the chalk or tape, provides context for photographs of the crime scene, and assists investigators in preserving the evidence.

Modern investigators almost never have to use chalk or tape as outlines at crime scenes anymore. But because of music, visual arts, literature, or anything in pop culture that has to do with a crime investigation by the police, people still think that to this day.

annotation.plain:
Alternate versions of this song here include the repeated line “Ain’t no gangstas livin' in paradise”. These closing lines from LV have multiple levels of meaning:


No gangsters are actually living in a “paradise”. The paradise itself is non-existent and the use of the word is ironic.
In the “paradise”, none of the gangstas are living because they get killed through gang activity.
Paradise is an unobtainable state for a gangster; when they die, they go to hell for their crimes, not to paradise.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
But I ain’t never crossed a man that didn’t deserve it
 Me be treated like a punk, you know that’s unheard of

annotation.plain:
Leading on from the last line, his justification for his actions, although he and his mother recognise he’s beyond saving, is that who provoked his reaction never went unjustified.

Being “treated like a ‘punk’” means a lot of things. It could mean that he got crossed or a gun pointed at his face or he got snitched on. At least one of those things deserve immediate retaliation of certain death to the other party.

He has the mentality, because of his lifestyle and environment, that you can’t be pushed around when someone tests you. If someone over steps their boundaries or acts out of line, then there are consequences. This implies he lives around people that are criminals and do bad deeds – either hangs out with them or they are the type of people in his neighbourhood.

There was always a reason for him getting into fights and dealing with the situation. To survive where he’s from, it was necessary to put people in their place if they behaved in a way which is asking for trouble.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I take a look at my life and realize there’s nothin’ left
 ‘Cause I’ve been blastin’ and laughin’ so long that
 Even my mama thinks that my mind is gone

annotation.plain:
Coolio is saying he realizes that that there is nothing left for him in life. Because he has been messing around, wasting his life and doing nothing productive for so long that even the one person, his mother, that always believes he’s going to be successful and thinks nothing but the best of him, has given up hope on him. She was the last person who would ever give up on her son, but his behavior and lifestyle means that he’s beyond saving – likely leading only to him being behind bars or buried six feet underground.

Now that he has disappointed his mother and torn his relationship with her, Coolio feels a sense of emptiness. He feels abandoned by his own family and all the people who have ever loved him. He no longer has anything in his life to make him feel happy.

annotation.plain:
Gangsta’s Paradise is like a sand castle that crumbles easily. Some deluded themselves with the glories of the crime and dedicate their lives to it, but it is all in vain. A life of crime is short, a waste of life.



Both the chorus and refrain, which L.V. sings, are interpolations of Stevie Wonder’s track “Pastime Paradise”, whose instrumental is also interpolated for this track.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Instrumental Break]

annotation.plain:
The synthesized electric guitars during this section recall the sound of whale songs.  The deep ethereal sound of whale calls was a staple of late 1960s and 1970s music, where whale songs were frequently used to give music a mournful, angsty, unearthly, or psychedelic feel.  For a period of time, samples of whale songs were extremely popular.  The use of guitars to mimic this sound gives a nostalgic aspect to the song which plays with the lyrical idea of lost youth and halcyon days at the beach but also calls to mind the theme of transition from childhood to adulthood while reflecting back on teenage years.

https://www.pri.org/stories/2014-12-22/how-pop-music-helped-save-whales

 But babe, I’m gonna get you back

annotation.plain:
It seems like a wonderful and powerful relationship but somehow—like memories—it was fleeting and he doesn’t know or believe what happened to drive them apart.

This second verse of the song mirrors the second part of his life as portrayed in the video. At this point he’s still a young man with the confidence, drive, and sheer willpower to reconnect with her and take her back.

As he gets older his motivation will wane, and is described in the third verse.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Remember how you made me crazy?
 Remember how I made you scream?

annotation.plain:
His girl was able to make him go crazy. Crazy with lust, crazy with jealousy. It appears their sexual relationship was great though, with him possessing the prowess to make her scream in delight.

On the other hand, these lines don’t inevitably have a sexual connotation. Perhaps he’s looking back regretfully and remembering how angry he made her, which infuriated her to the point of screaming. which would also make sense with the upcoming lines about “not understanding” and vowing to win her back. One thing’s for sure, however… They had a very passionate relationship.

annotations.lyric_fragment:

annotation.plain: As he remembers those warm summer nights with his girl, he now wonders if it was real or a dream. Though the memories appear strong because he will never forget, they are such good memories that he questions the possibility of such a perfect time.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I thought I knew what love was, what did I know?
 Those days are gone forever
 I should just let them go but...

annotation.plain:
People in their youth always think they know everything about the world though only time and experience can really teach one about the myriad of emotions and experiences that make us human.  Sadly, once we are of an age where this all makes sense, we realize how wrong we were in the past.  Many of us soon regret the choices we made or the chances we never took.

He thought he was truly in love in his youth but now realizes that it was a fleeting thing amplified by the ignorance of youth.  He realizes that now as a much older man he must move on from these memories and live in the present.  However, the memories and the desire to feel that way again are too overwhelming.

Again he emphasizes this in the following chorus…

annotations.lyric_fragment:
But I can see you
 Your brown skin shining in the sun
 You got your hair combed back and your
 Sunglasses on, baby
 I can tell you, my love for you will still be strong
 After the boys of summer have gone

annotation.plain:
The shift from a past focus to the present brings the listener to the current state of the singer. It’s all about memories, but like all memories with strong emotions attached to them, this one is as vivid as if it were happening right now.

Though he knows it isn’t possible to reclaim the past, his wonderful memories of the past keep him revisiting it.  Specifically, a great love from a summer long past haunts him, impeding his ability to move on.

The imagery in the lyrics perfectly captures the feeling of youth and summerly love that eludes us as we age and become entrapped with the trials of life.

He feels that his love is so strong for another individual that it will conquer all and remain true even if she has her own experiences with others as many youth are wont to do. After she’s moved on from them or they’ve left her, he will remain, ever faithful and endearing.

Below: an example of the idealized memory he has:

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Nobody on the road
 Nobody on the beach
 I feel it in the air
 The summer’s out of reach
 Empty lake, empty streets
 The sun goes down alone
 I’m driving by your house
 Though I know you’re not home

annotation.plain:
This whole verse exhibits a conceptual ending to something.  Whether it was a specific event or period in one’s life, he uses the end of a summer to portray this concept.

The rhythm and melody of the song captures this emotion perfectly with the chosen lyrics.  One can imagine an empty beach, the smell and temperature of the air as the season changes and a once bustling vacation town now quiet after a summer season full of fun and excitement.

He’s getting older and losing more every year.  Reminiscing about past relationships and events he longs to reattain these things.  He tries to revisit old places in a vain attempt but knows it isn’t possible.

annotation.plain:
Age difference = 12-28 years

If this guy is 41, by the well-known code of relationship ethics, she should be no younger than…41 / 2 = 20 + 7 = 27 years old. Aino Jawo is 25, while Caroline Hjelt is 24.

However, if these girls had enough sense to follow socially accepted age guidelines, we wouldn’t have this badass song

This was written by Charli XCX, who was born in 1992. Caroline Hjelt and Aino Jawo of Icona Pop were born in 1987 and 1986, respectively.

Icona Pop commented on this line to Pitchfork:


Is the 70s line about an older man?

AJ: Yeah, it was this older, gorgeous man. It’s about having different opinions, and when you’re in love you can sometimes see them as beautiful. But that line is more about: “I’m fed up of your stories about what you will be like when you get older.”

CH: You won’t get smarter.

AJ: Age ain’t nothing but a number.
