annotations.lyric_fragment: (Fuck off!) Oh no!

annotation.plain:
As per Ray Davies' autobiographical performance The Storyteller, the “OH NO!” was overdubbed to drown out Dave Davies telling his older brother to “FUCK OFF!” right before taking the solo.

If you doubt me, if you doubt what I’m saying, I challenge you to listen to the original Kinks recording of ‘You really got me’. Halfway through the song, after the second chorus, before the guitar solo, there’s a drum break. Boo ka, boo boo ka, boo ka, boo boo. And in the background you can hear “Fuck off!”. You can, you can. When I did the vocal I tried to cover it up by going “Oh no”, but in the background you still hear it, “Fuck off”. And it’s even clearer on CD, it’s really embarrassing.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Guitar Solo]

annotation.plain: The entire guitar on this song, done by a 17 year old Dave Davies, was altered when he sliced the speaker cone of his amplifier with a razor blade. This gave it a heavier distorted sound. The guitar solo, however, is highly controversial. Supposedly, the solo was played by Jimmy Page of the Yardbirds and Led Zeppelin, rather than Davies. Jon Lord of Deep Purple has comfirmed this myth, as he played piano in the song. Page himself, however, denies ever playing the solo. So the world may never know.

Using the “got me” phrase he indicates that she both has him in her “web” and is able to cause him to do and feel things.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I can make the bad guys good for a weekend

annotation.plain:
This line is in reference to how the media commonly portrays Taylor as a woman who is good at attracting men but not good at keeping them around (at the time of writing this song she hadn’t had a relationship that lasted longer than a few months).
Swift references this in Shake It Off:

I go on too many dates (Haha)
But I can’t make them stay

annotations.lyric_fragment: ’Cause you know I love the players

annotation.plain:
As explained on Urban Dictionary:

Usually a boy who makes you feel special. He makes you feel like you are the only girl in his life, when really you are just one in 100.
They flirt with other people, not just you. They talk to you all day, then the next day they ignore you. They send you mixed messages, and your not sure whether he likes you or not?
You can’t keep your mind off him, even though you know your nothing to him.

She’s saying here that she’s attracted to men who want to hurt her – or, at the very least, don’t care if they do. This further illustrates the comically toxic relationship described here.

annotations.lyric_fragment: ”Oh, my God, look at that face

annotation.plain:
A similar line appears in Swift’s 2017 song, “Gorgeous”:

I can’t say anything to your face
‘Cause look at your face

This line is intentionally objectifying. Swift says “that face” rather than “your face” – while this is a common turn of phrase, and not out of place, it also subtly disconnects her attraction from the person she’s singing about. In doing so, she mocks the perception that she lacks a real connection with the men she dates.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
So it’s gonna be forever
 Or it’s gonna go down in flames?

annotation.plain:
Swift’s black-and-white thinking emphasizes her character’s passionate mindset. It’s a sharp departure from “Begin Again,” the closing track of her October 2012 album, Red:

I’ve been spending the last eight months
Thinking all love ever does is break and burn and end
But on a Wednesday in a cafe, I watched it begin again

Swift uses similar wording to describe a relationship’s potential on “Style,” the next track on 1989:

Could end in burning flames or paradise

It’s also important to note the quick juxtaposition, which is a key feature of this song’s lyrics.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Love’s a game, wanna play?” Ayy

annotation.plain:
Comparing love to a game eventually became a motif in Swift’s discography. She first did this on October 2012’s “State of Grace”:

Love is a ruthless game
Unless you play it good and right

She compared flirtation to poker on the later 1989 track “New Romantics”:

It’s poker, he can’t see it in my face
But I’m about to play my ace

The poker metaphor returned on November 2017’s “End Game”:

You’ve been calling my bluff on all my usual tricks

On August 2019’s “Cornelia Street,” she used cheating at a card game as a metaphor for being secretive about true feelings:

Back when we were card sharks, playing games
I thought you were leading me on

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You can tell me when it’s over, mm
 If the high was worth the pain

annotation.plain:
Taylor compares a high from using drugs to the pleasant part of a relationship: it’s nice while it lasts, but it will eventually fade. This was the first time Taylor referenced drugs in her music — she later did so on 2017’s “Don’t Blame Me,” another satire on the public’s perception of her love life:


Lord save me, my drug is my baby
I’ll be using for the rest of my life

I get so high, oh
Every time you’re, every time you’re lovin' me

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Boys only want love if it’s torture
 Don’t say I didn’t, say I didn’t warn ya
 Boys only want love if it’s torture
 Don’t say I didn’t, say I didn’t warn ya

annotation.plain:
Boys are often intrigued by mystery and drama; they don’t want “boring” good girls. She is thus warning her potential lover that he mustn’t expect her to be sweet and the relationship to be easy. If he enters into something with her, he must be prepared for a crazy ride. Swift uses the word “boy” purposefully to allude to a lack of maturity by her former partners.

Unlike in past songs about bad boys breaking her heart, such as “I Knew You Were Trouble”, she’s the bad girl that will break his.

Swift explained this lyric to The Sun:

I was thinking about this. Boys only want love if it’s torture and a constant chase. Men want love if it’s real, right, healthy and consistent.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
But you’ll come back each time you leave
 ’Cause, darling, I’m a nightmare dressed like a daydream

annotation.plain:
Swift also mentions both “night” and “dream” can be seen on another 1989 track, “New Romantics”:

And every day is like a battle
But every night with us is like a dream

As with the rest of the verse, these lines are meant to be viewed ironically. She is illustrating herself in the way the media often does.

In this case, she is portrayed to be someone who lures men in with her good looks but once they enter into a relationship with her she becomes crazy and obsessive – and it is like a nightmare rather than what her current significant other might have perceived her to be.



Also, of course, nightmare is recurring and terrible whereas a daydream is usually short and pleasant. Their love might seem short and pleasant, but realistically? It’s going to come back and haunt you.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Wait, the worst is yet to come, oh, no

annotation.plain:
This alludes to the rumors which claim that Swift is a crazy and psycho girlfriend. She states that although she may seem pretty on the outside, like a rose garden, she is actually very dangerous and you will get hurt if you mess with her. She illustrates that the relationship will be a messy one, and her lover should be prepared for that. She may come off as naive, but internally she is a dominant female.

Swift very clearly states that she is capable of many things. So, in many cases, this would be the perfect storm of “crying” (rain) and “screaming” (thunder). This isn’t the only time Taylor discusses “perfect storms” on 1989 — she does the same on “Clean,” the last track of the album’s standard edition.

She illustrates the imagery into your head:  she is a psychotic girlfriend.

The imagery of a rose garden is reminiscent of a panel from her music video for “Our Song.”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Find out what you want
 Be that girl for a month

annotation.plain:
Rumors have gone around that Taylor will change who she is in order to impress a guy. The media essentially says she will do anything for a guy. This subtle innuendo calls them out while mocking the public’s belief that her relationships are short-lived.

This lyric can also be taken feministically. Even though for a period of time, Swift may lead the boy on thinking he is dominant in the relationship, she will come back and claim her place as the queen.

Emphasizing that even though this person causes a physical reaction in her, she understands and need this person to understand that what they are both feeling, is a normal reaction of two people physically attracted to each other excited that they are interacting with each other.

annotation.plain: Since she was hurt in loving relationship so she is now avoiding this feeling as this scares her. She is kinda protecting herself by not falling in love again.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
There’s a phrase that fits
 But whatever the reason, you do it for me

annotation.plain:
There’s a term or phrase that fits exactly what he is or is trying to do. Whatever the reason that this man is doing what he is, whether he truly likes her and wants to be with her or is just trying to get her to bed, he does it anyways for her. Maybe he’s “doing it” as in he qualifies for her.

Much how like someone who is satisfied will say “that’ll do it” translating to “that’s sufficient enough” or “it’ll suffice” all meaning it’s good enough. Or maybe, he “does it” as in his reason is enough for him to keep trying to do what he does for her.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
If I tend to look dazed, I’ve read it someplace
 I’ve got cause to be
 
 [Pre-Chorus 2]
 There’s a name for it

annotation.plain: If she DOES look confused,it’s because she’s read it somewhere before. Whether she means literally “read” as in a book, or “read” as in she “read” the expression or actions of a guy before and she can compare them to the man now. She has probable cause to act the way she does. She has proof and evidence that this could be nothing more than just another “show” or “act” to win her over. There’s the risk of her getting hurt.

annotations.lyric_fragment: It may seem to you that I’m acting confused

annotation.plain: Tina has seen it all before, she claims she might seem confused to what he says or does. She could be just acting like she’s never heard it all. Better to be “safe than sorry.”

annotations.lyric_fragment: What’s love got to do, got to do with it?

annotation.plain: If it’s just a physical attraction, why is there talk of love? What love? She doesn’t want to get involved in love. She’s most likely had bad experiences with love before and maybe she’s afraid or not willing to try it again. What does love have to do with all this?

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You must understand, oh, the touch of your hand
 Makes my pulse react

annotation.plain: The touch of his hand makes her heart rate start to react abnormally. Maybe she feels nervous or her heart already knows what the risks could be. Maybe now just a touch, but later on it could end in a heart break.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
What’s love got to do, got to do with it?
 Who needs a heart when a heart can be broken?

annotation.plain: Perhaps having suffered heartbreak before, Tina fears the way love makes one vulnerable. So she asks the rhetorical question in a tough-skinned, practical manner.

We in the bed like, ooh, ooh, ooh, woah, woah, ooh, ooh
 We in the bed like, ooh, ooh, woah, ooh, woah, woah, ooh, ooh, woah

annotation.plain:
We’ve all heard the idiom “actions speak louder than words”, however, in T-Pain’s case, melodies do too. He uses onomatopoeia to emulate the sounds his woman makes during sex, and the rhythm also mimics their lovemaking. This suggests that this girl is in for a long and sensual experience if she chooses to stay the night.

Many artists have since followed suit, using similar techniques to describe sex:

Bring a girlfriend, man, trouble when I see her
“Err-err-err-err”: onomatopoeia

But I have to respect how you play the game of baseball.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7mGqkPADUEQ
Starts around 2:48.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Call me (Call me), call me for your lover’s lover’s alibi

annotation.plain: Blondie has two other songs either narrated as a call girl “X Offender” or addressing one “In the Flesh”.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Dress me in the fashions of the 1980s

annotation.plain:
The late 70’s and early 80’s fashion was a transitional one. It ranged between the preppy



to the freaky look.



If her lover is a fashion designer, the next line may contradict the image one has from this line…

annotations.lyric_fragment: You’re a man, no in-between

annotation.plain:
A not exactly politically correct statement, especially in the current view of sexes and gender role.

The lyricist alludes to a notion that her “man” may be considered by some not “manly” – effeminate? Considering the 80’s outfits she mentions earlier – there may be a reason for this assumption…



Since she knows for sure that he is no “in between”, she is not shy of declaring it.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Emotions come, I don’t know why
 Cover up love’s alibi

annotation.plain:
These two lines should be considered as one sentence.

One could read it – “I don’t know why (we should) cover up lover’s alibi, (when) emotions come”.

Lover’s alibi is an unconditional, “no excuse” love, that needs no defense.

Hear Debbie Harry declares that since the love is so strong, even when emotional/upset/confused – one has no reason to hide it (behind “coloring”, for example).

The term has been used in One Republic’s All We Are.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Roll me in designer sheets, I’ll never get enough

annotation.plain:
A thinly veiled hint of an impending sexual contact. Not surprising, since it is assumed that the song is narrated by a call girl. However, it just as well does not exclude the possibility of a promise for a “happy ending” of an impending date.

The “designer sheets” reference ties up with the film’s (American Gigolo) where Richard Gere’s character’s clients are rich enough to use designer sheets.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Call me (Call me) on the line

annotation.plain: It was much simpler back in the early 80’s – “on the line” had one meaning – by phone, in contrast to days myriad  ways of communication, where “on line” means something else altogether.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Come up off your color chart

annotation.plain:
Now the colors are a metaphor for moods, a ranking system the narrator attributes to the person she addresses.

One would expect her asking him to “come off his high horse” for example, but Debbie Harry cleverly builds up on the mysterious “color me” theme she has created in the previous lines.

songs.lyrics:

annotation.plain: It feels like Miley is expressing this intense longing and attachment to someone, despite whatever might have happened between them. It’s like she’s saying, “I may have left, but that doesn’t mean I stopped caring about you” It’s that bittersweet mix of love and pain. Sometimes you need to leave for your own mental health and thats what Miley did, But leaving doesn’t always mean all your feelings are lost and thats why she’s trying to say, sometimes toxic partners will use the excuses, like “Well you left” as an excuse for their bad or toxic behavior, But Miley is admitting she never stopped caring or loving for this person so their excuse is invalid.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I came in like a wrecking ball

annotation.plain:
The “wrecking ball” is a common image used in popular music. Bruce Springsteen and Emmylou Harris both released albums titled Wrecking Ball, and Neil Young wrote a song of the same name.

The word Wreck comes from Reka, which in Old Norse is to drive or push. In the 15th century the word Shipwreck was first used, and that is how the word Wreck as we know it came about.



While several wrecking ball companies have claimed to have been the inventors of the technology, Henry Bath & Co are responsible for the first documented use of one in 1888-1889. Henry and Bath was founded in 1794 and is based out of Liverpool.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Pre-Chorus]

annotation.plain: The pre-chorus also reflects how Miley went through a big change once Hannah Montana ended and she changed drastically, from a haircut to an overall change in attitude and persona. This also coincided with the end of her relationship with Liam Hemsworth, and it was rumored that her change in attitude was one cause for the break up – Liam may not have liked who she was becoming and she didn’t want to be living in a lie. Miley is the type of person who will not, under any circumstances be someone she is not and that may have been how she was feeling towards the end of the relationship after the change.

annotation.plain:
At this part in the song we can hear a sudden shift from a whisper to a scream. This technique provides some of the most powerful moments in pop music. Its technical term is a vocal crescendo.

Miley has a vocal range of 3 octaves, from approximately C#3- E6, which is impressive. She touts her vocal chops throughout the song, by constantly changing her voice.

For other examples of this trick, see Oasis’s “Wonderwall,” Fountains of Wayne’s “Mexican Wine,” and Fall Out Boy’s “Sugar Were Going Down Swinging.”

In 2014, a physicist published a paper in The Journal of Interdisciplinary Science Topics titled “The Viability of coming in like a Wrecking Ball,” in which he analyzed whether or not “such a feat is possible.” It’s not…

annotation.plain:
In Greek mythology, Daedalus constructs wings so that he and his son, Icarus, can escape from Crete. Daedalus warns Icarus that flying too close to the sun will cause his wings to melt. Icarus becomes too excited by his ability to fly that he ignores his father and tragically falls to his death.



Similarly, Miley’s lover becomes too arrogant, and, like Icarus, their relationship is reduced to “ashes on the ground.”

annotation.plain:
While Miley and Liam had their fair share of ups and downs, the two ultimately split after rumors began to circulate that Hemsworth had cheated on Cyrus with Mad Men star January Jones. The “lie” Miley sings about here could be related to this scandal.



Similarly, in her song “Drive,” Miley sings about the deterioration of a relationship, ultimately concluding that it was “all just a lie,”

You acted like you wanted this
But then you led me on
I thought you would be there when I go
You promised you would be there when I go
But all broken promises I won’t miss, I’m finished
Underneath, all I know are the facts
When I look you in the eyes, all I see are the lies
Been there done that

In any given year there is a 6% chance there will be infidelity. That rises to 25% if you measure the chance of infidelity over the course of the entirety of your relationship. Miley happened to be one of the unlucky ones.

Some of the most famous affairs include John F. Kennedy and Marilyn Monroe, Franklin D. Roosevelt with Lucy Mercer, and Bill Clinton with Monica Lewinsky.

annotation.plain:
Miley attempted to break into her lover’s heart, but was ultimately left heart-broken.

Note the switch in tone here–Miley admits her fault for the first time and concedes that the relationship is finished.



Miley started an unintended war with Sinéad O'Connor, whose video for “Nothing Compares 2 U” inspired the video for this song. Sinéad responded with a harsh open letter:

You will obscure your talent by allowing yourself to be pimped, whether it’s the music business or yourself doing the pimping.

Wars have been started over fur (The Pemmican War in 1811), a golden stool (The War of the Golden Stool in 1900), and honey (The honey war in the 1830’s).

annotation.plain:
It is rumored that this song is directed at Miley’s former fiancé Liam Hemsworth. The two met when Miley was only 16 years old and were on-again, off-again for much of their relationship. Miley was 20 when she released this song.



Others believe the song serves as a response to former beau and “first love” Nick Jonas’s remorseful love song, “Wedding Bells”.



At this point in the video, there is a closeup on Miley’s face. Her natural eye color is darkish blue, but she has worn light blue colored contacts in the past, yet it seems as if she’s sporting her natural eye color here. As for her lipstick, it’s Sephora’s Cream Lip Stain in Always Red. You can cop it for $12 exclusively at your local Sephora.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I came in like a wrecking ball
 I never hit so hard in love
 All I wanted was to break your walls
 All you ever did was wreck me
 Yeah, you, you wreck me

annotation.plain:
Newton’s third law says that every action has an equal and opposite reaction. Here, Miley uses the image of a wrecking ball as a metaphor for the strength required to break through her lover’s emotional barriers. In turn, her lover releases the same amount of force to destroy their relationship. Miley swinging on this wrecking ball would exert approximately 198,000 newtons—in other words, Miley’s wrecking ball could push a wall (or Hemsworth) with as much force as a 747 engine. A wrecking ball like the one in the video is about 1000 pounds while Miley is around 105 pounds.

She threw herself into the relationship like a wrecking ball. She wanted it so bad. She felt like she needed it. It was different from her other relationships. And why she came in so hard, she thought she would be able to understand him more and he would be himself and let her in his life. She didn’t hold back her feelings, and in the end, both (specially her) were destroyed as if hit by demolition equipment.

annotation.plain:
The repetitive lyrics are a characteristic of the music genre Bubblegum Pop, or Rock, or Music that made its mark between the years 1967 and 1972.

Most groups were faceless studio artists and the songs had very catchy, simple light tunes with easy to memorize (and even easier to grasp) lyrics, that appealed to teenagers by their “catchiness”, and by the facts that most songs came as singles – i.e. – demanded the smallest possible expense for music.

annotation.plain:
“Get Ur Freak On” marked Elliott’s first music video collaboration without Hype Williams, the creative mind behind her trademark futuristic look. The problem was, Elliott didn’t want a trademark and was already feeling pigeonholed to fit the image that was expertly laid out for her in Williams' videos.

“You see, I change my music and I change my image at the same time. I felt like as long as me and Hype continued to work together we would probably keep it going in the same kinda of direction,” she told interviewer Amy Linden.

Instead, she worked with Dave Meyers, who would be her “go-to” for her next ten music visuals. She was definitely on some new shit.

Dave Meyers is “another prolific director known for his work on Outkast’s ‘So Fresh, So Clean’ video,” according to SongFacts.com.

annotation.plain:
Missy is not just whistling Dixie: her star, surprise performance on the heels of Katy Perry in the 2015 Super Bowl halftime show caused this song to return to the Billboard Hot 100 the following week (#40), after being off the top chart for more than a decade. Missy was correct when she mentioned that her revival on the airwaves has s got the radio shook and people are sweating her when she’s not live on stage.

Missy “Misdemeanor” Elliott’s ability to constantly reinvent herself and provide hot new dance rhythms may be what keeps her hot for another twenty years:

annotations.lyric_fragment: Stay in one spot, another day of monotony’s gotten me

annotation.plain: Here, Em says that he’s stuck in life. Monotony is the repetition or invariance of schedule or action. So, Em is saying he’s doing the same thing,  and isn’t able to change.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You can do anything you set your mind to, man

annotation.plain: Eminem has become a cultural icon and a symbol of resilience and determination. His rags-to-riches story, coupled with his unapologetic attitude and unwavering dedication to his craft, has inspired countless individuals to pursue their dreams despite the odds. Eminem’s influence can be felt not only in the music world but also in popular culture, where his name has become synonymous with excellence and authenticity. Source

annotations.lyric_fragment: He’s dope, he knows that, but he’s broke, he’s so stagnant

annotation.plain: At this point in Eminem’s biographical timeline and the 8 Mile narrative, he is conscious that he is a prodigy and a gifted rapper. However, he is writing from a point when he has yet to find success, is financially unstable, and is stuck in his situation.

annotations.lyric_fragment: He knows when he goes back to this mobile home,

annotation.plain:
At the beginning of the film 8 Mile, Eminem’s character, Jimmy “B-Rabbit” Smith moves back into his mother’s mobile home at 8 Mile Mobile Court due to his financial struggles. This was filmed at A&L Mobile Home Park in Warren, Michigan.



This location is once again alluded to in Verse 3:

Mom, I love you, but this trailer’s got
To go, I cannot grow old in Salem’s Lot

This characterization of “B-Rabbit” is true to Eminem’s real-life experiences; in 1997, he was forced to move into his mother’s mobile home after getting fired from his minimum wage restaurant job.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
God only knows he’s grown farther from home, he’s no father
 He goes home and barely knows his own daughter

annotation.plain: Maybe people are just thinking father rhymes with daughter or something. But it’s about repeating a pattern. The trick is to get the pattern to hit on the same beat—“grown farther,” “own daughter,” the “knows” and “goes,” like that.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
’Cause, man, these goddamn food stamps don’t buy diapers
 And there’s no movie, there’s no Mekhi Phifer, this is my life

annotation.plain:
Putting the name of the actor right there in the lead single was just about the rhymes. I had started with this syllable scheme — “somebody’s paying the pied piper” and “Mekhi Phifer” ended up fitting. That was all it was.

That was one of those songs where I remember telling Paul, “I don’t know how to write about someone else’s life.” Because the movie is not me, the movie is Jimmy Smith Jr. So I’m playing this character, but I have to make parallels between my life and his, in this song. I gotta figure out how to reach a medium. It would sound so corny if I was just rapping as Jimmy Smith Jr. How is that going to come from a real place?

If I’m telling you that my daughter doesn’t have diapers, I need this amount of money to pay my bills this month, and it’s some real shit I’m telling you, then you know that it’s just coming from me. That was the trick I had to figure out — how to make the rhyme sound like him, and then morph into me somehow, so you see the parallels between his struggles and mine.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
His palms are sweaty, knees weak, arms are heavy
 There’s vomit on his sweater already, mom’s spaghetti

annotation.plain: The first verse is all about Jimmy Smith Jr. It’s me talking about Jimmy Smith Jr.—like, I’m not saying my sweater, I’m saying his. I’m trying to show you what his life is about.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Intro]

annotation.plain:
When we were making 8 Mile, I was revisiting this old CD from two years before, going through old loops. I found the “Lose Yourself” demo on this session where me and Jeff Bass were just making beats. Jeff was just sitting on those guitar chords, and then it went into something different. I was just like “Yo, that section, right there, I gotta make a beat out of that.” I recorded the demo version of it the same day I made the beat. I didn’t like the rhyme, and put it off to the side.

But it’s one of those beats I never gave up on. That beat was definitely a highlight of my producing. I ended up doing the new version on the set of the movie, just writing between takes.

8 Mile wasn’t coming out for another year and a half, and Curtis really wanted music for the movie. He wanted it to be created from the environment, so he was pushing me to make stuff. I think “Lose Yourself” was the only thing I worked on specifically for the movie.

We filmed half of it in the dead of winter. We had a music trailer on set, designed like a studio. One trailer was music, and we had another with gym equipment in it.

We were on lunch break, and I needed to finish the track. I don’t think it was one take all the way down, but it was one take each verse. “Got the first verse, okay, punch me in at the second. OK, the whole third verse.” For some reason, I just captured something there that I didn’t want to change. I remember trying to change it and go back and re-do the vocals, and I was like “Yo, let me listen to the old ones? Just keep the old ones, fuck it.”

annotations.lyric_fragment: Homie grows hotter, he blows, it’s all over

annotation.plain: As he gains more fame, girls, and respect, it becomes even more disastrous to lose it all by going soft. Em is emphasizing his near-meltdown state. Like a volcano; there is a destructive potential lurking deep within him, and he has to learn how to constructively channel it.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
This world is mine for the taking, make me king
 As we move toward a new world order

annotation.plain:
Eminem is NOT rapping about the Illuminati here. The king of controversy just used that as a metaphor to show he is going to change the game once he is recognized as the best (and made king).

This line also relates the end of 8 Mile when Rabbit defeats  his three final rap battle opponents, all members of a group who call themselves “Leaders of the Free World.” He defeats them and is on his way to becoming the king of hip-hop, ushering in a “new world order.”

annotations.lyric_fragment: ‘Cause when I leave for the night, I ain’t comin’ back

annotation.plain:
The first four lines bear striking resemblance (in meter, rhyme, diction and subject matter) to a verse of Jonathan Swift:

As clever Tom Clinch, while the Rabble was bawling
Rode stately though Holbourn to die in his Calling;
He stopt at the George for a bottle of Sack,
And promis’d to pay for it when he came back

The next six lines are not unrelated either—they discuss the dress of Tom Clinch and his popularity with the ladies.

Swift’s verse references an unfortunately common sight in Georgian England: condemned men, on their way to be hung at the gallows at Tyburn, were given something of a triumph by the crowds. They went dressed in white suits, ribbons hanging from their hats, flowers clutched in their hands. The crowd favoured the brave and cocky (as discussed in chapter 2 of The Fatal Shore).

What does that say about Kesha, especially in light of the sexual and emotional abuse she suffered on her rise to stardom? This first stanza shows us a girl who’s carefree and ready to party, but when she hits the city tonight, she’s condemned to die, never again coming back to her previous self. Like Jonathan Swift, Kesha explores these troubling ideas veiled with satire and ridicule.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Tonight, I’ma fight ’til we see the sunlight

annotation.plain:
This fight is a quite obvious nod to the Beastie Boys' “(You Gotta) Fight for Your Right (To Party)”.



She covered this song in her Get $leazy tour in direct juxtaposition to TiK ToK, and she’s cited the Beastie Boys as one of her musical influences. In an interview with The New York Times, she says:

I love the Beastie Boys—that’s probably why ‘TiK ToK’ happened […] Rap in general has never been my steez, but I like it.

Ke$ha is clearly writing within the tradition that the Beastie Boys set in the 80s.

It’s worth noting the importance of having this allusion in her first single. The Beastie Boys ushered in a certain level of acceptance/appropriation of white people in rap/hip-hop music and culture. Ke$ha’s sing/talk style and flow may be taken as an attempt to enter into the rap scene as a white female, and the parallel with the Beastie Boys helps situate Ke$ha’s relationship with the music she’s putting out.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’m talkin’ ‘bout everybody gettin’ crunk (Crunk)
 Boys try to touch my junk (Junk)

annotation.plain: Crazy, hyped up. Also an allusion, of course, to the crunk genre. With any luck they were drinking out of crunk cups.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Now, the party don’t start ’til I walk in

annotation.plain:
Ke$ha is stating that she is basically the life of the party and that nothing is complete without her.

This is also a recycled line from Whodini’s classic song, “Five Minutes of Funk”.

annotations.lyric_fragment: (Hey, what up, girl?)

annotation.plain:
This is P Diddy saluting Kesha (or maybe it’s supposed to represent Kesha as P Diddy macking on girls).

In an interview, Kesha revealed that Puff said the phrase for free, as a favor.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Grab my glasses, I’m out the door, I’m gonna hit this city

annotation.plain:
The literal meaning is straight-forward: Ke$ha puts on her glasses (probably sunglasses) to get ready to party around the city.

On a metaphorical level, the speaker is clearly impaired and intoxicated as evidenced by her diminished sense of self perception. “Grab my glasses,” in this case, is the natural reaction—her vision is blurred, and she’s dizzy. Despite the fact that these are, quite clearly, the effects of alcohol overindulgence, she attempts to correct her problem with an external tool. She tries to treat the symptoms, hoping the glasses will adjust her debilitated vision, but never addresses the real issue, her inebriation.

Taking alcohol to be a symbolism for an abusive relationship, it becomes easy to understand what the lyric self is going through. This negative relationship has had a such a strong grip on her for such a long time that, even after being rested, she still feels out of place as soon as she wakes up in the morning—she’s no longer who she used to be. She understands the suffering because it is being experienced on a personal level, but perhaps in fear to blame her abusive relationship for her perilous predicament, she seeks out temporary and external remedies, symbolized by the glasses, in order to palliate her impairment. It is even possible that the same glasses, futile in the correction of her folly, serve as mask that conceals the abuse she has experienced.

As the lyrics continue, the profile of the speaker as a victim of abuse becomes even clearer. After she grabs her glasses, she’s “out the door, I’m gonna hit this city.” On the literal level, this is a young woman who, as we find out later on in the song, is destitute (“ain’t got no money in my pocket”) and non-influential in her community. Claiming to hit the city, in its entirety, is a hyperbole that evokes a stark contrast between who she claims to be and who she really is.

This dichotomy, which from the very beginning is a leitmotif, leads the audience to ponder the deeper meaning behind the song. The upbeat rhythm coupled with the “I’m on top of the world” words is nothing but an inflated sense of confidence that serves as a disguise for the unbearably painful environment of abuse in which the speaker currently resides. Though she may look and act like she is about to “hit this city,” this boastful attitude is nothing but an attempt to make up for the sense of belonging she lacks.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Wake up in the mornin’ feelin’ like P. Diddy

annotation.plain:
The song starts with the iconic statement where the speaker declares she “wake[s] up in the morning feeling like P. Diddy,” a famous rapper.

Ke$ha, the author of the lyrics, takes pride in her country roots that have taught her how to tell a story through music, but the reason for placing this phrase as the opening of the song goes beyond mere chronological order. Much like George Orwell’s “all the clocks were striking thirteen” in 1984, the comparison between the speaker, a woman, and a rich black man is striking enough to set the tone for the rest of the song. This same tone of irony that makes everything seem out of place is what drives the underlying theme of the song, the duality of what is felt and what is expressed. The speaker is hung over from a night of late partying and wakes up confused, hazed, and feeling like a rap mogul instead of feeling like her true self. (and given her possibly hungover status, she’s even puffy, Diddy’s nickname)

In an interview to Esquire, Ke$ha explains the literal, non-metaphorical meaning of her first line:

One morning I just woke up, and I live in this house with I-don’t-even-know-how-many roommates – it’s this Laurel Canyon house with seven rooms and roommates fluctuating monthly […] Well it was the house The Eagles recorded Hotel California in. So it’s just this huge hippy… There are a bunch of hippies who come in and out, and there are all these people sleeping on the couches. I don’t really care, I don’t mind it. But I woke up one day after we went to a party, and I was surrounded by ten of the most beautiful women you’ve ever seen. And I was like, I’m like P. Diddy – there’s no man like this in the entire world. So that became the first line of the new single, and we just went from there.



As is explained in the refrain, this song, as a whole, is a nod to the Beastie Boys' “Fight For Your Right.” The first line of TiK ToK alludes to [the first line in the Beastie Boys' song, “You wake up late for school”. That, in turn, follows a longer-standing tradition of starting lines. Some Blues songs start with the phrase “I woke up this morning” before listing a list of woes/tragedies in a godless, abandoned world. This traces back further to the starting statement “The Lord woke me up this morning” that is recurrent in black gospel music. The book Woke Me Up This Morning: Black Gospel Singers and the Gospel Life explains this trope at length.

It’s no coincidence that both Ke$ha and the Beastie Boys allude to this phrase, along with their own take on it. As they, white artists, are entering a black-dominated music genre (namely rap/hip-hop), having this connection establishes their recognition of hip-hop roots and acknowledges the rich tradition that precedes them.

During a performance at Coachella 2024, Ke$ha changed this opening lyric:

Wake up in the morning like, “f*** P. Diddy”

This change was in a response to Diddy’s physical violence, sexual abuse, and sex trafficking charges, after his two houses were raided by law enforcement, for the foretold matter.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Before I leave, brush my teeth with a bottle of Jack

annotation.plain:
This line oddly caused a bit of controversy, enough of such to where Kesha had to respond:

Everyone’s really offended by [the Jack Daniel’s line in ‘TiK ToK’]. But come on, brushing your teeth with Jack Daniel’s – What girl does that? People are like, ‘Do you really advocate brushing your teeth with bourbon?’ I’m like, ‘Yes, actually, I do, every day, for everybody. Especially 8-year-olds’. I mean, what are you talking about? Of course I don’t. Come on.

Kesha may have taken inspiration from Jason Schwartzman brushing his teeth and rinsing with some Jack in the video for Phantom Planet’s “California,” the theme song for The O. C.

annotations.lyric_fragment: But we kick ’em to the curb unless they look like Mick Jagger

annotation.plain: This line underlines the subtle satire of the partying lifestyle that runs throughout this song and much of Ke$ha’s other music, all while being somewhat serious. Because let’s not forget that Mick Jagger used to be a rock ‘n’ roll sex symbol.

annotation.plain:
The sentiment stated in these lines and repeated throughout the song is that the narrator is hopelessly in love with this girl, and he is past the point of being able to pull back or move on. He goes on to explain that he couldn’t stop loving her even if he wanted to or tried to.

This idea is written about in many love songs such as “I Can’t Help Falling in Love” by Elvis.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
As he rises to her apology
 Anybody else would surely know
 He’s watching her go

annotation.plain:
Her “apology” in this instance is her stating “I’m sorry” as she stands excuses herself from the conversation to leave. He stands as well.
We (non-fools) know that this is the last time she’ll entertain his request to meet. He still hopes they will meet again.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Keeps sending him somewhere back in her long ago
 Where he can still believe there’s a place in her life
 Someday, somewhere
 She will return

annotation.plain: Even though nothing ever came from his long-ago crush on this girl, he still enjoys reminiscing about a time where there was still a chance that she would finally reciprocate his feelings for her.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
But what a fool believes, he sees
 No wise man has the power to reason away
 What seems to be
 Is always better than nothing
 Than nothing at all

annotation.plain:
No matter how “smart” you think you are, love/a crush can blind you to what’s really going on. You won’t try to rationally analyze the scenario to realize the feeling isn’t mutual. Thinking someone may feel the same for you is better than knowing nobody does.

When someone is in denial such as the man in the story, no one can tell him otherwise. To the ‘fool’, having some kind of relationship is better than coming to the realization that there isn’t any relationship and that it is only a desire that cannot be satisfied.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
She had a place in his life
 He never made her think twice

annotation.plain:
He admired her so much that he considered her a big part of his life, even though they never had a relationship.

She only acknowledged that he had a thing for her, but didn’t reciprocate the feeling.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
She musters a smile for his nostalgic tale
 Never coming near what he wanted to say
 Only to realize it never really was

annotation.plain:
Depending on the perspective taken, there are different possible interpretations of this verse. From the woman’s perspective, she is humouring this man while he talks about their shared past, but is coming to realise that what they had doesn’t really mean anything to her and there’s no reason to prolong their reunion.

From the man’s perspective, this introduces the theme of denial. It is significant that he is talking around the real reason he is meeting with her (he wants to get back together with her) rather than coming right out and saying it. He’s bringing up their shared past to try and trigger some kind of response or revival of her feelings towards him, but as he does so it’s becoming clear that she has no feelings towards him – and yet he continues regardless.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Tryin’ hard to recreate
 What had yet to be created once in her life

annotation.plain: He is trying to recreate a relationship that never existed to her. She probably saw him as nothing more than an an acquaintance but he saw it as something more.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
He came from somewhere back in her long ago
 The sentimental fool don’t see

annotation.plain: He’s meeting with her. They were together in the past.  But he’s too stupid or still in love with her to see that this meeting has no hope of ending in a rekindling of their long-ago relationship.

 We’ll give it a shot”

annotation.plain: Although sounding like the same sentence, “we’ve got each other and that’s a lot” and “for love, we’ll give it a shot” may be on a different sentence. The first one means that, despite all the disgrace they’re living, they have each other, and that, off course, is a lot, considering some do not have others help. The second one tells us that “For love” you should “give it a shot”, not only love for your partner, but for yourself as well. Meaning all deserve better, even though it may take a lot from you, you should give it a try.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Woah, we’re halfway there

annotation.plain: Bon Jovi does not hide the optimism in some songs. Livin' on a Prayer is pretty much about it, although, using a bitty reality. The sentence “We’re halfway there” indicates that just by being alive you are already on your way to succeed, once the characters are already in a doomed condition and escaping this problem depends on themselves.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Tommy’s got his six-string in hock

annotation.plain: “in hock” refers to something being in a pawn shop, meaning that the situation has become dire enough that Tommy was forced to pawn his beloved guitar for money.

annotation.plain:
Songwriter Desmond Child told People:

I was thinking about the early hungry years in N.Y.C. in the late 1970s with my girlfriend, Maria Vidal, who was also co-founder of our band, Desmond Child & Rouge. Maria worked as a singing waitress at a joint called Once Upon a Stove, where they named her Gina Velvet. I stayed home writing songs and she worked “to bring home her pay for love.”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
When he used to make it talk
 So tough
 Ooh, it’s tough
 Gina dreams of runnin’ away
 When she cries in the night, Tommy whispers
 ”Baby, it’s okay
 Someday”

annotation.plain:
Tommy once used his guitar to express himself, now he’s holding in because of the tough times around him.

Gina has no intention of leaving Tommy. She dreams that one day they both will be able to leave their dead end town. Their finances, alas, do not allow that to happen, thus her late night tears. But, Tommy is a good man. He always encourages Gina. “Someday”, he says. Someday they will be on the road (heading west, the direction of the American Dream!) and in a better town. One with opportunities.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Once upon a time, not so long ago

annotation.plain:
The introduction uses the classic fairytale opening of ‘once upon a time’, suggesting it is a modern day fairytale; or at least contains similar melodramatic elements.



Jon is trying to portray this as a story. He is using the “once upon a time” phrase to capture the attention of the listener.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Tommy used to work on the docks
 Union’s been on strike, he’s down on his luck
 It’s tough
 So tough

annotation.plain:
Jon Bon Jovi hailed from working-class Sayreville, New Jersey. Despite making an effort towards redevelopment, including the incorporation of luxury apartment blocks and marinas, Sayreville remains largely an industrial town.

“Living On A Prayer” was Jovi’s statement about the dire economic situation of the borough during Reagan’s term in the White House.



Tommy’s “down on his luck” because of a workers' strike aimed to improve pay, working conditions, and rights for their members, and protest by not going to work. However, workers are not paid while they are striking, which puts people like Tommy at a financial disadvantage.

Love wasn’t enough for her partner. She wasn’t enough for him. I’ve been there, and it’s like being hacked to pieces through your back until they reach through and squeeze your heart to jelly.

annotations.lyric_fragment: (Oh-oh-oh, oh-oh, oh)

annotation.plain:
The final chorus of the song is partly drowned out by these chants and the timpani crescendos as the protagonist is delivering his final words.

A popular belief about the meaning of the song is that it’s an interpretation of King Louis XVI’s last speech before his execution.

According to witnesses, he tried to give an extensive speech upon the platform, and his voice was drowned out by the drum rolls and roars from the crowd:

Louis addressed the crowd in a clear voice, “I die innocent. I pardon my enemies and I hope that my blood will be useful to the French, that it will appease God’s anger…” At this point, the drums began to roll, and Louis’ final words were inaudible. -Ohio State University



This is one of the band’s most infamous chants. All band members except Chris Martin but with Brian Eno sing the bridge. However, in the present, only drummer Will Champion does the chant.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
For some reason, I can’t explain
 Once you’d gone, there was never

annotation.plain:
The song features heavy connections to the reign of King Louis XVI and the French Revolution. The idea that the song is Coldplay’s take on the lost speech of Louis XVI could very well also mean that the line here could refer to how when the reigning monarch at the time died, his grandfather King Louis XV, he had to take on the mantle of ruling the Kingdom, and with the death of his grandfather thus went the last person who truly spoke honest to him and didn’t try to deceive and lie to him to gain control of power. A very young King at the time King Louis XVI strived to be loved by the people, but as explained later on in the song

“Revolutionaries wait
For my head on a silver plate
Just a puppet on a lonely string (Mmm, mmm)
Aw, who would ever wanna be king?”

King Louis XVI was for most part of his reign controlled by the noblemen around him and in turn he met his bitter demise by the people fueled by hatred.
And that is what this song is about, King Louis XVI last speech accepting his fate. https://medium.com/@Jaebs/coldplays-viva-la-vida-is-a-retelling-of-the-french-revolution-ad686bde8b6#

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Never an honest word
 And that was when I ruled the world

annotation.plain:
This line evokes a stanza from the 1623 Shakespeare play Macbeth, in Act IV.

When night falls
She cloaks the world
In impenetrable darkness
A chill rises
From the soil
And contaminates the air
Suddenly, Life has new meaning

This is quothed shortly after the barbaric decision of Macbeth to massacre Macduff, Thane of Fife’s subjects, he did this in his inane thirst for power to secure his place on the throne. Macduff, however, was not in the castle at the time and as Macbeth would later learn, this would be his downfall.
In Act V Macbeth’s wife commits suicide due to his actions. Later Macbeth and his subjects were put to death both by orders and hand of Macduff. Chris Martin is evoking this in saying ‘but that was when I ruled the world’ thus showing how he has fallen from grace. This could be interpreted as Macbeth’s as well as the king in the song Viva la Vida’s final thoughts before being beheaded.
The “To-morrow, and to-morrow, and to-morrow…” soliloquy could also invoke these same ideas. ‘Never an honest word’ additionally displays the underhanded practices that these two kings partook in.

annotations.lyric_fragment: My missionaries in a foreign field

annotation.plain: It seems as if the king that Coldplay is referencing in this song is looking back at his prosperous nation. Due to no true internal problems of his nation, this nation had been able to have missionaries to spread his beliefs. He may be looking back at this because it truly displayed there was no internal problem in his “world” until these revolutionaries came and “ruined it”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Mmm, mmm, mmm, mmm
 Mmm, mmm, mmm, mmm
 Mmm, mmm

annotation.plain: The ending of the song is provided with heavenly “hymns,” symbolizing the narrator (most likely the king) has been executed, with the angelic humming only going on for so long, and it eventually ending abruptly. This gives us the listener, to wonder if this king had made it into heaven after his demise, although he himself, had believed he would not be called upon in heaven from St. Peter himself.

annotations.lyric_fragment: My missionaries in a foreign field

annotation.plain:
A missionary is someone, usually Christian, who spreads faith and help in other lands. But given the context of the chorus, the “missionary” would just be another representation of the narrator spreading his personal beliefs through another person.

The missionary here would be a personality of what the narrator would want, along with mirror (same beliefs), sword and shield (warrior for the narrator).

annotations.lyric_fragment: Next, the walls were closed on me

annotation.plain: Continuing with the previous line, the King -in this case Louis XVI-, after holding the power of his kingdom (holding the key), he found himself enclosed within walls (Louis XIV was effectively imprisoned after the 1789 Revolution until the day of his execution by guillotine). The phrase “the walls were closed on me” can also be a metaphor for the author’s personal state of mind, feeling like his world is closing on him, which means he is desperate or anxious but cannot find a solution to his current situation.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Now in the mornin’, I sleep alone
 Sweep the streets I used to own

annotation.plain:
He’s no longer the glorious Emperor he once was. He compares this to sweeping the streets, a job associated with blue-collar work and a far cry from his former glory.

This is possibly a reference to Puyi, the 12th and final Emperor of the Qing Dynasty of China. After becoming a reformed communist, he worked for a while as a street sweeper in Beijing.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Listen as the crowd would sing
 “Now the old king is dead, long live the king”

annotation.plain:
These lines refer to the traditional European proclamation “The king is dead, long live the king!” – which denotes the ascension of a new monarch.

Thus, the narrator reminisces about the very beginning of his reign, as well as the temporal nature of kingship.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Just a puppet on a lonely string (Mmm, mmm)
 Aw, who would ever wanna be king?

annotation.plain:
As a head of state, despite seemingly absolute power, you are beholden to the interests of those whose support you need to maintain power. Thus being a monarch can feel like being a puppet on a single string, as you may have a lot of power, but never complete agency.

Another interpretation of this line would be as a reference to hanging from a noose, as one would also be strung from a lonely rope or “string”. This would tie back to the rest of the verse as it describes the prosecution of the king.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Para

annotation.plain:
At this point in the recording, you can hear Ritchie Valens coming in off-mic, about a half-second early, and on a different note, before his main vocal starts.

Here’s what producer Bob Keane told NPR about how that happened:

“When we got into the studio, Ritchie showed up and he had a cold, a pretty bad cold,” recalls Keane. “So I couldn’t cancel the date and they couldn’t get the musicians back, and I had to pay for the studio. So I had him stand off-mic and sing along with the track as we cut the track to make sure that the tempo was right and that the breaks were right and all that kind of stuff. And then later on we brought him and we had a two-track machine and we dubbed him in. There’s a break and then, you know, the band goes silent, and he comes in, `Ba-la-ba-la, la bamba.‘ And right there he comes in just a little bit early on the off mic. So we didn’t wipe it because we figured well nobody’s gonna be playing this record anyway. So we didn’t clean it up.”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Yo no soy marinero
 Yo no soy marinero, soy capitán
 Soy capitán, soy capitán

annotation.plain:
Literally: “I am not a sailor, I am not a sailor, I’m the captain, I’m the captain, I’m the captain”.

Within context, couples dances often require one person to lead the dance. The singer indicates this will be him, since he has been instructing his partner on how to properly do the dance.

Alternatively, if the dance in question does not require one partner to literally lead the dance, it could be meant more symbolic. As in “just follow my lead and you’ll get the hang of it”.

annotations.lyric_fragment: La Bamba

annotation.plain:
In keeping with many hit songs of the 50’s and early 60’s, La Bamba is a song about a dance that instructs the listener on how to do the dance in question; e.g. The Twist by Valens' contemporary Chubby Checker.

“Bamba” has several meanings depending on local dialect of Spanish. In the Caribbean, “bamba” is a term for people of African descent; in Central America, “bamba” can mean a silver coin. However, the most likely use in this case comes from Mexico – Valens' parents were Mexican – where “bamba” is a term for dance.

In short, a literal English translation would make the song titled “The Dance”, and – in a slight break from Checkers' Twist, which gives literal instructions on how to do the Twist – the lyrics to La Bamba impart the qualities one must possess in order to do the titular dance properly.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Some of them want to be abused

annotation.plain:
The narrator has a very bleak view of the world, believing life is about using and being used.

In this view, even kindness is viewed in a negative way with the belief that it is only used as a means for personal gain. Anyone showing tender emotions towards another is only doing so in an attempt to exploit the emotional side of human nature.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Sweet dreams are made of this
 Who am I to disagree?
 I travel the world and the seven seas
 Everybody’s looking for something

annotation.plain:
Lennox was fighting depression when she wrote these lyrics. She explains their significance in her biography:

The song “Sweet Dreams” is a personal statement about people’s motivations, in their loves, their own dreams. I replaced the word “motivations” with the word “dreams.” I’m saying these are motivations as human beings, and there’s no way, whether I disagree, that I want to change anything about that. And everywhere I look (“I travelled the world, and the seven seas”), all I see is that every person on the earth is looking for that kind of fulfillment. So you have the extremes from the people who want to use and be used, the whole spectrum.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Hold your head up
 Keep your head up (Movin’ on)
 Hold your head up (Movin’ on)
 Keep your head up (Movin’ on)
 Hold your head up (Movin’ on)
 Keep your head up (Movin’ on)
 Hold your head up (Movin’ on)
 Keep your head up

annotation.plain:
Lennox’s lyrics are somewhat dark since she and Stewart were fighting at the time. Stewart suggested this more upbeat part to strike a balance:

I suggested there had to be another bit, and that bit should be positive. So in the middle we added these chord changes rising upwards with ‘Hold your head up, moving on.’ To us it was a major breakthrough. It just goes from beginning to end and the whole song is a chorus, there is not one note that is not a hook.

annotation.plain:
Simon admitted to People Magazine in November 2015 that this verse is about American actor and director Warren Beatty, whom she met while she was opening for Cat Stevens.

As The New York Post reported in 2015, Simon wrote about her relationship with Beatty in a memoir, explaining that he was unfaithful and their love was very sexual.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I had some dreams, they were clouds in my coffee

annotation.plain:
Carly liked the phrase “clouds in my coffee” and used that reference to an “illusion” to describe her dreams of having a relationship with the subject of the song. She said:

It came from an airplane flight that I took with Billy Mernit, who was my friend and piano player at the time. As I got my coffee, there were clouds outside the window of the airplane and you could see the reflection in the cup of coffee. Billy said to me, ‘Look at the clouds in your coffee’.

When Carly wrote additional material on Janet Jackson’s “You’re So Vain”-sampling hit “Son of a Gun (I Betcha Think This Song Is About You)”, she states:

The apricot scarf was worn by Nick

Thus identifying the subject of the first verse Carly’s ex-boyfriend, the novelist Nicholas Delbanco.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Chorus]

annotation.plain:
The chorus of “bad guy” is unique for a pop hit as it is almost entirely instrumental, based on a repeating synth melody. In a video for Rolling Stone, Eilish revealed that the melody was inspired by several musical themes from her childhood: the theme song from the Disney Channel show Wizards of Waverly Place, as well as the theme from the video game Plants vs. Zombies. Fans have also noticed similarities to the melody of the song “We Are Number One” from the children’s television series LazyTown, which became an internet meme in 2016.

Coincidentally, Eilish’s brother FINNEAS has produced for Selena Gomez, who starred in Wizards of Waverly Place and sang its theme song. Gomez was made aware of the theme song’s inspiration on “bad guy” during an interview on The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon in 2020, in which Jimmy Fallon played both songs side-by-side:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f7TCzxOS6H4&t=3m25s

Fellow Wizards co-stars Jennifer Stone and David DeLuise also acknowledged “bad guy” in the first episode of the Wizards of Waverly Pod podcast series in 2023. DeLuise revealed that he too has a connection to Eilish as his cousin is friends with her parents, and he met her when she was much younger.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Bridge]

annotation.plain: Billie and Finneas told in an interview with Roling Stone on December 16, 2019, Billie first had the music made in her bedroom of this bridge before the song even existed. Even her laugh is imported in the bridge.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I’m the bad guy

annotation.plain:
Billie explained the “bad guy” lyric in a August 2019 Billboard interview:

It’s a weird thing to hear come out of a girl’s mouth. I think Nicki Minaj said in one of her songs that she’s the bad guy, and I didn’t realize that until recently….It’s such a cool juxtaposition of that sentence. Why do people resonate with it? I know why I resonate with it, but they’re all my own reasons.

The Nicki Minaj song that Billie refers to is “Chun-Li,” where Minaj raps:

Oh, I get it, huh, they paintin' me out to be the bad guy
Well it’s the last time you gonna see a bad guy do the rap game like me

Both Eilish and Minaj’s “bad guy” lines reference a scene in the 1983 movie, Scarface, where Tony Montana complains:

Me, I always tell the truth. Even when I lie. So say good night to the bad guy! Come on. The last time you gonna see a bad guy like this again, let me tell you. Come on. Make way for the bad guy. There’s a bad guy comin' through! Better get outta his way!

Billie further explained the idea behind the line in a July 2019 KIIS FM interview:

It’s basically making fun of everyone and their personas of themselves…. In general, I feel like you will never catch a bad bitch telling everyone she’s a bad bitch…. If you’re going around all the time saying, like, ‘Yeah, I’m bad, I’m always breaking rules and doing this and doing that.’ You’re not. I know that because I used to say that and I wasn’t. Bad kids, bad boys, bad bitches, whatever, they do that shit and they don’t even know.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Bruises on both my knees for you

annotation.plain:
Yet another line that is taken literally in the music video.



Though the bruises on her knees could be interpreted as her begging for something repeatedly, this seems to be alluding more to kneeling down to perform a sexual act. It should be noted that the male subject of this song already has a girlfriend, though this would align with Billie’s boasts in the chorus, in particular being the type to “make your girlfriend mad tight”.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
So you’re a tough guy
 Like it really rough guy
 Just can’t get enough guy
 Chest always so puffed guy
 I’m that bad type
 Make your mama sad type

annotation.plain:
The pre-chorus sees Billie equally comparing herself to the man she wants a relationship with. Her description of him ties into the image of the “bad boy” that any sane father would disapprove of. This doesn’t frighten her, however; instead, she counters by telling him how similar they are.

Billie would later explain in a video for Rolling Stone that these lyrics are sarcastic – if this man can lie about his characteristics and be “fake”, she can certainly do the same.

Billie describing herself as the “might seduce your dad type” garnered some minor controversy due to the singer only being 17 at the time of the song’s release. The line is intentionally questionable, however, and serves to drive the point home. This “bad guy” character that Billie is pretending to be seems to be boastful and proud of their actions (“I’m only good at bein' bad”), and they threaten to go to extremes without caring about the emotional destruction they may cause in the process.

annotations.lyric_fragment: White shirt now red, my bloody nose

annotation.plain:
This line is taken literally in the song’s music video, which sees Billie wearing a white shirt while her nose bleeds.



The Pop Song Professor explains:

The contrast of the “white shirt” with the red of her “bloody nose” likely illustrates with colors the internal change her character undergoes. Billie Eilish has often talked about how colors are very expressive to her, and she loves to tie visuals to her songs in music videos. It makes sense then, that she would use the imagery of a white shirt, pure and untainted, now corrupted by blood, symbolizing pain as a metaphor for the loss of innocence.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Semi-charmed kind of life, baby, baby

annotation.plain:
Leading a “charmed life” means leading an easy life, rarely encountering significant obstacles or experiencing bad luck.

Semi-charmed, by comparison, may refer to a life that’s not quite good enough to coast, but still relatively easy; the perfect breeding ground for a drug addiction.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Come on like a freak show, takes the stage

annotation.plain:
Most likely referring to the “come on” you get as the drugs hit and you start to feel them. They are hitting Jenkins fast and unexpected, much like how a “freak show” would take to the stage.

According to the Encyclopædia Britannica, a “freak show” is:

[The] term used to describe the exhibition of exotic or deformed animals as well as humans considered to be in some way abnormal or outside broadly accepted norms.

annotations.lyric_fragment:

annotation.plain: As alluded to previously, his crystal meth experience has gone from lifting him up to becoming a bad trip, and the one person who could give him comfort is in the throes of her own high.

annotations.lyric_fragment:

There’s a woman who he’s in love with, and who he claims lives for him…however he also notes that besides her feelings for him, she also has another reason/motivation for being so happy to see him.

(It’s drugs).

annotations.lyric_fragment: Smiling in the pictures you would take

annotation.plain:
This line could mean two things:

1) He is looking at pictures from before his life fell apart and he wants to return to that point.

2) He is smiling in more recent pictures under influence of the drugs.

Stephan omits the word “smiling” from this line in some live performances, re-recorded versions, and the 1995 demo of this song.

You can hear him clearly end with “start” here:
https://youtu.be/W8X4PWqlMoc?t=240

annotations.lyric_fragment: And when the plane came in, she said she was crashing

annotation.plain: A reference to being on a meth comedown.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
She’s got her jaws now locked down in a smile
 But nothing is alright, alright

annotation.plain: People often clench their jaws together after taking methamphetamine.  If his partner has her jaws clenched, this could mean she is addicted to meth as well.  This is not “alright” because the narrator now knows others have drug problems just as bad as his.  In addition, drugs can also make you smile even when you don’t want to. People also often take drugs to escape from how terrible their life is so “nothing is alright” but she’s still smiling due to the drugs and the high.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
When I’m with you I feel like I could die
 And that would be alright, alright

annotation.plain: Overdosing on crystal meth or other hard drugs could be fatal (causing death) to those who use them.  The narrator can already feel his soul escaping and is content with his death, which would thusly end his drug problem.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I believe in the sand beneath my toes
 The beach gives a feeling, an earthy feeling
 I believe in the faith that grows
 And the four right chords can make me cry

annotation.plain: The beach, a source of fun and excitement for teens and young adults, could be symbolic of cleansing in this verse.  The grains of sands between his toes are a type of potion that removes the sin and addiction from his body and the “four right chords” are symbolic of heavenly music telling him his soul has been cleansed.  However, the narrator’s soul is already tainted and, upon leaving the beach, he snaps back into his drug addiction, as seen in the next line.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Verse 1]

annotation.plain:
In Blue Hawaii, Elvis sings this song not to his girl, but to her grandmother whom he brought back a music box from Europe for her birthday.

Elvis' character claims that “Can’t Help Falling in Love” is an old European love song. We learned in an earlier song, “Almost Always True”, that he was in France. So it is likely that the lyrics he sings wouldn’t be the lyrics of the fictional original “European love song”.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Like a river flows
 Surely to the sea
 Darling, so it goes
 Some things are meant to be

annotation.plain: All bodies of water eventually end up in the ocean. The water was meant to end up in the ocean. In his eyes, he and his lover are the same.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Take my hand
 Take my whole life, too
 For I can’t help
 Falling in love with you

annotation.plain:
Going back to the very first line of the song “Wise men say only fools rush in”, he here demonstrates that he really is being rather foolish by being willing to trust a woman he probably has not known for very long (considering that he is just falling in love with her) with his life.

“Take my hand, take my whole life too”

Look how quickly it escalates. First he is just asking her to take his hand (not a sin, not rushing in), but in the next line he is telling her to take his whole life.

He is surrendering to the inevitability of falling in love with this woman and choosing to give up his whole life for her.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Wise men say
 “Only fools rush in”
 But I can’t help
 Falling in love with you

annotation.plain:
The “Memphis Mafia” say that only fools fall in love but Presley can’t avoid the same.

The phrase is first known from An Essay on Criticism by Alexander Pope.

“No place so sacred from such fops is barr’d,
Nor is Paul’s church more safe than Paul’s churchyard:
Nay, fly to altars; there they’ll talk you dead:
For fools rush in where angels fear to tread.”

annotation.plain:
In this verse Beyoncé is going to the club to have a good time, especially after the tears she cried because of [the] break-up.
After she’s finally having fun, not crying anymore and get some attention from men in the club, ‘the ex’ wants to get back with her.

Beyoncé is reclaiming self love and confidence in this verse, by doing her own thing. “It’s okay I’ve cried, but I’m stronger and moved on.”

annotation.plain:
At the time, when I wrote that [“Singles Ladies”] record, if you guys can recall, I was on a tour with Jay and Mary J. Blige at the time. Part of the City tour, right. I was on that tour and I believe Jay caught me in one of those cities and he was like, ‘Yo, I need you to go in with my girl.’ I’m like, alright, cool. Literally, when the buck stopped here, we went to rock the mic and there’s everybody and this is a true story. Everybody is ready to work, Stargate is in one room, there’s a couple of other producers in one of the side rooms, Timbaland is in the back and I walk in. The thing that people mostly don’t know about me is I talk shit to literally rev myself up to do it. It’s not that I may believe it, it’s the crazy part of why did you put yourself in that scenario, now you’ve got to come up with some shit.

I walk into the studio and I’m just loud and obnoxious and being silly and I said, ‘I don’t know who has or think they have the first single on B but it’s over with, I got the first single.’ I had not wrote a record, I didn’t know what I was going to write. I ain’t heard a beat, nothing. I literally backed myself into this corner. That wasn’t the first record I wrote that night. There was another record, it was really, really good, it just wasn’t “Single Ladies,” which was the next record I wrote, which it took probably approximately around 17 minutes to do. Usually those songs that take a small amount of time are usually the bigger ones because you’re not thinking about it, it’s just a mood. I had no idea had already been calculating what I felt like Beyoncé should say to everybody if you were Beyoncé, which is kind of everybody. If you’re not married, you’re in a relationship with some guy that just happens to be Jay Z.

You’re in a relationship with a guy, you want him to commit. How do I make this a coffee table conversation that the guys of course are going to lynch me for, of course, but all the women are going to love it and that’s who I love so I don’t really care. I come up with this brilliant idea, “If you like it, then you should’ve put a ring on it.” I’m like, yeah that sounds like some sassy shit a girl would say to me. Well, now I’m gone so you should’ve seen some at first, bye.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Bridge]

annotation.plain:
But that wasn’t enough. I had to make sure it was universal. So, the hook was good. “If you like it, then you should have put a ring on it.” I knew every girl would say, “That’s me! That’s me and my ex-boyfriend!” You know what’s up. But once I got the bridge, I thought the song could become iconic. Without the bridge, it would just be this melodic hip-hop record. I believe that’s why it got Song of the Year.

There was no discussion of the lyrics. Me and B at that time wasn’t like the me and B of now, where we could have that discussion. At that point it was like “Hey, I’m B, this god of a songstress, and you’re a writer who is just now getting here.”

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Produced by Beyoncé, The-Dream & Tricky Stewart]

annotation.plain:
I was opening up for Jay and Mary J. Blige on tour at the time, and “Falsetto” was starting to go crazy on the radio. We got to the studio and were going to work on Beyoncé’s stuff. We were at Roc The Mic Studios. I walk in and there were producers to my left, and on the backside. I remember saying “Oh, I’ve got the first single. I don’t know why all of you are working so hard!” I hadn’t written shit. I didn’t know what I was going to write. “Single Ladies” wasn’t the first song we did.

We did something first, just getting oiled up. We weren’t in our home studio, it was a foreign studio. So the second track Tricky pulls up is “Single Ladies” — he’s done the beat but that’s all. In my head, I’ve conjured up what I want to talk about, in terms of subject matter, but I don’t have any melodies. I was doing this thing that now I see Jay do, sitting there and compartmentalizing. I could tell Trick was looking at me, trying to figure out what I’m doing. He said, “OK, OK, let’s start on another one.” I said, “Oh hell no, we’re going to do this shit right here.” He said “Alright, I’ll step out for a second.” I walk in the booth, and it may have taken two takes to get “Single Ladies.” Started out with “all the single ladies,” just like the song goes.

After two takes, about 75% of the song is done. I knew that talking about B’s life and what you probably understood of it, with her and Jay being married or not being married, would strike a chord with people, because everybody wanted to know what was going on.

annotation.plain: Although certainly not the first appearance of the word, this hook was long before “twerk” was a part of the popular vernacular.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You see these shackles, baby, I’m your slave (Uh-huh)
 I’ll let you whip me if I misbehave (Uh-huh)
 It’s just that no one makes me feel this way (Uh-huh)

annotation.plain:
PROPOSED SUGGESTION:

Timberlake is suggesting a positive punishment – a consequence that decreases the likelihood of a behavior by giving something undesirable. He is pretending like him misbehaving is a behavior that can only be corrected by something painful, like getting whipped. However, the highly sexual song clearly is pretending like getting whipped is undesirable; he sees it as positive reinforcement. In the words of Edward Thorndike and BF Skinner, behaviors with favorable consequences will occur more frequently and behaviors followed by less favorable consequences will occur less frequently".

annotation.plain:
This is a masochist move. Some men find it appealing when their partners control them, so in the song, he expressed it in many lines

According to B.F. Skinner, Timberlake is exhibiting positive reinforcement. His behavior will result in him getting whipped, which he implies is a desirable event.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
’Cause the players tried to take the field
 The marching band refused to yield

annotation.plain:
These lines most likely refer to the Vietnam War protests, and how it crowded out every other social cause in the late 60s and became the overwhelming flashpoint for national dialogue. The “marching band” (military and police) refusing to yield is echoing the increasing focus of the country on the Vietnam War and the growing opposition to it.

The fact the protests, and subsequent violence, often took place on school campuses, particularly the Kent State Shooting, is likely the reason for the allusion to school sports.

A more musical interpretation of the lines would be that The Sgt. Pepper album cover has the 4 Beatles dressed in psychedelic versions of military uniforms, and begins with a somewhat mocking musical reference to military marches (plus, military bands are mostly composed of soldiers with the rank of Sergeant). The album jokes that the Beatles were taking over yet another genre. For a few years, the Beatles top the charts with successive albums, refusing to yield to other musical players, as adults and politicians bemoan the lack of interest of young people in more traditional genres of music.

annotations.lyric_fragment: And can you teach me how to dance real slow?

annotation.plain:
‘Slow dancing’ refers to a type of partner dance in which a couple dance slowly, swaying to the music. It would have been commonplace at events throughout the 60s, 50s and before.

For the youth however, some might say slow dancing was little more than an excuse for teenagers to hold each other closely during the era of the song. Although McLean enjoyed dancing, there’s probably some cheeky innuendo here too.

annotation.plain:
The line that the “good old boys” are singing is a slightly altered lyric from one of Buddy Holly’s songs, “That’ll Be The Day”.

Well, that’ll be the day, when you say goodbye
