You say you’re going to leave, you know it’s a lie
Because that’ll be the day when I die

annotations.lyric_fragment: With no time left to start again

annotation.plain:
McLean’s generation was growing out of its youth, and running out of hopeful figures in music, pop culture, and society to relate to/rely on.

The 70s also saw what many consider a darker time for the US, as distrust in government culminated in the Watergate Scandal and NYT v. US, which revealed that President Nixon had been secretly bombing Cambodia and Laos. The 1970s also saw the US energy crisis and a weakened economy.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And there I stood alone and afraid
 I dropped to my knees and there I prayed

annotation.plain: McLean was scared that the production of good music would cease. McLean very much liked music and wanted good music to keep being made. As stated in the following lines he just wanted the music to live.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Do you recall what was revealed
 The day the music died?

annotation.plain:
The death of Buddy Holly signaled the end of an era. The cheery optimism and calm of the 1950’s was drawing to a close…



…and a new phase of American history was about to unfold. President Kennedy would ramp up U.S. involvement in Vietnam, become embroiled in the Cuban Missile Crisis, and ultimately be assassinated.



With the conclusion of the fifties, it was revealed to the American people that the world was much darker than we had led ourselves to believe.

annotations.lyric_fragment: But this time one would equal four

annotation.plain:
The four are probably the Beatles; the “one” may be Elvis Presley, alluded to in the earlier line, “Oh, and while the king was looking down / The jester stole his thorny crown”.



The Beatles were both influenced by Elvis Presley and took his place as the most popular act in music.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And in five years four had come to mourn
 And the music was reborn

annotation.plain:
The meaning of lines in this “lost” verse can feel as elusive as the rest of the song.

Many think of the day “the music died” as the famous plane crash that killed Buddy Holly, Ritchie Valens and the Big Bopper. Five years later, The Beatles came for their first tour in the US, “and the music was reborn”.



The Fab Four at the Washington Coliseum, February 1964.

annotation.plain:
Beach Boys songs often get adapted for new media, but few have gotten as much love as “God Only Knows.”  In addition to dozens of cover versions, two stand out for their creativity.

The paleo-futuristic game Bioshock Infinite reimagined the song as a 1910s-era barbershop quartet:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C39RTJWWw8k

HBO’s show about Christian schismatic polygamists, Big Love, used it as its opening theme for the first three seasons:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tcdpUu7jPJY

annotations.lyric_fragment:
But long as there are stars above you
 You never need to doubt it
 I’ll make you so sure about it

annotation.plain:
An immediate flip on the opening line. In Asher’s words:

“‘I’ll love you till the sun burns out, then I’m gone,’ ergo ‘I’m gonna love you forever.”

We’ve got about 5 billion years before the Sun dies, and even then, there will still be other stars. Essentially, Brian and Tony are going to make sure that their lover knows their love will never die.

annotations.lyric_fragment: God only knows what I’d be without you

annotation.plain:
Wilson and Asher were taking a real risk in including the word “God” in the song’s title and hook. They risked alienating both America’s religious right, and trendy young people.

The first time I heard it, Brian played it for me at the piano. And I went, ‘Oh my God, he’s talking about God in a record.’ It was pretty daring to me. And it was another time I thought to myself, ‘Oh, boy, he’s really taking a chance.’ I thought it was almost too religious. Too square. At that time. Yes, it was so great that he would say it and not be intimidated by what anybody else would think of the words or what he meant.
- Marilyn Rovell (then Brian’s wife)

annotations.lyric_fragment: I may not always love you

annotation.plain:
Brian Wilson initially hated this opening line, considering it too negative for a love song. Co-writer Tony Asher, however, was sold:

This is the one [song] that I thought would be a hit record because it was so incredibly beautiful. I was concerned that maybe the lyrics weren’t up to the same level as the music; how many love songs start off with the line, ‘I may not always love you’? I liked that twist, and fought to start the song that way. Working with Brian, I didn’t have a whole lot of fighting to do, but I was certainly willing to fight to the end for that.

annotations.lyric_fragment: God only knows what I’d be without you

annotation.plain:
This song is often heralded as one of the greatest songs of all time. Musicians such as Paul McCartney were terrified of how good they viewed this song as being upon release. In a 1990 interview with David Leaf, McCartney said:

“It’s a really, really great song—it’s a big favorite of mine. I was asked recently to give my top ten favorite songs for a Japanese radio station…I didn’t think long and hard on it, but I popped "God Only Knows” on the top of my list… Very emotional, always a bit of a choker for me, that one. There are certain songs that just hit home with me, and they’re the strangest collection of songs…but that is high on the list, I must say."

Hearing Pet Sounds drove McCartney to greater innovation – Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band.

annotation.plain: I believe the term “little red corvette” is also a code name for a certain female body part that a saddening amount of men just have no clue how to find it…..

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Move over, baby, gimme the keys
 I’m gonna try to tame your little red love machine

annotation.plain:
This is the most important sentence imo in this song, since it shows possibly the real intent and motivation for Prince to write this song: He wants the keys to this car (so meaning that he probably fell in love with her, despite all of the above), and he wants possibly “tame” her, meaning start a real relationship with her. The refrain also makes now more sense, and you understand why he wants her to slow down…My interpretation is that he wants her for himself, and start something serious with her.

In this moment, in my opinion, this song becomes a song about a broken heart, or a failed attempt, of Prince, trying to start a relationship with a girl who he cared and loved deeply, but who would not stop changing regularly sex partners.

Another interpretation might be that he inversed the roes in this song to a real life situation, which may have occurred to him, with possibly a woman who wanted a serious relationship, but him being the corvette.

Anyways, a beautiful song, telling the story of one-sided love for someone only looking for sex.

annotation.plain:
Chorus again. The song is getting progressively more sexual, it sort of speaks for itself.

The song tells the story of a woman that Prince applies the merits of a red Corvette sports car too. She is attractive, built for two and very fast. Yet this sports car is fueled by the illusion of love which is sex. Being like a sports car she isn’t built for anything meaningful or practical and therefore like most sports cars she will eventually breakdown or crash as a consequence of her fast and reckless lifestyle.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I guess I should’ve closed my eyes when you drove me to the place
 Where your horses run free
 ’Cause I felt a little ill when I saw all the pictures
 Of the jockeys that were there before me

annotation.plain:
This line is a sexual metaphor relating to the place where she chose to have sex. She takes Prince back to her place, and he gets sickened when he sees pictures of various men she brought back before him. She’s the kind of girl you don’t take home to mother.

The line equates horses to Trojan horses, because Trojan is a popular condom brand) and the jockeys, men who commandeer horses in professional sports, as men who have previously been in this Corvette. Since a ‘horse’ is a metaphor for the male genatalia, Prince is subtly explaining that his female companion is frequented by many others.

annotation.plain:
This line draws a similar flow and structure to a line from Snoop’s verse on “Bitches Ain’t Shit” on The Chronic.

I once had a bitch named Annie Mae
Used to be all in them guts like every day

In a ruthlessly indifferent move of sexuality, Snoop describes himself getting involved with a girl who used to be a romantic partner of one of his friends. “Macking” could refer to anything from flirting to full-on hooking up.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
So what you wanna do? Shit
 I got a pocket full of rubbers and my homeboys do too

annotation.plain:
“Rubbers” is a slang term for condoms that goes back to the mid-1800s, when they were actually made from vulcanized rubber. Today condoms  are made from latex, a material that’s also typically derived from the rubber tree.

Snoop’s prepared for safe sex at all times—this line is illustrated in a scene from the “Gin & Juice” video where his homeboy Dr. Dre lends him his pocket full of rubbers:

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Rollin’ down the street, smokin’ indo
 Sippin’ on gin and juice

annotation.plain:
This anthem of smoking weed and drinking Snoop’s favorite alcoholic beverage has become one of the most famous rap hooks of all time.

This line interpolates Slave’s hook on “Watching You”:

Walking down the street, watching ladies, rolling by, watching you.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Gs up, hoes down

annotation.plain:
Double Entendre


It’s a reference to another track on the album, “Gz Up, Hoes Down”. It indicates the need to have the gangstas “up” or on top of things, and keep the ho’s (bitches) down. Thought to have originated from pimps who would say it to indicate their whores were on their backs making the money for the pimps. Often said when greeting a fellow G, or upon entering a room or party.
G could stand for guys here, who are on top of the girls while having sex and bouncing to Snoop’s music.

Some facts, made our made, now you wanna run and play

With more than 30 records and a career spanning 20 years now, it seems like Snoop truly does come up with music “every single day.”



As far as genres go, he’s more than just funky. Though he started out alongside fellow West Coaster Dr. Dre with gangsta funk, he’s also messed around with electronic instrumentals and more recently, he’s been reincarnated as a reggae artist Snoop Lion.

See a common theme? (hint: weed.)

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Don’t hide yourself in regret
 Just love yourself and you’re set

annotation.plain: The lyrics made sure to remind people that everyone is their own selves, and everyone has their own journeys, personalities, and identities. Regret can lead to things like anxiety, self-criticism, and depression, so that is why Lady Gaga says in the lyrics, “Don’t hide yourself in regret”. This song came out in 2011, and it was a time where LGBTQ rights, metal health, and disability rights were not fully accepted in society. 71% of youth reported feeling sad or hopeless for at least two weeks in the past year. So, the song came out at a god time to help people hear the powerful message of loving yourself. https://youtu.be/SdjJ7Pz7Ddw

annotations.lyric_fragment: She said, “’Cause He made you perfect, babe”

annotation.plain: “Cause he made you perfect” is a direct reference to God and the perception that he made everybody in his image. It emphasizes the fact that everyone is perfect in their own way.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
She rolled my hair and put my lipstick on
 In the glass of her boudoir

annotation.plain:
A boudoir—the now-obsolete equivalent to an aristocratic man’s study—is the private bedroom/“sulking room” of upper-class women, in which one applies makeup and other beauty accessories. Gaga makes reference to this as someone may have their hair rolled and lipstick applied using one of these. She felt precocious and empowered whenever she dressed up—a thing she still does today.



At Vulture, Nitsuh Abebe said, “The song’s so disco that the mention of a mother’s “boudoir” in the first verse becomes totally natural and hilarious.”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Same DNA (Hey, hey, hey, hey)
 But born this way (Hey, hey, hey, hey, hey, hey, hey, hey)
 Same DNA (Hey, hey, hey, hey)
 But born this way (Hey, hey, hey)

annotation.plain:
Even though people might look drastically different from each other, any two humans can share 99.5% of the same DNA. At least chromosomally, homo sapiens grow from an identical basis.

For Gaga, humanity might be different from each other, they should recognize that those differences all stem from the same place, and one should think carefully before being the one to judge.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Believe capital H-I-M, hey-hey-hey

annotation.plain: Gaga tells us just to believe in God (H-I-M). No matter who we are.

annotations.lyric_fragment: A different lover is not a sin

annotation.plain: Many believe that homosexual relationships are a crime against God. Gaga asserts that it isn’t true; love is just love.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I love my life, I love this record and
 Mi amore vole fe yah (Same DNA)

annotation.plain:
Gaga asserts that she loves her life regardless of what anyone else says about her. She admits pride to the record as well, demonstrating that she stands fully behind its powerful message. The line may also be a reference to her 2008 hit song “Just Dance”:

I love this record, baby, but I can’t see straight anymore

Lastly, she gives an old Italian saying: “Mi amore vole fe yah" (Gaga has Italian ancestry). This saying roughly translates to “Love can’t exist without trust,” or more simply, “Love needs faith.” Gaga sings this to encourage the listener to keep faith in what they love, because that is essential to the love itself.

“Same DNA” refers to the fact that all humans are, genetically, practically the same, so we shouldn’t ostracize people for being “different”.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
In the religion of the insecure
 I must be myself, respect my youth

annotation.plain: Gaga is suggesting that there’s this vague “religion” around the insecure that they need to “be themselves” but at the same time not waste their youth away with their idiosyncrasies, be it their sexuality or just a personal perk. She infuses a sense of self-determination into this lyric, proclaiming that she will be herself, and thereby truly respect her youth.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Whether you’re broke or evergreen

annotation.plain:
Whether you’re rich or poor, you have a right to love yourself.

In this line, Lady Gaga is comparing a rich person to an evergreen tree. An evergreen tree is able to keep its green bristles even in winter. It’s a clever metonym. Evergreen might also be referencing the colour of an American bank note.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
No matter black, white, or beige
 Chola or Orient made
 I’m on the right track, baby
 I was born to be brave!

annotation.plain:
It doesn’t matter what levels of melanin you have, or if you are of African-American, Caucasian, Spanish, Asian or of multiracial descent, you’re on the right track just the way you are.



Also, by putting all these lines in one part, Lady Gaga equates LGBT discrimination to racism. Prejudice is prejudice, regardless of its nature.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Third world democracy

annotation.plain:
Reppin' her homeland of Sri Lanka



Since MIA is a Sri Lankan Tamil, she is probably describing the Sinhalese Government during the Sri Lankan civil war and their oppression of Tamils.

More broadly the song is probably meant to represent all “third world” democracies – viz countries that are not a part of the affluent west (e.g. US, UK, Canada, France, Germany, etc.) or Russia

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Yeah, I’ve got more records than the KGB
 So, uh, no funny business

annotation.plain:
M.I.A. boasts that the police keep more files on her than the KGB—the secret police of the totalitarian Soviet Union—kept in total, or alternatively, that she’s sold more musical records than the KGB kept.

“Funny business” is also doing double-duty, implying both that you shouldn’t mess with her, and that she’s a serious businesswoman.

Finally, this plays into the previous line – “third world” countries were those unaffiliated with the “first world” (the US and its allies) or the “second world” (the USSR and its allies)

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Ringin’ the bell
 And nobody’s coming to help

annotation.plain: In most inpatient care facilities worldwide, patients have some form of ‘bell’ or ‘button’ they can ‘ring’ or activate to notify medical providers that they need assistance of some kind. Harry seems to be referencing this here – he keeps ringing the bell, and yet no one seems to notice or want to help him. Or maybe it just feels like that. Either way, the emotions are there.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Your daddy lives by himself

annotation.plain: This lyric is probably the literal truth. When Styles was seven years old, his parents divorced. While his mother got remarried twice after the divorce, Styles' father has stayed single since, making it likely that he lives alone.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Nothin’ to say

annotation.plain:
This specific lyric reminisces of another line from “Two Ghosts,” a 2017 track that belongs to Harry’s debut album

Telling those stories we already told

Styles' 2019 single “Falling,” also shows similarities, when he sings:

And the coffee’s out at the Beachwood Cafe
And it kills me, ‘cause I know we’ve run out of things we can say

At this point in “As It Was,” we can interpret this line as Harry only being able to think about or focus on the past. Stuck within a loop of struggle, he can’t move on from whatever it is that has happened to him, but also doesn’t want to open up about it — which is something he probably should do, since talking with someone tends to be a healthy way of processing feelings or emotions.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Come on, Harry, we wanna say goodnight to you

annotation.plain:
Styles introduces us to his lead single with a voicemail from his goddaughter Ruby, whose father is British television producer Ben Winston, a close friend of the artist who also directed quite a few One Direction music videos. Styles confirmed this during an interview promoting the release of the single:

It’s my goddaughter at the start of the song. [She] got a streak of calling me every night before bed, and I missed it once, and she wanted to let me know that she was quite angry with me.

A potential interpretation of this interjection, following the album’s promotional motif of doors, is that Ruby is speaking to Harry from the other side of a closed door as he refuses to let anyone into his house. This metaphor relates to the theme of struggling with honesty and vulnerability that is prevalent through Styles’s discography. The image of Styles behind a door mirrors the beginning of the music video.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I don’t wanna talk about the way that it was

annotation.plain:
The motif of not wanting to talk about certain topics has already been expressed throughout Styles' discography. It made its first appearance on his breakout debut single, “Sign of the Times:”

We don’t talk enough, we should open up
Before it’s all too much
Will we ever learn? We’ve been here before
It’s just what we know

Harry’s debut album’s opening track, “Meet Me in the Hallway,” also expresses similar feelings:

We don’t talk about it, it’s something we don’t do
‘Cause once you go without it, nothing else will do

Carrying emotions and oppressing them because of the pain they could cause when opening up about them, seems to be a habit. This attitude towards emotions can lead to the recurrence of these harmful feelings. Consequently, it can also cause a sudden explosion of emotion within the person, which may destroy valuable things in their life.

This cycle was also represented on the song’s music video, where Styles and his partner can be seen running in a circle:

annotations.lyric_fragment:
”Harry, you’re no good alone
 Why are you sitting at home on the floor?
 What kind of pills are you on?”

annotation.plain:
This manner of bearing with the distance of an ex partner resembles of the attitude Styles took previously on his 2017 track, “Meet Me in the Hallway:”

Just let me know, I’ll be at the door, at the door
Hoping you’ll come around
Just let me know, I’ll be on the floor, on the floor
Maybe we’ll work it out
I gotta get better, gotta get better

These lyrics show devastation, caused by the break-up. Styles finds himself alone and outside his lover’s bedroom, crawling for their comeback “on the floor,” “at the door.”

There’s also an interpretation that suggests those lyrics are taken from a possible conversation between Styles and his sister, Gemma, after their parents' divorce.

The pills mentioned in this verse are also reminiscent of the opening lines from “Meet Me In The Hallway:”

Meet me in the hallway, meet me in the hallway
I just left your bedroom, give me some morphine
Is there any more to do?

Styles also writes about his self-destructive behaviours on tracks such as April 2017’s “Ever Since New York,” as well as December 2019’s “To Be So Lonely.”

annotations.lyric_fragment: You know it’s not the same as it was

annotation.plain:
In a May 2022 interview for Apple Music, Styles explained his perspective on this line:

For me, everything that happened in the pandemic, like, it’s never gonna be the same as before. All of the things happening in the world, it was so obvious that you just can’t go backwards, whether that’s us as people, or me in my personal life, or any of those things, you learn so much in those moments. A force to, like, face things head-on, whether that is your least favourite things about the world, or your least favourite things about yourself, all of those things, you just can’t then pretend that stuff doesn’t exist.

This line reflects on how the passage of time affects on many things and changes its essence. On one side, maybe because of a breakup, a hypothetical couple has been affected by some circumstances that changed them and their ways of acting with each other.

On the other hand, Styles could be talking to himself, contemplating how time and the experiences he faced have modified him.

In both cases, Harry seems to have gone through situations like this one, as he wrote in a similar way in the 2017 track, “Two Ghosts.” His debut album song reflects on the major character developments of two people after some time:

We’re not who we used to be

annotations.lyric_fragment: Your love is like a shadow on me all of the time

annotation.plain:
This line is a double play on the song’s two themes. In a total eclipse, the moon casts a shadow (an umbra) that creates the total eclipse with a penumbra (outer shadow) that becomes the partial eclipse.  Here, his love, being like a shadow cast on her, places her in the titular total eclipse.  For the other theme, Vampires famously cast no shadow, which makes the fact that his love is like a shadow on her proof to her that his love is tangible in a way even his body is not.

https://www.britannica.com/science/eclipse/Solar-eclipse-phenomena

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Forever’s gonna start tonight
 Forever’s gonna start tonight

annotation.plain:
As the quote goes: ‘this is the first day of the rest of your life.’



 The Quotes is credited towards: John Denver .

annotations.lyric_fragment:
(Turn around, bright eyes)
 (Turn around, bright eyes)
 (Turn around)
 (Ooh-ooh)
 (Ah-ha, ah-ha)
 (Ah-ha, ah-ha)
 (Ooh-ooh)

annotation.plain:
The song ends with a beautiful outro – Roy Bittan playing a decorative and gentle piano part with Rory Dodd’s gentle vocals on top.

Maybe Jim Steinman can explain what “Turn around, bright eyes” truly means, but I think it’s better to keep it a mystery. The song opens and closes with these words, and you imagine it continues forever in the girl’s mind.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Every now and then, I know there’s no one in the universe
 As magical and wondrous as you

annotation.plain: This is one of my favourite lines from the song, and I think it reinforces my belief that “Total Eclipse of the Heart” is purely a love song. We had to cut the third verse out for radio airplay – Jim Steinman was gutted about that. It was like cutting up his baby!

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Every now and then, I get a little bit terrified
 But then I see the look in your eyes

annotation.plain:
In the music video, they used a lighting effect to give the school boys glowing eyes. We filmed the video at Holloway Sanatorium, a former Victorian gothic hospital near London – it’s all apartments now. It took two days to film. Jim Steinman wrote the storyboard and Russel Mulcahy directed.

They used to do electroshock treatment at the hospital. It was strange because the security guards brought in some dogs to guard the filming equipment. The dogs wouldn’t walk past the threshold of certain rooms – it was like they sensed something. The whole place had a very eerie feel.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
(Turn around, bright eyes)
 Every now and then, I fall apart
 (Turn around, bright eyes)
 Every now and then, I fall apart

annotation.plain: The key change when we arrive at the chorus is very dramatic. We move from E major to A-flat major, which, musically speaking, are far apart from each other. As the chorus goes on, the melody notes become progressively higher in line with the increased tension.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And I need you now tonight
 And I need you more than ever

annotation.plain: Some people think this song is about a vampire, but I’ve never understood that interpretation. Jim did once tell Playbill that he had been working on a musical interpretation of the silent film ‘Nosferatu’. I’ve always thought of “Total Eclipse” as an impassioned love song. Jim did eventually include the song – under the name “Totale Finsternis” – in his 1997 musical ‘Tanz der Vampire’, sung entirely in German. I performed an English/German duet version of that song with Florian Silbereisen in 2014.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I really need you tonight

annotation.plain: The climax of the song, with that high E-flat note. It took five minutes of build-up to get to this moment. In the studio, I always felt that Jim was pushing my voice to its limits. Maybe if I could go back in time, I’d have put the song down by a tone. But then, would it still have the same impact? The whole song is about someone being pushed to the very limits of existence.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Every now and then, I get a little bit restless
 And I dream of something wild

annotation.plain: The emotions are heightened in the second verse. Where before she was lonely, tired, nervous and terrified, she’s now feeling restless, helpless, angry, and still terrified. More instruments are introduced here – drums, bass, and some gentle, sigh-like backing vocals.

annotations.lyric_fragment: (Turn around)

annotation.plain: Rory Dodd sings the male vocals (Holly Sherwood and Eric Troyer join him on backing vocals). I met Jim Steinman at his New York apartment in 1982 – he invited me and my manager back a few weeks later when he and Rory performed “Total Eclipse of the Heart”. I couldn’t believe Jim was offering it to me. I cried when I heard the lyrics.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Loves horses and her boyfriend too

annotation.plain: The first two lines paint a wholesome picture: loves mom, faith in Jesus, patriotic American. The next two lines contrast by listing Elvis (“the Pelvis”), horses, and her boyfriend. All hinting at a more sensual side.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’m gonna free fall out into nothin’
 Gonna leave this world for a while

annotation.plain:
He wanna stop thinking about her for a while and take a break from his routine and need solitude.

This usually happens when a person is in depression.

He wanna write her name in the sky before doing this – it shows that he still loves her, miss her and he is not a bad boy, like the girl thinks.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And I’m a bad boy ’cause I don’t even miss her
 I’m a bad boy for breakin’ her heart

annotation.plain: Petty’s delivery of these lyrics is sardonic, even bitter.  This suggests that the circumstances of the breakup is more complex than just “bad boy breaks good girl’s heart.” In fact, there seems an implication that Petty’s “bad boy” is the one who got hurt, but the “good girl” is the one whose reputation is intact.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I wanna write her name in the sky

annotation.plain:
He knows he has to win her back, therefore he needs something dramatic, like writing her name in the sky with a plane. Love can drive you crazy.



This gesture is grand and romantic, and describing it the way Petty does here lends it cosmic implications. But skywriting is also markedly impermanent, suggesting that perhaps, despite his best intentions, his love for her will be temporary.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
She’s a good girl, loves her mama
 Loves Jesus and America too

annotation.plain: It is speculated that the first 5 lines of the song are inspired by Reseda-born “Queen of the Groupies” Pamela des Barres, whose best-selling memoir I’m with the Band was published in 1987–just two years before the release of “Free Fallin’”.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
All the vampires walkin’ through the valley
 Move west down Ventura Boulevard
 And all the bad boys are standing in the shadows
 And the good girls are home with broken hearts

annotation.plain:
The “vampires” are hungover men walking home after their nightly activities. These “bad boys” are leaving the suburbs (west down Ventura Boulevard, a major thoroughfare in Los Angeles) to head home, while the “good girls” they’ve taken advantage of are left wondering what went wrong.

Alternatively, on an episode of Geek & Sundry’s Twitch show “Gather Your Party” from May 25, 2018, actor Taliesin Jaffe, who was a part of LA’s goth scene in the 90s, suggested that the line may have referred to young goth kids hanging out at various gathering spots in that part of town. If this is true, it would connect “Free Fallin'” to “Zombie Zoo,” the last song on Full Moon Fever.

After Petty’s death in October, 2017, many fans dressed up in black and emulated the vampires in a walk down Ventura Blvd. as a tribute to the rock legend.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And I’m free
 Free fallin’
 Yeah, I’m free
 Free fallin’

annotation.plain:
Now that he’s broken up with his girlfriend, in one sense he is free and can now do whatever he wants without worrying about upsetting her, but on the other hand, he feels aimless and as if his life is a “free fall.”

Notice the movement from positive to negative territory. “Free” is to be liberated from oppression. “Free fall”, however, is the force of gravity exerted on an object in space. A free fall might end in a splat.

And the magic of this line is that the relation between “free” and “free fallin'” is vague. The relation can be either the contrast between positive and negative, or it can have no contrast in the sense that it is all positive. It is about asking yourself the question whether the obtained (absolute) freedom is something good or bad (for you); it’s about questioning who you are and who you want to be; it’s about identity.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I wanna glide down over Mulholland

annotation.plain: Mullholland Drive is a famous street in LA that gained even more attention after acclaimed director David Lynch used it as the title of his 2001 cult classic psychological thriller, which was in part about the trappings of fame and the plight of unsuccessful Hollywood starlets. The road goes up and over the hills separating the Westside of Los Angeles from the Valley.

annotations.lyric_fragment: She’s a good girl, crazy ’bout Elvis

annotation.plain:
On a summer morning in 1961, an 11-year-old Tom Petty sat on pine straw in his front yard, wondering how he was going to spend his day. By the end of the day, he had encountered Elvis Presley on the set of the 1962 movie Follow That Dream and knew he wanted to spend the rest of his life making music.

In Paul Zollo’s 2005 book Conversations with Tom Petty, Tom said:

I caught the fever that day and I never got rid of it. That’s what kicked off my love of music. And I’d never thought much about rock ‘n’ roll until that moment.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
It’s a long day livin’ in Reseda
 There’s a freeway runnin’ through the yard

annotation.plain:
Reseda is a family-oriented suburb in the San Fernando Valley in Los Angeles, California. The city has been referenced in a number of other songs, like Soul Coughing’s 1994 track “Screenwriter’s Blues,” and has been the location for many films, notably the original The Karate Kid, released in 1984.

Freeways dictate a lot of daily life in LA and in some cases they cut right through residential areas. No freeways actually run through Reseda, but California State Route 14 was once proposed as “Reseda Freeway” and was intended to cut through the town, but was ultimately cancelled before it got there and remains unfinished.

annotation.plain: He is watching a commercial about laundry detergent, but finds him inferior because “he doesn’t smoke the same cigarettes as he does”. The line “how white my shirts can be” could be misheard as “how white my church could be”, suggesting a political statement against segregation (which would be appropriate given the times).

annotation.plain:
Mick Jagger went on to say that, while the first line caused outrage for a supposedly sexual tone, the menstruation reference that follows went without notice:

They didn’t understand the dirtiest line. It’s just life. That’s what really happens to girls. Why shouldn’t people write about it?

annotation.plain: The song is all about annoyances that cause Mick’s lack of satisfaction in life. For starters, radio hosts who ramble with (supposedly clever) mindless banter.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Well he can’t be a man ’cause he doesn’t smoke
 The same cigarettes as me

annotation.plain:
Many people at the time speculated that the different kind of cigarettes here were of the marijuana persuasion.  Keith Richards told Rolling Stone that he wasn’t so sure:

 I don’t think that [lyric] is [a drug reference].  It might have been.  I don’t know if it was a sly reference to drugs or not.  After a while, one realizes that whatever one writes, it goes through other people, and it’s what gets to them.  Like the way people used to go through Dylan songs.  It don’t matter.  They’re just words.  Words is words

annotation.plain:
Sometimes you don’t make it. And that’s why the third verse is dark, because at the same time the city is intoxicating. It can sweep you up and you can get sidetracked. You get caught, you come here and you take the city for granted, nightlife, things like that.

— JAY-Z, Village Voice, 2010

annotations.lyric_fragment: Statue of Liberty, long live the World Trade

annotation.plain: Referencing the horrific attacks on the World Trade Center on September 11th, 2001, where 2 planes were hijacked and flown right into the 2 buildings causing both of the towers to collapse killing around 3000 people.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Took it to my stash spot, 560 State Street

annotation.plain:
A “stash spot” is a place to safely store cash and drugs. 560 State Street is a residential building in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn. Hov bought apartment 10B in the early-90’s, and lived there with B-High and Ty Ty. The apartment served as a stash spot for him.

Having moved out in 1997, he visited his old apartment with Ron Howard 15 years later for the Made In America documentary. As you can see in the below photo, the Barclays Center, which Hov is an investor in, is now a stones throw away from Hov’s old bachelor pad.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Yeah, I’m out that Brooklyn, now I’m down in Tribeca

annotation.plain:
Shawn Carter was born and raised in Brooklyn’s Marcy Houses. After overcoming the racial bias and sabotage displayed by the building’s other residents, he purchased his Hudson Street TriBeCa penthouse apartment in 2004. It is still the main New York residence of Jay and wife Beyoncé.

Fellow TriBeCa resident Robert DeNiro has received credit for the neighborhood’s mid-‘90s revitalization. DeNiro is one of the co-founders, and the public face, of the annual Tribeca Film Festival, as well as one of the co-founders of The Tribeca Grill and the production company TriBeCa Productions.

Back in 2012, DeNiro and Jay shared a few unpleasant words (mostly on DeNiro’s part) after he repeatedly failed to call the movie star back, and never delivered on a promise to record a song for the Tribeca Film Festival. DeNiro called him “rude [and] disrespectful,” with Hov replying that the veteran actor hadn’t shown him enough respect:

It doesn’t matter who you are, everybody has to be respectful and everybody has to be a human being, you know? No one’s above manners … We’re all human beings and we all have to be respectful to one another and that’s just standard. That’s how I carry on with anybody.

In February 2016 they re-united publically at the amFAR Gala, signalling their issues had been resolved.



DeNiro also sounds like “dinero,” the Spanish word for money. In his previous career as a drug dealer Hov would follow the money across the city; and later his success in the rap game meant he was able to pay $6.85 million for his penthouse.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Sittin’ courtside, Knicks and Nets give me high fives

annotation.plain:
At the time of recording Jay-Z was a co-owner of the NBA’s Brooklyn Nets, and Brooklyn’s own Spike Lee is known as the quintessential court-side sitter at New York Knicks games. Like Spike, Hov sits so close to the court that he could stick his foot out a little too far and trip a referee.

When you front row at the Knicks game, those the Spike Lees
You front row everywhere, you in the H.O.V.’s

In an interview with Time Out magazine in September 2008, Jay named Spike Lee as one of his favorite New Yorkers, saying:

… because he’s a fixture courtside. When you think about the city, you think of [him.]

annotations.lyric_fragment: Me? I’m out that Bed-Stuy, home of that boy Biggie

annotation.plain: Jay-Z and his close friend The Notorious B.I.G. were both born and raised in the Brooklyn neighborhood of Bedford-Stuyvesant.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Say “What up?” to Ty Ty, still sippin’ Mai Tais

annotation.plain:
Tyran “Ty Ty” Smith is Jay’s right-hand man, who has been working alongside him since the early Roc-A-Fella Records days. He is currently an A&R executive at Roc Nation, an entertainment company he co-founded with Hov in 2008.



Since the ‘90s Hov and Ty Ty have been together, ordering themselves a Mai Tai, which is an alcoholic cocktail based on rum, Curaçao liqueur, orgeat syrup and lime juice.

Can’t stop I, from drinking Mai Tais, with Ty Ty

annotations.lyric_fragment: (You welcome, OG; uh)

annotation.plain:
Yankee Stadium is in Morrissania, a section of the Bronx which is oft nicknamed “The X.” Jay is at the game with his close friend and 40/40 Club co-owner Juan “OG” Perez, who Hov also shouts out in “My 1st Song” and “Success.”

Juan’s wife, Desiree Perez, is a close friend and adviser to Yankee’s controversial player Alex Rodriguez, so it’s no coincidence that Hov is there with him.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Shit, I made the Yankee hat more famous than a Yankee can

annotation.plain:
In the greatest Yankees rap reference of all-time, Jay-Z proclaims that he is a major reason for the high sales of New York Yankees headwear. Since the beginning of his career Hov has proudly worn a Yankees fitted to show support for his favorite MLB team; and his influence has rubbed off on the general public.

Jay told Village Voice:

I believe it to be true. Not in the way that I’m bigger than the Yankees, but in the way where when I tour London and Canada and there’s a whole crowd full of people wearing Yankee hats, they don’t have Yankee hats on there because it’s Yankees, they have Yankee hats to show they’re rolling with me that night.

This line would come full circle for Hov when he performed the track live at Yankee Stadium prior to the start of Game 2 of the 2009 World Series:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N7HAMsB2FLc
Jay was able to explore the field before his performance, and described the feeling of hearing his music being played there in an interview with ESPN:


I felt like a kid. The field is beautiful. I’ve never been that close to the field. Walking around, I jumped over the center-field fence and everything, like I was catching a home run.

Incredible. Beyond explanation. Just the whole fact, being in Yankee Stadium, really interacting, knowing the players. I grew up a fan of the Yankees – Reggie Jackson, Mickey Rivers, Chris Chambliss, God bless Thurman Munson, all these guys. To be there and interact with all these guys [the current Yankee team], they’re throwing the Roc sign up – it’s fantastic."

annotations.lyric_fragment: Sweet Caroline

annotation.plain:
The “Caroline” in question is Caroline Kennedy, having been inspired by a picture Neil had seen of her. The picture in question was of Caroline over-equiped in riding gear next to a pet pony when she was 9 years old, and the innocence and spectacle of it all prompted him to start writing something with “sweet Caroline,” incorporated in the lyrics. Neil always dreamed of performing the song for her, which he did on her 50th birthday.

When he finished writing the rest of the song it actually became about Neil’s then-wife Marsha.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Suitcase of memories
 Time after

annotation.plain:
“Suitcase of memories” was one of the first lines written for the song, penned by co-writer Rob Hyman of The Hooters. Cyndi was struck by it and said it was a “wonderful line”.

Coincidentally, both were having relationship problems at the time of writing this song, with Rob just going through a breakup and Cyndi having troubles with her then-boyfriend and manager.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
If you’re lost, you can look and you will find me
 Time after time
 If you fall, I will catch you, I’ll be waiting
 Time after time

annotation.plain:
Rob Hyman recalled recording the backing vocals on the chorus:

I added my voice just as a reference for another singer, a male-female dialogue thing, as if they’re singing to each other. When Cyndi listened back, she liked it and said, “We’re keeping it.”

annotations.lyric_fragment: The drum beats out of time

annotation.plain: This could be about how sometimes the only reason relationships never happened or relationships don’t work out is because the timing is just not right. One person has just gotten out of a serious relationship, or one person is already in a relationship, or they are pursuing their own goals, etc. The drum could also symbolize their heartbeats, which aren’t quite synchronized together.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Sometimes you picture me, I’m walkin’ too far ahead

annotation.plain:
This line could go along with the “go slow” line. He thinks she is taking things too fast. In his head, she is walking much too far ahead of him in the relationship. He isn’t ready to go that far yet, perhaps physically or emotionally.

It also could be about a guy who longs for her. He really wants to be with her, but she is always just out of reach. “The drum beats out of time,” and it’s never the right time for them to be together. Whenever he tries to picture being with her, she is just too far away, always right out of his reach.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You say, “Go slow,” I fall behind

annotation.plain:
Sometimes when someone tells  you to go slow in a relationship, your blossoming feelings may atrophy and eventually fade completely and you ‘fall behind’.

On the other end, your feelings could already be strong and you are asked to go slow so you feel like your feelings aren’t reciprocated so you stop trying with the relationship and ‘fall behind’

In this song, I think Cyndi is going for the second meaning.

annotation.plain:
Lauper explained to the Wall Street Journal:

My repeating “time after time” as a fading whisper at the end just happened. I had fallen into a trance and came out of it like that, singing softly. I wanted it to sound hushed, like my voice was trailing off into the distance.

 If you fall, I will catch you, I’ll be waiting
 Time after time
 If you’re lost, you can look and you will find me
 Time after time
 If you fall, I will catch you, (I’ll be waiting) I will be waiting

annotation.plain:
Cyndi Lauper talked about writing this hook with Rob Hyman in an interview with the Wall Street Journal:


We started by putting together a list of song titles. I thumbed through a TV Guide magazine. One movie title seemed good—a sci-fi film called “Time After Time” from 1979. I never meant for it to be the song’s real title. It was just supposed to get me thinking…

While Rob [Hyman] played, I stood next to the piano and danced, kind of free form. Moving around like that to the music helped me figure out how the song should feel. I wanted to catch a vibe off what Rob was doing.

Rob had just the chorus—a good melody but no words. As I danced to what Rob played I started thinking about up and down, lost and found: “If you fall I will catch you, I will be waiting / Time after time” and “If you’re lost you can look and you will find me / Time after time.” It sounded odd at first, but when I sang it, I realized what I was talking about. They were pieces of my personal life.


At the time, Rob Hyman was coming off of a breakup while Lauper was having her own issues with her then-boyfriend/manager Dave Wolff.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You’re callin’ to me, I can’t hear what you’ve said
 Then you say, ”Go slow”, I fall behind
 The second hand unwinds

annotation.plain:
Cyndi Lauper talked to The Wall Street Journal about this line:

That was inspired by [producer] Rick [Chertoff]. At some point in the studio, his watch came in contact with something and it became demagnetized. Its second hand was going backward and he was saying, “Look, look, my second hand is unwinding.” I loved that line.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
After my picture fades and darkness has turned to gray
 Watchin’ through windows, you’re wondering if I’m okay

annotation.plain:
Cyndi Lauper talked to The Wall Street Journal about this line:

[That] was about my past relationships. I used to sit up on that loft bed and look out the window and watch darkness turn to gray, thinking about them.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Lyin’ in my bed, I hear the clock tick and think of you

annotation.plain:
Cyndi Lauper talked to The Wall Street Journal about this line:


The first verse I wrote was, “Lying in my bed I hear the clock tick/and think of you.” That was about my life. I had a clock that I got for my birthday that I kept up on my loft bed in my one-bedroom walk-up apartment on 77th St. near York Ave. Dave Wolff, my boyfriend and manager at the time, had climbed up to sleep and the clock fell and smashed. I loved that clock.

Dave went and got a windup clock from his mother’s house. But when we set it up, it was so loud. I climbed down and put it in the tub and closed the curtain. But I could still hear it ticking from the bed. I remember lying there and thinking about all this personal stuff I had gone through.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You need to give it up

annotation.plain:
This could be referring to 3 similar but slightly different things


Surrender or concede: In a more general context, “give it up” can mean to surrender, concede, or yield. For example, this woman is trying to say the other should stop trying to make the man love her because he doesn’t
Offer or provide: “Give it up” can also be used to mean offering or providing something.



For instance, in this context this means the other women (second woman displayed by Monica) could say that she is giving this man to her (first woman displayed by Brandy). Of course this is a form of figurative speech because you can’t legally “give over a man” to another woman.


Stop doing something: In some situations, “give it up” can mean to stop doing something, especially when the activity is seen as negative or harmful. For example, in this context this could mean that the second woman should  stop saying such lies that the man loves her and that she must be delusional or confused if she seriously means it.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Keep on with the force, don’t stop

annotation.plain:
This is commonly believed to be a reference to the Force, the metaphysical power from the Star Wars movie franchise. The first Star Wars film was released just 2 years prior to this song, and Michael Jackson was notably a big fan of the series. He had life-size statues of several characters from the movie at his Neverland Ranch, and even collaborated with Star Wars creator George Lucas in 1986 on his own science fiction short film called Captain EO:



The line has gone on to become one of the most misheard lyrics in pop music, both due to the esoteric reference and the way the vocals are sung. It is also difficult to hear the word “stop” in the song as it is sung much softer and is largely buried by the instrumentation – however, it can be clearly heard in the isolated vocal track.

So – the time wasted is not really a waste, perfectly put by John Lennon –

annotation.plain:
This is a somehow controversial verse. It has to be taken in the context of other Cars songs that have dark, brooding lyrics, some leftovers from the teenage years maybe.

There are hints of codependency – “loss of Self in Others” here – the need to nurture somebody else, magnified by the fact that she is his love object. Not a negative trait in case of pure two way love.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You always knew to wear it well and
 You look so fancy I can tell

annotation.plain:
A double entendre here, using the “wear” on two levels.

If joined by the second line – a straight compliment to her looks and general appearance.

However, “You Wear It Well” also signifies adaptation, portraying age and experience and general attitude.

The phrase has been made common by Rod Stewart hit with the same name –

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rsqKdZ3JZ2k

annotations.lyric_fragment:
It doesn’t matter where you’ve been
 As long as it was deep, yeah

annotation.plain:
Seems disjointed, unless one notices the clever juxtaposition to the previous two lines:

“I don’t mind your hangin' out…..It doesn’t matter where you’ve been” – a super tolerant person he is….

And –

“And talking in your sleep….As long as it was deep”.

This way, it makes perfect sense.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I don’t mind you hangin’ out
 And talkin’ in your sleep

annotation.plain:
If he can hear her talking in her sleep, they are much more than just “hanging out”.
Conspiracy theorist may suggest that it was innocent – as part of sleepwalking. Regardless – the point he makes is clear – she can do no wrong in his eyes, even regardless what she says while sleep Talking.

annotations.lyric_fragment: It’s not the ribbons in your hair

annotation.plain:
Ribbons in a girl’s hair symbolize childish innocence and purity, though from the ‘60s the scope has expanded.

It even drew some example for the message behind ribbons.



Her “purity” is not an attraction factor – and as the perfume in the previous lines, “external' factors are not determinants in his love attraction to her.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I guess you’re just what I needed
 (Just what I needed)

annotation.plain:
Many of the song’s admirers use the same words to describe the song’s (and by extension, The Cars) effect on them.

In the late ‘70s music lovers were recovering from glam rock, “sweet” (Abba…) rock and disco, and this song and other new wave by groups like Foreigner, Styx, Journey and others was “just what they needed”.

annotations.lyric_fragment: And wastin’ all my time

annotation.plain:
A tongue in cheek statement – he would never have been so infatuated with her, let alone write a song about her, had she wasted his time.

An example of turning a negative phrase 180 degrees, to achieve the opposite meaning.

Kind of like today’s “sick”, or yesterday’s “bad”.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Chorus]

annotation.plain:
For obvious reasons, the Kansas City Royals fandom embraced the song (even if the team wasn’t so enthusted, except the resident organist).

It got to the point one year later, KC was back in the World Series against the San Francisco Giants, and the Bay Area retaliated by banning Lorde from the radio. A 2015 return actually resulted in a Royals title, and all the Lorde jokes one would expect.

https://twitter.com/royals/status/447230300397924352

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Video by Joel Kefali]

annotation.plain:
Shot in what might be called a “normcore aesthetic,” the video for “Royals” features slow motion shots of everyday teenage youth—Lorde’s schoolmates. While the US version includes several close-ups of Lorde herself, she rarely appears in the International version, about which she commented:

The music video for me was about creating a piece of art and I wanted it to feel cinematic and like it’s something you can immerse yourself in. Having me in it didn’t feel like something that was necessary to create that world. So I’m just in it for just a little bit. I think it works well.

Lorde released the official “Royals” video via her YouTube channel on May 12, 2013, followed by a U.S. version released on VEVO on June 18. It won ‘Best Rock Video’ at the 2014 VMA’s, and has amassed more than 565 million views as of March 2016.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Produced by Joel Little]

annotation.plain:
Joel Little produced and co-wrote “Royals”, as he did on every song on The Love Club and Pure Heroine. Little included no samples in the final, pared-down mix.

“Royals,” is phenomenally self-possessed,“ writes Sam Lansky of Idolator

… all finger snaps and toe-tapping bass and lyrics that turn the aspirationalism of hip-hop culture on its head.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
My friends and I, we’ve cracked the code
 We count our dollars on the train to the party
 And everyone who knows us knows
 That we’re fine with this, we didn’t come from money

annotation.plain:
We already know from the song’s opening verse that Lorde and her friends aren’t an affluent bunch, but it’s not as if they’re impoverished. They can still socialize and have a good time–they just keep to a budget instead of blowing money needlessly like the “royals” they see in music videos. Lorde’s friend group has a clear perspective (“cracked the code”) on its place in the world, making its lack of riches a joke to them.

Lorde stated in an interview with Rolling Stone that she is fascinated with old money:

I’ve always been fascinated with aristocracy. I’m really interested in the Ivy Leagues, the final clubs, all the really old-money families, the concept of old money.

Lorde’s interest manifests itself through her Queen Bee persona and the fact that the theme of opulence and her problems with what opulence stands for pervades most of her older songs.

annotations.lyric_fragment: We don’t care, we aren’t caught up in your love affair

annotation.plain:
The love affair is the public’s love affair with the opulent lifestyle that the media sells them. Lorde isn’t interested in this opulence, as she told Interview Magazine in 2013:

Around the middle of last year I started listening to a lot of rap, like Nicki Minaj and Drake, as well as pop singers like Lana Del Rey. They all sing about such opulence, stuff that just didn’t relate to me—or anyone that I knew.  I began thinking, “How are we listening to this? It’s completely irrelevant.”

While she may admire certain artists' “musicianship and careers,” Lorde doesn’t care for all the swagger and bravado that has become synonymous with pop music fame and feels her life is better off for it.

annotations.lyric_fragment: That kind of luxe just ain’t for us

annotation.plain:
Lorde previously used the term “lux” in “400 Lux.” While it is seemingly being used as shorthand for luxury here, a lux is also a unit of illumination.

Since bright lights are often used as a metaphor for fame (e.g. Kanye’s “All of the Lights”), Lorde is letting us know that she doesn’t envy or desire anyone trapped in the bright lights of fame.



Premiere at Grauman’s Chinese Theatre, Hollywood, 1927. Via LA Public Library Image Archive

annotations.lyric_fragment:
But everybody’s like
 Cristal, Maybach, diamonds on your timepiece
 Jet planes, islands, tigers on a gold leash

annotation.plain:
Much like the opening of Pink Floyd’s “Money,” Lorde rattles off a list of high status symbols before moving on to the ridiculous and bloated. It’s a rhetorical transformation that captures the ludicrous essence of excess.

This part of the pre-chorus caught criticism for seemingly singling out the hip-hop genre. As Verónica Bayetti Flores, an outspoken feminist, wrote: “we all know who she’s thinking when we’re talking gold teeth, Cristal and Maybachs.” Rap Stats can confirm that Maybach cars, Cristal champagne, and diamonds are all hip-hop staples:



Ultimately, while some felt Lorde could have been more mindful considering the negative stereotypes hip-hop videos can create for African-Americans, most journalists (especially international journalists) disagreed with Flores. In a post titled “Intercultural Competence”, Martin Boyd dismissed Flores argument as ethnocentric, reminding Flores that Lorde is from New Zealand. Since Lorde derives her entire understanding of America through these music videos, it isn’t a generalization for her to say that every American she sees is participating in these activities. Another New Zealand journalist, Lynda Brendich, echoed that “not everything in this world should be viewed through the lens of Americans, particularly when it comes to race and cultures of other countries.”

Lorde declined to comment on the controversy.

annotations.lyric_fragment: We don’t care, we’re driving Cadillacs in our dreams

annotation.plain:
Lorde originally wrote this line when she was 12, in a journal that she rediscovered later in life. In the context of this song, it means Lorde enjoys the luxury these expensive items provide but hates what they represent. This makes driving a Cadillac in your dreams the best of both worlds – Lorde can enjoy the Caddy in the comfort of her own mind without worrying about the message it sends.



The mention of Cadillacs shows that “Royals” is especially about American music. Cadillac has been building powerful luxury cars for American figures such as Al Capone, Elvis Presley, President Obama, and Big Boi, since before WWII.

Lorde re-used the line as a tag for her Tumblr.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
(Oh, oh-oh)
 We’re bigger than we ever dreamed
 And I’m in love with being queen
 (Oh, oh-oh)

annotation.plain:
“Royals” topped both the Alternative and Rock Airplay Charts, became a Top 10 Hit, and even reached #1 on the Billboard Hot 100 – the highest ascent for a solo female’s first appearance since M.I.A.’s “Paper Planes”.

Before her fame – when she penned the lyrics to this song – Lorde may have been queen of her small clique, but that was enough for her to feel satisfied. After she grabbed the media spotlight, Lorde told The Guardian that, while growing up, her favourite author was Raymond Carver. It’s no surprise that she liked the famous realist author: one of his re-occuring themes is the “extraordinary in the ordinary". Lorde’s success, in a way, could be seen as Carveresque, she championed “the ordinary” and it made her famous.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
We crave a different kind of buzz
 Let me be your ruler (Ruler)
 You can call me queen bee
 And baby, I’ll rule (I’ll rule, I’ll rule, I’ll rule)
 Let me live that fantasy

annotation.plain:
As Lorde suggested earlier when she fantasized about Cadillacs, she isn’t immune to temptation. She just understands that not all desires should be acted upon. If you can’t own a Caddy or be a ruler, there’s no need to cut someone’s throat – you can still drive one in your dreams or be a leader in your friend group.



On her tumblr, Lorde confirmed this was in reference to a honey bee, not Beyoncé. The “buzz” can refer to the excitement that comes with a life full of “luxe”, but is also the sound the bee makes; the pun also calls back to Lorde’s self-proclaimed title: Queen Bee.

And I forget just why I taste
Oh yeah, I guess it makes me smile
I found it hard, it's hard to find
Oh well, whatever, never mind

Hello, hello, hello, how low

A denial, a denial

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Our little group has always been
 And always will until the end

annotation.plain:
The “True Meaning of ‘Smells Like Teen Spirit’” has been the source of much debate since its release in September 1991. Several years later, in January of 1994, Kurt Cobain would famously admit to Rolling Stone that he was just “trying to write the ultimate pop song.”

His signature use of sarcasm and nihilistic wordplay throughout Nirvana’s catalog makes it easy to write these cryptic lines off as meaningless; however, different iterations of Cobain’s hand-written lyrics depict a much darker inception.



This scan is taken from page 141 of Kurt Cobain’s Journals, published in November 2002—just eight years after his alleged suicide in April 1994 at the age of 27. According to the LiveNirvana song guide, the original words were:

The secret handshakes pretend
Our little group has always been and always will until the end
We cut our hands & made a pact & swore we’re never going back

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Guitar Solo]

annotation.plain:
Kurt Cobain’s guitar solo is as simple as the chords required for this song. The guitar part is very similar to the vocal line sung by Kurt in verse one and two.



Guitar World magazine ranked it at #26 on their list of the ‘Greatest Guitar Solos of All Time.’

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Hello, hello, hello, how low
 Hello, hello, hello, how low
 Hello, hello, hello, how low
 Hello, hello, hello

annotation.plain:
Kurt Cobain is playing with assonance—or, the repetition of a vowel sound to create internal rhyme—perhaps in order to underscore the prevalence of nonsense in most mainstream music.

This is regarded as one of the most interesting sections Cobain ever wrote. The repetition of “hello” sounds rather simple; even dumb or silly. A slight change in pronunciation becomes a typical, depression-oriented Nirvana line, with “how low” likely being a commentary on Kurt’s mood.



An alternative interpretation points out that “hello” becomes “hollow,” just like the average artist’s method for lyric-writing relies on basic repetitions, or catchiness over meaning.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And I forget just why I taste
 Oh yeah, I guess it makes me smile

annotation.plain:
When people inject drugs, they “taste” that drug in their mouth. Thus, getting high is sometimes called “having a taste.” This probably refers to Kurt’s well-known drug use. He has stated on multiple occasions that drugs, especially his heroin habit, made him feel better.

It might also allude to why he makes music. Kurt’s alleged suicide note—which has been transcribed—includes the following statement:

I haven’t felt the excitement of listening to as well as creating music along with reading and writing for too many years now. I feel guilty beyond words about these things.

It can also extend beyond his feelings on music, and into life. Two of his uncles committed suicide, and Kurt suffered from bipolar disorder. He had frequent mood swings, causing him to feel conflicting emotions toward fame, drug use, the music industry, and his own identity.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I found it hard, it’s hard to find
 Oh well, whatever, never mind

annotation.plain: This example of epanodos presents Cobain acknowledging (and perhaps mocking) his own tendency towards “simple, abstract, and nihilistic” lyrics. It is also a reference to the group’s album Nevermind, which this song is featured on.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Load up on guns, bring your friends
 It’s fun to lose and to pretend

annotation.plain:
Some listeners thought that “Smells Like Teen Spirit” was a call for revolution. However, this gun reference is a possible allusion to getting “loaded” on heroin or other drugs. Nirvana’s Top of the Pops performance included altered lyrics:

Load up on drugs, kill your friends
It’s fun to lose and to defend

“In Bloom” also has a reference to guns being used for amusement.

The opening line of Kurt Cobain’s most famous tune would take on an eerie resonance when a shotgun became the symbol of his questionable 1994 death, presumably by suicide.



The second line may imply that when someone is down on their luck, they can keep their spirits up by pretending things are alright—a sentiment that might have been fueled by Cobain’s breakup with former girlfriend Tobi Vail.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’m worse at what I do best
 And for this gift, I feel blessed

annotation.plain:
Kurt’s saying that the more he practices something, the better he gets at it – but once he begins to understand it too well, he no longer finds it as fascinating as he did when he knew nothing about it.

“And for this gift, I feel blessed” shows Kurt realizing that the things he does best in life are done far better by others. He’s using irony to show that he is in fact depressed by the thought that there are people that do what he does best far better than him.

It is a depressing feeling to realize your best traits are inadequate in comparison to others.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Here we are now, entertain us
 I feel stupid and contagious
 Here we are now, entertain us

annotation.plain:
Kurt’s depression was well-documented. He was an extremely humble and self-deprecating individual, coming to loathe his fame and hating the image that the media portrayed of him. It is ironic that in the song that propelled him to stardom he alludes to his disgust with himself.

This also has a tie to his suicide note where he feels that his daughter Frances B. Cobain would grow up to be like him, his worst fear. He says to Boddah (His imaginary friend) that she,

Reminds me too much of what I used to be, full of love and joy, kissing every person she meets because everyone is good and will do her no harm. And that terrifies me to the point to where I can barely function. I can’t stand the thought of Frances becoming the miserable, self-destructive, death rocker that I’ve become."

In an interview with Rolling Stone, Cobain explained the “Here we are now, entertain us” line saying:

That came from something I used to say every time I used to walk into a party to break the ice. A lot of times, when you’re standing around with people in a room, it’s really boring and uncomfortable. So it was “Well, here we are, entertain us. You invited us here.”

In this setting, Kurt uses the line to mock his fans' attitude. “Teen Spirit” ends up being a bunch of teenage fans that expect to be entertained. Kurt feels the pressure of this demand, and he is cynical about the selfish desires that underlie fandom.

Justin Timberlake would later pay homage to this lyric in his collaboration with rapper JAY-Z, Holy Grail, the opening track off of the latter’s thirteenth album.

And we all just entertainers
And we’re stupid and contagious
And we all just entertainers

annotations.lyric_fragment:
A mulatto, an albino
 A mosquito, my libido, yeah

annotation.plain:
The word “mulatto” is an outdated term for a person of mixed European/African ancestry; someone with tan skin. In modern times, it is looked at as offensive or derogatory. More acceptable classifications would be “mixed” or “biracial.” Albinism, from the Latin word albus, meaning “white,” is a genetic condition which results in melanin deficiency; the complex polymer responsible for pigmentation in skin.

Both of these terms can be seen as opposites, even though people of mixed race have the same chances of being born with albinism. Due to the inherent differences from the Western “norm,” these separate groups of people may feel “left out” in society. This could be one of the reasons why Kurt Cobain mentioned them—because he could relate to not fitting in.

Interestingly, a “Mulatto,” an “Albino,” and a “Mosquito” are all different types of old-fashioned cocktails. It is widely known that alcoholic beverages are capable of enhancing one’s libido, or sex drive.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
She’s over-bored and self-assured
 Oh no, I know a dirty word

annotation.plain:
This line, and much of Nevermind, is about Bikini Kill drummer Tobi Vail, who began dating Kurt Cobain in 1990. According to Everett True’s 2006 book Nirvana: The Biography:


The couple started dating officially a week before Tobi’s 21st birthday, July 1990—when [his previous girlfriend] Tracy moved out of the Pear St. apartment, to go back to Tacoma.

Tobi was different from Tracy in terms of how she viewed relationships: where Tracy was nurturing, Tobi considered herself an equal, not to be taken advantage of. It was quite an eye-opener for Kurt, who up to that point had undeniably been influenced by society’s insidious belief that it’s a man who is the leader, woman the comforter.


The second line regarding “a dirty word” is largely open to interpretation.

annotations.lyric_fragment: But confess

annotation.plain: The word confess has two main meanings; the first being confessing to a lie, aka telling the truth. The second meaning is to tell someone your feelings about them. In this story it could be the guy telling the author that they love them, or the author confessing their feelings (probably negative) to the lover. It could also mean one of the characters confessing to their wrongs, such as being a bad partner (ex; cheating, lying, treating them poorly, etc…)

annotations.lyric_fragment:
[Verse 2]
 You keep lying when you ought to be truthing
 You keep losing when you ought to not bet
 You keep saming when you ought to be changing
 Now what’s right is right, but you ain’t been right yet

annotation.plain:
Nancy uses two neoligisms, truthing and saming, to describe how this guy is doing everything he shouldn’t be doing.

The final line of verse two may allude to William Penn’s quote:

Right is right, even if everyone is against it, and wrong is wrong, even if everyone is for it

annotations.lyric_fragment:
[Verse 3]
 You keep playing where you shouldn’t be playing
 And you keep thinking that you’ll never get burnt, hah
 Well, I’ve just found me a brand new box of matches, yeah
 And what he knows, you ain’t had time to learn

annotation.plain:
Seemingly calling upon the old idiom:

If you play with fire, you’re gonna get burned

The saying basically warns that if you do something dangerous, you’re going to get hurt.

In this case, this guy has been messing around with other girls, so she is going to be the one to hurt him – symbolized by the box of matches that will do the metaphorical burning.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Yeah, but you don’t care

annotation.plain: Huey is likely taking about empathetic love here. In a situation where a loved one is hurt by someone else, it’s easy to see that not all behavior is justified or “fair” by love.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You feel the power of love
 Can you feel it?
 Hmm-mm, hmm

annotation.plain:
Huey responds to his own question here, in case you didn’t catch that. He says hmm hmm, as in “yes”. In fact, in the 1986 Fore! Tour, he replaces the hmm hmm lyric with “Yes I can”.

The guitar solo is placed perfectly in the song because it also represents the striking discovery of reciprocated love. The initial bend of the guitar solo is meant to represent someone loving you back.

annotations.lyric_fragment: And with a little help from above

annotation.plain: With a little luck and effort, your love interest might love you back. It’s at this point that you “feel” the power of love.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
But you know what to do
 When it gets hold of you

annotation.plain: Huey is saying that you already know what love costs for you. The tricky part is staying committed through those sacrifices.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
But you’ll be glad, baby, when you’ve found
 That’s the power, makes the world go ’round

annotation.plain:
Huey Lewis takes the classic proverb, “Love makes the world go ‘round” and rewrites it a bit to match the beat and the rest of the lyrics.

By the way, here’s a partial list of the songs about how love makes the world go ‘round:

https://genius.com/Madonna-love-makes-the-world-go-round-lyrics
https://genius.com/Kiki-dee-love-makes-the-world-go-round-lyrics
https://genius.com/The-melodians-love-makes-the-world-go-round-lyrics
https://genius.com/Deon-jackson-love-makes-the-world-go-round-lyrics
https://genius.com/Ashlee-simpson-love-makes-the-world-go-round-lyrics
https://genius.com/Paul-anka-love-makes-the-world-go-round-lyrics

annotations.lyric_fragment: More than a feeling; that’s the power of love

annotation.plain:
Nice tip of the hat to “More than a Feeling” by Boston, one of the Classic Rock bands of the 70s whose sound had a strong influence on Huey Lewis and the News.

The sentiment, for both Boston and Huey Lewis, is that love is far too powerful to be lumped together with other feelings; it’s in a class of its own.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
It’s strong and it’s sudden and it’s cruel sometimes
 But it might just save your life

annotation.plain: Love is passionate and careless in its choosing. It’s cruel if you love someone you can’t have, but it can change your life for the better if you’re lucky.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Tougher than diamonds and stronger than steel
 You won’t feel nothin’ ’til you feel

annotation.plain:
Diamonds, on Moh’s scale of mineral hardness, are ranked as the hardest mineral on earth.



Steel is a very strong and versatile alloy.

For something to be tougher than diamonds and stronger than steel would mean you were dealing with a daunting power; the power of love.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Make a bad one good, make a wrong one right

annotation.plain: Love can make bad people into good people. And the other way around.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Change a hawk to a little white dove

annotation.plain:
Love can make the toughest, scariest guy (a hawk) become gentle and peaceful (a dove).

Hawks are often used as a symbol of war, hence the term war hawk, while doves are often used as a symbol of peace.
