annotations.lyric_fragment: Nibblin’ on sponge cake

annotation.plain:
“Sponge cake” has become a popular phrase due to the famous line from the iconic song “Margaritaville” by Jimmy Buffett: “Nibblin' on sponge cake.” While seemingly lighthearted and casual, this line holds a deeper meaning beyond its surface level.

Sponge cake is a soft, light, and airy dessert that has been enjoyed by people around the world for centuries. Its origins can be traced back to the Mediterranean region, particularly to Italy and Spain. The cake gets its unique texture and sponginess from a careful balance of ingredients, including flour, sugar, eggs, and sometimes butter or oil. It is leavened mainly by beaten eggs, resulting in its distinct airy texture.

Metaphorically, the act of “nibbling on sponge cake” in the song represents a carefree and indulgent mindset, highlighting the joys of simple pleasures. It symbolizes finding contentment and bliss in life’s small and humble moments. It encourages us to appreciate the sweetness of life, even in the smallest moments, by savoring the metaphorical sponge cake.

By associating sponge cake with a relaxed and carefree attitude, the song reminds us to shift our focus from the pressures and complexities of life and find joy in the present moment. It encourages us to adopt a mindset that allows us to take a step back, breathe, and enjoy the delightful simplicity that life can offer.

So, when contemplating the phrase “nibblin' on sponge cake,” let it serve as a reminder to relish the simple pleasures, find contentment in the present, and embrace a carefree mindset that allows us to savor life’s sweetest moments.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Cut my heel, had to cruise on back home

annotation.plain: In live performances, Buffett often altered this line to “Broke my leg twice, had to limp on back home.”

annotations.lyric_fragment: There’s a woman to blame

annotation.plain: The narrator lives alone and apparently spends most of his time drinking, His acquaintances speculate as to what may have caused this self-destructive behavior.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
But there’s booze in the blender and soon it will render
 That frozen concoction that helps me hang on

annotation.plain:
We all know what “frozen concoction” Buffet is talking about:

https://static.skillshare.com/cdn-cgi/image/quality=80,width=1000,format=auto/uploads/project/aac6778aa4724a354f0bcc70fb666724/fa18460f

annotations.lyric_fragment: Now I think, hell, it could be my fault

annotation.plain: Throughout the choruses of the song, the last line is the only line that changes. At first, he blames “a woman”, but now he’s starting to think it’s his fault for getting wasted (drunk).

annotations.lyric_fragment: Woman

annotation.plain: Possibly Eve: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Original_sin

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Verse 3]

annotation.plain:
In the original version, Buffett actually wrote another verse that goes:

Old men in tank tops, cruising the gift shops
Checking out chiquitas down by the shore
They dream about weight loss
Wish they could be their own boss
Those 3-day vacations become such a bore.

This verse was cut from the final recording of the song, but Buffett has performed the verse during concerts, referring to it as “the lost verse”. The lost verse can be heard on two lives albums: You Had To Be There: Recorded Live (1978) and Buffett Live: Tuesdays, Thursdays, And Saturdays (1999).

annotations.lyric_fragment:
A Mexican cutie
 How it got here I haven’t a clue

annotation.plain: When performing the song live, Buffett usually changes the lyrics to refer to the location where he’s performing. For example, in his live album Live In Cincinnati, OH, Buffett says “all those sweet Ohio cuties, or maybe she snuck over the border from Kentucky, I haven’t got a clue”.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I blew out my flip-flop, stepped on a pop top

annotation.plain:
Way back when, flip-flops were very cheaply constructed rubber shoes. The thong part that went between your toes would easily come apart, thus ‘blowing out’ your flip flop.

A pop-top is a metal tab that can come off of a drink can, be it beer or soda pop. They were often found littered on the side of the road. They had a sharp edge and would cut you if you stepped on it.

Producer Norbert Putnam told Sound On Sound:

One day in the studio, (Jimmy Buffet) comes in and starts telling me about a day he had in Key West. He was coming home from a bar and he lost one of his flip-flops and he stepped on a beer can top and he couldn’t find the salt for his Margarita. He says he’s writing lyrics to it and I say ‘That’s a terrible idea for a song.’ He comes back in a few days later with ‘Wasted Away Again In Margaritaville’ and plays it and right then everyone knows it’s a hit song.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
It’s gonna take a lot to drag me away from you
 There’s nothin’ that a hundred men or more could ever do

annotation.plain:
These lines are somewhat reminiscent of the traditional English idiom “wild horses couldn’t drag me,” which is used to indicate that someone would never abandon their goal or passion, regardless of the circumstances. Here, the narrator expresses his devotion to the romantic sentiments expressed throughout the song, asserting his will against any forces that may attempt to separate him from his subject.

As with much of the song, there is some ambiguity as to whether the subject is the female figure mentioned in Verse 1, or the continent of Africa itself, or perhaps just a general sentimental devotion.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Chorus: Bobby Kimball]

annotation.plain: Although sung by Bobby Kimball, the chorus was written by David Paich, who thought up the song after playing on his new keyboard and humming the melody.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
The wild dogs cry out in the night
 As they grow restless, longing for some solitary company

annotation.plain: The African wild dog is a canine species native to regions all across sub-Saharan Africa and can be found in the Tanzanian Serengeti, which is mentioned later in this verse. The howling of the wild dogs adds auditory details that evoke the sensations of awe inspired by the natural beauty of Africa, a prominent theme of the song. The dogs are also yearning for companionship, much like the song’s narrator.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I bless the rains down in Africa

annotation.plain:
In an interview with Grantland, songwriter David Paich said,

It was back in ’82. The chorus came very quickly, but I didn’t have a verse, I had the music. When I sat down and played the chorus, the way you hear it just came out: ‘It’s gonna take a lot to drag me away from you … I bless the rains down in Africa.’ I just stopped for a second. I said, ‘Whoa, whoa, I gotta write this down.‘ It’s different, and I wasn’t sure what it meant at the time.

Later, in an interview with The Guardian in early 2018, David elaborated:

One of the reasons I was in a rock band was to see the world. As a kid, I’d always been fascinated by Africa. I loved movies about Dr. Livingstone and missionaries. I went to an all-boys Catholic school, and a lot of the teachers had done missionary work in Africa. They told me how they would bless the villagers, their Bibles, their books, their crops and when it rained, they’d bless the rain. That’s where the hook line – “I bless the rains down in Africa” – came from.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I know that I must do what’s right
 As sure as Kilimanjaro rises like Olympus above the Serengeti

annotation.plain:
Mount Kilimanjaro is the tallest mountain in Tanzania, the tallest mountain in Africa and the tallest free-standing mountain in the world at 5,895 meters (2,977 meters higher than Olympus) or 19,341 feet above sea level.



 Mount Kilimanjaro

Saying Mount Kilimanjaro “rises like Olympus” isn’t exactly hyperbole, but it is incorrect to locate the mountain in the Serengeti. The Serengeti, while also in Tanzania, does not contain any mountains; however, it is still a notable region in Africa. It is an ecosystem that hosts the largest terrestrial animal migration in the world, making it one of the ten natural travel wonders of the world.



 An image of the Serengeti

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I seek to cure what’s deep inside
 Frightened of this thing that I’ve become

annotation.plain:
Paich told SongFacts.com,


“That was me using a lot of writer’s license.  I remember seeing lots of films of starving and famine when I was a kid in pictures of Africa. Then I’d seen some movies and read a lot of the National Geographics, and always wanted to go to Africa, so I romanticized this story about a social worker that goes over there and falls in love with working with the country and doing good.

But he also falls in love and has to make a choice between helping people for the rest of his life or having a family and doing that kind of thing.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Before this river becomes an ocean
 Before you throw my heart back on the floor

annotation.plain: Idiomatically, rivers and oceans are often associated with crying a lot. The lyrics make it clear that despite this person’s attractiveness, George doesn’t think they’ll treat him very well. Just like a river will let out into an ocean, George wants to heed the warning signs and get out of this relationship before it leads to more serious heartache.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Well it takes a strong man, baby
 But I’m showin’ you the door

annotation.plain:
Such an attractive person offers a strong temptation to men like George, and only an equally strong will could resist that and ask them to leave.

Calling himself a “strong man” also ties into the song’s branding of George Michael as a masculine heartthrob—the music video goes to great lengths to emphasize George Michael’s own physique.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I feel stressed out, I wanna let it go

annotation.plain: This song was released in 2009 which means that it was written during the height of the 2007-9 financial crisis. Fergie said in a behind the scenes video for this music video that they especially wanted to write party songs like this to help people let go of their financial problems for a bit and just have some fun. So the ‘stress’ is particularly poignant to the hard times then.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday (Do it)
 Friday, Saturday, Saturday to Sunday (Do it)

annotation.plain:
Here we see the songwriting talent of will.i.am at its absolute peak. He creates a running motif by listing off the days of the week. However, this creates a problem; there’s only seven days in a week, so the passage could only last three and a half measures instead of the required four.



However, will.i.am cleverly tackles this problem by repeating Saturday. Not only does this extend the passage to the correct length, but it also places emphasis on the days of the weekend, which he explores in the following lines. Additionally, will.i.am writes “Saturday to Sunday,” adding depth by suggesting that their weekend parties last overnight.

annotation.plain: Rolling Stone: “Berry Gordy initially resisted releasing ‘What’s Going On,’ telling Gaye that he thought scatting was out of date and protest lyrics were too commercially risky. But when the song became an instant hit, Gordy gave Gaye a single month to craft an album… What emerged was soul music’s first concept album” – and according to Rolling Stone in 2020, the greatest album of all time.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Chorus]

annotation.plain: The chorus in What’s Going On reflects the influence that the labor movement (and folk music in general) had on anti-war protest songs. Both genres were listened to by members of the progressive left because they had similar messages contained within lyrics. The allusion to “picket lines and picket signs” is a clear linkage between both genres. As Bierman illustrates in “Solidarity Together,” “music connected to labor falls under the heading of protest music.”

 Hey, man, what’s happening?
 Woo
 Everything is everything
 We’re gonna do a get down today, boy, I’ll tell ya

annotation.plain: The song begins with a faint sound bite detailing a reunion amongst family members. It’s supposed to represent a solider returning home from Vietnam reuniting with his family. The entire album is told from the point of view of a Vietnam veteran returning to America to witness hatred, suffering, and injustice.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Intro]

annotation.plain:
The name of this song and the LP it was published under share the same title: “Whats Going On”. This was the first ever concept album published by Gaye (a compilation of songs and melodies that are meant to portray an overall message, theme or narrative). “Whats Going On” has been described as a concept album because of the “interrelation of each of the album’s nine songs, both musically and
lyrically, and the album’s uncommon production style of removing standard breaks between
each song thus allowing them to flow uninterrupted from one to the next. “

annotations.lyric_fragment:
(In the meantime, right on, baby)
 Woo (Right on, baby), woo
 Ah-ya-ya-ya-ya-ya-ya, ya-ya-ya-ya-ya
 Woo (Right on, baby, right on)

annotation.plain: Marvin starts riffing here, referencing a common phrase of the time and a song later on down the track list of the album, “Right On”. The song’s intricately laid vocals and overdubs are very apparent here as the tempo begins to crescendo, with the second verse being marked by a piercing falsetto.

annotations.lyric_fragment: (Right on, baby, right on)

annotation.plain:
During these lines, as well as earlier in the song, some voices can be heard in the background talking to each other jovially and also singing some backup vocals. Funnily enough, these are actually the voices of Lem Barney and Mel Farr, the cornerback and running back for the 1968 Detroit Lions.

Marvin was very close to the two men, and they actually convinced him to sing the song in the first place. As a thank you for letting them be on the song, Barney and Farr decided to let Gaye try out for the Lions, although this was called off when the team’s coach decided he didn’t want to be responsible for the well-being of one of the country’s foremost singers.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Oh, what’s going on (What’s going on)
 Yeah, what’s going on (What’s going on)
 Tell me what’s going on (What’s going on)
 I’ll tell you what’s going on

annotation.plain:
When you initially hear Gaye sing the words “What’s going on” you could perceive it as being a question. But the text on the album cover and the song title don’t contain question marks.

These final lines confirm that Gaye isn’t asking what’s going on. He’s telling us about all the troubling things that are going on in the world in the early ‘70s.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You know we’ve got to find a way
 To bring some loving here today, yeah

annotation.plain: With everything swirling around in his life and the world — the loss of Tammi Terrell, the Vietnam War, the atrocities humans do to each other every day — Gaye wanted all of us to knock off that nonsense now. Gaye suggests creating a new way to relate to each other, a way that encourages love and compassion.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Brother, brother, brother
 There’s far too many of you dying

annotation.plain:
Gaye’s lyrics in this song were inspired by the stories his brother Frankie told him when he came back from the Vietnam war.



Gaye was deeply affected by the death of his partner Tammi Terrell, who succumbed to a brain tumor a year earlier. This led him to take charge of his career and infuse messages in his songs.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I got more clothes than Muhammad Ali

annotation.plain: Muhammad Ali was a professional boxer, who often only wore shorts, boxing gloves, and boots.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Kaopectate

annotation.plain: A stomach medicine

annotations.lyric_fragment: Lincoln Continental and a sunroof Cadillac

annotation.plain: The most exclusive domestic car brands at that time. The main competition, as heard in other songs of the era, was Mercedes and Rolls Royce (among others). To each rapper their own preferred cars !

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I know a man named Hank
 He has more rhymes than a serious bank

annotation.plain:
It’s true, Big Bank Hank did have a lot of rhymes. The problem was that they weren’t his own rhymes. Virtually all the rhymes he uses on “Rapper’s Delight” were originally written by his friend Grandmaster Caz. When Hank asked Caz if he could borrow some of the rhymes, Caz had no idea that Hank was going to use them for what would become the first hip-hop hit record.

At the time of recording, no one in the studio knew that what Hank rapped weren’t his own rhymes. Fellow crew member Master Gee, in an interview with JayQuan for The Foundation, remembered:

When Hank started with “I’m the C-A-S-AN, the O-V-A, and the rest is F-L-Y,” we didn’t know, the sh*t sounded good! The funny thing about it was that he kept doing the same raps! We noticed in the beginning, even that first night, that he kept saying the same rhymes. We started saying, maybe that’s all he got. We went and recorded it, the record blew up, and we didn’t find out until a year later.

It was all he got. Later, when the Gang was working on new songs, it turned out that Hank wasn’t good at all at coming up with rhymes. In the same interview, Master Gee disclosed:

But what we noticed was when we went to do pre-production for all those songs – it was like, ok it’s writing time. I would write something, Mike would write something, we would ask each other what we thought about the rhymes. When we got to Hank he had his pad, but never had anything! This struck us as odd, and we were like “damn you said all that on "Rapper’s Delight,” what happened?“ So we eventually found out, and what happened was he never wrote on anything. He gets no mechanical royalties on any of the songs because he never wrote anything.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Oh, so you bust out the door while it’s still closed

annotation.plain: This line seems to imply the cartoonish idea that the food was so gross that the singer smashed through the door to get out of there and away from it.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Verse 6: Big Bank Hank]

annotation.plain:
Grandmaster Caz alleged that this verse was originally written by him and Hank stole it. Listen to Caz elaborate on this situation below.

https://youtu.be/3FBXRUWraKo?t=28

annotations.lyric_fragment: And that is called originality

annotation.plain: He really likes doubling down on claims.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I didn’t even bite, not a god**** word

annotation.plain:
This line is quite ironic as well, considering at least his opening line in this song.

Big Bank Hank actually self-censors in the song–he hints at the ‘damn’ part of the word with the initial ’d' sound, but doesn’t follow through.

Unfortunately for the lexical purists among us, rappers would be dropping profanities left and right in just about every bar by the time this song would turn fifteen years old.

annotations.lyric_fragment: ’Cause I’ma get a fly girl, gonna get some spank and drive off in a def OJ

annotation.plain: “Def OJ” refers to the special luxury cabs folks uptown and in the Bronx used when they had the loot to really show out.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Let’s do it, a don’t stop, y’all, a tick a tock, y’all, you don’t stop

annotation.plain:
Six years after “Rapper’s Delight”, Slick Rick ended “La Di Da Di” (another hip hop classic in its own right) with the line “Tick tock ya don’t stop” – likely an ode to this song – and made the phrase a staple in hip hop lyricism.

References to ‘tick tock ya don’t stop’ are too numerous to count, but a few examples are Dre/Snoop “Deep Cover”, Dre/Snoop “Nuthin But A G Thang”, Snoop “Who Am I (What’s My Name)” and Candyman “Knockin' Boots”.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Now every one of us was made to suffer
 Every one of us was made to weep

annotation.plain: From the First Noble Truth of Buddism, to Job’s lament (“Let the day perish in which I was born, and the night that said, ‘A man-child is conceived’” Job 3:3), and the unknown writer of Ecclesiastes (I said of laughter, “It is folly,” and of pleasure, “What does it accomplish?“ 2:2), to philosopher’s like Schopenhauer ("Suffering is essential to life, therefore does it not flow in upon us from outside, but everyone carries around within himself its perennial source”) and writers like Orwell (“Most people get a fair amount of fun out of their lives, but on balance life is suffering, and only the very young or very foolish imagine otherwise”) it seems that the consensus and distillation of the wisdom of the ages agrees with Lennox in this regard.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You were the sweetest thing
 That I ever knew
 But I don’t care for sugar, honey
 If I can’t have you

annotation.plain: Even the sweetest substance can’t take away the bitterness of her lover jilting her.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
So take me from the wreckage
 Save me from the blast
 Lift me up and take me back
 Don’t let me keep on walking (don’t let me keep on walking)
 I can’t keep on walking (keep on walking on)
 Keep on walking on broken glass

annotation.plain: The narrator desperately, and seemingly foolishly, believes that the very relationship that came crashing down before could possibly rescue her from the aftermath of all of them.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Walking on, walking on broken glass

annotation.plain: The idea is something we can all relate to, and we cringe just thinking about it.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
The sun’s still shining in the big blue sky
 But it don’t mean nothing to me
 Oh-woah, let the rain come down
 Let the wind blow through me

annotation.plain:
Wonderful turn of phrase

The sun almost mocks her, and she asks for the rain and cold wind that would suit her feelings.



Compare this idea to one from Garbage, called “Only Happy When it Rains”.

annotations.lyric_fragment: In the club, ain’t got no ones, then we would become (Yeah)

annotation.plain:
Uzi talks about his past, explaining how he didn’t have ones to throw in the clubs and would beg strippers to perform acts.

Throwing ones (one dollar bills) are a common act performed in a strip club by many people. It’s kind of like a new “wave” the people have caught on to. Another artist close to Uzi, NAV, also talks about throwing ones on his song “NAVUZIMETRO#PT2” which coincidentally features Uzi. NAV explains,

Threw so much ones on that bitch I gave her paper cuts and a rash, yeah

This verse leads to the next verse on which he talks about this present life, having plenty of money.

annotations.lyric_fragment: That is not your swag, I swear you fake hard

annotation.plain:
Lil Uzi is accusing other rap artists that steal his style in music and fashion as a result of his recent mainstream popularity. He talks about this on “Two®”, the opening track to Luv Is Rage 2.

‘Cause you know I’m the one
Yes, I’m the one that really started all this
And you know I changed a lot of you niggas
In a matter of months, I raised a lot of you niggas

Another source where Uzi would rap about this subject is in his collaboration with popular Atlanta rap group, Migos, “Bad and Boujee”.

Ayy, wait, these niggas watchin'
I swear to God they be my clones

 (Yeah, yeah, yeah)
 Countin’ them bands

annotation.plain: One “band” is a thousand dollars. Uzi is “stacking” their money, which means “saving.” They hinted on their song “444+222” that their net worth was $4 million.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Everybody got the same swag now
 Watch the way that I tear it down

annotation.plain:
Uzi claims that nowadays, everyone is trying to emulate him and dress and act how he does.  In his XXL 2016 Freshman Class Interview, in regards to the new-school form of rapping that he personifies, Uzi explains:

Everybody wanna be in your lane.  They know you ain’t nothing but a clone.

annotations.lyric_fragment: My Brittany got mad, I’m barely her man now

annotation.plain:
Although Uzi and Brittany were in love in the past, their love is fading now and they are arguing and having relationship issues: Brittany may be threatening to commit suicide, while Uzi is struggling with substance abuse.



Note: Uzi and Brittany broke up in June of 2016, so it is assumed that this song is describing the end of their relationship and shows an argument that took place in the past.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Now these niggas wanna take my cadence (Yeah)

annotation.plain:
A “cadence” is a rhythm that rappers use to flow on a beat.

Uzi used a cadence on his 2015 song “Super Saiyan Trunks” that has become popular amongst other artists.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Fast car, NASCAR, race on ’em

annotation.plain:
NASCAR stands for National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing.  It’s a sport where top athletes race vehicles for hundreds of miles in a closed loop circuit.



Uzi mentions racing and coincidentally has a new song called, “Go Off,” featured in the film, The Fate of The Furious.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I cannot die because this my universe

annotation.plain:
Uzi is known to be very philosophical. He has expressed on Twitter that the universe is a figment of his imagination and he considers himself “not from this Earth”:

https://twitter.com/LILUZIVERT/status/837481519534964737

He has also tweeted an image referencing solipsism, or the belief that only one’s own mind is sure to exist; the only thing we can known to be real if what we perceive with our own mind.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
She say I’m insane, yeah
 Wanna blow my brain out (Hey)
 Xanny, help the pain, yeah
 Please, Xanny, make it go away
 I’m committed, not addicted, but it keep control of me
 All the pain, now I can’t feel it
 I swear that it’s slowin’ me, yeah

annotation.plain:
Xanax or Xanny is a prescription benzodiazepine that treats anxiety and panic disorders. It’s often abused as a relaxant and stress reliever.

In a 2016 interview with Sway, Uzi said that he’s trying to slow down or stop using Xanax:

https://youtu.be/4QYfD43mJSU?t=19m53s

In November 2017, rapper Lil Peep died of a Xanax-related drug overdose, which prompted Uzi to go on Twitter and re-iterate that he was trying to kick his habit. He struggled with anger issues while trying to quit.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Are you alright?
 I’m alright, I’m quite alright
 And my money’s right

annotation.plain:
These are questions Uzi and Brittany ask each other after their argument, outlined throughout this song, is over.

In a similar fashion, Uzi assures Brittany and their listeners that they’re doing good since they have a lot of money.

annotation.plain: This is sung in a more synthesized voice as opposed to the standard voice later on.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Won’t you take me to Funkytown?

annotation.plain:
So what, or which is “Funkytown”?

The band and the song originated in Minneapolis, though no evidence it was ever called Funkytown. The only logical sentence in the song would indicate a desire to leave the city to another, true “Funkytown”.
Wikipedia and The Urban Dictionary agree that Fort Worth in Texas is known as Funkytown. Some believe it is a fictitious city, center of disco culture(?) – New York?

Others usages per the Urban Dictionary are a synonym for Cocaine (Mid South), a section of LA and a generic town in Texas.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Instrumental]

annotation.plain: The song riff sounds to many very similar to that of The Doors' “The Changeling”, where the instrumentation is far superior to that of this song.

annotations.lyric_fragment: (Won’t you take me to) Funkytown?

annotation.plain: Sung(?) by a male robot voice – hugely different than the “funky town”, almost screamed by Cynthia Johnson.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Instrumental]

annotation.plain: Percussionists – drums and congas do slightly more justice to the term “instrumental” – keeping the beat very much alive.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Instrumental]

annotation.plain: This bridge is more “musical” with string section leading and then the horn section kicks in (lead singer Cynthia Johnson played the Saxophone).

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Instrumental]

annotation.plain: Basically the drums in a simple, though addictive beat. Disco was not known for elaborate instrumental solos and this one does nothing to change this impression.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Instrumental Intro]

annotation.plain: Drums, then guitar and a signature organ riff establish the very distinct disco rhythm.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Ow, she’s a brick house

annotation.plain:
While the term brick house refers to a woman who is solidly built , well-shaped, that turns heads, former Commodore’s member Lionel Richie expounded on the turn of phrase in an interview with Maria Granditsky aka Miss Funkyflyy:

You see, a brick house means she’s stacked. Let me explain that to you. See, when you have these wonderful measurements, 36-24-36 or variations of that in any form and you got these legs and this body and guys turn around and go “aww”… that’s a brick house! She’s built like a brick shit house means that she’s strong, shit is not a negative thing, it just means that the brick shit house is not gonna fall down, it’s not a wooden house. I know that sounds bad (laughs).

There’s also the recollection from Commodore’s founder, guitarist, and trumpeter William King, who added that the term has a degree of fluidity and isn’t limited to a women with a particular physique. In a 2013 interview with AL.com, King shared:

“Oh, it’s about any girl,” King says. “A girl that’s strong. The whole idea was a brick house is any guy’s imagination of his girl. Some guys like them tall, some guys like them short. Some guys like a little meat on the body, others like them slim. Some like them top-heavy, some like legs. It’s all about what he perceives to be the girl of his dreams. That’s what a brick house is.”

annotations.lyric_fragment: Yeah, she’s the one, the only one built like an Amazon

In ancient Greek mythology, Amazons were fierce female warriors.



The Commodores are making a comparison, saying that his girl is strong and solidly built.

annotation.plain:
Adele spoke briefly about this verse in her 21: The Inspiration interview:

We completely happened by accident, that’s what I mean by ‘glory days’ and stuff like that in it. It was never really meant… it was never meant to happen. I don’t think we ever felt like that about each other at the beginning, and it just turned into it.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I heard that you’re settled down
 That you found a girl and you’re married now
 I heard that your dreams came true

annotation.plain:
“When I was writing it, I was feeling pretty miserable and pretty lonely … this one was kind of my on my knees really.”

Adele, in an introduction before the performance Somebody Like You live at home, explains the song as her feelings as her partner has moved on from the relationship.

She described vaguely what their future may look like:

“… I can imagine being about 40 and looking for him again and turning up and he’s settled and he’s got a beautiful wife and some beautiful kids and he’s completely happy and I’m still on my own, it’s kind of about that.”

She is weeping and reflecting of the time she cherishes the man he was. She realises how he has changed; moved on and she adopts a similar attitude in pursuit of her self-discovery. She wants to get over how good of man he was and become happy at last.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Who would have known how bittersweet this would taste?

annotation.plain:
In a way, she is happy to have both been of part of his old life and looked into his new one. She is glad he is doing well, and glad they are no longer together and fighting. This is the “-sweet” part.

What is “bitter-” is that she isn’t a part of that new life, another woman is. By being with her, he has clearly moved on, while she hasn’t entirely.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Never mind, I’ll find someone like you
 I wish nothing but the best for you, too
 Don’t forget me, I beg
 I remember you said
 Sometimes it lasts in love, but sometimes it hurts instead
 Sometimes it lasts in love, but sometimes it hurts instead

annotation.plain:
Adele explained these lyrics on an interview with ELLE for their “Life in Lyrics,” saying:

I can’t remember if I had the chorus before I arrived or whether it was there, but the song came to life in LA. I remember that I wasn’t stumbling over those lyrics, I sang it all out as I wrote it, as it came to my head. We didn’t realize it would be a hit, because it was a piano ballad, but we were excited, because it was perfect for the song and what I was saying in the verses. There’s two choruses at the end, on the first chorus, I got really emotional. I had to sit on the floor in the booth, and I actually wanted to redo that chorus the next day, but Dan loved it, and he said it’s full of emotion, so we kept it. But there’s so much grace and forgiveness in these lyrics, which was very important for me in that relationship that 21 is about. I guess what inspired this lyric was similar to what I said earlier, about how you can go from loving someone to really hating them and despising them. I never felt like that, really, I know it probably seems like I did with that 21 album, but actually it wasn’t, I had the best time for a couple of years and I was really grateful that we’d come into each other’s lives, and I was just sad that we couldn’t really be friends anymore, ‘cause that was why we were together, it was because we got on so well. I could definitely write a lyric like this at this point in my life [2022] of being more mature and things like that if anything weren’t to last, so I relate to it.

Adele’s ex (who she has still declined to name) says love sometimes lasts and sometimes it hurts instead. Evidently, this is one of those hurt relationships. According to the bridge, it’s bittersweet––the love and pain are both there.

She bitterly repeats his line at the end of the chorus, as if she’s reflecting on her (hurt) relationship with him. There’s hints of desperation in her “begging” to get back with her ex and hoping he’d see her face and want to get back together, but in the end, all she can do is reminisce about it and find someone like him to make new memories with. Maybe this song is a remedy for getting over him?

annotation.plain: She was waiting for the man she loved to finally acknowledge it, and she wonders whether he was thinking about her like she was. She knows that her love is unrequited. Maybe she came back to her hometown and visited him to see if he still cares.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You felt the weight of the world fall off your shoulder

annotation.plain: He’d been carrying emotions and concerns for too long; he was worried that she didn’t love him, or at least not as much as he loved her, he might as well be concerned as what did she think of his family. Regardless, once she told him that she loved him, he felt all his problems go away.

annotations.lyric_fragment: And to your favorite song

annotation.plain:
Hayley said in an interview with KISS FM that this part of the song is a true story, and that the song she and Chad were listening to was Birdhouse In Your Soul by They Might Be Giants.
She also talked about this, and her birdhouse collection, in an interview with Beat magazine:

I actually started to collect birdhouses because when I started dating my boyfriend Chad, we were listening to They Might Be Giants and they have a song Birdhouse In Your Soul. It’s such a good song! It’s so poetic, too. Actually that’s the song that I’m talking about in the second verse of Still Into You, when it says “we sang along to the start of forever.” I talked about painting a birdhouse somewhere and after that people started bringing me birdhouses. They’re everywhere in my back yard and my house."

She also designed a birdhouse that was auctioned off by Abolition International.



You can see part of her collection in this video on Paramore.net.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
’Cause after all this time
 I’m still into you

annotation.plain:
The key here is “still.” When Hayley wrote the lyrics for this song, she really wanted it to be different from most love songs. She wanted it to be about monogamy. She talked about this when she was interviewed on Fuse’s Trending Ten.

I don’t know, I guess I just feel like there’s a lot of love songs on the radio, but sometimes it’s nice to hear one about monogamy, about sticking together. There’s tons of songs about falling in love and there’s lots of songs about one night stands and lust and all those things. But I think that having a real relationship is much more than those fleeting feelings. It’s a choice that you have to make over and over again, even when it gets rough. Even when it’s downhill, it’s like, ‘I think I still love you.’ Or, ‘I think I hate you, but I’m still going to stick around a little longer.’ Haha."

annotations.lyric_fragment: We sang along to the start of forever

annotation.plain:
“Forever” is a big word. Although false rumors of Hayley being pregnant with Chad’s baby have emerged on multiple occasions, a proposal is yet to come. With both Hayley and Chad on tour as often as they are, it can’t be easy to think about settling down forever. Still, Hayley told SPIN in January that she’s “deeper in [love] than ever.”

Seeing one of my best friends [bassist Jeremy Davis] so happily married does inspire me in a great way to keep believing in love. It’s hard, man! I really have to fight the realist in me at times."

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Some things just, some things just make sense
 And one of those is you and I (Hey)
 Some things just, some things just make sense
 And even after all this time (Hey)

annotation.plain:
Hayley has been known to have a downward  look on love:

In Brick by Boring Brick, Hayles says:

If it’s not real, you can’t hold it in your hand."

And in The Only Exception:

And that was the day that I promised, I’d never sing of love if it does not exist."



However her and Chad have been a committed relationship since 2008 and he has made a serious impact on the way she views love. She’s come to the conclusion that when it happens, it just works.

Hayley talked about the contrast between Still Into You and The Only Exception when she was a guest on Fuse’s Trending Ten.

The Only Exception was a song off of our last record where I was just getting into this relationship and I was really scared of it and it talks about all of the darker, more pessimistic and cynical thoughts and points of view that I had about love in general. And this is maybe some sort of happier sequel, where somehow down the line it’s become more freeing.”

annotations.lyric_fragment: I am everyday people

annotation.plain: The narrator is saying that they are the ‘everyman’; the Average Joe that’s struggling every day.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
There is a yellow one that won’t accept the black one
 That won’t accept the red one that won’t accept the white one
 Different strokes for different folks
 And so on and so on and scooby-dooby-dooby

annotation.plain:
Like the previous bridges, the narrator critiques people who can’t live together due to certain qualities. Here, however, he takes an exclusive look at race being the factor keeping them apart.

While Bridge 1 used nonsense colors for race (blue and green), the narrator now uses colors typically associated with those of Asian descent (yellow), African descent (black), American indigenous (red), and Caucasian (white).

annotations.lyric_fragment:
There is a long hair that doesn’t like the short hair
 For being such a rich one that will not help the poor one
 Different strokes for different folks
 And so on and so on and scooby-dooby-dooby

annotation.plain: Same as the previous bridge, the narrator describes people who can’t get along for material reasons, such as haircut and class.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You love me, you hate me, you know me and then
 You can’t figure out the bag I’m in

annotation.plain: The narrator criticizes someone who goes from “loving him” to “hating him”, and from knowing him, to not being able to figure out what’s going on with him.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I am no better and neither are you
 We are the same, whatever we do

annotation.plain: The narrator says that no one is better than anyone else. Everyone is human, no matter what they “do” (could be their occupation, or more broadly, their general actions in life).

annotations.lyric_fragment: And so on and so on and scooby-dooby-dooby

annotation.plain:
A reiteration of the previous line, no one will ever be able to think the exact same as someone else, and this will be true for countless types of humans.

The nonsense phrase “scooby-dooby doo-bee” is a sort of ad lib meaning “et cetera” here. While it seems to be a reference to the cartoon dog (whose series was also released in 1969), it is more likely an homage or reference to scatting.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
There is a blue one who can’t accept the green one
 For living with a fat one, trying to be a skinny one
 Different strokes for different folks

annotation.plain:
The narrator says how a few different people of different colors and bodies can’t accept each other.

“Different strokes for different folks” is a phrase that means not every way of doing things is appropriate for everyone. Everyone thinks in different ways and does things differently.

In Sly Stone’s autobiography Thank You (Falettinme Be Mice Elf Agin), he claims he doesn’t remember where the phrase came from, but it summed up his message.

You couldn’t take turns with freedom. You couldn’t have one moment where freedom went with the majority and one where it went with the money and one where it went with one skin color or another. Everyone had to be free all the time or no one was free at all.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
The butcher, the banker, the drummer and then
 Makes no difference what group I’m in

annotation.plain: The writer is writing from the perspective of the people. This is an accessible message that anyone can relate to.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Sometimes I’m right and I can be wrong
 My own beliefs are in my song

annotation.plain: The narrator opens the song by admitting that he isn’t perfect, but no matter what he puts what he believes into his writings.

annotations.lyric_fragment: All up in your slot ’til a nigga hit the jackpot, I’m saying

annotation.plain:
A slot machine is a gambling machine operated by inserting coins into a slot, and then pulling a handle that activates a set of symbols. A jackpot is achieved when all symbols are the same.

Drake plays on the analogy of a slot machine, likening the women’s vagina to the slot and his penis as the coins entering the slot, saying he will continue to enter until she orgasms, which is an analogy for the jackpot.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Every single show, she out there reppin’ like a mascot

annotation.plain:
A mascot is a person or animal, traditionally adopted by a sports team, as a symbolic figure that intends to bring good luck. Drake is saying his girl is at every show of his representing him, just how a mascot for a sports team would be at every game supporting the team.

  The Toronto Raptors Mascot

annotations.lyric_fragment: And niggas’ll buy it too and claim they got it for they sister

annotation.plain: When men buying a Drake album for themselves but claim it’s for their sister, this suggests that they might be concealing their personal interest in the album to protect a certain image or avoid potential judgment.

annotations.lyric_fragment: When my album drop, bitches’ll buy it for the picture

annotation.plain: When Drake releases an album, some women may buy it because they are fans of Drake and enjoy seeing him, whether in photographs or other visual content associated with the album.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Have a nigga thinkin’ that he met you in a past life

annotation.plain: Drake is saying that the the girl he is describing is so unique that he believes he has encountered her in a previous life. They have a deep connection and the sense of familiarity he feels with her goes beyond the current moment. She has a strong and timeless impact on Drake.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You could have my heart or we could share it like the last slice

annotation.plain:
Drake is willing to give his lover his entire heart, metaphorically representing all his love and affection. He also gives her the option to “share it” if she wishes.

The reference to sharing it “like the last slice” is  likely drawing on the popular meme associated with sharing the last slice of pizza. In this context, it adds a playful and relatable element to the lyric.

Drizzy firstly plays on the homonym official, which can mean to have authority and be certified, but is also another word for a referee. Drake’s saying she calls him a referee because he of the authority he holds in the rap game, just like a referee (or official) holds when referring.

Drake continues the referee puns by stating his shirt doesn’t have stripes, like a referee’s traditionally does, but he can still make her vagina whistle, meaning to make noises from orgasm, like the sound a referee makes when he blows a whistle when calling a foul.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Outro]

annotation.plain:
Arguably the most famous and quoted part of the entire song, this outro features a “Na-na-na-na” refrain, which is repeated for the remainder of the song, occupying its entire second half. This section features at least 19 repetitions of the same phrase, gradually fading out to silence in the middle of the final repeat. The lyrics include the sound “Na” a total of 240 times. The total runtime of this outro is about 4 minutes long.

There are several reasons attributed to this repeat, most likely to increase run-time and memorability/simplicity of the song. Making it easy for people to remember and sing-along to.

On an episode of “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert”, Paul McCartney was shown a clip of the host asking the members of the hit Korean boy band BTS about their favorite Beatles song(s), to which they proceeded to sing the “NAH-NAH-NAHS” (as Colbert called it).

https://youtu.be/475Yc5YlqAU?si=ooVV_FS1W_1yb2N_&t=493

In response, McCartney said that “easy lyrics” are the reason why the Beatles' music is so easily understandable and loved across the world, despite potential language/cultural barriers.

annotations.lyric_fragment: And don’t you know that it’s just you, hey, Jude, you’ll do

annotation.plain:
Although Jude is “waiting for someone to perform with,” Paul reminds him that he’s still good enough as an individual; he doesn’t need someone else to make him whole.

This ties into the next line’s meaning of already having what you need, whether it’s your own abilities or close friends and family, to pursue what you want.

annotation.plain: Let out the pain and anguish, and let in love.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You’re waiting for someone to perform with

annotation.plain:
Paul was going through a split up with his fiancée Jane, after meeting an American photographer, Linda Eastmann. It was often said that him and John both found “someone to perform with” when they found Linda and Yoko, these were women that they collaborated with musically and got to marry as well. After the Beatles split, Paul taught Linda how to play the keyboard and they then created Paul’s first solo album, RAM.



Yoko and Lennon also helped each other with songs and albums since they were both artists, they made album’s together until the 1980’s.

annotations.lyric_fragment: (Woah, fucking hell!)

annotation.plain:
This quite unlikely expletive heard in the background is believed to be from either Lennon or McCartney. In the 2006 book Recording the Beatles, engineer Malcolm Toft explained:

Barry Sheffield engineered ‘Hey Jude,’ but I mixed it. John Lennon says a very rude word about halfway through the song. At 2:59 you will hear a ‘Whoa!’ from him in the background. About two seconds later you will hear, ‘Fucking hell!’ This was because when he was doing a vocal backing, Barry sent him the foldback level too loud and he threw the cans on the ground and uttered the expletive. But, because it had been bounced down with the main vocal, it could not be removed.

Another theory has it that the expletive is due to Lennon getting the previous lyric wrong and singing “let her into your skin” while doing the backing vocals under McCartney’s “let her under your skin.” On the other hand, tape operator John Smith recalls the exclamation came from McCartney:

Paul hit a clunker on the piano and said a naughty word, but I insisted we leave it in, buried just low enough so that it can barely be heard. Most people won’t ever spot it—but we’ll know it’s there.

According to engineer Ken Scott:

I was told about it at the time but could never hear it. But once I had it pointed out I can’t miss it now. I have a sneaking suspicion they knew all along, as it was a track that should have been pulled out in the mix. I would imagine it was one of those things that happened—it was a mistake, they listened to it and thought, ‘doesn’t matter, it’s fine.’

annotations.lyric_fragment: (Go listen to ya ma-ma-ma-ma-ma-ma-ma-ma)

annotation.plain: This is perhaps a reference to Julian Lennon’s mother Cynthia, who would often tell him to “stay strong” and “hold it together.” Paul is effectively telling him to heed his mother’s advice and keep his head up through his parents' divorce.

annotation.plain: The 40th anniversary edition of Synchronicity (released 4 days ago) contains 55 previously unreleased tracks and +6 versions of this song. None of these versions have the faint whispered “250” in the background, which was apparently a post-production tag in the original 1982 version.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Claim

annotation.plain:
The line “Every claim you stake” is part of a broader theme of obsession and surveillance.

In the context of the song, this line suggests the narrator’s intense scrutiny and possessiveness over their love interest. It’s as if the narrator is closely watching and monitoring every action of their love interest, including every claim they make or stake.

Despite the seemingly romantic tone of the song, Sting has described it as “very, very sinister and ugly” and not a “gentle little love song” as many people have interpreted. So, “Every claim you stake” contributes to this darker, more obsessive theme of the song.

Source: Conversation with Bing, 4/28/2024

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Verse 2]

annotation.plain: Sting wrote Every Breath You Take while staying a GoldenEye, the former residence of James Bond author Ian Fleming in Oracabessa, St Mary’s, Jamaica.  He was no doubt thinking about spies when he wrote this song about surveillance.

 With every step you take

annotation.plain:
The song theme bears a striking resemblance to the haunting 1836 Robert Browning poem “Porphyria’s Lover” where a high class lady takes a lower class casual lover and spurns him. His reaction? He stalks her and then strangles her with her own hair and then sits with her corpse, telling it she will always love him…

Since Sting was originally a high school English literature teacher I’m sure the reference is there. Sting was and is a prolific reader – there are many literary references in his songs.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Verse 1]

annotation.plain:
Every harmony you play

“Every Breath You Take” follows the Aeolian I-vi-IV-V harmony progression, one of the most used structures in pop music. In fact, it even has a code name, “the 50s progression” based on its heavy use in the early soul and rock music of the 1950s. The best example of this song’s influence comes from Ben E. King’s classic 1961 song, “Stand By Me.”

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hwZNL7QVJjE

So why two Grammy awards, millions of albums sold, nine million plays on the radio and the $2000 a day Sting receives in royalties?

Musical genius

Sting leans over and says, ‘Go on, go in there, make it your own.’ …It’s a simple chord sequence and shouldn’t prove a problem… What are the criteria? It should sound like the Police—big, brutal barre chords won’t do, too vulgar; it has to be something that says Police but doesn’t get in the way of the vocals; it should exist as music in its own right, universal but with just a hint of irony, be recognized the world over… The track rolls and I play a sequence of intervals that makes it sound like the Police, root, fifth, second, third, up and down through each chord. It is clean, succinct, immediately identifiable… I play it straight through in one take. There is a brief silence, and then everyone in the control room stands up and cheers… With this lick I realize a dream that maybe I have cherished since first picking up the guitar as a teenager — to at least once in my life make something that would go around the world, create a lick that guitarists everywhere would play.
- Andy Summers, One Train Later: A Memoir, pg. 323



Production genius



Hugh Padgham is the record producer behind Synchronicity and was called upon by the band after their previous success with 1981’s Ghost in the Machine. Padgham had previously worked with bands like Yes, XTC and Peter Gabriel and was not much of a referee to the squabbling musicians. Recording took place at AIR Monserrat, a recording studio built by George Martin and located in the Caribbean. It was known as a “recording getaway” because it was the best way to record an album outside the reach of the record company.



The band during the recording of Ghost in the Machine.

In that environment, many tricks were employed to give this song, and the rest of the album, its timeless sound. With Stewart Copeland’s drums, Padgham had him record hitting a tightly-wound snare drum with a Tama gong drum at the same time. Copeland explains the rather unorthodox way his sounds were recorded:

The big studio that George Martin built was at one end of the building, and I was upstairs in the old house in the dining room, all by myself with a television monitor connecting me to the studio downstairs across the way… The first thing you have to do when you record music is lay down a drum track, but we were making it up as we went along, and I wasn’t in the room with them. So, instead of finishing playing and going, ‘Hey, that was good there, and that went there,’ there is silence. I can’t hear what one of them is saying unless one of them presses the talk-back button. They aren’t pressing the talk-back button, but I can see that they are talking and I assume it’s bad. The drums sounded incredible because that was definitely the place to get the best sound out of the drums. Inarguably, the drums sounded brilliant in that room.
-Stewart Copeland, mixonline.com



Funny enough, a lot of press would harp on the idea that each member of the band would record in separate rooms, though mainly it was a circumstance of finding the best sounds for the recording.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Middle-Eight]

annotation.plain:
While recording the song, producer Hugh Padgham and Sting found themselves having to fill in the space between the end of the bridge and the start of the next verse, otherwise known as the “middle-eight.” At first it was indistinguishable from the verses and it needed its own charm. That’s when a happy accident changed everything, according to Padgham:


[Sting] was fiddling around on the piano, banging away on the same note, and I remember shouting to him on the talkback, ‘Yeah! That’s it! Just the one-note thing is great!’ I was always into one-note stuff, ever since we did a one-note guitar solo on an XTC song — I liked its hypnotic effect and thought it was really cool. So, suddenly, when I heard Sting playing that note, it was like ‘There it is! We’ve got it!’ And that was after he’d been fiddling around for hours, trying to find a part.

Listening to the song now, I really like the dynamics going into the middle eight — the big, explosive ‘shplang’ guitar chords and overdubbed toms that were played with mallets — and that was all about experimenting until we got the right sound. In fact, the song’s overall sound still stands up because it’s not full of gimmicks…

annotation.plain: Sting has said that this song is about a “jealousy and surveillance and ownership”, though it can have multiple meanings. annotations.lyric_fragment: [Intro]

annotation.plain:
This track, which is laid on Slick Rick’s “Children’s Story,” is exemplary of the New Jack Swing style popular from the mid-80s to the mid-90s. It was characterized by smooth, R&B-style vocals with clearly enunciated lyrics, on top of steady beats created not by sampling, but by then-new drum machines.

In this case, the beat is sampled, but one can still hear the insistent pulse (“swing”) to it.

annotations.lyric_fragment: The summertime skirts and the guys in Kani

annotation.plain:
In the summer, girls wear short skirts. On a related note, girls themselves are sometimes called, “skirts”.

Karl Kani (born Carl Williams) established a popular line of clothing geared toward hip hop culture in the 1990s.



Biggie in all his Kani glory

While many brands and styles had seen popularity among hip-hop artists and fans, Kani, also called ‘The Originator’, was the first to take inspiration from and aim his line directly toward the hip-hop community. Thus he paved the way for brands like FUBU, Sean Jean, Eckō, Rocawear, Enyce, Bape, and others (many, many others.)

He has been recognized for his contribution by the Urban Fashion Awards, Black Enterprise Magazine, and The Big Dog himself, Pres. Bill Clinton. Legend has it he took his name from his childhood ur-question: “Can I?” (Be the Ralph Lauren of the streets, e.g.)

annotations.lyric_fragment: SCC

annotation.plain: A reference to South Central Cartel, a Los Angeles-based gangsta rap group active in the early 1990’s.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Y?N-Vee

annotation.plain: A reference to a female R&B/hip-hop group  Y?N-Vee signed to PMP Records, the same label as Montell Jordan. Their name was pronounced “why envy” as in “why can’t we all just be happy for each other?”

annotations.lyric_fragment: I’ll never come wack on an old school track

annotation.plain:
He won’t ruin an old school beat (the Slick Rick sample he uses in the song) and intends to match or make his a better song.

And interestingly, where Children’s Story is a cautionary tale of how the gangster lifestyle can end you up dead and disgraced, This is How We Do It is sort of the other side, how staying real and hard work pay off to success and celebration.

A debutante is a young woman of aristocratic or upper-class family background who has reached maturity. Traditionally, a debutante’s transition into society is marked at a formal “debut,” or even a ball.

This also points to Diane having her fist sexual experience (“debut” means first time) in Jack’s car.

annotation.plain: After his record label insisted Mellencamp change the song from being about an interracial couple, he settled for writing it about his “small-town upbringing and referenced universal issues of growing up and moving on.”

annotation.plain: It means that even after you grow old and can’t find the thrills you once could, life still goes on and you keep living.  The point is, live life while you’re young because all you’ll have left in your old age is your memories.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Scratches his head and does his best James Dean

annotation.plain:
Actor and cultural icon James Dean starred in East of Eden, Rebel Without a Cause and Giant. He was killed in a car accident on 30 September 1955. He was 24 at the time.

James Dean was born on 8 February 1931, in Marion, Indiana. He starred in the film adaptation of the John Steinbeck novel East of Eden, for which he received an Oscar nomination. His next starring role, in Rebel Without a Cause, made him the embodiment of cool to his generation. Shortly after completing work on the film Giant, Dean was killed in a car crash near  Cholame, CA, while on his way to sports car races at Salinas.

John Mellencamp was also born in Indiana, about 120 miles south of Dean’s birthplace.  He was 4 years old at the time of Dean’s death.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Diane’s sittin’ on Jackie’s lap, he’s got his hands between her knees
 Jackie say, ”Hey Diane, lets run off behind a shady tree
 Dribble off those

annotation.plain: This verse indicates that Jack and Diane are having a sexual relationship. Premarital sex increased throughout the 60s and 70s.  By 1980 (when this song was released), 56% of unmarried teenage girls admitted to having had sex. By 1988 that number had risen to 70%.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
So let it rock, let it roll
 Let the Bible Belt come and save my soul
 Holdin’ on to sixteen as long as you can
 Changes come around real soon, make us women and men

annotation.plain:
(Bridge – only drums playing)

The Bible Belt is comprised of almost the entire southern U.S., in which reside many a devout Baptist.

Premarital sex is considered sinful in many Bible Belt denominations. What Jack and Diane are described as doing in the song could get the both of them in a lot of trouble.

The line “Let the Bible belt come down” is a play on the word “belt” both describing the region in which the song takes place, and the punishment that could very well follow in the wake of their sexual exploration.

In the lines that follow, Jack justifies these actions in that the punishment would save his soul, that youth is fleeting, and adulthood is just around the corner. i.e. it’s a sin, but it’s worth it.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Bobby Brooks slacks and do what I please”

annotation.plain: Bobbie Brooks fashions may look hopelessly outdated today, but in their prime, they were aggressively marketed as what girls of fashion wore.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Suckin’ on a chili dog outside the Tastee Freez

annotation.plain:
Tastee-Freez is a soft-serve ice cream chain that was ubiquitous in the 1950s.  Kind of like Dairy Queen, some stores also served chili dogs and other things.



By the way, internet comic Randall Monroe thinks this is the best line of the song.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
All the good love (Ooga-Chaka, Ooga-Ooga)
 When we’re all alone

annotation.plain: When Björn Skifs is alone with the love of his life, he feels as though his “good love” has reached its pinnacle. There’s nothing that can come between the two entranced lovers while they feel that way about each other.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’m hooked on a feelin’
 I’m high on believin’
 That you’re in love with me

annotation.plain:
In slang, to be hooked generally refers to being addicted to a drug of some sort, therefore Björn Skifs juxtaposes a drug to his beloved, providing an insight into Mark James' (the original songwriter) perception of love, symbolising the addictiveness of his beloved, and the feeling that he’s constantly hooked on.

Björn Skifs is ecstatic at the belief that his beloved is indeed in love with him, thus generating a romantic tenderness that seamlessly flows throughout the song’s duration. This underlying feeling of love has resulted in Björn Skifs feeling “high”, either figuratively or physically:


Physically: The persona is legitimately feeling light headed or delirious that the love of his life feels the same as he does, very much similarly to getting high via explicit substances
Figuratively: The allusion to feeling “high” may also refer to an angelic reference, meaning that the woman is so high, she is divine and relates much to angels in heaven, therefore representing the pedestal that the persona places this woman upon



Therefore, he is “Hooked on a feeling”; presumably not love or happiness, but rather a feeling he himself cannot find the words to explain, as it is a multitude of other feelings, all morphed into a single compassionate devotion that resonates within the listener’s ears. The listener can relate to this theme, as they too have felt the sweet embrace of love for themselves, and found themselves speechless at conveying that exact same feeling.

annotation.plain:
Bob Thiele and George Weiss wrote this song to counter the racially and politically charged atmosphere of the U.S. in the late 60s.

Bob Thiele:



George Weiss:



George Weiss recounts in the book, Off the Record: Songwriters on Songwriting by Graham Nash, that he wrote the song specifically for Louis Armstrong. Weiss was impressed by Armstrong’s popularity with both whites and blacks.  Read more about the making of the song at PopHistoryDig.

The song was not a hit in the U.S. at the time of its release because Larry Newton, head of ABC Records at the time, didn’t like it and didn’t promote it. However, it was very successful in the U.K. where it reached number one on the their singles chart in 1968. The song has been featured in several movies and TV shows, and has been covered over a dozen times.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
The colors of the rainbow
 So pretty in the sky

annotation.plain:
coheirwithchrist made this observation:
The colors of a rainbow in this line and the colors of man in the next are really parts of the same phrase.  The colors of the rainbow and the colors of man mirror each other in God’s eyes. Each of the colors is  meant to complement the others.

Biblically, the true meaning of the rainbow or rainbows are primarily mentioned in only the first book (Genesis) and the last book (Revelation) of the Bible.



In the Genesis account, a rainbow appears right after the great flood brought in order to remove sinful and evil-minded man from the earth. It symbolized God’s mercy and the covenant He made with Noah (representing mankind) not to destroy the world in such a way again:

And God said:  ‘This is the sign of the covenant which I make between Me and you, and every living creature that is with you, for perpetual generations’

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Are also on the faces
 Of people going by

annotation.plain:
On April 4th of the same year as the release of the song Martin Luther King had been shot in Memphis, Tennessee. The result of this was riots kicking off in more than 100 American cities.



Also in this year, the Olympic Games were held in Mexico City. To protest against the racism which was still very much so present amongst the majority of America, a group of American athletes formed the Olympic Project for Human Rights (OPHR) and planned to boycott the games.

The boycott didn’t materialise, but despite this Tommy Smith and John Carlos who finished 1st and 3rd in the 200 metre sprints executed one of the most spectacular political gestures of all times in which, when they received their medals they closed their eyes and raised their fists in a Black Power salute to symbolise the racial struggle in America. A lot more medals were won by black athletes and that year was a year for black athletic power.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I see skies of blue and clouds of white
 The bright blessed days, the dark sacred nights

annotation.plain:
Louis' episodes of luxury made it effective when Armstrong did speak out, and at one point, even calling President Eisenhower two-faced and gutless because of his inaction during the conflict over school desegregation in Little Rock, Arkansas in 1957.



As a protest to this Armstrong cancelled a tour of the Soviet Union saying

The way they’re treating my people in the South, the government can go to hell

And that he could not represent his government abroad when it was in conflict with its own people. Six days after this Eisenhower ordered Federal troops to Little Rock to escort students into the school.

These represents Louis' dark sacred nights.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And I think to myself
 What a wonderful world

annotation.plain:
A message of hope. Despite all the starvation, poverty, genocide, and the general devastation of the world and the bad things that are happening in it, the world is a wonderful place full of beauty and we all need to take time to realize that and appreciate it.

It is also a paradoxically ironic song title as it depicts a utopian world and society, but was made during the Vietnam War.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I see trees of green, red roses too
 I see them bloom for me and you

annotation.plain:
Despite the racism going on at the time, Armstrong was actually largely accepted into white society both on and off stage: a privilege reserved for only a few African-American public figures, and he himself had an influence on black history.



As he became more famous, his access to the finer things in life became even more, such as dining in the best restaurants and staying in the best hotels, usually reserved for white people. Despite this power and luxury, he was careful not to flaunt it to other people.



Some of the African-American community didn’t like this and though that he was selling out at the expense of his own racial identity. And some musicians criticised him for playing in front of segregated audiences.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I hear babies cry, I watch them grow
 They’ll learn much more
 Than I’ll ever know

annotation.plain:
Louis uses a hopeful, optimistic tone with regards to the future in which Armstrong sings about babies being born into a better world and having a lot of look forward to.



This song really fit what was happening at the time because there were a lot of positive things to come out of 1968 and the song looked to the future in relation to these positive things, and if things continued the way they were going, there really was reason for optimism.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Verse 1]

annotation.plain:
What A Wonderful World was written by Bob Thiele (as George Douglas) who was a producer, and George David Weiss who was a composer and performer.



Released in 1968, it was intended as an antidote for the increasingly racially and politically charged climate in the US.

The song was originally offered to Tony Bennett who turned it down, then offered to Louis Armstrong.

annotations.lyric_fragment: (We got the refugees up in here)

annotation.plain:
Wyclef Jean was a member of the legendary hip-hop group the Fugees with Lauryn Hill and Pras Michel. Since Fugees is derived from the word refugees, Jean is shouting out his crew.



The Fugees shortly made a comeback from 2004 to 2006, during which this song was recorded, after a long hiatus. They then disbanded indefinitely, with Jean and Michel citing strained relationships with Lauryn Hill and her deteriorating psychological well-being as the main cause. “Hips Don’t Lie” was released as a single shortly afterward.

annotations.lyric_fragment:

 I ain’t guilty, it’s a musical transaction

annotation.plain:
Wyclef is curious of the CIA’s suspicion of him being a terrorist or possibly smuggling in drugs.



Just because of his ethnicity. He does an excellent play on words here using “transaction” as in money which the CIA could use to convict him, comparing it to the multicultural nature of the song.



This is probably also a reference to the CIA’s history of being covertly involved in Latin American affairs.

Wyclef relays this reference to compare himself to Tupac, in terms of going from a simple clubgoer, to a global superstar.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
¿Cómo se llama? (¡Sí!), ¿bonita? (¡Sí!)
 Mi casa (Shakira, Shakira), su casa

annotation.plain:
Translates in English to:

What is your name, pretty girl?
My house, your house




“Mi casa, su casa” is a phrase used when the Spanish want someone to feel welcome and at home. Wyclef portrays a character who isn’t very well versed in the Spanish language yet tries to pursue his interests in a woman that Shakira takes the role of.

PROPOSED SUGGESTION: It can also be more suggestive, implying “My house, or yours?”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’m on tonight
 You know my hips don’t lie (No fighting)
 And I’m starting to feel it’s right
 All the attraction, the tension
 Don’t you see, baby? This is perfection

annotation.plain:
According to Starpulse, Shakira says the following about the origin of the phrase, “My hips don’t lie”:

I always used to joke with the guys from my band about how important it is to listen to my hips in order to determine if a song is where it has to be. Every time we were rehearsing and I was doubtful about how a song was sounding I would tell them, ‘Listen, my hips don’t lie… If they’re not moving, it’s because this is not working out, so lets work on it a little bit more until my hips start shaking!’

She also wields this form of communication to the club. When her hips move, that means that she’s loving the club, and her pursuer has hit the jackpot. Call it a below-the-gut feeling.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I put the sing in single
 Ain’t worried ’bout a ring on my finger

annotation.plain:
Lizzo spoke about her independence and focus on her career in a June 2017 interview with Sway in the Morning:

I am definitely the type to always be very, like, ‘I don’t need nobody,’ you know. I’m very, like, what’s the word? I’m self-sufficient, you know? And I’ve sacrificed love and romance for my career. Like, when I was a teenager, I was like, ‘mm-mm, no boyfriends, I don’t, mm-mm.’ Then even when I got older I was, like, ‘I’m not where I wanna be, so someone’s gonna distract me.’

She brought this lyric to life in the music video for this song, in which she marries herself.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Bom bom bi dom bi dum bum bay (Eh, yeah, yeah, yeah)

annotation.plain:
Lizzo revealed via Twitter in December 2019 that this  vocalization was originally just a filler for yet-to-be-written lyrics:

https://twitter.com/lizzo/status/1210253669209272320

annotations.lyric_fragment: It’s okay, he already in my DMs

annotation.plain:
The term “in my DMs,” meaning direct messages on social media like Instagram or Twitter, is a flirty statement implying someone is talking to you privately with romantic or sexual intent. Lizzo is making a point about how she is so great, even her ex’s friends are already trying to make a move on her.

She sang a similar lyric in 2018’s “Juice”:

Somebody come get this man
I think he got lost in my DMs, what?

annotations.lyric_fragment: I just took a DNA test, turns out I’m 100% that bitch

annotation.plain:
It seems that this line is inspired by Twitter user @MinaLioness, who posted this tweet in February 2017:

https://twitter.com/MinaLioness/status/835347243020451840

“Truth Hurts” came out about seven months after the viral tweet. The original tweeter expressed disappointment with this interpolation, and the fact that Lizzo has trademarked the phrase for use on her merchandise:

https://twitter.com/MinaLioness/status/1143465963041492992
https://twitter.com/MinaLioness/status/1143499843521982464

On October 23, 2019 after an embattled lawsuit, Lizzo awarded @MinaLioness songwriting credit for the track

The phrase-as-meme saw a resurgence in 2019 after the explosion of TikTok videos in which someone pretends to take a DNA test with different “turns out” results as the punchline.

annotations.lyric_fragment: New man on the Minnesota Vikings (Minnesota Vikings)

annotation.plain:
The Minnesota Vikings are a football team that joined the NFL in 1960. Lizzo revealed the nature of this connection in a video with YouTuber Zachary Campbell:

Meanwhile, this Minnesota Viking was in my DMs, we were chatting, we were texting, we went on a date.

Lizzo moved to Minneapolis, Minnesota, in 2011 and began her career there. In December 2019, she teased that she’d reveal the man if her tweet got one million retweets, but didn’t reach the milestone.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Why men great ’til they gotta be great?

annotation.plain:
When you first find “the one,” they seem to be great until you actually need something from them. Lizzo explained this line via Twitter:
https://twitter.com/lizzo/status/919264662251716608

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Best friend sat me down in the salon chair (Down in the salon chair)
 Shampoo press, get you out of my hair

annotation.plain:
The idea that a new hairdo will help someone move on from a relationship first appeared in “I’m Gonna Wash That Man Right Outa my Hair,” a song from the 1949 musical South Pacific. It’s since appeared in pop songs like Little Mix’s 2016 track “Hair.” Lizzo included a similar analogy on her 2016 track “Coconut Oil.”

There’s a common image that women in the black community go to a salon for self-care as well as a place to gather and socialize. They’re usually open, welcoming spaces for black women, who can rarely express their anger or sadness without being judged harshly by society.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Don’t text me, tell it straight to my face (Tell it straight to my face)

annotation.plain:
Lizzo may be referring to an incident she described in a June 2017 interview with Sway in the Morning:

He was with somebody when I met him, but we were working together, and then he, like, caught feelings for me. And then he was like, ‘I’m leaving her,’ and he was trying to leave her before I even met him. […] So then they separated, then we came together when they separated. Then once, she came back, everything went crazy, and he left [me] this voicemail that was like, ‘…Lizzo, I’m just calling to let you know that I am desperately in love with [my ex] and I can’t let her go, so I’m not gonna talk to you anymore.’
