https://genius.com/The-supremes-you-keep-me-hangin-on-lyrics

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Anticipating
 For that soft voice
 To talk to me at night
 For some tender arms
 To hold me tight
 
 [Chorus]
 I keep waiting (Can’t wait, ooh, until that day)
 I keep on waiting
 But it ain’t easy (Love don’t come easy)
 It ain’t easy

annotation.plain: Notice that there are no specific gender pronouns used throughout the song, either to describe herself or the love who she happens to be waiting for. Just like the choruses pay tribute to its predecessor “You Can’t Hurry God (He’s Right on Time),” the lyrics throughout the song could easily be interpreted as describing a struggling relationship with God, waiting for him to come in times of hardship. This is a common theme in many gospel songs, past and present, as well as more and more current pop songs.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
”You can’t hurry love (Ooh, until that day)
 No, you just have to wait
 You got to trust, give it time (Love don’t come easy)
 No matter how long it takes”

annotation.plain: This song was actually inspired by and partially based upon a song by Alabama-based group The Gospel Harmonettes titled “You Can’t Hurry God (He’s Right on Time)”, released in 1950. In the following lyrics from the song – which was written by member Dorothy Love Coates – you can see just how much of a direct impact it had on The Supremes tune: “You can’t hurry God / You just have to wait / Trust and give Him time / No matter how long it takes.”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
But Mama said
 
 [Chorus]
 ”You can’t hurry love
 No, you just have to wait”
 She said, ”Love don’t come easy
 It’s a game of give and take”

annotation.plain:
“You Can’t Hurry Love” is reminiscent of content you would find in a journal entry or a very personal and detailed autobiography, quoting a distinct memory of a mother’s words of encouragement to her daughter, who we can see from the lyrics has had her heart broken time and time again. This lyrical content containing what seems to be a firsthand experience of a certain event is a very specific quality that one can find over and over again in the history of early gospel music and old Black/African American work songs.

Though the orchestration of pop/R&B music has changed significantly since the Motown era, this trend of very personal and descriptive lyrical content in gospel music continues to be a trend in pop/R&B and soul music up to this day.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Liming, fiesta, forever

annotation.plain:
Lime means to hang out:

“Lime” is a word used in Trinidad and Tobago and throughout the Caribbean as a synonym for “a gathering” (noun) or “to hang out” (verb).

annotations.lyric_fragment: We’re going to party, Karamu

annotation.plain:
Karamu is the Swahili word for banquet, feast or festival.

It can also be, more specifically, a festival and feast held during Kwanzaa.

The Kwanzaa Karumu is traditionally held on December 31st … the celebration and feast continue throughout the festive times of Kwanzaa but on December 31, the celebration takes altogether a different mood for the special feast called Karamu.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Throw away the work to be done
 Let the music play on

annotation.plain: Forget everything that’s stressing you out and just enjoy yourself while you listen to some music and party.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Well, my friends, the time has come
 To raise the roof and have some fun

annotation.plain:
That’s right, kids, “raise the roof” has meant “party” for over 30 years.

Actually, it’s even older than that: see this painfully earnest attempt to use the hip kid’s slang from a 1970 ad in Field & Stream Magazine.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Tam bo li de say de moi ya
 Yeah, Jambo, Jambo
 Way to parti, o we goin’
 Oh, jambali
 Tam bo li de say de moi ya
 Yeah, Jambo, Jambo

annotation.plain:
Total nonsense, meant to sound like some African language.


“That is a wonderful joke,” Richie says of the lyrics. “ ‘Tam bo li de say de moi ya, Hey Jambo Jumbo.’ ” He had called a friend at the United Nations to get some African phrases. “The guy said, ‘Lionel, there’s 101 African dialects.’ ” When the singer asked for just a few words, he was told it would take a few weeks. But Richie needed them immediately — so he churned out his own dialect.

“Somewhere in that made-up language, I am actually saying something, because even to this day, we’ll play India, and someone will tell me, ‘Yes, you’ve touched on certain words in {our language}.’ As long as I am not cursing you out, I am going in the right direction.”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
So let’s set the world on fire
 We can burn brighter than the sun

annotation.plain:
The sun is extremely bright, with an apparent magnitude of -26.7. This could show how reckless the narrator can be while drunk and under the influence that they are young, believing they can challenge the light of the sun.



Recklessness and conceit are often qualities attributed to the United States, something which this line could portray. Nate Ruess said on the political past of this line in an interview for Rolling Stone:

I started to try and write a completely different song […] where it was, like, a little more upbeat and it might have been about the arrogance of […] America and, like, let’s just set the world on fire just so we can be better than, like, the sun!

annotations.lyric_fragment: Carry me home tonight

annotation.plain:
This could be interpreted in two different ways

Carrying someone can sometimes happen in romantic situations. The girl could be indicating that she is willing to move on from their argument, and make up with him.

It is also most likely a reference to Ruess’s earlier line:

So if by the time the bar closes
And you feel like falling down
 I’ll carry you home tonight.

This suggests that she is willing to accept his apology and she trusting him to get her safely home while she is inebriated.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
So if by the time the bar closes
 And you feel like fallin’ down
 I’ll carry you home

annotation.plain: He senses that she won’t accept his verbal apology, so instead he will let his actions speak for themselves, and tells her that, no matter what, he will always be there for her when she needs it the most.

annotations.lyric_fragment: The moon is on my side, I have no reason to run

annotation.plain: “the moon is on my side” could mean that the moon represents the night and Nate owns the night, thus not being scared of anything now.

annotations.lyric_fragment: But our friends are back, so let’s raise a toast

annotation.plain: They might have been in conversation away from the group but now the friends are back and they need to rejoin the party. So they raise a toast and start drinking again.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
My lover, she is waiting for me just across the bar
 My seat’s been taken by some sunglasses askin’ ’bout a scar, and
 I know I gave it to you months ago
 I know you’re tryin’ to forget
 But between the drinks and subtle things
 The holes in my apologies
 You know, I’m tryin’ hard to take it back

annotation.plain:
“Sunglasses” is a slang term for police officers that references their common use of aviator shades in movies.



In the Heat of the Night was a pioneer film in the buddy-cop genre

According to Nate Ruess, the scar in the song is metaphoric — it’s an emotional scar not a visual scar.

The imagery of a police officer asking about the scar is intended to paint a picture of the guilt the narrator feels about hurting his lover and/or fear for being perceived as a bad person.

annotations.lyric_fragment: My friends are in the bathroom getting higher than the Empire State

annotation.plain:
The Empire State Building isn’t just high—it was once the tallest building in the world, standing at 1,454 feet (443.2 m) tall.



To get high is an expression that means to take drugs in an effort “to have a feeling of pleasure or excitement.” Often people use hyperbole (‘higher than the stars’ or ‘higher than Mars’) to say that someone is very affected by the drugs they’ve taken.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
So I remember when we were drivin’, drivin’ in your car
 Speed so fast, I felt like I was drunk
 City lights lay out before us
 And your arm felt nice wrapped ’round my shoulder

annotation.plain: The placement of the second chorus in the structure implies that the strength of this memory and associated hopes that have since faded is much of what has kept her from leaving her partner thus far.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Chorus]

annotation.plain: The musically open and upbeat chorus contrasts strongly with the rigid and monotonous verses, as is typical of a verse-chorus structure. Chapman uses that structure to contrast the giddiness of that moment of change with the hard monotony of grinding out a difficult but perhaps rewarding life. Across three verses the narrator progresses from a “convenience store” (and savings) to a “checkout girl” and finally a “job that pays all our bills.” The chorus, by contrast, just repeats and never changes. Because the narrator does change, we can interpret her as able to integrate this thrilling experience as a memory, whereas it seems the partner can’t let go of the “fast car” and live in the monotony of the verses, in which s/he never does seem to find a job.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I got a plan to get us outta here
 I been working at the convenience store
 Managed to save just a little bit of money

annotation.plain: The narrator makes an asymmetric “deal” with her partner: she bring stability and income – first a little bit of savings, later enough to pay the bills – while all the partner brings is a “fast car.” Without that “fast car” (likely not a literal car, as the next line makes clear), she probably wouldn’t have left, but whatever it offers to her isn’t something sustainable.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Won’t have to drive too far

annotation.plain: If it wasn’t clear that the “fast car” is metaphorical, this line makes it clear: the narrator doesn’t need a “car” so much as something “fast.” Whatever the “deal” is she strikes in the first verse, it’s not access to a motor vehicle.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I got no plans, I ain’t going nowhere

annotation.plain: The idea of “nothing” figures strongly in the first and last verses as counterpoints. Initially it’s clear the narrator has “nothing” in the sense of material poverty. But she also has “nothing to prove” which, at the beginning of the song, is a little ambiguous. As the relationship fractures, however, this “nothing” becomes a base of strength: “I got no plans, I ain’t going nowhere” conveys rootedness. When you have a home and children, having “no plans” means you’re the one who stays and keeps what she has.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
We gotta make a decision
 Leave tonight or live and die this way

annotation.plain: The hardest part of beginning a new journey is taking the first step. By continuously putting it off (e.g., “I’ll do it tomorrow” or “next time”), one will remain stuck in their undesirable situation. Tracy is suggesting if they don’t leave now, they never will. Another way of saying, “If not now, when?”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
So I remember when we were drivin’, drivin’ in your car
 Speed so fast, I felt like I was drunk
 City lights lay out before us
 And your arm felt nice wrapped ’round my shoulder
 And I had a feeling that I belonged
 I had a feelin’ I could be someone
 Be someone, be someone

annotation.plain:
In the chorus the speaker reveals through this memory that the closest she’s ever been to feeling important was in this moment, sat in the passenger seat of the subject’s car. In this moment of intense sensory stimulation, it is easier for the speaker to live solely in the present and escape the tragic realities of her life at home. Only in this moment of lights, touch, speed, adrenaline, has the speaker been able to imagine a purposeful future outside of their reality.

However, the use of the word “drunk” is telling, especially as we understand that the speaker’s father is an alcoholic. Although she is not inebriated, in this moment she feels the same impulsiveness, numbness, and instability a drunk person would. Where her father’s escapism lies at the bottom of a bottle, hers lies in the feeling of this moment.

 Not only is the car a means of physical escape, but it also represents the speaker’s addiction to the search for identity, purpose, and independence.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
See, my old man’s got a problem
 He lives with a bottle, that’s the way it is
 He says his body’s too old for workin’
 His body’s too young to look like his
 When mama went off and left him
 She wanted more from life than he could give
 I said, “Somebody’s gotta take care of him”
 I quit school and that’s what I did

annotation.plain:
This verse tells the tragic story of how the speaker ended up in her current situation. After her mother left her alcoholic and unemployed father, the speaker was forced to give up her dreams and her education to take care of him. She has sacrificed everything for her deadbeat father, and now she is living with the consequences of it.

This sheds some light on why the speaker is so desperate to escape, and why she keeps talking about the fast car, hoping that she can “fly away” from her current life, leaving the past behind her and finally pursuing a proper life for herself.

The phrasing of the first two lines may be a reference to “The Bottle” by Gil Scott-Heron

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You and I can both get jobs
 Finally see what it means to be living

annotation.plain: Working in a convenience store has little to offer in the way of wages, and it would be highly unrealistic to make a proper living out of it. The speaker is hoping she can get a decent job in the city and finally live a decent life.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And I had a feeling that I belonged
 I had a feelin’ I could be someone
 Be someone, be someone

annotation.plain: The phrase “a feeling” takes on a darker meaning in this chorus. In the earlier choruses, it reflected the narrator’s optimism that things will get better, and that someday she would “be someone.” However, now that she’s given up on her optimism, she realises that that feeling of belonging and being someone was never any more than a feeling.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Enjoy the silence

annotation.plain:
The outro of the track seems logical and perfectly fits with its end (where the music fades out, leaving the listener in silence for a few seconds), recalling its name, but also making a conclusion about what is previously said during the verses and the chorus.

It also fits perfectly with the music video in which Dave reaches the peak of the mountain and sits down on his chair to “enjoy the silence”.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Vows are spoken to be broken
 Feelings are intense, words are trivial
 Pleasures remain, so does the pain
 Words are meaningless and forgettable

annotation.plain:
Relationship Interpretation

If you follow the romantic relationship interpretation, he saying, why make vows, they can be broken, let’s just enjoy the feelings, the pleasures and even the pains the relationship brings without words. This reinforces the in my arms escape.



Drug Interpretation

It’s breaking of a vow because feelings are so intense for the drug, though gives pleasure, it doesn’t remove the pain it was meant to quell, and the stupor of the high makes words meaningless and forgettable.



Music Video Interpretation

For the folks following the music video symbolism, vows and promises are often made in a position of privilege, but no matter how you try to escape, pleasures remain, so does the pain and hence you can never have a moment of escape last.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
All I ever wanted
 All I ever needed is here in my arms
 Words are very unnecessary
 They can only do harm

annotation.plain:
Relationship Interpretation

If you follow the romantic relationship interpretation, he is confessing that his love for his little girl and admits that she is his escape, and that why worry a perfect moment with imperfect words.



Drug Interpretation

If you follow the drug interpretation, he is confessing that all he needs is the drugs running in [his] arms and that words would only take him way from his high.



Music Video Interpretation

If you follow the symbolism of the video, then his escape is being way from his court and using the chair in his arms to enjoy the silence and actually enjoy his kingdom, little world or just his daily journey through life. There is also an underlying desire to stay away from expression, as words are very unnecessary, they can only do harm.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Words like violence break the silence
 Come crashing in into my little world
 Painful to me, pierce right through me
 Can’t you understand? Oh, my little girl

annotation.plain:
Simply stated, the narrator is disscussing a chaotic point of violence in the world around him, that it is painful. And there is a need to have an escape.

Relationship Interpretation

If you follow the romantic relationship interpretation, it is him pressing his need to be in a quiet moment with his loved one to escape.



Drug Interpretation

If you follow the drug interpretation, it is his confession to his naive little girl that he needs an injection to escape.



Music Video Interpretation

If you follow the music video symbolism of a crowned king/prince (often a literary symbol of privilege, authority, higher spiritual state, or superego), then he is explaining the desire to flee the bickering of his court to his little girl princess.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Heaven holds a place for those who pray

annotation.plain: A naughty reference: praying is often associated with a kneeling position, also common while giving oral sex.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Put it in your pantry with your cupcakes

annotation.plain:
As Myra Groenewegen notes:
“The meaning in the film may well not be the meaning in the song as a standalone work. Without the film’s context, it seems to refer to church participation and religious conviction and perhaps the group support circles offered by churches (“look around you all you see is sympathetic eyes”) which is a little strange to be hiding, at this very religious time, but that seems to be it. Church organizations, remember offer various kinds of pastoral care and religiously guided emotional and life help support circles (Alcoholics Anonymous started in churches, as a well-known example). The focus [was on] on reassurance of divine love, reward for effort and praying.”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Look around you, all you see are sympathetic eyes
 Stroll around the grounds until you feel at home

annotation.plain:
If the previous part of the verse is Eleanor Roosevelt speaking to her psychiatrist, then this is Eleanor Roosevelt voluntarily entering a psychiatric institution. The lines may recall a time when “female hysteria” was a popular diagnosis among upper middle class White women. This diagnosis could include boredom, depression, alcoholism, lesbianism, sexual indiscretion, or really anything a married woman might experience that might lead to social awkwardness or her husband’s discomfort.

However, other verses suggest participation in a liberal church women’s group. These were popular in the 1940s and emphasized faith, self-help, education, and voting.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Hide it in a hiding place where no one ever goes

annotation.plain: Mrs. Robinson’s secret (her affair with Benjamin) would completely ruin her family’s image. Her husband is a successful businessman (not to mention a friend of Benjamin’s father’s).

annotations.lyric_fragment: A nation turns its lonely eyes to you

annotation.plain: At the point of this album’s release Joe DiMaggio had largely exited the public eye after the death of his wife, Marilyn Monroe, in 1962. DiMaggio, in Paul Simon’s own words, represented “traditional American values,” and his departure from the limelight represent’s America’s departure from glory. Note that this is the same album as the song America.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Dee dee dee dee dee dee dee dee dee dee dee dee dee
 Doo doo doo doo doo doo doo doo doo
 Dee dee dee dee dee dee dee dee dee dee dee dee dee

annotation.plain: During recording, they realized that there was no lyrics in the intro and it sounded a bit long without any lyrics at that specific part. So, they said “Dee dee dee, doo doo doo” for filler.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Mrs. Robinson
 Jesus loves you more than you will know
 Woah, woah, woah

annotation.plain:
The constant repetition of “Jesus” tries to tell the listeners that Mrs. Robinson should not cheat and sin (thus the biblical reference) on her husband by sleeping with her daughter’s boyfriend.

This can be seen as encouraging Mrs. Robinson to stop, pray, and become a woman who would not do such things, or it can merely be reminding her that forgiveness awaits. The song never explicitly condemns her; there may be more empathy here than most commentators see.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Coo, coo, ca-choo

annotation.plain: Seemingly a reference to a similar nonsense line from the Beatles' “I Am The Walrus”.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Sitting on a sofa on a Sunday afternoon
 Going to the candidates debate
 Laugh about it, shout about it
 When you’ve got to choose
 Every way you look at it, you lose

annotation.plain: Even if this song had been written for the movie The Graduate (which it was not), this doesn’t seem to fit the archetype of Mrs. Robinson, a bored socialite housewife.  It is more likely that Simon & Garfunkel are commenting on the sorry state of politics in general, that watching a candidate’s debate is an exercise in choosing the lesser of two evils. Just by “going” to the debate via your television, you’re part of the political process. A cynic would say, whether or not you shout because you care or laugh because you don’t, you lose whichever one you choose to vote for, if neither candidate is fit for office.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
It’s a little secret, just the Robinsons’ affair
 Most of all, you’ve got to hide it from the kids

annotation.plain:
FDR had many affairs, reputedly with the Princess Martha of Sweden, his secretary Missy and Eleanor’s social secretary Lucy Mercer. These indiscretions would eventually lead to their separation and ending any intimacy in their relationship. Eleanor has also been reported to have been a lesbian and had a relationship with reporter Lorena Hickock.

Despite their unfaithfulness, they had to keep their affairs a secret because society wouldn’t agree and they have to teach their children morals.

annotation.plain:
Jitterbug is a term used since the early 20th century, which also developed into a dance with the same name. Jitter meaning restlessness and bug indicating how contagious it can be.

Here George Micheals indicates that, when he fell in love, his brain has supposedly “caught” a Jitterbug.

annotation.plain: Britney tells us how her romantic involvement with this person was only her having fun. The man became emotionally attached but Britney never had intentions of a serious relationship. The other party took her flirting as the beginning of something special where as to Spears, it was all just a game.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I’m not that innocent

annotation.plain:
This is the first time that Britney opposes the “Good Girl” image that was attributed to her.

This could be a response to the controversy she’s caused since the beginning of her career, as she often wore skimpy and revealing clothes that weren’t “suitable” for her age and audience.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I think I did it again

 Oh, baby, it might seem like a crush
 But it doesn’t mean that I’m serious

annotation.plain: These lyrics are a departure from “…Baby One More Time”’s often lovesick songs. Instead of Britney having the crush, this man is. Brit’s language and attitude has caused this man to think that Britney wants to start a romantic relationship with him, but Britney is uninterested.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’d shine up the old brown shoes, I’d put on a brand-new shirt
 I’d get home early from work if you say that you love me

annotation.plain: Shining up old brown shoes and putting on a brand-new shirt are symbolic gestures of grooming and presentation, suggesting a desire to look good and present oneself in the best possible way. Getting home early from work is a commitment to prioritize the relationship and make time for the other person.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I’m beggin’ you to beg me

annotation.plain: Instead of saying, “I’m begging you to love me” he’s saying, “I’m begging you to beg me”. What does he want to be begged into though? He wants his crush/lover to beg him to love her back. In sum, the lyric is shorthand for, “I’m begging you to beg me to love you”.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Didn’t I, didn’t I, didn’t I see you cryin’?

annotation.plain: The album version features an echo effect on the last word of each line of the chorus, which the audience of Japanese girls shout back at the band during the much more famous At Budokan version.

annotations.lyric_fragment: They hate and the devil keep jumpin’ me (Jumpin’ me)

annotation.plain: The line “They hate and the devil keep jumpin' me (Jumpin' me)” means that there are people who harbor strong dislike or animosity towards the speaker, and they continually face challenging or negative situations, symbolized by the phrase “the devil keep jumpin' me.”

annotations.lyric_fragment: Nutty Buddy, now that nigga duckin’ (Phew)

annotation.plain:
Nutty Buddies, or Nutty Bars, are a snack from the brand Little Debbie containing 4 peanut butter wafers combined together and covered in chocolate.



With the inclusion of the phrase “Nutty Buddy” right before he lets us know that “that n**** duckin'”, Quavo compares his opposition to Nutty Bars and states that they’re scared to face him. Through the use of the N-word, he implies to the listener that his opposition is a black man or group of black men, which fits in line with the idea of a Nutty Buddy: Quavo is saying that his enemies, while dark on the outside, are soft and sweet on the inside (just like a Nutty Buddy).

annotations.lyric_fragment: Courtside with a bad bitch (Bitch)

annotation.plain: Courtside tickets for a NBA game costs roughly $1,200. Offset is saying that he have a lot of money to watch really closely to a NBA game.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Countin’ that paper like loose-leaf, yeah

annotation.plain:
Loose leaf is notebook paper in individual pieces, typically sold in packages of 100 sheets.



As paper is slang for cash, Uzi is comparing the vast quantity of his money to the great amount of actual paper a packet of loose leaf offers.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Offset, woo, woo, woo, woo, woo

annotation.plain:
The onomatopoeia, “whoo,” often expresses excitement or signifies a hot temperature. Offset told The Breakfast Club that when he heard the beat drop, he couldn’t contain himself. He played back the sounds and decided to keep them.

https://youtu.be/c6AF9LQBZBE?t=4m47s

Interestingly, Offset would go on to adapt this as his signature sound. On his 2017 track, “Ric Flair Drip,” he seems to attribute its origin to Ric Flair:

Ric Flair drip, go “woo” on a bitch (woo)

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I gave her ten racks
 I told her go shoppin’ and spend it all at the pop up (Ten)

annotation.plain:
While stacks and racks can represent different amounts, the two can also be used interchangeably to mean $1,000. Quavo is such a baller, he gives his girl $10,000 to go shopping.

Pop-up shops—examples of the “flash retailing” trend—are short-term shops that usually sell exclusive, limited-time-only merchandise.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Saw your girl once, now she choosin’, yeah (Hey!)

annotation.plain:
Uzi uses pimp vernacular to describe a woman who’s attracted to him.

“Choosing” is southern slang for guys or women that make it obvious to another person that they’re interested.  Most of the time, these men and women are already in relationships, but the flashiness or sex appeal of the other person makes them consider leaving.

Fellow Atlantan rapper Gucci Mane, dedicated a song to choosing.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Switchin’ my flows like my clothes (Like what?)

annotation.plain:
As documented by The FADER in an interview with LUV, Uzi is a big fan of fashion; he can often be seen rocking brands such as Vetements and Supreme, and he’s collaborated with A$AP Bari—the founder of Vlone.



Lil Uzi is also known for his ever-changing flows, from his Future-like flow on “All Night” to his singsong flow on “Ps and Qs.”

annotations.lyric_fragment: Switchin’ my hoes like my flows (What?)

annotation.plain:
Lil Uzi is known for his ability to effortlessly switch up the his flow. While this verse is slow, he told Vibe:

Some guy was just like ‘you rap fast, man. Like a little machine gun’ and from that moment I was Lil Uzi.

After his first mixtape, The Real Uzi, Uzi added “Vert” to the end. In an interview with Rolling Stone, Uzi described the meaning of “Vert” as “straight to the top, like a vertical leap.”

Uzi spits a similar line during his feature in Lil Baby’s recent track, “Life Goes On”:

I can switch my girls up the same way that I change my clothes (okay)

Like his ability to change up the flow, Lil Uzi gets with all sorts of different women.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Holdin’ the fire with no holster (Blaow)

annotation.plain:
Holsters are used to carry or restrict the use of an item, in this case it would be a handgun holster (The Fire).

Since he is holding it without a holster, he is simply carrying it around, nothing to hold it back.

annotation.plain:
In an interview with producer Mark Rooney, who worked with MJB on this song, he told the story behind coming up with “Real Love”:


Mary J. Blige is the female that’s from the hood that sings the pain of all of the females from the hood. At that point in her life, she was being taken advantage of by a lot of the industry cats and a song like ‘Real Love’ described her situation.

One day, she said with tears in her eyes, ‘I just want a real love in my life for once.’ We wrote four or five songs before “Real Love” came together for her. […] She was so emotional back then. Sometimes, we would be in the studio and she would have tears in her eyes. Right in the middle of a take, you wouldn’t hear anything in the dark vocal booth. We would wonder if she was still in there. She would be in there, but her emotions took over. All of these records started becoming real life records for her.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Produced by Mark Morales & Mark C. Rooney]

annotation.plain:
The drum pattern that loops throughout this song was sampled from the classic track “Top Billin'” by Audio Two (as well as MC Lyte’s “10% Diss”).

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0wbWPyhW7fE

In an interview 20 years after the album’s release, Rooney told the story of how “Real Love” transpired:


‘Real Love’ was the first song we did because we actually recorded it two years before the album came out. We did it at our home studio. The other thing about ‘Real Love’ is that when it came time to use the song for the album, I told Puffy I wanted to go back in and reproduce it. I wanted to take the sample out and replay the drums. He said, ‘No, No, No!’ I told him I wasn’t going to give away my publishing to Milk and Giz when we can play our own drums. He said, ‘That’s what makes the record dope. That’s what makes it hip-hop. Are you crazy? Don’t change it.’ Of course, I was fighting the fight and he came to the studio physically prepared to fight all of our asses that day. My partner, Mark Morales ended up siding with him.
So, I walked out of the studio and told them don’t put my name on that bullshit. I’m thankful that they didn’t pay me any attention.

Mark Morales was a rapper who never wrote R&B lyrics. He was a member of the Fat Boys. Mark was sitting on the other side of the room with a pad of paper and a pen. He starts writing lyrics down and all of a sudden he approaches me saying that he wrote some lyrics down to the music I was working on. He said, ‘Don’t laugh.’ I told him I wasn’t going to laugh and he started singing the first four lines of ‘Real Love.’ It was almost like a rap and I told him it was hot. I put melodies behind it and a bridge. The bridge was borne out of the melodies. It came together really fast. The original recording of the song took place in my basement in Queens.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Off the chain, I leave niggas soft in the brain

annotation.plain:
DMX leaves his opponents with a soft part in their brain. This part of the line has this tie in with “off the chain,” which could mean anything, but I believe he’s referencing the following:

DMX has stated himself that he has been to jail 30 times and when he is “off the chain” or un-incarcerated he’d leave opponents hurt

Or it could mean when he is on a rampage, like a dog off its leash, which DMX references a lot in his music. I personally believe this one more.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You

annotation.plain:
You wack, you twisted, your head is fucked
Your old man say you stupid, you be like, “So?”

annotations.lyric_fragment: Y’all niggas is characters, not even good actors

annotation.plain:
Wordplay. On the streets “actors” are people who play the role of being tough guys/street guys when in reality they’re usually punks. X here is saying you rappers are playing the role of tough guys and aren’t even good at it.

Characters are typically what actors play in films and tv shows, but X here is saying these rappers are literal characters, meaning made up personas trying to portray something they are not.

annotations.lyric_fragment: They fuck it up for real niggas like my mans and them

annotation.plain: Weak men mess the game up for real street Gs, like DMX, making it hard for strong men like him to have a relationship with a female like Foxy Brown. who is really attractive. He could be implying that  weak men make women doubt the strength of men in general.  Another, more sinister interpretation is that men like him hit their women when they cheat, and weak men make it more difficult for them to get away with that because women come to expect gentler treatment. As they should.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’m tired of weak-ass niggas whining over puss
 That don’t belong to them, fuck is wrong with them?

annotation.plain: A continued diss of Kurupt, who at the time was in an on and off relationship with Foxy Brown that was broken up with Foxy falling for DMX. It got to a point where Kurupt was so love stricken he came to New York to help Foxy fight assault cases and dissed DMX in The “Source” and then dissed him all throughout his Streetz iz A Mutha album

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And I don’t know who the fuck you think you talkin’ to
 But I’m not him, aight, Slim? So watch what you do

annotation.plain:
This line relates to some controversy among hip-hop listeners, particularly because of the term “Slim”. It’s often interpreted as a diss to Eminem, who has an alter ego named Slim Shady. If you come to think about it, it actually makes sense because …And Then There Was X was released in 1999, year when Eminem was at the top of the music industry with his classic hip-hop album The Slim Shady LP.

As far as dissing content goes, it’s possible to understand that DMX and Eminem had a curious relationship, often remembered by radio freestyles and obscure interpretations of suspicious lyrics. The most clear sign that this subliminal beef actually happened may be the “Wordplay” freestyle:

Rappers know that I’m the same, they don’t wanna step to this, they don’t wanna feel the pain,
Like DMX (DMX VOICE): “what? you gon think that he’s gon step to this now? eurgh, yo, you don’t think you wanna fuck with this now

It is said that the beef was squashed when 50 Cent beefed with Ja Rule. They’ve even made a diss called Go To Sleep, also featuring Obie Trice, for Ja.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Bridge: DMX]

annotation.plain:
In an interview Swizz Beatz mentions how the outro was originally unscripted and it was just Swizz, acting out for fun, pretending to be a dj in the club spinning records.

When X heard it he liked it and asked him to run it back and add some of his own ad-libs to it. The second part that’s all Swizz was purely on the fly improvisation that they left on.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Grandma wishin’ your soul’s at rest
 But it’s hard to digest with the size of the hole in your chest

annotation.plain:
Double meaning here. Grandma will hope you are in heaven, but knows that the number of shots you took on the street from DMX probably means Hell.

Also, the amount and size of the holes makes it hard to digest food, as the stomach is probably ruptured.

He’s also saying that since the soul lives in the body in biblical terms, that with how big of a wound to the chest, there’s figuratively and literally no way the soul escaped the body unscathed.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I see us written in the stars

annotation.plain: That they are meant to be together

annotations.lyric_fragment:
If you’re feeling like you need a little bit of company
 You met me at the perfect time

annotation.plain: Dua Lipa’s own comment about the song “It’s about having fun and meeting someone and falling in love and thinking, “You’ve probably met me at the perfect time, let’s just go for it.” It’s the feeling when love makes you feel like you’re levitating. It’s otherworldly.”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I feel like we’re forever every time we get together
 But whatever, let’s get lost on Mars

annotation.plain: The idea of transcending “Earth” appears in this verse, with “forever” implying breaking the rules of mortals. Both Dua and her lover enter almost a fantasy world. Getting lost on Mars appears as almost a means of escape from the normality of everyday life, as the only way in order to truly live together “forever”. This could also reference being intoxicated, with the prospect of going to outer-space seeming psychedelic, highlighting unrealistic expectations. The word “whatever”, relates to an aloofness associated with being young, again alluding to a sense of immortality.

annotations.lyric_fragment: The Milky Way, we’re renegading

annotation.plain:
While by 2020 the renegade was a popular dance that might be thought of in the context of dancing the fact that Future Nostalgia was recorded between January and November 2019 makes this connection something that probably was not intended.
“To renegade” as a term is the act of becoming a renegade. In the context of the song it might mean that they plan to break with traditions (for example traditional courtship) and begin a new exciting love.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Bridge]

annotation.plain: Dua has noticed that many people aren’t aware she’s British, so she showcases it with a playful ‘rap’ in the song’s bridge.

annotations.lyric_fragment: My sugarboo, I’m levitating

annotation.plain: On episode 194 of the podcast Song Exploder, Dua explained that “sugarboo” is a term of endearment she and her collaborators on the song use for each other. She was unsure whether to keep the term in but ultimately decided to do so.

annotations.lyric_fragment: And I’m feeling so electric, dance my ass off

annotation.plain: While a more common expression would be to “work your ass off” (showing how invested into a project one is) the lyrical I is showing a great effort in having fun with dancing. This creates a sort of oxymoron as a phrase that usually has a connotation of hard work is here associated with fun. Likewise, love and relationships take hard work but here it is alluded that this work might very well be amusement.

annotations.lyric_fragment: My love is like a rocket, watch it blast off

annotation.plain:
This line works on several levels: While they are not as common or popular these days rocket launches used to be the center of international attention. For example the launch of Apollo 11 had a worldwide viewership of an estimated 650 million people. So watching the love blast off is possibly witnessing a monumental event.

Also the blast off of a rocket is the start to an exciting, once in a lifetime adventure which is in turn like the start of a possibly great love.

annotations.lyric_fragment: How deep is your love?

annotation.plain: Here, he is complaining that despite her knowing how much he cares for her, she doesn’t acknowledge his love and keeps asking him to do more and show how much he loves her.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And you may not think I care for you
 When you know down inside that I really do
 And it’s me you need to show

annotation.plain: Sometimes we get into our heads about our friendship/relationship/companionship. One may not feel their partner cares, but if the bond is strong they will feel it and in turn would reciprocate in a way that proves it, or a gesture.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I believe in you
 You know the door to my very soul
 You’re the light in my deepest, darkest hour
 You’re my saviour when I fall

annotation.plain: To be totally in love with someone you have to believe in every part of them, all the demons, scars, trauma, all of it. When the trust and loyalty bonds are strengthened, the soul will open up to that person. They will be the yin to your yang.

annotations.lyric_fragment: And it’s me you need to show

annotation.plain: They need to show him how much they love him, because their behavior isn’t helping him to figure out. How deep does this person’s love go for him?

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And you come to me on a summer breeze
 Keep me warm in your love, then you softly leave

annotation.plain:
Summer usually represents youth, adolescence, or warmth (as in heat or love). The man is starting to have an interest in the woman.

This is also a moody transition from a rainy spring to a warm and dry summer.

The summer and the breeze are a metaphor for a contradiction; summer enlightens the couple’s warm-heated love, but the wind blows it away, just like a candle in the wind.

Or, like a dying wind, she would softly depart from the scene as she [metaphorically] vanishes into the air.

  


Notice the pararhyme on “love” and “leave.” There’s a brief alliteration of the “s” vowel: “summer”/“softly.”

annotation.plain:
Everyone is trying to get involved in their relationship. Trying to tell them how to feel and what to do, but they’re just making things harder for them.

He wants everyone to leave them alone because they are each others and nobody else really matters.

annotation.plain: The bond they share is being established as truly special – they are inseparable, and he knows her better than she knows herself.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Intro]

annotation.plain:
The “dead giveaway” entry and riff of this classic.

It sounds quite a bit like the Rolling Stones' intro for “What a Shame” from their second album released two years before “Happy Together” in 1965.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Outro]

annotation.plain: A big, bombastic, sing-along outro with layers of brass, vocals, and reverb, akin to Phil Spektor’s famous “Wall of Sound” technique. In spite of the song’s earlier wistfulness, where the lyrics imply that the singer is only imagining life with his beloved, the song ends with an echo of optimism: maybe imagining a future with the girl is as good as having her, or maybe he’s confident that his heartfelt plea (in the form of this song) will win her over.

annotation.plain:
Likely “to think about… (holding) her tight”; ie – imagining holding her.

The sentence as it is presents it as an additional action to thinking about her.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
No, I don’t like you, I just thought you were cool enough to kick it
 Got a beach house I could sell you in Idaho
 Since you think I don’t love you, I just thought you were cute
 That’s why I kissed you
 Got a fighter jet, I don’t get to fly it though
 I’m lying down

annotation.plain:
It’s possible George Strait’s “Ocean Side Property” served as inspiration for this verse. In it he sings:

Girl, your memory won’t ever haunt me
Cause I don’t love you, and now if you’ll buy that
I got some ocean front property in Arizona

Frank’s usage of Arizona in the first verse can also be attributed to this song, and in a similar fashion he builds on it by mentioning a beach house in Idaho. Yet, neither of these states have an oceanfront.

This points out to wordplay on “lying” since he apparently isn’t telling the truth. It’s also pretty clear Frank doesn’t actually own a fighter jet, but he accurately compares an unrequited love to having a jet you can’t fly. The cover of the single has Frank sitting in a Go-Kart, which is a visualization of this line.

However, the motive behind lying is unclear; he could be doing it sarcastically to assert the person he loves them, or it’s his way of wiggling out of a rejection.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’m thinkin’ ’bout you, ooh, no, no, no
 I’ve been thinkin’ ’bout you, you know, know, know
 I’ve been thinkin’ ’bout you, do you think about me still?
 Do ya, do ya?

annotation.plain:
Frank Ocean dreams of spending his life with the song’s subject, but he isn’t sure if they feel the same way, hence in the pre-chorus, he admits that he cries whenever he thinks of them. The fact that the lyrics don’t tell us if they’re even in a relationship anymore shows how complicated the situation is.

While it’s not clear if “Nikes” uses the same relationship as an inspiration, it discusses a similar situation:

He don’t care for me
But he cares for me
And that’s good enough

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Yes, of course, I remember, how could I forget (How could I forget)
 How you feel? (How you feel?)
 You know you were my first time, a new feel
 It won’t ever get old, not in my soul, not in my spirit, keep it alive
 We’ll go down this road ’til it turns from color to black and white

annotation.plain:
In his 2012 open letter, Frank Ocean revealed his first love was a man, which asserts the idea that this song is about a male partner:

4 summers ago, I met somebody. I was 19 years old. He was too. We spent that summer, and the summer after, together. Everyday almost. And on the days we were together, time would glide. Most of the day I’d see him, and his smile. I’d hear his conversation and his silence.. until it was time to sleep. Sleep I would often share with him. By the time I realized I was in love, it was malignant. It was hopeless. There was no escaping, no negotiating with the feeling. No choice. It was my first love, it changed my life.

Frank also revealed through the letter that his love seemed unrequited when he confessed his feelings, which he acknowledges here. The entire song seems to take place in a conversation between them after his confession, or perhaps a conversation that Frank desperately wants to have with him but can only initiate in his mind—a conversation in which Frank’s first love seems to deny and diminish Frank’s feelings towards him, with Frank responding sarcastically to assert his love for him. Frank emphasizes that he still remembers his first love can never love him the way he wants, likely in response to him reminding Frank that he does not feel the same way. Regardless, a lovestruck Frank emotionally discloses the “forever” they spend together that he’s been dreaming of, before sadly pointing out once again how he probably hasn’t been thinking that far ahead.

Furthermore, the road changing from color to black and white represents them sticking together until gay people get the right to marry. They’ll wear black and white, like a bride and groom, instead of the rainbow-colored LGBT flag.

To bring the song full circle, the road changing colors is another reference to The Wizard of Oz, in which the movie changes to black and white once Dorothy heads back home from Oz.



Gay marriage was ruled legal nationwide in the US in 2015.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
A tornado flew around my room before you came
 Excuse the mess it made, it usually doesn’t rain in
 Southern California, much like Arizona
 My eyes don’t shed tears, but, boy, they pour when

annotation.plain:
Frank’s room represents his life; he’s well aware it was messy and out of order before he met his significant other, who brought peace into his life. However, they’ve broken up and it makes him cry which is as rare as rain in California and Arizona. Interestingly, it was thought his second LP would be titled Boys Don’t Cry, but it ended up being the name of the magazine that went along with Blonde.

“It Never Rains in Southern California” is a song that tells a story of a musician who moved to Cali in pursuit of a music career. The tornado is one of two references to the classic novel/movie “The Wizard of Oz” in this song, in which the main character Dorothy is swept away into the Land of Oz by a tornado.

Once you put those two references together, and mix water with a tornado, you get a highly influential event that happened to Ocean. After hurricane Katrina hit his hometown of New Orleans, Frank moved to Los Angeles to chase his dream of being a musician.

Furthermore, “It Never Rains in Southern California” contains the following lyrics:

It never rains in California, but girl, don’t they warn ya?
It pours, man, it pours

In the mentioned lines, “girl” is a vocative, and “man” is just a phrase that is there to amplify the meaning. However, Frank’s usage of “boy” in this verse could be interpreted as both, and that means the love he’s talking about could be male or female. Note that when “Thinkin Bout You” came out as a single it was still unknown if he was straight or not. Prior to the release of channel ORANGE, he came out as bisexual.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Feel so enamoured
 Hold me tight within your clutch (’Nother)

annotation.plain:
Enamoured comes from the French words “en amour” meaning literally “in love.” However, it has the idiomatic meaning of being captivated, bewitched by love. Most often, young couples are depicted as being “enamoured”:

‘Encaptured’ and ‘enamoured’ are related in terms of meaning and rhyme; some clever word-play.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Got you shackled in my embrace
 I’m latching on to you (’Nother)

annotation.plain:
Smith’s embrace of this boy is similar to being chained up or shackled — an odd metaphor.

There is a view that the word ‘shackled’ is unfortunate in respect of relationships. Shackles imply imprisonment, which is not what true love is about. ‘Circled in my embrace’ might have been more appropriate. But these are the words as written by Disclosure, as they wanted it, and it fits the rest of the song.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Now I’ve got you in my space
 I won’t let go of you (’Nother)

annotation.plain:
Sam refuses to be like Edward MacFarlane in “Defeated No More”.

I just feel I let you go

Now that he’s got his crush right where he wants, he’s gonna seize the opportunity.

Also, note how he enunciates “space.” On the album (and in live performances) Smith puts a small pause before the word, breaking rhythm. This break could be a sign of our narrator’s precision…possibly someone obsessed with invading someone else’s space. It seems a little more menacing, doesn’t it?

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I feel we’re close enough
 I wanna lock in your love
 I think we’re close enough
 Could I lock in your love, baby?

annotation.plain: Continuing the latch analogy, Sam wants to lock this playful, flirty engagement into a fully fledged relationship with all its affectionate perks. The notions of “lock” and “latch” also fit many of the intimate actions couples do: hugging, holding hands, sexual intercourse, etc.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’m latching on, babe
 Now I know what I have found (’Nother)

annotation.plain:
Sam knows that they have found the right man, and as a result is steadily fastening themself onto him.

The locking and latching and shackling imagery are related — if this were poetry it would be described as a lexical or a semantic field.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
’Nother
 ’Nother
 ’Nother

annotation.plain:
The vocal sample of “(a')nother” is taken from Zed Bias and Jenna G’s cover of “Fairplay”.



It’s repeated at the end of each line, offering a sort of playful response to Sam Smith’s affectionate requests.

In a track breakdown, Disclosure explained the sample:

First thing obviously we need to talk about is this sample. Here’s where the confusion came in, I labeled it as “Never”, it sounds like “Never”, but it is the word “Another”. Cut straight from the old Zed Bias acapella. It’s probably slowed down. I just really loved that delivery.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Yo, ’member back on the bouley when cats used to harmonize like (Ooh, ooh-ooh, ooh)

annotation.plain:
Doo-wop is a genre of Rhythm and Blues music that originated in African-American communities during the 1940s, mainly in cities such as New York and Philadelphia  and it featured vocal group harmony that carried an engaging melodic line to a simple beat with little or no instrumentation.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=we2kmO24rgE&list=PLHlSiA_Lj8dd9EDb3Lm6l7TFvj1xk5VRK&index=6

The harmonic singing of syllables (such as “doo-wop”) is a common characteristic of these songs, hence Lauryn mimicking the iconic harmonization in the second opening line and throughout the song.

As displayed in the music video for “Doo Wop (That Thing),” Lauryn showcases elements of both 1960’s and 1990’s culture, celebrating both eras and as a whole black artistry.



Comparison side to side: in the left, 1960's and the right, 1990's


It also represents the blend of genres in the song, the soul of old-school R&B in the repetitive piano notes and brass horns, combined with the hard-hitting boom bap drums of modern Hip Hop.

The song is both retro and modern, and that is introduced right in the first two opening lines, an expression of immortality as the message that Lauryn Hill is about to portray in “Doo Wop.”

annotations.lyric_fragment: Look at where you be in, hair weaves like Europeans (Europeans)

annotation.plain:
Lauryn appears to be chastising Black women who may be perceived as not being proud of their natural hair when they choose to wear wigs, extensions, weaves or relax their hair to give it a straight look like that of Caucasians.

Ms. Hill may be making a statement to Black women in particular in telling them to be true to themselves and not conform to the standard of beauty others may have set.

However, a Black woman wrote an article for POPSUGAR where she talked about different reasons Black women may alter their natural hair outside of assimilation, such as testing different styles on the fake hair and saving styling time. The author also pointed out the weave double standard where Black women get criticism such as self-hatred but white women wouldn’t face the same scrutiny.

annotation.plain: Sex

annotations.lyric_fragment: Let it sit inside your head like a million women in Philly, Penn (Philly, Penn)

annotation.plain:
Lauryn is probably referring to the Million Woman March, a protest demonstration that took place in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, on October 25, 1997.



The mission of the march was shedding a light on the issues African-American women were facing at the time and firmly reminding their need for self-determination.

As stated in the previous lines, Hill’s goal is not so different from the one of the manifestation: she primarily wants to spread a message people can chew on and maturely discuss about for a very long time.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Need to take care of they three or four kids
 And they face a court case when the child support late (The child support late)
 Money taking and heart breaking, now you wonder why women hate men (Why)

annotation.plain: Lauryn blames men just as much as women for their contributions to the failed relationships she talks about throughout the song. Both genders flaunt money they don’t actually have to attract the opposite sex, which works short-term, but will cause long-term problems, like child support, abuse, and broken homes.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Now, Lauryn is only human (Human)
 Don’t think I haven’t been through the same predicament (I been there)

annotation.plain:
Lauryn is not speaking from a place of judgement, since she also once had that same mindset. However, as she grew out of it, now she’s trying to convince other women to do the same. Lauryn elaborated on this thought on a 1998 interview with Details magazine, where she said:

I’m not dissing them, I’m dissing their mind-set. My music talks about a certain way of thinking, and if the cap fits, you know? I knew girls like Kim growing up – I might have even been one at certain age – and there’s a huge lack of self-esteem behind that thinking. I mean, when I was 14 I thought that if a guy didn’t whistle at me, that meant I wasn’t pretty. But either you mature past that or you get caught in the concept of, ‘Oh, I have to show some ass, 'cause that’s the only way I can feel beautiful.’ Sex is cool, but it’s only part of the story.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
It’s been three weeks since you were looking for your friend
 The one you let hit it and never called you again (Uh)

annotation.plain:
Lauryn starts off the verse by directly addressing a woman in a one-night stand. The woman was hoping for more to come from this romantic relationship, but instead she was “ghosted”.

“Ghosting” is slang for when a person cuts off all communication with their friends or the person they’re dating, with zero warning or notice before hand.

annotations.lyric_fragment:

 Don’t be a hard rock when you really are a gem

annotation.plain:
Lauryn needs these women to know their true worth and not degrade themselves.

There is also a pun on “gem” since it is more valuable than just another “hard rock” but also since “gem” is slang for somebody who is excellent and stands out from their peers.

There are two possible ways of interpreting this line:

1) She views as merely someone to be teased, but he wants her to truly understand his affectionate emotions towards her and love him back.

2) She sexually objectifies the man and pays attention only to his sexual attractiveness, but he wants her to know that she is shallow and dishonest and pay attention to his personality and not just his looks.

annotations.lyric_fragment: (God and man) No confessions

annotation.plain:
In the Catholic religion, followers confess their sins to a priest.

The love that the narrator is looking for is simple and pure.  This likely isn’t meant to be interpreted as a literal Christian reference, but rather a metaphor for honesty and respectability.

annotations.lyric_fragment: There’s no sign of life

annotation.plain:
Being an old-fashioned man in the world of Modern Love has left the narrator in despair. It’s like searching for others on a lonely, desert island. He searches for romantic prospects who reject Modern Love, but there’s no sign of life.

The following line affirms this by stating “It’s just the power to charm”. The people he meets aren’t real or interested in true love—they’re superficial. This may be the reason why the narrator despises Modern Love so.

Sometimes, the omnipresence of vapid “Modern Love” makes him give up hope. But he always picks himself up and tries again.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Never going to fall for
 (Modern love)

annotation.plain:
The early 80’s was the time AIDS has been recognized as the scourge of gay and bisexual men. Though homosexuality is as old as mankind – its acceptance and prevalence have been brought to the forefront at that time.

Some believe that Bowie is rejecting here this “modern” love – past his well known bisexual stage from the 70’s, and even advocating against the “free for all” attitude of the preceding years.



One of his better known liaisons.

David Bowie vehemently denied his bisexuality at the time the album (Lets Dance) was written and produced.

annotations.lyric_fragment: (Modern love) Gets me to the church on time

annotation.plain: Modern love is ephemeral, and can’t satisfy us, so we have to look for love elsewhere. Many people look for it at church.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Puts my trust in God and man

annotation.plain:
An interlude of sensible and wise results of his church visit?

Sounds this way, but dismissed in the next lines – at least the God part…

Bowie’s attitude toward God changed over the years. In the early 70’s he was influenced by Friedrich Nietzsche’s philosophy of God’s death, and sang about “bullshit faith”. However, in a 1993 interview he said: “On a personal level, I have an undying belief in God’s existence. For me it is unquestionable.”

In this line he expresses belief in God, while rejecting the religious establishment in the following lines.

annotations.lyric_fragment: But things don’t really change

annotation.plain: “Changes” are a major theme in Bowie’s work – both as social progress/human evolution and his own ever-changing identity.  This line is more pessimistic than usual.

annotations.lyric_fragment: No confessions

annotation.plain:
Confession is a name for the Sacrament of Penance & Reconciliation in the Catholic Church:

“Those who approach the sacrament of Penance obtain pardon from God’s mercy for the offense committed against him, and are, at the same time, reconciled with the Church which they have wounded by their sins and which by charity, by example, and by prayer labors for their conversion.”

The singer trusts “God and Man” but rejects religious dogma – although the line also sounds a little insecure, like he’s trying to deny his own sins, and convince himself and the audience that he nothing to confess.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Never going to fall for
 (Modern love) Walks beside me
 (Modern love) Walks on by
 (Modern love)

annotation.plain:
The ambiguity of “Modern Love” is the song’s emotional core.  In the context of the song, Bowie could be speaking about romantic love, or “philanthropia,” the love of God.

The song’s themes – longing, loneliness, skepticism, doubt, and finding the sacred in the mundane – apply to either kind of love, but the song’s power ultimately comes from the juxtaposition and synthesis of human and divine love.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’m lying in the rain
 But I never wave bye-bye

annotation.plain:
Is he lying down in the rain (who does that?) or telling a falsehood?
Rain is often used to symbolize washing away, so maybe he recognizes that at the same time that he is washing away his past (love? beliefs? sins?), he continues to lie. Seems to tie in the following line: “I never wave bye-bye,” which would be to say he never lets go of his past; he can’t change.

To strengthen the argument for “lying” as in not telling the truth, in a 1993 interview Bowie admitted that he had been lying about his drug problem at the time of “Let’s Dance”: “I was still fighting desperately to stop the drug thing, which was intermittent by then, but kept coming back. I told everyone that I was no longer an addict – including myself – because it was only occasional. But of course those occasions got closer and closer together.” So his claim that he “gets things done” turns out to be a lie.

It’s a great line, connecting back to “standing in the wind.”

A likely interpretation seems to be a negative progression from ‘standing in the wind’ to ‘lying in the rain’; he tries, but he’s going downhill with the weather & his environment.

annotation.plain:
This song played a significant role in a first season episode of Mad Men, in which Peggy Olsen tries to convince Pete Campbell to twist with her. Creator Matthew Weiner explains how he weaved the song into the episode:

Most of the office leaves work early and heads over to P.J. Clarke’s, a long-running Manhattan bar, to drink and dance. Everyone goes wild when Chubby Checker’s new hit song, which was released in the summer of 1960, pops up on the jukebox. Everyone but Pete. Glum and pouty, he rejects Peggy’s awkward Twist come-on with a withering, “I don’t like you this way.” Peggy, who moments before had been celebrating the fact that her copy was successfully used in a client pitch, is brought back down to earth.

annotation.plain:
The massive success of this dance is partly due to it’s simplicity. Chubby once described it:

like putting out a cigarette with both feet and coming out of a shower and wiping your bottom with a towel to the beat

The dance poses no challenges to coordination and requires a minimal amount of athleticism. Consequently people of all ages could easily groove to the twist.

annotation.plain: “It’s a small world” is a figure of speech used to denote surprise regarding interpersonal knowledge between two or more people, when considering the likelihood that both parties would know something or someone simultaneously. Rae Sremmurd have blown up to the point that multiple women are vying for their attention.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Came in with two girls, look like strippers in their real clothes

annotation.plain: Gucci’s gift of narrative is embodied in this verse, which is bookended by announcing his entrance to and exit from the club. In typical Wizop fashion, he shows up with women dressed provocatively and sexily enough to rival the club’s professional dancers.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
New day, new money to be made
 There is nothin’ to explain

annotation.plain:
A reinterpretation of the commonly used phrase: “another day another dollar.”

Rae Sremmurd’s salary is about $360,000 a year, breaking down to roughly one thousand dollars every day, or $500 for each of the two members if the salary is split evenly. The duo also charges roughly $30,000 per show.

It is unclear what the original Beatles made in their prime, but this Forbes article states that they made 71 million dollars in 2016… sort of.

http://www.forbes.com/sites/zackomalleygreenburg/2013/10/23/how-the-beatles-earned-71-million-this-year-sort-of/

annotations.lyric_fragment: Pint of lean, pound of weed, and a kilo

annotation.plain:
Promethazine with codeine, most commonly referred to as Lean, is a popular drink amongst some hip-hop artists. The drink was first originated in Houston, TX, and was later introduced by DJ Screw, one of the most well known and well respected hip-hop artists during his time. He fatally overdosed on the drug in the fall of 2000.



A kilo is short for a kilogram, and often used in when referring to drugs like cocaine and marijuana.

annotations.lyric_fragment: That girl is a real crowd pleaser (Oh, yeah)

annotation.plain:
A “crowd pleaser” is a phrase used to describe something reliably popular—this girl is adored or desired by many.

Considering that he later says “Quick release the cash, watch it fall slowly,” it’s highly likely Swae is talking about a crowd-pleasing stripper.

This line also seems inspired by the 2008 Lil Wayne song “Dick Pleaser,” which contains the refrain: “I gotta bitch named Keisha, she a real dick pleaser.” Tyga even remade Wayne’s track years later, while Wayne’s line has its roots in the Too $hort song “Freaky Tales.”

In Nicki Minaj’s version of this song, “Black Barbies,” she flips the line to: “That boy is a real pussy pleaser.” In her world, it’s the men who do the pleasing. Nicki’s flip adds even more credence to the fact that this is an echo of Wayne’s “a real dick pleaser” line.

https://twitter.com/raesremmurd/status/805885987419279360

annotations.lyric_fragment: They lose it when the DJ drops the needle (And they lose it)

annotation.plain:
“Dropping the needle” refers to disc jockeys starting the music by dropping the needle onto a spinning record.

This line takes on a new meaning when you consider that in some of the Mannequin Challenge videos, people start moving when the beat drops.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’ve been walkin’ Central Park, singing after dark
 People think I’m crazy

annotation.plain:
When Some Girls was released in 1978, Central Park was not the gentrified, tourist attraction it is today. It was graffiti-ridden and decaying.



Stumbling around, singing at night, Mick probably would seem like one among the host of junkies that used to inhabit the park.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’ve been waiting in the hall
 Been waiting on your call

annotation.plain: This song is about Texan model Jerry Hall. Using her name in a mundane way emphasizes the narrator’s fanatic devotion. She is everywhere.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Hey, let’s go mess and fool around
 You know, like we used to”

annotation.plain: In times gone by, Mick was a promiscuous party-phile. However his desire for the woman has turned him away from the good old raucous times.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
When the phone rings
 It’s just some friends of mine that say
 ”Hey, what’s the matter, man?
 We’re goingna come around at twelve
 With some Puerto Rican girls thats just dying to meet you

annotation.plain: Groupies, it seems, desperate to bed Jagger regardless of his lust for Hall. The introduction of a moral dilemma for a man who has purportedly slept with over 4,000 women in his career!

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Produced by The Glimmer Twins]

annotation.plain:
The Glimmer Twins is the cheeky nickname Mick Jagger and Keith Richards gave to their production company. The supreme irony of this track is that the flashy disco instrumentation implies coked-up Studio 54 hedonism, but the lyrics themselves are an ode to obsessive love of one person, and refusing to partake in aforementioned hedonism because of this.



Another strange anecdote about this record, is that half of the band didn’t think it was disco, but Keith Richards begged to differ, saying:

“…‘Miss You’ was a damn good disco record; it was calculated to be one.”

 You’ve just been blotting out my mind

 No, I won’t miss you, baby, yeah

annotation.plain: He tries to fool himself saying that he won’t miss her, and at the same time steps on his own foot, because he knows that she’s the only one for him and that he will keep missing her anyway.

annotation.plain: Mick Jagger was recently seeing his future wife, Texan model Jerry Hall. She was married to Brian Ferry, and Mick to Bianca Jagger. He fell in love with Jerry and went after to seduce her for an entire year. They started an affair. They were later married. These lyrics are about him missing her the days she couldn’t escape with him.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
The cops came by to bring Earl in
 They searched the house high and low

annotation.plain: The police came to Earl’s house to arrest him for violating the restraining order and for beating up Wanda. They searched his entire house, yet they could not find Earl.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Mary Anne flew in from Atlanta

annotation.plain: With 93 million visitors to Hartsfield Jackson airport. It’s no shocker that Mary-Anne flew from Atlanta.

annotations.lyric_fragment: That Earl had to die

annotation.plain: Having exhausted all legal means, the girls realized that the only way Earl’s abusive behavior was going to stop was if he was dead. So, goodbye, Earl.

annotations.lyric_fragment: We need a break

annotation.plain: “Break” is a musical term meaning a slight pause in a song. So in this case, the lyric has two meanings: within the context of the story as an excuse to Earl for needing a picnic by the lake, and as cute nod to the listener that the song needs a musical break which happens immediately after the word “break” (drum fill + slight pause).

annotations.lyric_fragment: Then they tipped their hats

annotation.plain: A common thing done to signal goodbye.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
She put on dark glasses and long sleeved blouses
 And makeup to cover a bruise

annotation.plain: A common way to cover up abuse or mistreatment marks is to wear longer clothes and makeup.

annotations.lyric_fragment: They sell Tennessee ham

annotation.plain:
One fan theory is that “Tennessee ham” means sex, and that Wanda and Maryanne started a highway-side brothel (which also happens to sell strawberry jam). Fans citing this theory claim that it is implied in the music video (2:55) by virtue of the women slapping their behinds at that point, though frankly this is one heck of a stretch:

https://youtu.be/Gw7gNf_9njs

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Let’s go out to the lake, Earl
 We’ll pack a lunch
 And stuff you in the trunk, Earl
 Well, is that all right?
 Good, let’s go for a ride Earl

annotation.plain: Having successfully murdered Earl and hidden his body from the police’s search, the girls' next step would be to dispose of the body. In the music video, this is shown by the girls stuffing Earl’s body into the trunk of their car, driving to the lake, and throwing the body into it.

annotations.lyric_fragment: On a red-eye midnight flight

annotation.plain: A red-eye flight is an aviation term for a flight that departs late at night and usually arrives the next morning. The term “red-eye” is derived from the red, bloodshot eyes people who takes these flights tend to have from having to stay awake too long.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
But Earl walked right through that restraining order
 And put her in intensive care

annotation.plain: A restraining order is a legal order that requires a person to stay a certain distance from another person or place. In this case, Earl violated the restraining order by beating Wanda up so badly that she was admitted to the hospital.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Just say that you need me

annotation.plain: She just wanna hear that her partner needs her, even if it’s not true

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Leave me, leave me
 Just say that you need me

annotation.plain: She seems to be okay with being left, but she still wants to feel like she is needed by the person.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Leave me, leave me
 Just say that you need me

annotation.plain:
These lyrics line up perfectly with the previous lyrics: “Love me, love me, pretend that you love me”.

The narrator feels that lying to themself and getting their partner to play along is better than being single. The narrator recognises that the relationship is essentially doomed and knows deep down that it’d actually be better if they were single (“Leave me, leave me”), but they can’t get over their attachment to their partner.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I can’t care ’bout anything but you

annotation.plain: The narrator is utterly obsessed with their partner and getting them to stay in the relationship. It’s a one-sided breakup; the partner doesn’t really want to stay, but the narrator is extremely attached to their partner.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I know that you need me

annotation.plain: This is a clever swapping of roles. If anything, the narrator needs the partner, not the other way round. The narrator is in denial and trying to find signs that their partner actually does want to stay.

annotations.lyric_fragment: So I cry, and I pray, and I beg

annotation.plain: She’s pleading and imploring him to love her, the singer uses tricolon to emphasise how much she cares

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Lately I have desperately pondered
 Spent my nights awake and I wonder
 What I could have done in another way
 To make you stay

annotation.plain: She overthinks and stresses a lot about the relationship and what could’ve been done differently.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Dear, I fear we’re facing a problem
 You love me no longer, I know and
 Maybe there is nothing that I can do
 To make you do

annotation.plain:
These lyrics regained a bit of popularity due to a Billie Eilish interview in which she recites them as part of a story about a former relationship.

https://youtu.be/aOrv50LDDNY

(5:50-6:05)

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I don’t care if you really care
 As long as you don’t go

annotation.plain: She doesn’t care if the relationship isn’t the same, she doesn’t even care if he wants her in the same way; she just wants him to stay with her.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Reason will not reach a solution
 I will end up lost in confusion

annotation.plain:
The narrator of the song is thinking to herself that trying to think this out logically is probably not going to give her any good answers to the question of what she could have done to make that person stay. Because of this, anything she thinks to answer the question will just leave her even more lost and unsure than when she started.

This line of thought works with the concepts of fools falling in love and love making a person loopy in the infatuation. In this particular case, trying to reason out love for someone who isn’t there is causing this feeling of foolishness. But, as stated in the next two lines, it’s all good to her as long as the person she’s singing to doesn’t leave.
