annotation.plain:
[Español]
Está diciendo “zúmbale”, para que le tiren, le den, o le pongan “mambo” (sabor/fuego), los DJ’s, a la música para que haga a las mujeres prender sus motores (mover sus nalgas). Ya que uno, poniéndole chispa o fuego al motor, hacé que prenda.

La palabra “mambo” se usa mucho en Puerto Rico, diciendo en otros dichos, “fiesta”, pero en tambien se puede definir como “cosa” o “lugar”.

Por ejemplo:


¡Así es el mambo¡".
Quiere decir, “¡Así es [que se hace] la cosa!”.

¡Vamos al mambo!“.
Quiere decir, "¡Vamos [para allá], a el lugar!”.


Finalmente, les dice que estén listas porque el ritmo que va a caer es para que ellas empiecen duro y rápido como un carro de carreras lleno de gasolina listo para empezar.

  


[English]
He’s saying “Zúmbale mambo” (swing fire), for the DJs to put up “lit/fire” music, so that it makes the women start their engines and/or twerk their butts, for the reason that sparking fire to the engine makes it start.

The word “mambo” is used a lot in Puerto Rico, meaning in other sayings (not this line) to “party”, but it can also be defined as “thing” or “place”.

For example:


That’s how the mambo is!
It means, “That’s how you do it!”

Let’s go to the mambo!
It means, “Let’s get to it!”


In the last line, he tells them to be ready because the beat that’s going to drop is for them to start hard and fast like a racecar full of gas ready to start.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Ella prende las turbina’, no discrimina
 No se pierde ni un party de marquesina

annotation.plain:
[Español]

Siguiendo con el tema de maquinas, Daddy Yankee menciona que “enciende las turbinas” para referirse a que la chica está lista para divertirse y que no le importa el lugar (ya sea la “marquesina” o garaje) ni el tamaño de la fiesta, ella va a pasarla bien.

  


[English]

Continuing with the theme of machines, Daddy Yankee mentions that “she turns on the turbines” to say that the girl is ready to have fun and that regardless of the place or the size of the party, she will still have a good time.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
(Duro) Todos los weekenes ella sale a vacilar
 (Duro) Mi gata no para ’e janguear, porque

annotation.plain:
[Español]

Yankee habla de una mujer que le gusta mucho divertirse o “vacilar”. También menciona que es una chica o “gata” que siempre está en reuniones con amigos o “jangueando”, que deriva del ingés “hanging out”.

  


[English]

Yankee talks about a woman who likes to have fun. He also mentions that she is a girl that is always hanging out with friends. The term “janguear” comes from the English phrase “to hang out” or “hanging out”.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Janguea en carros, motoras y limusinas
 Llena su tanque de adrenalina
 Cuando escucha reggaetón en las bocina’

annotation.plain:
[Español]

Estas líneas comparan la necesidad de gasolina de un coche a la adrenalina que siente la chica al escuchar reggaetón. Cuando ella está jangueando en los coches que están poniendo la música de reggaetón a todo volumen, ella se siente energizada.

  


[English]

This lines compares the necessity of a car needing gasoline to the adrenaline that the girl gets from listening to reggaetón. By partying and hanging out in these cars that blast reggaetón music, she becomes energized.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Coro: Daddy Yankee & Glory]

annotation.plain:
[Español]

En el coro, Daddy Yankee usa la estructura “llamada y respuesta” de la década de 1970 que ha sido parte clave de muchos estilos musicales con raíces africanos, afrocubanos, y afrocaribeños. Se puede oír esta estructura en la salsa y otros estilos musicales de Puerto Rico, Cuba, y muchos de los países latinoamericanos.

En una entrevista, Daddy Yankee menciona que la canción se hizo famosa a causa de las varias interpretaciones del significado del coro y de la canción.

  


[English]

In the chorus, Daddy Yankee uses the “call and response” structure from the 1970s, which has been a key part of many musical styles with African, Afro-Cuban, and Afro-Carribean roots. One can hear this structure in salsa and other musical styles from Puerto Rico, Cuba, and many other Latin American countries.

In an interview Daddy Yankee mentioned that a part of the fame this track gained was caused by the fact, that people found various interpretations for what the chorus and the song in general is about:

https://youtu.be/QPOWVoFDb2U?t=49s La entrevista mencionadaThe mentioned interview

annotation.plain:
[Español]

La expresión “le gusta la gasolina”, muy conocida en Puerto Rico, se puede traducir como “a ella le gusta salir y pasarla bien”. Daddy Yankee está hablando sobre las chicas que les gusta bailar, ir a las fiestas, o la vida nocturna.

  


[English]

“She likes gasoline” is a well known Puerto Rican expression that means “she likes to go out and have a good time”. Daddy Yankee is talking about girls that like to dance, go to parties, and enjoy nightlife.

Glory’s adlibs translate to “give me more gasoline.”

annotation.plain: This is a sample of a Kurtis Blow drum sample song called “Super Sperm” from the 1985 album America.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Three-piece suit

annotation.plain:
Three-pieces suits (a jacket, matching trousers, and a waistcoat) are a long standing symbol of wealth because they are even more expensive than the more-common two piece models. Funnily enough: at the time this line is recited, the music video for this song shows a man on screen in a two-piece suit.



A proper three piece suit would look like this:

annotations.lyric_fragment: I’m not shy, so I asked for the digits

annotation.plain: Pepa isn’t reserved, so she is comfortable asking for the phone number (digits) of the person she’s interested in.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I love you in your big jeans, you give me nice dreams

annotation.plain:
The use of the words jeans, dreams, and scream is a great example of using interior rhymes. This song by Salt-N-Pepa has many examples of interior rhyme. Another example within this song would be in verse 2 when Salt raps, “Um, you’re packed and you’re stacked ‘specially in the back
Brother, wanna thank your mother for a butt like that.” This creates a truly catchy song that makes the lyrics easy to learn.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Getcha, getcha lips wet cause it’s time to have Pep

annotation.plain: This line is an example of something Hip Hop skeptics could say is completely inappropriate. Although, if you switch the perspective of women expressing sexuality from unbecoming, disgusting to progressive and natural, the song can take on a much more positive message. Female rappers of present day fight the same sexist critiques. Cardi B and Megan Thee Stallion came out with the song “WAP” in 2020 and were met with criticism from those who felt threatened by a raw voicing of a woman’s sexual experience.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Shoop

annotation.plain: The word “shoop” means to have sex. Before this song was created shoop was not a word. This is an example of neologism. Like traditional poetry the poet holds the power, and exercises that power by creating words and/or altering meanings to words already used. I think it is important to point out how the music backing the rhymes is “shoop” repeated over and over.

Everybody goes, “What does shoop mean?” And I say, “Shoop is whatever you wanna do. I just wanna shoop, baby!”

annotations.lyric_fragment: Committed a crime and went inside

annotation.plain: “went inside” i.e., did jail time for the aforementioned crime.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Put a girl on the corner so you can make a pile

annotation.plain: This is where the would-be gigolo tries to make the transition to “pimp”. Many pimp-hooker relationships start out as “sugar mama-gigolo” relationships, and once the gigolo tries to “turn her out” i.e., make her “trick”, that’s when the pimp-hooker relationship starts. In this way, a lot of women who had no ambition of ever sleeping around for money get turned, because the gigolo (ie “for love” exploitation) is easily converted into the pimp (ie “for money”) relationship. Nenah is saying a hearty “fuck no” to either proposition.

annotation.plain:
The flipside of the 1986 Morgan-McVey single “Looking Good Diving” is the origin of “Buffalo Stance”. On it, Neneh Cherry rapped on the b-side “Looking Good Diving With The Wild Bunch”, which later became “Buffalo Stance”.

“Looking Good Diving” has the line “Looking good diving for your love” in its chorus.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Bomb the Bass, rock this place!

annotation.plain: Another homage to Tim “Bomb the Bass” Simenon

annotations.lyric_fragment: Looking good, hang in with the Wild Bunch

annotation.plain:
“Looking Good Diving with the Wild Bunch” was an early version of “Buffalo Stance”. It was the B-side on the 1986 single “Looking Good Diving” by duo Morgan-McVey, which was made up of Jamie Morgan and Cherry’s future husband,Cameron McVey. Neneh Cherry also appears in the video of the song, playing guitar (with Naomi Campbell, also of the Buffalo Posse, on keyboards.)
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vKJH_cbFm_0

The Wild Bunch was a sound system based in the St Paul’s district of Bristol, England from 1983 to 1986. They were a key member of what became the Bristol underground scene. It included several notable British DJs and performers, such as:

• Robert Del Naja, Grant Marshall, Tricky and Andrew Vowles, of Massive Attack.

• Nellee Hooper, who moved to London after the group’s dissolution and worked as a producer and remixer for a number of major artists, including Madonna,U2, No Doubt, Björk and others. He was also a member of Soul II Soul.

annotations.lyric_fragment: We always hang in a buffalo stance

annotation.plain:
A Buffalo Stance is one in which one stands with their arms tightly crossed looking over to side at somebody. It was popularized by Bruce Smith of the Buffalo Bills in the late 1980’s.



The Buffalo Posse was supposed to be a group of photographers, models, musicians, hair and makeup artists, etc. formed by fashion stylist Ray Petri of whom Cherry, Morgan and McVey were all members.

Petri once explained:

People tend to associate the word Buffalo with Bob Marley’s Buffalo Soldier, but in fact it’s a Caribbean expression to describe people who are rude boys or rebels. Not necessarily tough, but hard style taken from the street … a functional and stylish look; non-fashion with a hard attitude.

Neneh Cherry told the New York Times in 2007:

The song is about our gang, our time and our mentor, Ray, who is still behind every word and every melody “Buffalo meant classic. None of us were into here-today-gone-tomorrow fashion, which is why we gravitated toward each other. Ray was always consistent, and he taught us that we shouldn’t be afraid to be honest.

The song’s name is also a reference to Malcolm McLaren’s 1983 song “Buffalo Gals”, which is sampled.

annotation.plain:
On top of the running man is the flying man, baby baby
I’m a man who knows a thing or two
On top of the running man is the flying man, baby baby
I’m a man who knows a thing or two

This is an adapted Korean proverb – “There is a flying man over the running man”. No matter how good a guy you are, there will always be someone who’s better. Psy is that guy.

Also possibly a reference to the hugely popular Korean show called Running Man, whose host is featured in the video (the guy with the yellow suit and red benz, Yoo Jae-suk). Psy’s been on an associated show previously (Infinite Challenge) and is probably gonna show up on RM any day now.

annotations.lyric_fragment: 강남 스타일

annotation.plain:
Gangnam Style

Gangnam:



 by far the most affluent neighborhood in South Korea is important because it demonstrates the lifestyle that men want to give to women and think they need in order to have a “sexy lady”. Gangnam is similar to Manhattan



or Beverly Hills



This desire for a wealthy lifestyle places and emphasis on what society deems as importance and how your city and zip code play and even more important role on how you are perceived by others.

annotations.lyric_fragment: 커피 식기도 전에 원샷 때리는 사나이

annotation.plain:
A guy who one-shots his coffee before it even cools down

It’s a combination of two ideas:


Psy is a busy, in-demand guy, who doesn’t even have time to let his coffee cool down before he drinks it
American-style “coffee shops” like Starbucks are considered trendy in South Korea. Coffee is incredibly expensive; around six or seven dollars a cup. So to down it in a single shot implies that he doesn’t even care. It’s the quintessence of Veblen’s theory of conspicuous consumption.

annotation.plain:
Oppa is Gangnam style, Gangnam style
Oppa is Gangnam style, Gangnam style
Oppa is Gangnam style

The word “Oppa” means “big brother” in Korean, which is seen more as a term of endearment for a girlfriend to call her boyfriend, unlike America where this would have awkward incestuous connotations. However the idea of marrying a man just like your father is a common Western wedding  myth. “Oppa” has also been translated as the Korean version of the word cougar in America, only for males.

Another explanation for Gangnam style would be to put it in American terms. Gangnam is like the Beverly Hills of Seoul, South Korea, so to be living Gagnam style means you are making mad cash and living large.

As stated in the first explanation (see the first chorus), Gangnam Style refers not just to having wealth, but also being primp, proper, and professional during the day while getting crazy at night.

People from the Gangnam area of Seoul or who live its lifestyle are often perceived as materialistic since they are so rich, and they often flaunt what they have.

Gangnam Style in Psy’s own words:

http://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2012/08/gangnam-style-dissected-the-subversive-message-within-south-koreas-music-video-sensation/261462/

annotation.plain:
A girl who is warm and humane during the day
A classy girl who knows how to enjoy the freedom of a cup of coffee
A girl whose heart gets hotter when night comes
A girl with that kind of twist

Psy is not just talking about women he is attracted to, but the qualities that describe women from Gangnam. And consequently, the younger generation of Koreans he views to be increasingly materialistic.

“Cup of coffee” refers to the incredible price of coffee in Gangnam–drinking it is seen as a status symbol. Young people of Gangnam are known to forego lunch to buy expensive coffee to appear more wealthy, and then go out at night to clubs. Materialistic, indeed.

annotations.lyric_fragment: 오빤 강남 스타일

annotation.plain:
Oppan Gangnam Style

“Oppa” is the term for older brother used by females only. Males would call older brothers (or older brother-like figures) “hyung.” “Oppa” is also what a girlfriend will call her boyfriend when they become close–it has a connotation of being able to provide. It is typically used by younger Koreans, and sometimes said by women to men as a means to flirt, similar to women in America calling men they are flirting with “Daddy” or “Papi”. Therefore, Psy is saying in third person he is boyfriend material, or an attractive guy. Gangnam is a wealthy district in Seoul, where the young people are known to be very prim, proper, and professional during the day, but get crazy at night.

“Gangnam Style” connotes not just wealth, but the aforementioned lifestyle. “Oppa” means big brother, or a brother-like endearment, in Korean. Gangnam is a wealthy district of Seoul where people come out at night. Basically, Psy says he wants to get a girl who is like Gangnam style, and he is explaining what type of guy he is.

annotation.plain:
This is a reference to a quote near the end of The Color Purple (1985), a movie that shares many similar themes as this song.



The quote goes, “the more things change, the more they stay the same.”

annotations.lyric_fragment: Tell me your favorite song

annotation.plain: When I was a kid, I loved this Mariah Carey song called “Vision of Love.” And I used to sort of sing that in the mirror with the hairbrush and just be like, “She’s amazing.” My dad had just gotten a CD player so it’s like early ‘90s and I had to put it on repeat and that’s me for like an hour, just listening to that one song.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You go ahead, let your hair down

annotation.plain:
I’ve had a few experiences of wearing my hair out and natural for the first time. I used to just tie it back and have it permed and then I’ve had relaxed super straight, probably short and straight hair.

I remember when I first started wearing it out and feeling self conscious and people were making fun of me as well because it’s so different, and living in England, it was against what was considered to be a nice way to have your hair.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Girl, put your records on

annotation.plain: I found that as a young person, music was a really amazing way to find confidence and to find self expression. You could always find that song that’s like, “That’s just me. That person knows exactly how I feel.” Certain pop songs. I feel like I just put on music and feel like invincible and super confident and bold and let the music sort of carry you. To me, that’s what my favorite song is doing. It would turn me from being someone that was shy or self conscious or uncomfortable into a feeling really sort of bold and confident while that song is on, you kind of live in the song.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Maybe sometimes, we’ve got it wrong, but it’s all right

annotation.plain: You are afraid, you are overwhelmed but that’s a natural thing to be and sometimes it’s like just do it anyways. I sometimes think that. We really are affected by emotions. You can do things and still be afraid of doing them and that’s kind of how you grow and how you develop. I love the idea of becoming bolder and more confident. I definitely recognize that in this song.

annotations.lyric_fragment:

annotation.plain:
A lot of the song focuses on being able to embrace inner beauty and being able to be yourself. These lines show that even with positivity, some days make it harder to accept yourself.

Most of the lines in the song show positive and encouraging thoughts but these lines show vulnerability and a hint of sadness.

Cinnamon grows there and they even have the so called “Mount Cinnamon Resort”.

annotations.lyric_fragment: (Know what I’m sayin’?)

annotation.plain:
Probably the funniest part of the song to me. The whole of the lyricism is full of double meaning, non-clarity, or straight-up nonsense. Some of it is in Spanish, and some of it in German.

And at the end of it all, he asks the question, “Know what I’m sayin'?”, knowing full well the irony of this statement: we don’t.

We have absolutely no clue what he’s saying. And the real beauty lies in the fact that, at the end of the day, neither does the artist.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Baby’s in Reno with the vitamin D

annotation.plain:
Probably referring to his girlfriend who is Reno, NV soaking up the sun while he is in cold New York

1) Beck moved from NY to LA a couple years before he wrote “Loser”
2) Vitamin D has nothing to do with LSD: http://www.ehealthme.com/ds/vitamin+d/lsd+abuse
3) The human body creates Vitamin D when exposed to lots of sunlight.  http://www.vitamindcouncil.org/about-vitamin-d/how-do-i-get-the-vitamin-d-my-body-needs/
4) Reno is famous for two things – being sunny, and being the “loser” town in Nevada, compared to the more fashionable Las Vegas.

Referencing early 90s LA rap, as in drive-by shootings…



…and body piercing, which wasn’t really a big thing until the ‘90s.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I’m a loser, baby, so why don’t you kill me?

annotation.plain:
According to Beck, this hook was a frustrated line sung in a stream-of-conciousness during an outtake recording:

“Beck wrote some lyrics on the spot and got on the mic trying to deliver a Chuck D-style rap. "When they played it back, I was like, ‘I’m the worst rapper!’ So when I did the chorus I was just putting myself down.” Meaning the put-down currently being appropriated for an already put-upon generation — “I’m a loser, baby, so why don’t you kill me?” — is actually just Beck’s critique of his own Chuck D imitation.

annotation.plain: Here, he’s making a prayer, more or less, to the world. He needs help. He needs something to change.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Verse 1]

annotation.plain: As with many of the songs on the Born in the USA album, this song could be interpreted as an anthem of the common man.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I ain’t nothing but tired
 Man, I’m just tired and bored with myself

annotation.plain: This song was written when his manager told him he needed a hit in his album, it made him so angry that he went home and wrote it all that night. He is explaining how bored and lonely he is from sitting inside and writing songs all of the time and hasn’t been able to go out and have fun. This line is explaining how tired and bored he is from writing songs and asking for help to get out of his own head and go out and have fun.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’m sick of sitting around here trying to write this book
 I need a love reaction
 Come on now, baby, give me just one look

annotation.plain:
He’s tired of sitting around trying to force something onto the page, as writers are often told to just put something down and let the rest flow out. He needs something to give him a spark of inspiration and her look could be the spark he needs to get the lyrics or words on the page.

He’s trying different ideas for the song, but he needs a click with one of those ideas, a melody or lyric he falls in love with and that propells the creative process forward.

annotations.lyric_fragment:

annotation.plain: If he maintains his life without any change, he’ll miss out on all the beautiful things in life, because he knows there’s a lot of things in the world going on that’s important and beautiful. He’s dying for some of that life. He lives a boring, miserable life right now and he wants to change that badly.

annotations.lyric_fragment:

 Hey, baby, I’m just about starving tonight
 I’m dying for some action

annotation.plain: That advice people always give to other people about in order to be successful, you need to be driven and passionate about what you’re doing. He said if that’s true, then he’s starving, meaning he’s driven to do whatever it is to change his crumby life around.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Even if we’re just dancing in the dark
 Even if we’re just dancing in the dark
 Even if we’re just dancing in the dark

annotation.plain: Dancing in the dark could imply a sexual encounter. However, it also illustrates the relationship of risk and reward. It is only by taking a shot in the unknown that one gets closer to earning that reward by overcoming the risks of rejection and failure.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You can’t start a fire
 Sitting ’round crying over a broken heart

annotation.plain:
Even if you’re nowhere (living in a dump or a rut), you can’t start something amazing or achieve success without leaving the baggage behind (bitter feelings, nostalgia, pain …etc.).

Instead of letting his frustration take the best of him, Bruce took the initiative by writing a song even if it felt like a shot at the dark. It turned out to be a damn good one.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You can’t start a fire
 You can’t start a fire without a spark

annotation.plain:
Without inspiration (a spark) you can’t achieve something amazing (a fire)…

Under pressure to write a hit for an upcoming album (Born in the USA), Springsteen is explaining how one cannot simply churn out a hit/ blockbuster song and inspiration is needed to create something truly special.

Ironically, an inspiration for this song was Springsteen’s frustration and that resulted in the song being a massive hit.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Stay on the streets of this town
 And they’ll be carving you up all right

annotation.plain:
In keeping with the theme of moving on and the stagnation resulting from staying in the same place, Springsteen worries that an inability to escape the people around him would result in their influence affecting him negatively. He’s worried about the people around him forcing their ideals/morals (the way that they think life should be lived) on him so much that they ‘carve’ or ‘mold’ him the way that they want him to be.

Another interpretation is this line is referencing something a bit more aggressive than molding, shaping, or artistically “carving” someone. The lines that follow (“gotta stay hungry” and “starving tonight”) seem to imply that if he stays on those familiar streets, they’ll pick him apart/eat him alive as one would carve up a piece of meat or turkey before consuming it. So it’s more of him getting chewed up and spit out or used up by those streets.

annotations.lyric_fragment:

 She’s always on my mind (Runnin’ away with me)

annotation.plain:
As the song fades, Eddie Kendricks sneaks a reference to the closing lines of Marvin Gaye’s 1969 hit “Too Busy Thinking About My Baby”, itself about being lost in imagination over a girl:

Yeah, she’s never hard to find
‘Cause she’s always on my mind

Ironically, the Temptations recorded the first version of “Too Busy Thinking About My Baby” in 1965. The lead singer on that recording? Eddie Kendricks.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Ev’ry night on my knees I pray

annotation.plain:
This line marks baritone Paul Williams' last lead appearance on a Temptations song.



The original lead singer and choreographer of the Temptations, by the end of the 1960s his health had begun to fail as he succumbed to alcoholism and sickle-cell anemia. Despite leaving the group with Eddie Kendricks, Paul remained on the Temptations' bankroll as an adviser and choreographer, and it was understood that he would return once his health improved.

Tragically, on August 17, 1973, two years after leaving the group, Paul was found dead from an apparent suicide. He was 34. One of his last public appearances was as a surprise guest at Eddie Kendricks' Club Kapana residency in 1972, singing none other than “Just My Imagination”. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5JxL3Bbwg9I

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Each day through my window I watch her as she passes by
 I say to myself, “You’re such a lucky guy”
 To have a girl like her is truly a dream come true
 Out of all the fellows in the world, she belongs to you

annotation.plain: Norman Whitfield took over as the Temptations primary producer after winning a bet against Smokey Robinson in 1966. Whitfield and co-writer Barrett Strong clearly learned a trick or two from their Motown colleague, though, as the bait-and-switch lyric is classic Smokey. Here, the first verse implies that the singer has landed the girl of his dreams, but as the chorus makes clear, the relationship is all in his head. Though he sees his dream girl walk by his window every day, he’s never actually met her.

annotation.plain: As he imagines this relationship, he’s still aware that it’s all fiction. Despite this realization, his imagination continues to take over and he proceeds to get carried away.

annotation.plain:
Daryl Hall shared with the BBC:

I like that sort of contrapuntal background vocal. It’s a trade-off, back-and-forth, and that’s sort of a trademark of mine. Listen to “No Can Do”, and it’s the same thing. The backgrounds are working in rhythm against the lead.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You make my dreams come true

annotation.plain:
Daryl Hall told the BBC:

The first words that came out of my mouth were: “You make my dreams come true.” I thought: “This is no good. This is such a cliché. I’ve got to think of something a little more provocative.” But after a while, I just went with it.

annotation.plain:
Robert Smith has claimed that this song is about his wife, Mary Poole, the lyrics “I
promise that I’ll run away with you” means how a night like he experienced with her is worth so
much that he is willing to risk it all and just run away with her. This song is about his crazy love
life with Mary, he told a source, “It’s about hyperventilating – kissing and fainting on the floor.”
It looks like his girlfriend at the time tells him exactly how she feels, but he does not tell her how
he feels and instead thinks of all the amazingly crazy ways he loves her. She thinks that he
doesn’t love her, but he does so much that he chokes up and just cannot put it into words.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I

annotation.plain:
“Why are you so far away?, she said
Why won’t you ever know that I’m in love with you?”

This part of the song gives me the vibes she feels he is more emotionally distant from her and he’s just so in love with her that he doesn’t see the struggles that she’s having internally. But she feels like she can’t tell him because he won’t think of her the same way and their love might fade.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I

annotation.plain:
“Alone above a raging sea
That stole the only girl I love
And drowned her deep inside of me”

I’d say that these are probably my favorite lyrics in the song because it really shows just how much he cares about her. And how he feels so alone now that she’s gone and no one can fill that empty space she left.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You’re just like a dream
 You’re just like a dream

annotation.plain:
“You’re Just Like a Dream”

To me, this line describes how the girl he’s signing about it so perfect that she seems like she can only be in his dreams. But the longer the song goes on, he starts to realize that she actually is only in his dreams and that she’s not real. I feel like this could maybe show how he’s lost people in the past and describes how no one else can ever live up to the way that he loved her.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You, strange as angels
 Dancing in the deepest oceans
 Twisting in the water

annotation.plain: This relates to the overall theme of the song where Smith is on a cliff. He can see the sea below him and perhaps the swell of the waves looks like angels dancing under there. It could also be an allusion to where the girl he was kissing earlier had gone, perhaps she had fallen off the cliff and drowned “twisting in the water”.

annotations.lyric_fragment: ”Show me, show me, show me how you do that trick

annotation.plain:
According to The Guardian:

Smith has claimed that the first verse is rooted in boyhood memories of practicing magic.

The thrill of Smith amazing his friends with magic tricks is similarly reflected when he is with the song’s central figure, Mary. Smith later told Blender in 2003:

on another [level], it’s about a seduction trick, from much later in my life. It was something that happened on Beachy Head, on the south coast of England. The song is about hyperventilating – kissing and fainting to the floor. Mary dances with me in the video because she was the girl, so it had to be her. The idea is that one night like that is worth 1,000 hours of drudgery.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And found myself alone, alone
 Alone above a raging sea

annotation.plain:
Robert Smith was inspired to write “Just Like Heaven” after his friends abandoned him near the cliffs above the sea at Beachy Head in East Sussex:

Actually, “Just Like Heaven” is about a night I spent there. We’d been drinking and someone thought it would be cool to go for a walk. But suddenly the fog came in and I lost sight of my friends and could not see a hand before my eyes. I thought I might fall down the cliff if I moved another foot so I had to sit down until dawn. Later I heard my friends didn’t even look for me … The bastards! Their explanation: ‘ah it was nearly 5am and we thought it’ll be light soon.’

annotations.lyric_fragment: Daylight licked me into shape

annotation.plain: Daylight is often in literature a metaphor for a kind of philosophical enlightenment, or general truth (as in the Bible) and serves this purpose here. Awoken from the ‘dream’ of falling in love he now realises, remembers, the detachment he will always feel from another human, and how it limits the love between them.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Verse 1]

annotation.plain:
Robert Smith didn’t purposely borrow the song structure of The Only One’s “Another Girl, Another Planet”, but he notes a strong similarity between them:

Although I didn’t realize it at the time, the structure is very similar to ‘Another Girl, Another Planet,’ by The Only Ones, which I can still vividly remember hearing on the radio late at night in the mid-‘70s.

 If he loves me

 (Hey) If he loves me
 If he loves me not

annotation.plain:
This is a reference to the common practice of young children picking up a flower and picking away its petals as they say, “s/he loves me, s/he loves me not”. Whichever it lands on at the final petal tells them whether their crush truly loves them.

Whitney is waiting with bated breath for the metaphorical final petal, which would be him admitting that he loves her, though she doesn’t truly intend to use the petal-picking technique.

annotation.plain: His gaze at her is so potent, so powerful that it takes her to the metaphorical clouds above. Whitney is likely referencing the phrase ‘on cloud 9’ or ‘walking on clouds’, meaning bliss.

You’re lickin’ your lips and blowin’ kisses my way
 But that don’t mean I’m gonna give it away
 Baby, baby, baby (Baby, baby, baby)

annotation.plain:
Christina’s target of affection expects too much from her, thinking that a simple approach will lead to romantic sparks. But just because he’s flirting with her doesn’t mean that she’ll have sex with him.

That said, if he listens to her and do what he’s told, she’ll entertain the possibility, albeit hesitantly.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
If you wanna be with me
 Baby, there’s a price to pay
 I’m a genie in a bottle (In a bottle, baby)
 You gotta rub me the right way (Yeah)
 If you wanna be with me
 I can make your wish come true

annotation.plain:
A genie, or as it was originally written, “Jinnī”, is a character from Arabian mythology. Although they were seen as ugly and evil creatures in Muslim and Arabian folklore, in western culture they are perceived very differently. This is partly due to the jovial portrayal of a genie in the Disney movie Aladdin, who grants the main character three wishes after the bottle in which he was trapped was rubbed.



Christina’s use of the phrase “rub me the right way”  however, takes on a different context, as it is a reference to sexual stimulation. In this case, the guy’s “wish” is also most likely referring to sex.

annotation.plain: Having fallen head over heels in love, Charli compares the pounding of her heart—known as the body’s most romantic organ—to the sound of a never-ending drumbeat. The “boom” likely represents a kick drum, while the “clap” is the snare. In hip-hop, the term “boom bap” is used to describe a ‘90s-era sound featuring especially thudding kicks and crackling snares.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You’re picture-perfect blue

annotation.plain:
Charli has synaesthesia, meaning she associates people, places, and music with colors. In 2013, she gave away the chart-topping “I Love It” to Icona Pop because it “was the wrong color.” She told BBC:

I see music in colours. I love music that’s black, pink, purple or red – but I hate music that’s green, yellow or brown.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I’ll be backstage after the show

annotation.plain:
After show back stage meetings are commonly attributed to groupies.
A groupie is a fan who has sex with a celebrity. While you are still rolling the dice, you can get lucky if you have a VIP, or Backstage pass. Avril is saying that after the show, she will be having sex with the skater boy.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Sorry, girl, but you missed out
 Well, tough luck, that boy’s mine now
 We are more than just good friends
 This is how the story ends

annotation.plain:
This was a “major plot twist” moment back in the 2000s, as it was more common for singers to sing about themselves in the third person. Avril manages to deliver two thirds of the song under the radar as a song about herself.

This line pulls back the curtain and reveals that the whole time, she was one of the protagonist’s friends providing peer pressure.

Because of the girl’s shy nature, and the peer pressure from her friends, Avril was able to swoop in and take the boy for herself.

Avril opens up the song by strongly introducing, and implying the love between her two main characters.

One of the most iconic lines from this song, it has often been parodied and interpolated. More recently, the line has received criticism for being heteronormative in its assumption of relationship from nothing but the characters' opposite sexes.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
(Do you believe like I believe?) Do you believe in magic?
 (Do you believe like I believe?) Do you believe, believer?
 (Do you believe like I believe?) Do you believe in magic?
 (Do you believe like I believe?) Do you believe in magic?

annotation.plain: The second part of the Coda repeatedly challenges the listener to ‘believe like I believe’. To become a ‘believer’, one who follows the power of music and believes that it can transform, inspire, and uplift.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Yeah, do you believe in magic? yeah
 Believe in the magic of the young girl’s soul
 Believe in the magic of-a rock ‘n’ roll
 Believe in the magic that can set you free
 Oh, talkin’ ’bout the magic

annotation.plain:
The first half of the coda touches on the three main points that Sebastian has communicated in the three verses. The ‘young girl’s soul’, ‘rock and roll’, and ‘the magic that can set you free’ refer to music as an instrument of identity, a cultural movement, and expression respectively. The message effectively parallels the light, happy, and upbeat tone of the song, emphasized by the fast tempo and the lack of discordant sound. The unique sound was created through the layering of guitar as well as the use of Sebastian’s auto-harp, an instrument that was also used extensively by Janis Joplin.



The message of the song has been one that has persisted throughout modern culture. Not only through recognition from magazines such as Rolling Stone, but also has been covered and featured in TV shows, movies, and commercials on numerous occasions.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
We’ll dance until mornin’ ’til there’s just you and me
 And maybe, if the music is right
 I’ll meet you tomorrow, sort of late at night
 And we’ll go dancin’, baby, then you’ll see
 How the magic’s in the music and the music’s in me

annotation.plain: The speaker continues to reference the power of music not only for the purpose of finding happiness and freedom, but now also to be a part of love.

annotations.lyric_fragment: How you got there so just blow your mind

annotation.plain:
The meaning of these two lines can be very dependent on how one views 60s rock culture. In a literal sense, the lines evoke the idea of experiencing music as a journey that ‘blow[s] your mind’. One reading of this is that music is the ethereal force that is meant to be experienced communally and that Sebastian is inviting the listener to join him on the journey.

Similarly these lines have parallels in many of the messages of Psychedelic Rock in the 60s. While by no means would ‘Do You Believe in Magic?’ be classified as psychedelic, the themes of music being a mystical force that frees people can be found in many examples of psychedelic rock.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Just go and listen, and it’ll start with a smile
 That won’t wipe off your face no matter how hard you try
 Your feet start tappin’, and you can’t seem to find

annotation.plain:
Sebastian is referencing the infectious quality music can have on listeners. The final couplet of the verse ‘Your feet start tapping…’ also nicely introduces the short instrumental guitar break inviting listeners to start dancing if they weren’t already.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lPj3SJcx0Wc

annotations.lyric_fragment:
If you believe in magic don’t bother to choose
 If it’s jug band music or rhythm and blues

annotation.plain:
Sebastian is encouraging people to not discriminate when listening to music. The two styles referenced in particular, ‘jug band’ and ‘rhythm and blues’, featured heavily in Sebastian’s and The Lovin' Spoonfuls own artistic roots.



Before forming the Lovin' Spoonfuls, John Sebastian was a part of the New York Based Even Dozen Jug Band in the late 1950s.  Furthermore, rhythm and blues served as the basis for almost all 1960s rock music. The 12-bar blues form was ubiquitous throughout the 60s and became many songwriters go-to form. Finally, Sebastian himself, in the 2007 DVD entitled The Lovin' Spoonful: Do you believe in magic?, that the intro to the song was inspired by the chord progression from Martha and the Vandellas' “(Love Is Like a) Heat Wave”, a popular mo-town song in the early 60s.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’ll tell you about the magic, and it’ll free your soul
 But it’s like tryin’ tell a stranger ‘bout-a rock ’n’ roll

annotation.plain:
The last couplet of the first verse addresses the second meaning of the song. Not only does the magic of music bring happiness and joy, but also it brings freedom and expression. Here Sebastian could be referencing the cultural changes that were occurring in the 1960s. By 1965, several protests were occurring throughout the United States. These protests were mostly made up of America’s youth and had a strong connection to music. One of the most notable examples being the https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_Speech_Movement.

The last line of verse 1 directly references the conflicts between movements that were closely tied to rock and roll and conservative authority figures.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And it’s magic if the music is groovy
 It makes you feel happy like an old-time movie

annotation.plain:
Sebastian creates an interesting parallel between the contemporary, a 1960s slang word ‘groovy’, and the traditional, ‘old-time movie’. This implies that magic of music can transcend generations if it has the right vibe.

Interestingly the history behind the slang word ‘Groovy’ parallels this comparison. The word arose in 1920s Jazz culture and eventually became adopted by the youth in the 1960s.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Do you believe in magic in a young girl’s heart
 How the music can free her whenever it starts?

annotation.plain: After a brief intro, Sebastian introduces the listener right away to the central theme of the track. The power of music and how it can bring forth happiness. It is important to note that the ‘magic’ is ‘in…[the] heart’. This implies that the power of music is something inherent in individuals, and not reliant on one’s ability to create or produce music.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You was at the farmer’s market with your perfect peach

annotation.plain:
Peach emoji in texts is often referring to butt in a sexual manner. Sometimes women are profanely called “a piece of ass” which is widely popular in rap and hip-hop culture.

Here SZA uses a play on the words, peach – ass, to talk about her ex’s new girlfriend. Him taking his new girl to the farmer’s market might be implying a different, domestic level of intimacy. “Perfect peach” – perfect butt, a perfect girl in general, underlines SZA’s unspoken jealousy.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I’m so mature, I got me a therapist to tell me there’s other men

annotation.plain:
In SZA’s 2017 hit single, “Drew Barrymore,” she mentions the idea of going to therapy to overcome her self esteem.

I get so lonely, I forget what I’m worth
We get so lonely, we pretend that this works
I’m so ashamed of myself, think I need therapy

Now, in “Kill Bill,” she shows growth getting a therapist to overcome her past relationship with her ex, but it doesn’t seem to work out yet, since she wants to kill him and his new girlfriend too.

Both songs are also inspired by 90s and 2000s movies such as Never Been Kissed, Poison Ivy and, of course, Kill Bill.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I did it all for love (Love)
 I did it all on no drugs (Drugs)
 I did all of this sober
 I did it all for us, oh
 I did it all for love (Love)
 I did all of this on no drugs (Drugs)
 I did all of this sober
 Don’t you know I did it all for us? (I’m gon’ kill your ass tonight)

annotation.plain:
SZA acknowledges that her intentions are homicidal, premeditated, and bafflingly driven by a deep love and devotion. She also seems to be admitting to first-degree murder without hesitation, while insisting that she wasn’t under the influence of drugs or alcohol to make herself sound more credible, but her infatuation with an ex is much stronger.

In a masterful reversal of the murder theme, she uses these phrases to make a connection with the criminal procedures necessary to ascertain whether a person was “in their right mind during murder,” a frequent Interrogatory form used to gauge responsibility and degree of negligence. The questions are modeled after the kinds of inquiries a judge may put to a murder suspect in order to rule out the likelihood of murder.

According to this view, SZA may be drawing comparisons to Bill, who had a relationship with Beatrix but later found out after their split that she was pregnant with his child and had married another man. Bill then became so enraged and jealous that he killed the man, who was merely a victim of Bill’s immense jealousy.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’m still a fan even though I was salty
 Hate to see you with some other broad, know you happy
 Hate to see you happy if I’m not the one drivin’

annotation.plain:
SZA likens herself to Bill from the 2003-2004 Kill Bill film duology. Bill crashes and massacres the wedding of his ex-lover Beatrix Kiddo after finding out she faked her death to get away from him. At the end of Kill Bill: Vol. 2, Bill reveals that his motive was jealousy:

Not only are you not dead, you’re getting married to some fucking jerk and you’re pregnant. I overreacted. […] There are consequences to breaking the heart of a murdering bastard.
https://youtu.be/yDjrX6mF89o

“I’m still a fan even though I was salty” encapsulates Bill’s feelings about Kiddo. He praises her character often, but still insists on having her dead if she’s not with him.

“Hate to see you happy if I’m not the one drivin'” may also be a subtle reference to Elle Driver, the one-eyed antagonist from the films:



“Broad” is also phonetically similar to “bride,” which would be a reference to Kiddo’s “the Bride” moniker.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Rather be in jail than alone

annotation.plain:
SZA’s never been comfortable by herself. She’s always sought to have others by her side, primarily for validation because of her insecurities, and was always left even more insecure after being dumped. This is something she already sang about in a song “Supermodel” from her previous album Ctrl. On it SZA sings:

Why I can’t stay alone just by myself?
Wish I was comfortable just with myself
But I need you, but I need you, but I need you

In “Supermodel,” she kept her discomfort of being alone under control and simply wrote a letter to her ex after he left her. But this time she’s committing double homicide. SZA’s not under control anymore as she’s saying it herself in the next track “Seek & Destroy”. She’s gone borderline maniac because of her jealousy and insecurity, prefering to be locked up for life rather than letting her ex go and be happy with another girl.

The line gets changed in the last Chorus where she switches jail for hell, stating she’d rather die than live her life without him. This change is also increasing the magnitude of how she feels being alone by comparing it to hell – telling us that the loneliness is the ultimate suffering for her.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I’m so mature, I’m so mature

annotation.plain:
In Kill Bill: Vol 2., protagonist Beatrix Kiddo is praised by Bill for her maturity. When telling her about the legend of Pai Mei, Bill notably says:

One of the things I’ve always liked about you, Kiddo, is you appear wise beyond your years.
https://youtu.be/S2ixJRwnbjU?t=247

It should be noted that this is a common grooming tactic that older men use on younger women. It’s heavily implied that Bill is doing just that to Beatrix; he’s old enough to masquerade as her father and Beatrix’s last name is literally “Kiddo.” Both SZA and Kiddo’s homicidal need for revenge obviously displays a lack of emotional maturity.

Alternatively, SZA could also be likening herself to Bill. Despite how much older Bill is, his refusal to allow Beatrix to live a happy life without him also displays a lack of emotional maturity.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I might
 I might kill my ex, not the best idea
 His new girlfriend’s next, how’d I get here?
 I might kill my ex, I still love him though

annotation.plain:
On the surface, SZA sings about wanting to kill her ex and his new girlfriend. However, this notably coincides with the plot of the iconic 2003-2004 Kill Bill film duology. SZA likens herself to Beatrix Kiddo, an assassin who goes on a vengeful killing spree that eventually ends with her ex-lover Bill.



 Bill (Left) and Beatrix Kiddo (Right) in Kill Bill: Vol. 2.


On January 10th, 2023, SZA would practically confirm this interpretation in the song’s music video, which roughly depicts the events of the Kill Bill duology with SZA suiting up as her own version of Kiddo:
https://youtu.be/MSRcC626prw?t=125

“His new girlfriends” could double as a reference to how Kiddo defeats every female member of the Deadly Viper Assassination Squad, a group of assassins led by Bill. Three out of the four members are women.

https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/villains/images/3/3b/Tumblr_static_deadly-viper-assassination-squad-chapel.png/revision/latest?cb=20180116164735 The Deadly Viper Assassination Squad in Kill Bill: Vol. 1.

 Still, I’m glad for what we had and how I once loved you

annotation.plain:
While she thinks that there will be more positive things waiting for them, the narrator feels that these happy moments are better off had apart, possibly in new and different relationships.

“Don’t you feel it too?” is her acknowledging and regarding her partner’s feelings as well, and confirming something she already knows: they must end the relationship to feel happiness again.

Although she is trying to end the relationship for both of their bests, she still views the time they shared together, and perhaps the lessons she has learned in their love, as important to her. This is a particularly mature way to end their relationship, especially that it seems they have fallen out of love for one another.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Now you look so unhappy and I feel like a fool

annotation.plain:
This line emphasizes the song’s previous ones, in which none of the efforts of the narrator are fixing what is “wrong” in their relationship. What she knows used to fix their problems in the earlier stages of their relationship doesn’t hold up anymore.

While she is confused by these changes, she can see that her partner is not even trying to fix what they have anymore. His sadness is evident, while she feels the “fool” for being the only person trying to save the relationship.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Something inside has died

annotation.plain:
The person is lamenting that something between them has fizzled out, and by the previous line “It’s too late,” it suggests that it has been a while since the narrator felt the shift in their relationship.

This timeline could explain why they can no longer keep quiet (hide) or pretend that she still feels the same for her partner any longer.

 There’s something wrong here, there can be no denying

annotation.plain:
The opening of the song sets the scene to the conflict the narrator is seeing. Staying in bed all morning is usually a sign of being stuck to thinking about something for a while. Instead of being productive, they ate “passing the time” to process what is currently happening in the relationship.

This is further emphasized in the following line, confirming that there is something “wrong”, and it cannot be overlooked. Though, the reason why the narrator is stuck to contemplating is unknown even to her, which could be why she is still stuck thinking about it.

annotation.plain: If this verse is discussing someone’s arrest, the big yellow taxi could a reference to the Metro Toronto Police patrol cars which were bright yellow until 1986. If, on the other hand, the verse is literally discussing “my old man” leaving, then its just a taxi reference. Whether the old man is a lover or a father is still contextually in dispute.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Verse 1]

annotation.plain:
Joni Mitchell provides some details about writing “Big Yellow Taxi” in the LA Times:

I wrote “Big Yellow Taxi” on my first trip to Hawaii. I took a taxi to the hotel and when I woke up the next morning, I threw back the curtains and saw these beautiful green mountains in the distance. Then, I looked down and there was a parking lot as far as the eye could see, and it broke my heart […] this blight on paradise. That’s when I sat down and wrote the song. When it first came out, it was a regional hit in Hawaii because people there realized their paradise was being chewed up. It took 20 years for that song to sink in to people most other places in the country. That is a powerful little song because there have been cases in a couple of cities of parking lots being torn up and turned into parks because of it.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
They paved paradise and put up a parking lot
 With a pink hotel, a boutique, and a swingin’ hot spot

annotation.plain: “The Paradise” was a hippie coffee house and club in Los Angeles on Sunset Boulevard at the corner of Laurel Canyon Drive. Joni lived (and still does) up in Laurel Canyon. Developers tore down the much loved Paradise and paved it over, then put up a hideous multi-plex theater, which is what stands there today. The double meaning is of course paradise as a noun (an idea) and Paradise as a proper noun (an actual place).

annotations.lyric_fragment: They paved paradise, put up a parking lot

annotation.plain:
All the natural beauty of undeveloped land was being covered in asphalt and buildings with no concern for the environment.  This song was a wake-up call to pay attention to nature because we can’t get it back once we destroy it.

Coupled with the preceding line about taking things for granted until we lose them, the narrator has hit upon the human condition. Our attempts to create are ultimately destructive and by the time we realize what we destroyed, it’s tragically irreversible.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Hey farmer, farmer, put away the DDT now
 Give me spots on my apples
 But leave me the birds and the bees, please

annotation.plain:
DDT is a highly toxic pesticide that was widely used.  It was banned after it was proven that DDT was leading to the extinction of birds like the bald eagle because it affected the shells of the eggs and chicks couldn’t hatch.

DDT was one of the first examples of chemicals introduced into the environment for one purpose ending up devastating a totally distinct, and at first seemingly unrelated part of the ecosystem.

Actually, since DDT was banned, the bald eagle and peregrine falcon are returning from near-extinction.  Also, the writer who first called attention to DDT is a graduate of the prestigious John Hopkins University and was a marine biologist with the US Bureau of Fisheries.  Very far from “scientifically illiterate.”

“Birds and the bees” is also a metaphor for potential life, and teeming, future vitality of the earth.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
They took all the trees, put ’em in a tree museum
 And they charged the people a dollar and a half just to see ’em

annotation.plain:
This song was written around the time of the beginning of environmental and preservation movements of the 1960s.

In 2012, you don’t have to go far to find, for example, a mining museum where there used to be a mine, or a recording studio museum where there was a studio. The “tree museum” has, in effect, almost come to pass.

This is a reference to the Foster Botanical Gardens in Hawaii.

It’s also ironic that they destroyed the trees only to put up a tree museum. Mitchell points out the flaws in a capitalistic society.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Don’t it always seem to go
 That you don’t know what you’ve got ’til it’s gone?

annotation.plain:
Joni is suggesting that we take things for granted until we lose them. Jay-Z claims to have been “inspired” by this line in his autobiographical “December 4th”

This line also directly interacts with Verse 2.  Before this, you could just go outside and enjoy the trees for free.  Now that they’re gone and you have to pay money to see them, maybe now you’ll appreciate them and realize what you’ve lost.

annotations.lyric_fragment: What happened to the girl I used to know?

annotation.plain: She’s taking a step back from their relationship. In an attempt to come to grips with the changes in her behavior, he attempts to ascertain her identity as matching the girl he knew in the past, or at least the positive representation he holds firmly to.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You got me shaking, got me running away

annotation.plain:
Jeff is emotionally distraught, and decides to flee.

The fight-or-flight response is a physiological reaction that occurs in response to a perceived harmful event, attack, or threat to survival.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’ll tell you once more before I get off the floor
 Don’t bring me down

annotation.plain:
If he is already as down as the floor, how can she bring him further down?

Naturally, a metaphor for somebody who has been beaten down and his tormentor is about to dish out the final blow.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You got me running, going out of my mind
 You got me thinking that I’m wasting my time

annotation.plain:
That’s the whole story of the song – the guy is crazy about “her” despite the abuse, cheating and cavorting.

However, it’s all her fault to make him “run”, “think” – so self examination is missing; he should be trying to figure out why he is such a pushover, submissive loser.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [​Outro]

annotation.plain: There is a strange, elongated one beat ending sound, followed by this noise – which was later confirmed to be a fire door closure at the recording studio. It is also the last sound on the album.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Don’t bring me down, groos
 Don’t bring me down, groos
 Don’t bring me down, groos

annotation.plain:
This is one of the most famously misheard lyrics in rock.

According to issue #1253 of Rolling Stone, Jeff Lynne said:

When I was singing it, there was gap in the vocals, so I just shouted out ‘groose.’ It was a word that came to my head. The engineer said that it meant ‘greetings’ in German, which I thought was lovely and decided to leave in. When I went onstage with it everyone would sing ‘Bruce.’ I just ended up singing ‘Bruce’ as well.

Rolling Stone contributor David Wild is also quoted in the liner notes for Flashback:

No, kids, Lynne’s not singing ‘Bruce’ in the backing vocals for the [Discovery] album’s inspired rocker Don’t Bring Me Down. ‘No,’ [says Jeff Lynne,] ‘it’s groos– just a word I made up in the studio to fill up this hole. Everybody loved it so I left it in. Mack– our great engineer at Musicland– said, How’d you know that? He told me that groos sounded just like the German word for Greetings. But everyone heard it as Bruce and at all the shows I ended up singing it that way too.’

The lyrics of this line led to numerous comments, many of the better ones can be read here.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Don’t bring me down

annotation.plain:
The Skylab was scheduled to re-enter the atmosphere on July 11, 1979.

ELO promoted the song feeding in on the frenzy created by the re-entry and its crash landing to promote the song.



The “relationship” with NASA continued in 1996, when the astronauts in the Columbia Shuttle were notified their flight will be extended because of bad weather on Earth – the wake up call that morning was this song! Actual recording is here.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Well, no one told me about her

annotation.plain: Heavily influenced by the discography of John Lee Hooker, The Zombies lyricist Rod Argent would base “She’s Not There” around his music, with the lyrics heavily mirroring those of Hooker’s. One song that struck a special chord with him was “No One Told Me,” which would serve as the opening line of their debut hit.

annotations.lyric_fragment: But it’s too late to say you’re sorry

annotation.plain:
Either the pseudo friends who did not warn him, or maybe a phrase directed to the girl who is trying to make amends.

Should have waited a few years and learned from the famous film –

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Well, no one told me about her
 Though they all knew

annotation.plain:
A bitter statement; “they all knew”, but still did not warn him. In a person nature’s there is a dark spot allowing, almost enjoying watching others falling to the same trap they did.
They probably expressed the same feelings to those that preceded them…

annotations.lyric_fragment: The way she acted

annotation.plain:
Another way to concisely describe her is as Femme Fatale – per the Free Dictionary

“ A woman of great seductive charm who leads men into compromising or dangerous situations.”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Well, no one told me about her
 How many people cried

annotation.plain: One cannot escape the allusion to the Greek Mythology’s Sirens, the dangerous beautiful creatures who lured sailors to shipwreck on the rocky shores.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Well, let me tell you ’bout the way she looked
 The way she acted, the color of her hair
 Her voice was soft and cool
 Her eyes were clear and bright

annotation.plain: A very complimentary description of the song’s subject – which just adds to the horror of the fact that “she’s not there”, as looks indeed deceive. This includes a very audible inhale.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Please don’t bother trying to find her
 She’s not there!

annotation.plain:
There is no universal agreement on the exact intention of the song writer when he wrote the song.

On the surface – “she ain’t here”, so “let it go!”.

More appealing, and frightening – “she is detached, not in full grasp of reality – she’s too far gone”, which explain her other negative attributes detailed in the song.

It was, very cleverly, left to the listener’s discretion to decide, keeping this haunting song mysterious and attractive.

annotations.lyric_fragment: She’s not there!

annotation.plain: “She’s not There” is a title by American novelist Jennifer Boylan, a book about her voyage from being man to a woman, and the song is mentioned prominently in the book.

annotations.lyric_fragment: But she’s not there

annotation.plain:
Santana covered the song in 1977, where the major changes are in the beginning and ending instrumental parts.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Instrumental Break]

annotation.plain:
The song has three instrumental breaks increasing in length after each chorus with the third elaborate solo being the most notable.

In an effort to make the song more marketable to radio stations, the song was shortened with much of Slash’s guitar solos removed. Axl loathed the radio edit, telling Rolling Stone in 1989:

I hate the edit of “Sweet Child O' Mine”… My favorite part of the song is Slash’s slow solo; it’s the heaviest part for me. There’s no reason for it to be missing except to create more space for commercials, so the radio-station owners can get more advertising dollars.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Instrumental Intro/Guitar Riff]

annotation.plain:
The now-famous intro, once chosen as the best riff of all time, started as Slash was “fucking around with this stupid little riff,” which caught Axl Rose’s attention. Within five minutes, the band had worked Slash’s cyclical riff into the bare bones of a song.

Slash told some more about the riff to Rolling Stone:

It’s a combination of influences. From Jeff Beck, Cream and Zeppelin to stuff you’d be surprised at: the solos in Manfred Mann’s version of “Blinded By The Light” and Gerry Rafferty’s “Baker Street.”

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Guitar Solo]

annotation.plain:
This guitar solo is widely known as the best guitar solo in history. In fact, this came in on Rolling Stones as the greatest guitar solo ever.

Apparently, however, Slash didn’t feel same-way:

When “Sweet Child O’ Mine” was written, it was a joke as far as I was concerned. I was just fuckin’ around when I came up with that riff. To me it was a nightmare because, for some strange reason, everyone picked up on it and, the next thing you knew, it had turned into a song. I hated it forever! The guitar solo itself is a one-take, spontaneous kind of thing. Having played the song at rehearsals enough times, when it came to recording it I knew exactly where the melody was and it came real easy.

annotation.plain: According to Slash’s autobiography, producer Spencer Proffer suggested adding a dramatic breakdown before the ending. No one had any idea what to do. As they listened again and again to the song in the control room, Axl started asking “Where do we go? Where do we go now?… where do we go?.” Spencer turned down the music, and said, “Why don’t you just try singing that?” and thus the last part of the song was born.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
She’s got eyes of the bluest skies
 As if they thought of rain

annotation.plain: Indeed.  “Blue skies” are also seen as perfect weather, so looking into them would be a good omen.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Woah, oh, oh
 Sweet child o’ mine
 Woah, oh, oh, oh
 Sweet love of mine

annotation.plain:
The “Sweet Child O' Mine” who inspired the song’s lyrics was Axl Rose’s girlfriend at the time, and future ex-wife, Erin Everly.  She was the daughter of Don Everly, of The Everly Brothers.

Erin would later claim that she married Rose solely because he had threatened to kill himself if she did not.  Needless to say, the marriage was very short-lived. Everly also appears in the music video for the song.

Why does he call his girlfriend child? One could imagine that she reminds him of his childhood—she is as innocent as a child.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I’d hate to look into those eyes and see an ounce of pain

annotation.plain: Eyes are described as a gateway to the soul. Although Axl claims that he does not want to look into this woman’s eyes and see sadness, he probably saw a lot of pain in the girl’s eyes considering he beat her.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Her hair reminds me of a warm, safe place
 Where, as a child, I’d hide
 And pray for the thunder and the rain to quietly pass me by

annotation.plain:
Axl, like many song writers before him, takes parts of his lover’s body and compares them to other things. In this case, her hair evokes a childhood memory—namely, of a place where a child scared of the storm outside hides until it’s clear.



Axl had a painful childhood where he would get beaten and his sister would get raped. So here he’s referring to the place he hid away from all that.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Now and then when I see her face
 She takes me away to that special place
 And if I stared too long, I’d probably break down and cry

annotation.plain:
He misses the days when he was a child and life was easy so if he thinks about those days for too long, he starts to cry

The special place refer to a mind-space of innocent love, which is free from the brutal world.  She takes him to that space and he realizes how reality-life is actually suffering, so comes the break down and cry.

He sees his childhood sweetheart, his first love around and about and it takes him straight back to where they used to ‘hang out’ together and what would his life be like if he was still with her and if he stares too long he thinks he would have been happier so he can feel the tears building up so he has to look away to keep his composure.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
She’s got a smile that it seems to me
 Reminds me of childhood memories
 Where everything was as fresh as the bright blue sky (Sky)

annotation.plain:
When he thinks of her smile it reminds him of the time in his life where he was happy and everything was good. The child-like smile is the intuition of all human. We lost it in the cruel egoistic society. The girl’s smile reminds him of the instinct of pure happiness, just like “fresh sky.”

Axl Rose had a traumatic childhood and suffered from molestation and abuse. This line is especially significant as it symbolizes how her smile reminds him of the few joyful childhood memories he has.

annotation.plain:
This is a reference to the stereotype that men are strong and “macho” as Jackson describes earlier, as well as a confirmation that the “you” he is directly addressing is a male.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Don’t wanna see no blood, don’t be a macho man (Ooh!)

annotation.plain: “Macho Man” was the nickname given to professional wrestler, Randy Savage. Wrestlers tend to bleed. Michael is saying that if you fight, you’re going to end up looking like a wrestler who’s bleeding.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Guitar Solo]

annotation.plain:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Aplfy9YZcZs

Legendary guitarist Eddie Van Halen shows his chops for 20 seconds in a solo recorded in half an hour for free as a favor to producer Quincy Jones (who at first, Eddie thought was a prank call…) while the rest of Van Halen was out of town. Michael wasn’t present for most of his recording session due to being busy with E.T., but once he heard Eddie’s collaboration, he complimented him.

The guitarist was surprised at how big Thriller got (to the point that, ironically, it held Van Halen’s 1984 from the top of the Billboard 200):

I said to myself, ‘Who is going to know that I played on this kid’s record, right? Nobody’s going to find out.’ Wrong! laughs Big-time wrong. It ended up being Record of the Year.

annotations.lyric_fragment: So beat it, but you wanna be bad

annotation.plain: The protagonist warns his friend about a gang who is trying to kick him out of town and rather than just leave, the friend feels he needs to be bad, and prove himself to these guys.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You have to show them that you’re really not scared (Ooh!)
 You’re playin’ with your life, this ain’t no truth or dare (Ooh!)

annotation.plain:
If you do fight them, you will get killed. You aren’t playing a game, and you really can get terminated.
Truth or dare is a game in which you choose whether you will tell the absolute truth about any single question asked toward you or accept any single challenge someone gives you. Usually, extreme dares are given or questions are asked, and the player will follow through to prove they are not scared. Michael is saying it is okay that you are scared, and you do not have to prove that you aren’t.

annotation.plain: in the real song, it sounds like oh-ooh-oh not ooh-oh! I personally think that should be changed, but that’s just me.

annotations.lyric_fragment: ’Cause it takes me so long just to figure out what I’m gonna wear

annotation.plain: This line is the narrator explaining why she is always late to work, saying it takes her forever just to figure out what to wear to work.

annotations.lyric_fragment: These are the days when you wish your bed was already made

annotation.plain: This doesn’t make sense, her boyfriend is unemployed, is still in bed and apparently is not in a hurry (he wants to make some noise).

annotations.lyric_fragment: I was kissin’ Valentino by a crystal blue Italian stream

annotation.plain: Most likely a reference to the actor Rudolph Valentino, the Italian actor who died young in the 20th century. Hoffs is reluctant to depart this idyllic vision.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Six o’clock already

annotation.plain: Waking up at six o'clock should be ample time for most people to arrive at work for nine o o'clock; Hoffs either has a major commute, or she spends a lot of time getting ready.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Blame it on the train, but the boss is already there

annotation.plain:
There is much debate over whether this line is ‘boss’ or ‘bus’.


‘Blame it on the train (a vehicle), but the bus (another vehicle) is already there’ makes sense. It’s like saying that making the excuse that the train was late means nothing because the protagonist (singing) could have taken the bus which would have arrived on time. ‘Blame it on the train, but the boss is already there’ doesn’t make any sense at all.

“Blame it on the train, but the boss is already there” makes more sense (to me, at least) because what it’s saying to me is this: “I can’t blame my tardiness on the train because the boss – who ALSO takes the train – IS already here on time, so my excuse of a late train would be feeble and transparent”.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Man, it’s a hot one

annotation.plain:
As the opening line of “Smooth”, these words set the tone for the rest of the music. What exactly is “it” that is hot?

The answer is purposely vague. Probably a very attractive woman he is interested in, but also possibly the burning passion that he feels for her, Santana’s solo, the general atmosphere of “Smooth” and the Summer vibes it evokes, clearly visible in the music video. Likely, a combination of all of them. Very hot indeed.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I could change my life to better suit your mood

annotation.plain: Rob Thomas, the writer of the song, is expressing that he is willing to change fundamental things about his life to be with the “smooth” female idol that drives the song. The use of “could” instead of “will” indicates that he is only willing to change his life if his female idol is just as willing to accept him. Otherwise he will probably remain the same.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You feel the turnin’ of the world so soft and slow

annotation.plain:
Perhaps the culmination of the entire song, but at the very least the culmination of the many intertwined metaphors contained within this work.

Here the metaphors of the “Smooth” woman as the sun and the moon and of Rob, the Planet Earth affected by his attraction to her like a gravitational pull, come together and immediately draw to mind the Earth religion and nature worship of ancient Native Americans whose culture, beliefs, and – yes – smooth musical traditions still influence Latin American culture to this day.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And it’s just like the ocean under the moon
 Well, it’s the same as the emotion that I get from you

annotation.plain:
In the same way that the moon’s gravitational pull affects the tides of the ocean, she, the titular “Smooth” woman, draws Rob closer.

Note the sun’s effect on tides as well, continuing the sun metaphor from the beginning of the song.

annotations.lyric_fragment: My muñequita, my Spanish Harlem Mona Lisa

annotation.plain:
Muñequita is an affectionate Spanish word, meaning “little doll”.

He quickly tops this by putting her in the same league as The Mona Lisa.

The words “Spanish Harlem Mona Lisa” were inspired by Elton John’s “Mona Lisas and Mad Hatters”, which in turn references “Spanish Harlem” by Ben E. King.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Out from the barrio, you hear my rhythm on your radio

annotation.plain: A barrio is a Spanish neighborhood. He brings his Latin influences from his heritage into this song, with the small hope that she’d enjoy it.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’ve gotta take a little time
 A little time to think things over

annotation.plain: “Agent Provocateur” is a concept album by Foreigner, which deals with a young spy who is in love with a young woman. The spy explains that his life was overwhelming and against odds, and that he has “to take a little time to think things over”.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’m gonna take a little time
 A little time to look around me

annotation.plain: The man is observing his surroundings. He is looking for any hazards, any guilt, any bitter memories. The man, to put in simpler terms, is indecisive, cautious, and wary. He’s like a character in “The Twilight Zone”, he got in, but he is dealing with a supernatural problem. He is trying to see if this relationship will work.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Can’t stop now, I’ve traveled so far
 To change this lonely life

annotation.plain:
The man singing this says that before his girl showed up, he was living a “lonely life”.

He has “traveled so far” to make this happen, and feels love for the first time.

annotations.lyric_fragment: In my life, there’s been heartache and pain

annotation.plain:
This completely supports the “mountain” that he holds on his hands.

The “mountain” is symbolism for his “heartache and pain”. The man is uncertain whether to face his demons, rather than running away.

And with this, he decides to try love.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Now, this mountain, I must climb
 Feels like the world upon my shoulders

annotation.plain:
A play on words.

His “mountain” is all the pain that he has been through, and the sufferings that he has encountered.

The weight bears on him, as he slips into uncertainty.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
No, you’ll never change her, so leave it, leave it
 Get out quick ’cause seeing is believing

annotation.plain:
Collins is stating that regardless if the person thinks they can change this woman it is impossible and they should get out quick.

I believe “seeing is believing” states that the person should see the way he is being treated as his real life experiences will be a more reliable indicator of his condition and relationship than his idealized version of the woman in his head.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
She’s an easy lover
 She’ll take your heart but you won’t feel it

annotation.plain:
They are stating that even if the person in question doesn’t feel like he is in danger from this woman he will have his metaphorical heart ripped out without even knowing it’s happening.

Perhaps this may be from denial that anything is wrong or the fact it may be disguised with affection.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
She’s the kind of girl you dream of
 Dream of keeping hold of

annotation.plain: This is towards the start of the song where it discusses that this girl seems to be special, one that you dream of. This may be chronological to the song structure as often people who end up in toxic relationships or breaking up with their partner are totally enamored with their partner.

annotations.lyric_fragment:

annotation.plain: Bailey is saying that he has been in this situation before and that the girl being spoken about often tells her partners that there is no one like them and that their connection is special only to move on to someone else. Perhaps this is implying that he has had a previous relation with this woman.
