annotations.lyric_fragment: Me gustan mucho las Gabriela

annotation.plain: Bad Bunny hace referencia a su novia, la cantante y modelo Gabriela Berlingeri, con la que lleva desde el año 2017 y la cual aparece en el final de la canción “El Apagón”.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Una dominicana que es uva bombón
 Uva, uva bombón

annotation.plain:
Bad Bunny hace sutil uso de la original frase dominicana “uva bombón”, la cual define a una mujer con un estilo único, fresco, y sobretodo, con atributos voluptuosos que hablan por ella misma.

Este concepto se popularizó a nivel internacional cuando en agosto de 2021, el dominicano Rochy RD hizo estreno la canción que igual lleva de título “Uva Bombon”, y trata la iniciativa del hombre de sentirse bajo las ordenes de aquella mujer única en su clase. Aquella mujer que “está uva bombón”.

https://youtu.be/lsEqmtE9UA0?t=8

annotations.lyric_fragment: I always get it up for the touch of the younger kind

annotation.plain: The lines that almost got the song banned, that induced anti-rock rallies, that parents used as an excuse to ban their children listening to rock and was a theme in every interview Doug Fieger ever gave…

annotations.lyric_fragment: Gun it coming off of the line, Sharona

annotation.plain:
“Gun it” is usually used for a car coming off fast from rest. This is one reasons some (not many) assumed that the song was about , well, cars.

Here it is used as a metaphor for starting fast – either Sharona with her teasing, or to himself – the speed in which he gets turned on by Sharona.

Very much in synch with the song’s rapid beat.



Or – something in the mood of The Beatles unforgettable – “Happiness is a Warm Gun”…

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Outro - Instrumental Bridge]

annotation.plain:
A long and very rocky guitar solo by lead guitarist and songwriter Berton Averre; considered one of the top guitar solos in rock.
Unfortunately most of it was trimmed in the single version.

Returning to the riff and drum fill before the last “ooooh, my Sharona"s.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Oooooh, my Sharona

annotation.plain:
Another use of the song was by a Chicago based DJ, Steve Dahl (and the Teenage Radiation) in a then current political parody – “Ayatollah” –

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=inQiIkz7J5Y

Ooh, you got a real nice beard
A real nice beard
You know it really caught-a my
Ayatollah

But you know your mind is weird
Your mind is weird
You really are a nutty kind of
guy-atollah…

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Bridge]

annotation.plain:
Drums and bass on both ends, with a lead guitar solo in the middle.
Bruce Gary, the drummer, staggered the drum beat using a flam – “A drumbeat consisting of two almost simultaneous strokes of which the first is a very rapid grace note”. In many minds he is considered one of the best drummers ever.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
When you gonna give me some time, Sharona?
 Ooh, you make my motor run, my motor run

annotation.plain:
Both lines/sentences start with “when”, meaning two different things.

The first refers to the future; at the time he wrote the lyrics, while infatuated with her, Doug Fieger had not started dating Sharona yet.

However, he was head over heels with her – from the first time he saw her at a clothing store; therefore the second “when” means “whenever I see you, you (make my motor run)”.

Feiger, hailing from Detroit, knows all one needs to know about motors…

annotations.lyric_fragment: Ooh, my little pretty one, pretty one

annotation.plain:
The song was controversial from its inception. The “Lolita” reference, actually only hinted in this line “My little one” and in the next stanza as “the younger kind”, very much a real life scene (Sharona was just 17 when Doug Fieger met her), drew a lot of attention, criticism and – publicity.

Later Fieger, not apologizing, stated that it was indeed a love directed at an underaged girl, with a caveat –

Sharona was 17. I was 25 when I wrote the song. But the song was written from the perspective of a 14-year-old boy. It’s just an honest song about a 14-year-old boy.

If so – why state “younger kind” later in the song?

annotations.lyric_fragment: Oooooh, my Sharona

annotation.plain:
This is one song “asking” for parodies,
Naturally “Weird Al Jankovic"was the first one. He recorded an accordion accompanied version with a Tarantella flavor – “My Bologna”, becoming his debut "hit' –

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C4_G7HHJ0GE

And, of course, commercials, like Taco Bell’s “My Chalupa –

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tZQTizNku08

annotations.lyric_fragment: M-m-m-my Sharona

annotation.plain:
The song was in the news in 2005, when it was revealed that it was on President G.W. Bush’s iPod’s playlist. The brouhaha was due to the racy lyrics, on which songwriter David Fieger said among other things –

“Q: Maybe President Bush thinks the song is about Ariel Sharon, the Israeli prime minister?”

“Fieger: It’s possible. Sharona is actually a Hebrew name. Sharona is a good Jewish girl. And the Knack is a good Jewish band.”

Later he quipped in answer to “How many other presidents expressed an awareness of your music?” –

“Yes, Lincoln and Roosevelt.

annotations.lyric_fragment: My, my, my, I, yi, woo!

annotation.plain:
Sounds like gibberish, but it is a possible adulteration of the famous Jewish exclamation Oy vey which is equivalent to the gentile “My, oh my”… Understandable, since Fieger was only half Jewish…

Probably a normal reaction of many of the listeners to the song’s subject.

annotation.plain: Stevie is insinuating that someday the two would be over one another.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
La-la, la, la, la, la
 La-la, la, la, la, la

annotation.plain: A mantra of fantasy, Stevie’s is enraptured by the one whom he admires. It seems as if his love is unreal to him,heightened by the fact that she is unaware of his feelings toward her. She is his dream, which is why he fantasizes about her so often.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
In a cafe or sometimes on a crowded street
 I’ve been near you, but you never noticed me
 My cherie amour, won’t you tell me how could you ignore
 That behind that little smile I wore
 How I wish that you were mine

annotation.plain:
A testimony of unrequited love. Stevie’s object of affections is unaware of his feelings toward her. When he is around her, be  a crowded street or elsewhere, she never takes notice of Stevie.

He feels as if his emotions towards her are no secret, therefore, to him, she is blatantly ignoring the signs he gives her of his love.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Lovely as a summer day

annotation.plain: She is as beautiful and as precious as a summer’s day in Stevie’s eyes; however she could also be considered fleeting, as summer is notorious for “never being long enough.” She is beautiful and radiant; however, she is difficult to grasp, so that he may have her for himself.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
My cherie amour, pretty little one that I adore
 You’re the only girl my heart beats for
 How I wish that you were mine

annotation.plain: Stevie is hopelessly infatuated; she is who he lives for; she is all he wants, yet somehow they are not together, possibly due to her being in a relationship, conflicting circumstance, or his bashfulness in approaching her.

annotations.lyric_fragment: My cherie amour,

annotation.plain: Translated from French to mean “My Darling Love”, Stevie cares tremendously for this person, yet she is unaware of his affections.

annotations.lyric_fragment: My cherie amour, distant as the Milky Way

annotation.plain: He admires her from afar; she is distant as he cannot get close to her either out of insecurity, or conflicting circumstances.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Somewhere beyond the sea

annotation.plain: “Beyond the Sea” had English lyrics by Jack Lawrence, but the melody was inspired by Charles Trenet’s [“La Mer.”]  (https://genius.com/Charles-trenet-la-mer-lyrics)  Both songs have been used in numerous movie soundtracks, such as Goodfellas, Finding Nemo, and French Kiss.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Somewhere beyond the sea
 She’s there watching for me
 If I could fly like birds on high
 Then straight to her arms
 I’d go sailing

annotation.plain: The woman he sings about is out of reach— just beyond the sea. This is an archetypal fantasy, especially for a sailor who travels constantly and never settles down. If he could, he would fly to her, but is bound by his travels.

annotations.lyric_fragment: U-City

annotation.plain:
U-City, short for University City, is an inner-ring suburb of the city of St. Louis in St. Louis County.

Nelly attended University City High, where he formed the St. Lunatics with his friends Ali, Murphy Lee, Kyjuan, Slo Down and others.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Jennings

annotation.plain: Jennings is a city in St. Louis, County.

Wood decorated on chrome and it’s
 Candy painted

annotation.plain: Chrome with wood trim interior is what the cars, in the video for the Country Grammar song had they were a 1970 Oldsmobile Cutlass and 1968  Pontiac GTO

annotations.lyric_fragment: Blowin’ up like Cocoa Puffs

annotation.plain:
Cocoa Puffs is an American brand of chocolate-flavored puffed grain breakfast cereal, manufactured by General Mills.

When milk is poured on to them they make a popping sound which is what Nelly is referring to.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Trife niggas who produce and sell the same beat twice, nigga

annotation.plain: Nelly explained this recently on an interview he did in 2021. Basically Jay E, the producer of the track, had already sold the beat to a group, but he didn’t believe they were going to do anything with it, so he sold it to Nelly.

This isn’t Nelly’s only reference to a Range Rover in one of his hits. On “Ride Wit Me,” he references his Rover again.

Watch me as I gas that 4 dot 6 Range
Watch the candy paint change, every time I switch lanes

annotations.lyric_fragment: We in now, candy Benz, Kenwood and 10's now

annotation.plain: Unlike the previous two references to automotive numbers, this doesn’t refer to his candy-colored Mercedes' wheel rims, but rather the 10" Kenwood speaker subwoofers that blast through the neighborhood.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
It’s not unusual to go out at any time
 But when I see you out and about it’s such a crime

annotation.plain: Tom acknowledges it’s normal to go out with friends , but it doesn’t stop him from being jealous when he sees her out and about with friends and not with him.

annotations.lyric_fragment: It’s not unusual to have fun with anyone

annotation.plain:
There is a double entendre here. Tom skillfully adds his natural sex appeal to the line to make the second, dirtier reference.

After all there is fun:



AND THEN THERE’S FUN

annotations.lyric_fragment: It’s not unusual to be loved by anyone

annotation.plain:
As love is an unexplainable emotion or feeling, trying to explain ours or anyone’s else love for someone is senseless. Never push someone to explain their love because often there is no explanation. Our heart chooses, not our brain.



Fun fact: “It’s not unusual” is an example of the rhetorical device called litotes.

annotations.lyric_fragment: And I know now that I’m so down

annotation.plain:
This is the pivotal line in the song.
The artist decides that he is down to get married with this girl. The rest of the song follows the theme of staying together through everything, as in a marriage.

annotations.lyric_fragment: And a shiny diamond ring with your name on it

annotation.plain:
This is a reference to an engagement ring. Offering someone a ring before proposing marriage is a common practice, but many feminist theorists have spoken out about how engagement rings treat womxn like property. As feminist writer Matilde Suescún put it:

I believe engagement rings are anti-feminist. They symbolise an attitude which is in complete antithesis to the idea of an independent woman, signifying that the woman with the ring belongs to another person.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Your lipstick stain is a work of art

annotation.plain:
5SOS might have referenced this lyric on their 2018 song, “Ghost of You”, where Luke sings:

There’s your coffee cup
The lipstick stain fades with time

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Simmer down, simmer down
 They say we’re too young now to amount to anything else
 But look around
 We worked too damn hard for this just to give it up now
 If you don’t swim, you’ll drown
 But don’t move, honey

annotation.plain:
People are saying their relationship will never work out. However, he doesn’t care. Despite the fact his girlfriend listens to everyone else’s opinions, Luke feels like they’ve worked hard enough just to give it up immediately.

Also, later lines hint at sex, so it’s possible that they don’t want to give that up either.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You look so perfect standing there
 In my American Apparel underwear

annotation.plain:
Best product placement ever?



Drummer Ashton Irwin explained how this line came about:

Song writer Jake Sinclair showed us an idea on an acoustic guitar – me and Mike (Clifford) sat and listened – he played a few chords and sung “you look so perfect standing there…“ He stopped and said “I don’t know it’s kinda weird” & we said “WE LOVE WEIRD”.



(American Apparel has not given an official statement)

annotations.lyric_fragment: I made a mixtape straight out of ’94

annotation.plain: Vintage is cool, right? It’s likely that this mixtape has some Green Day, Nirvana, and some Flaming Lips, all rock bands which were popular back in 1994.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Let’s get out, let’s get out
 ’Cause this deadbeat town’s only here just to keep us down

annotation.plain:
It’s a common trope in both teen fiction and pop punk music for adolescents to want to escape their small, boring town.



This line is similar to Lorde’s Tennis Court, as the artist(s)‘ self is still home, while in real life, they’re performing worldwide. Coincidentally, Lorde is from New Zealand, which is right by 5SOS’s native Australia.

annotation.plain:
Tat my name on you so I know it’s real
Tat my fuckin name on you so I know it’s real

Getting a tattoo of your true love’s name is the ultimate sign of endearment, as it’s (somewhat) permanent, leaving a long-lasting display of love.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Just come on down to the 54

annotation.plain: In the 70s, there was a little hole-in-the-wall dance club called Studio 54. Perhaps you’ve heard of it. 😊😉

annotations.lyric_fragment: Le freak, c’est chic

annotation.plain:
“Le freak, c'est chic” in French translates roughly to “The freak, it’s elegant”.

The word chic also exists in English as a loanword from French, which means stylish and fashionable. Chic is often used as a noun to describe a type of style or fashion (i.e. French chic, Boho chic).

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Come on along and have a real good time
 Like the days of “Stompin’ at the Savoy”

annotation.plain:
“Stompin' at the Savoy” is a 1934 jazz song which originally has two recordings, one by the “King of Swing” Benny Goodman’s band and one by Ella Fitzgerald’s band Chick Webb.

Fun Fact: Both bands battled in 1937 at the Savoy Ballroom in NYC – To which “Savoy” in “Stompin' at the Savoy” actually refers – and Chick Webb was announced the winner.

annotations.lyric_fragment: When I feel blue in the night

annotation.plain:
Blue is the color most associated with sadness, coldness and isolation.  Blue is the ‘coldest’ color: it is the color of the deep ice of Antarctica, it is the color that remains after removing the warm reds and the life-giving greens.
Here, the imagery of blue is coupled with the imagery of night.  Nighttime is a common metaphor for a time in one’s life when they are feeling the most sadness (one’s “darkest hour”).   The author is counting on their happy dreams to comfort them during this time of sadness.

annotations.lyric_fragment: All your charms

annotation.plain: Her charms are anything about her behavior that the author finds attractive.  When one is “charming”, one is behaving in a way that attracts positive attention in a social context.  The author not only wants to experience her physical beauty, but also her mannerisms and sense of humor.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I need you so that I could die

annotation.plain: The author believes that the only way for them to die happy and without regret is to have and hold the one they love for the rest of their life.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I can make you mine, taste your lips of wine
 Anytime, night or day

annotation.plain: The metaphor “lips of wine” compares the effect of kissing the one you love to the  enjoyable effects of alcohol consumption.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Dream, dream, dream, dream
 Dream, dream, dream, dream

annotation.plain: The theme of “dreams” is a powerful and ancient one.  In this song, as in so many others, dreams refer to a yearning for an ideal life that one has not yet found.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Only trouble is, gee whiz
 I’m dreamin’ my life away

annotation.plain: If we assume that the author is actually in a relationship with the one they dream about, then that “gee whiz” helps make these lines sound quite tongue-in-cheek, the truth being that to have these dreams is really no trouble at all.  However, these two lines could be evidence  of a sad thematic revelation: that the author’s love has not been reciprocated in the real world, only in his dreams.

annotations.lyric_fragment: And you say I only hear what I want to

annotation.plain: But then I give up one more time. I have to say, “And you say I only hear what I want to.” So am I hearing you actually say stay? Or am I deluded and I’m just thinking that you’re saying stay? And maybe you don’t really want me. You know, it’s that push and pull again. And then the video doesn’t help, because I walk out the door. But then I turn around. But then I kneel. Like am I leaving? Am I staying? What’s happening?

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You said you caught me ’cause you want me
 And one day, you’ll let me go
 You try to give away a keeper
 Or keep me ’cause you know you’re just so scared to lose

annotation.plain: That’s giving the audience a glimpse into the fact that this other person is saying to me, “I do want you. You can be in the middle of an argument. But I still want you.” They want me in their life. And then I turn it again and say, “You try to give away a keeper.” You just want me because you’re scared to lose me. You don’t actually want me. And then the person kind of interrupts and says, “And you say stay.”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I thought, “Hey, I can leave, I can leave”
 Oh, but now I know that I was wrong

annotation.plain: And I say I thought I could leave. You know, then you think, “I’m just gonna leave this. I can leave. But now I know that I was wrong, cause I missed you.” That’s the other thing I like putting in songs. People sometimes do things that are rash and then they just leave. Sometimes you really need to take a minute and think, “What’s my real object in this whole larger life scheme?” You know, my love for this person is more important than winning a fight. So I decide to stay. You know? At that point I decide to stay.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You said that I was naive and
 I thought that I was strong, oh

annotation.plain: It’s back to tit for tat. It’s back in that kind of bickering. “You said that I was naive. And I thought that I was strong.” Again, I think this is coming from a very me, Lisa place.  feel like I’m the kind of person that’s aware of my surroundings and the people in my life. And when people accuse me of things, like that—I’m naive—I think, “Oh. I kinda thought that I knew what was going on.” I feel especially little.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
So I, I turned the radio on, I turned the radio up
 And this woman was singing my song
 Lovers in love and the others run away
 Lover is crying ’cause the other won’t stay

annotation.plain:
It’s funny, because the radio part, it does all of a sudden lighten up and pick up at that part. When I wrote it, I was trying to get away from this intense situation I’m in. Like, “Ah, I’m just gonna get away from this.” I turn the radio on, and then this woman’s singing my song. I can’t get away from this. But then there’s a little satisfaction because she’s singing my song. She’s singing the same thing that’s happening to me. And I realize this happens to everybody. Everybody goes through those these same things. “The lover’s in love and the other’s run away. The lover is crying cause the other won’t stay.” Everybody goes through this. This is just a human thing that we all are always going through.

It’s not weird that I became the person singing this song. It’s like I’m Tony the Tiger holding the box of Frosted Flakes and on that box is Tony the Tiger holding a box of Frosted Flakes, and then on that box… So, it’s self-referential. I know. It’s very strange. Also, I remember when I wrote it and I wrote the word “Lover.” Like, “lover” was a word that we all hated using. It was just, kind of a tacky word, in a way. But I wanted to use the word because it was the kind of word you would hear in someone else’s old-school song and it works in that area. But I would never actually use “lover” when it applies to my own music. Sounds kind of like Gilligan’s Island, Mrs. Howell or something.

annotations.lyric_fragment: And you say I only hear what I want to

annotation.plain: I think the second time, I say, “And you say I only hear what I want to,” I’m about to go into this section which is repeating the kind of things I’m hearing. “You don’t listen hard. You don’t pay attention to the distance that I’m running. Or to anyone, anywhere. You don’t understand if I really care.” It’s like the person’s saying to me that I don’t recognize how great they are. I don’t listen hard. And I’m so negative. I’m only hearing negative. “No, no, no. Bad.” It’s sort of an accusation and a reality at the same time. It sort of has that double entendre. It’s somebody accusing me of hearing negative, but I also am… You know sometimes when you’re just in a bad mood, everything makes you mad and everything bothers you. And I feel like, sometimes you can feel everybody saying no to you. And you’re bad and you’re wrong. You know, everybody’s sort of accusing you. You feel kind of attacked.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And I thought what I felt was simple
 And I thought that I don’t belong
 And now that I am leaving

annotation.plain: I say, “You say I talk so all the time,” then I go on to talk a lot. I’m like, “So. That’s okay.” “And I thought what I felt was simple. And I thought that I don’t belong. And now that I am leaving. Now I know that I did something wrong.” I think those lyrics reflect when you’re in the moment. You’re almost like a child. You’re like, “I’m done with this! I’m done with you!” But then when you leave the room, you realize, “Oh shoot. I cut my nose off to spite my face. I actually miss you. I missed you. I actually wanna be back with you. Even if I have all these terrible feelings, I still wanna be back.”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You say I only hear what I want to
 You say I talk so all the time, so?

annotation.plain: I think “You only hear what you want to” is a baseless accusation when it comes to me. I think other people sometimes only hear what they want to, but I feel like I err on the side of trying to listen too much, to what everybody else is saying. So that makes it even worse for me, because when you feel like you’re a person who really tries to listen to the details and understand, not even just the words, but the feelings that are being thrown in your direction. When somebody accuses you of only hearing what you want to, it’s even worse, you know? Because if you’re the type of person who does hear everything.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You said you caught me ’cause you want me
 And one day, you’ll let me go
 You try to give away a keeper
 Or keep me ’cause you know you’re just so scared to lose

annotation.plain: That’s giving the audience a glimpse into the fact that this other person is saying to me, “I do want you. You can be in the middle of an argument. But I still want you.” They want me in their life. And then I turn it again and say, “You try to give away a keeper.” You just want me because you’re scared to lose me. You don’t actually want me. And then the person kind of interrupts and says, “And you say stay.”

And I thought what I felt was simple
 And I thought that I don’t belong
 And now that I am leaving

annotation.plain: I say, “You say I talk so all the time,” then I go on to talk a lot. I’m like, “So. That’s okay.” “And I thought what I felt was simple. And I thought that I don’t belong. And now that I am leaving. Now I know that I did something wrong.” I think those lyrics reflect when you’re in the moment. You’re almost like a child. You’re like, “I’m done with this! I’m done with you!” But then when you leave the room, you realize, “Oh shoot. I cut my nose off to spite my face. I actually miss you. I missed you. I actually wanna be back with you. Even if I have all these terrible feelings, I still wanna be back.”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
The taste of love is sweet
 When hearts like ours meet

annotation.plain:
Johnny, as many other lovers, knows how just delicious love can be when fully corresponded.

Johnny Cash and June Carter were ready for such a love, and its fruition is reminiscent of ripened fruit.

‘Once in awhile, like today, I meditate on it and realize how lucky I am to share my life with the greatest woman I ever met,’ Cash wrote in a birthday letter to June while he was in Odense, Denmark. ‘You’re the object of my desire, the #1 Earthly reason for my existence.’

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4GvD_NQrLFo

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Love is a burning thing
 And it makes a fiery ring
 Bound by wild desire
 I fell into a ring of fire

annotation.plain:
In this first verse, the protagonist describes what love is like, describing the feeling of desire as if you yourself were on fire.

June Carter wrote “Ring of Fire” early on in her relationship with Johnny Cash, while they were both married to others. It was a tough time for her because she was already married, and because she knew the kind of person Cash was, even as she was falling in love with him. She once wrote this about the song:

“There is no way to be in that kind of hell, no way to extinguish a flame that burns, burns, burns.”

Johnny Cash compared love to a ring of fire, saying they both excite and torment the victim. The longer you stay in the relationship, the more intense the flames become.



– June Carter in 1963

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I fell into a burning ring of fire
 I went down, down, down
 And the flames went higher
 And it burns, burns, burns
 The ring of fire
 The ring of fire

annotation.plain:
Although many believe “Ring of Fire” to be about falling in love, Johnny Cash’s first wife, Vivian Liberto, offers a different perspective.  In her book I Walked The Line she contends that June (Cash’s second wife) didn’t co-write the song as credited. Vivian writes:

To this day, it confounds me to hear the elaborate details June told of writing that song for Johnny. She didn’t write that song any more than I did. The truth is, Johnny wrote that song, while pilled up and drunk, about a certain private female body part. All those years of her claiming she wrote it herself, and she probably never knew what the song was really about.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Rolling and rocking

annotation.plain:
This could be talking about dancing or listening to rock & roll music. But the term “rock & roll” originally meant to have sex:

By the 1920s, “rocking and rolling” became a popular double entendre referring to either dancing or sex. Trixie Smith’s 1922 blues ballad, “My Man Rocks Me (With One Steady Roll)” may be the first use of the phrase in song.

A boat on water ‘rocks’ back and forth when waves hit it from the side. And it ‘rolls’ over waves when it hits them head on. These steady, rhythmic motions became slang for making love. So, she could be talking about lovemaking as well!

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Spoken in gibberish language by Lani Weymouth]

annotation.plain:

https://www.songfacts.com/facts/tom-tom-club/genius-of-love

annotations.lyric_fragment: Cup of milk, let’s rock and roll

annotation.plain:
This line is a reference to the ‘90s advertising campaign, “Got Milk?,” encouraging the consumption of milk by Goodby Silverstein & Partners agency.

The milk mustache Jung Kook ends up with in the song’s music video, which frequently appeared on the “Got Milk?” commercials, restates the reference.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hTru-Cy7taM
“Got Milk?” commercials compilation

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Bring a friend, join the crowd, whoever wanna come along
 Word up, talk the talk, just move like we off the wall

annotation.plain:
BTS has a reputation for being unconventional and “off the wall” in terms of their lyrics, production, delivery, and even marketing. The term was used by the American youth brand Vans for promotional slogans since the 1970s. BTS stays on-brand by referencing a brand that is a staple to youth culture across the globe while maintaining the retro theme of the song.



The music video for the song features many odes to the King of Pop, Michael Jackson, through its choreography. Therefore, “off the wall” could also be a reference to the superstar’s seminal eponymous album and its title track.

With “Dynamite” being released at a high point in their career, BTS can gather a huge crowd with their unconventional ways. They hope that this song will resonate with as many people as possible. During the press conference for the song, member Suga commented saying,

We want to give strength during these times of difficulty for everyone, so we hope that many people listen to the song and feel comforted.

Another retro slang term used in these lyrics is “word up,” firstly popularized in hip-hop by Cameo’s eponymous hit song in the 1980s.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Rolling on like a Rolling Stone

annotation.plain:
This lyric is alluding to the famous saying “A rolling stone gathers no moss,” in the modern meaning of “stay active to avoid stagnation.” The BTS members are encouraging their listeners to stay active and hopeful with this uplifting lyric. This lyric is also an allusion to Bob Dylan’s hit June 1965 track, “Like a Rolling Stone”.

Keeping in the theme of the song, “rolling stone” could also be an allusion to the iconic magazine, Rolling Stone, a monthly magazine that focuses on popular culture founded in the 1960s.

The lyric could also be alluding to the legendary English rock band The Rolling Stones, formed in London in 1962.

annotations.lyric_fragment: King Kong, kick the drum

annotation.plain: King Kong is a film monster (Kaiju), resembling an enormous gorilla, that has appeared in various media since 1933.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Jump up to the top, LeBron

annotation.plain:
LeBron James is one of the greatest basketball players of all time, partly due to his vertical leap—LeBron has a vertical jump of 40 inches, whereas an average NBA player can jump 28 inches.

Interestingly, SUGA is seen wearing a Tune Squad basketball jersey from the 1996 movie Space Jam in the music video—this loosely ties in with the LeBron reference, who is the protagonist in the sequel, Space Jam: A New Legacy.



SUGA donning a vintage Tune Squad jersey.




Furthermore, these lines can also be interpreted as a metaphor for BTS' success on the charts, as they’ve “jumped” from a rookie K-pop group to international superstars.

annotations.lyric_fragment: The wisdom of the fool won’t set you free

annotation.plain:
The wise fool, or the wisdom of the fool, is a form of literary paradox in which, through a narrative, a character recognized as a fool comes to be seen as a bearer of wisdom. A recognizable trope found in stories and artworks from antiquity to the twenty-first century, the wisdom of the fool often captures what Intellectualism fails to illuminate of a thing’s meaning or significance; thus, the wise fool is often associated with the wisdom found through blind faith, reckless desire, hopeless romance, and wild abandon, but also tradition without understanding, and folk wisdom.

In this situation, going with reckless desire won’t fix things and may even worsen them. Since nobody can properly advise this person, he gets more confused and stuck in his situation unless something changes

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’m not sure what this could mean
 I don’t think you’re what you seem
 I do admit to myself that if I hurt someone else
 Then I’ll never see just what we’re meant to be

annotation.plain: How do you make sense of it all? Should you be with the new woman? Maybe he is blinded by the love, and she is not what she seems. But he knows one thing for sure: if he consummates their relationship, he’ll be hurting, and betraying his wife, destroying any foundation of the new relationship, and then there would be no hope of that relationship working out in a healthy way.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I feel fine and I feel good
 I’m feeling like I never should

 Why can’t we be ourselves like we were yesterday?

annotation.plain: He feels great when he is with the new woman, but he knows he’s not supposed to. Sometimes, he is overcome with this feeling, and has no clue how to vocalize those thoughts. It just makes him wish that things would go back to the way they were. Before they fell for each other, when they weren’t even trying.

 You say the words that I can’t say

annotation.plain:
Every time he sees the new woman falling for him, he prays she will tell him that she loves him. He knows this, but he can’t say it, but that would be a final, defining moment.

From there, it can really only go one way, or the other, rather than a constant state of confusion.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’ve been searching for the daughter of the devil himself
 I’ve been searching for an angel in white
 I’ve been waiting for a woman who’s a little of both
 And I can feel her, but she’s nowhere in sight

annotation.plain:
Slightly reminiscent of the Longfellow poem  … There was a little girl …when she was good, she was very, very good, and when she was bad, she was horrid" but that’s not the kind of bad, this man is looking for. He wants a woman who will cast aside inhibitions to satisfy both his desires and hers, yet at the same time has beauty and purity of spirit. This is setting the bar pretty high and as yet, he hasn’t found her.

But in that regard these lyrics are somewhat confusing, maybe due to the song’s dual writing credits. In these earlier lines:
One of these crazy old nights
We’re gonna find out
Pretty mama
What turns on your lights

… it would appear that the singer is addressing a woman he already knows.

annotations.lyric_fragment: A-keep away from a Runaround Sue

annotation.plain:
Dion Dimucci recalled that while the song sprang from his feelings toward a neighborhood girl named Ellen, he chose a different name:

I wanted the song to be about a girl we knew from the neighborhood who had broken every guy’s heart. Not Ellen or anyone else [we knew]. What can I tell you, we were kids. Ernie [Maresca] and I didn’t want to use [Ellen’s] real name. Instead, there was this girl named Sue we had admired from a distance at the Harwyn Club in Manhattan. Her name fit the lyric line perfectly.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
She likes to travel around, yeah
 She’ll love you, and she’ll put you down

annotation.plain:
These lines are interesting in the context of Dion’s next single, “The Wanderer,” penned by “Runaround Sue” co-writer Ernie Maresca. In that song, the narrator’s love-‘em-and-leave-'em attitude is presented as charming. He’s not a scumbag—he’s just got a wanderlust. Did the word “problematic” exist in 1961?

Oh well I’m the type of guy who will never settle down
Where pretty girls are well, you know that I’m around
I kiss ‘em and I love 'em 'cause to me they’re all the same
I hug 'em and I squeeze 'em they don’t even know my name

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Here’s my story, it’s sad but true
 It’s about a girl that I once knew
 She took my love, then ran around
 With every single guy in town

annotation.plain:
Sue was a girl who ran around on Dion. This story is very vague but really strikes home for everyone who has ever been cheated on by a girl.

Dion uses an extensive hyperbole here. He describes Sue as the ultimate slut, who literally plays every guy in town for her own benefit in exchange for what they think is love.

This introduction would also later be used in G-Eazy’s sample in his song by the same name.



Because Sue broke Dion’s heart, Dion may have stopped searching for love and instead looked for short flings with many women, turning him into person he describes himself as in “Wanderer”.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Now check it: I got more mack than Craig, and in the bed

annotation.plain:
A pun based on the name of Bad Boy rapper Craig Mack—"mack" is slang for seduction skills.



The way Big says “in the bed” while bragging about his bedroom skills could be a reference to Shabba Ranks‘ 1989 dancehall hit “Wicked Inna Bed.”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Yeah, honey, check it
 Tell your friends to get with my friends
 And we can be friends
 Shit, we can do this every weekend (That’s right), alright?
 Is that aight wit’ you?
 Yeah, keep bangin’

annotation.plain:
This iconic spoken interlude made Puff Daddy a star. In the song’s video, Puff sips champagne in a hot tub with four women while spitting game to his then-girlfriend, Misa Hylton.



A similar “get with my friends, and we can be friends” sentiment popped up two years later on the chorus of the Spice Girls' #1 hit “Wannabe”:

If you wanna be my lover
You gotta get with my friends
Make it last forever, friendship never ends

Puff’s words were directly quoted by Wyclef in 2002, Juelz Santana in 2005, Pitbull in 2007, and DJ Khaled in 2011. Puffy quoted himself on his 2015 track “Money Ain’t A Problem”:

Catch me at the back blocks, I be creepin'
Call your friends, we could do this every weekend

annotations.lyric_fragment: Who rock grooves and make moves with all the mamis?

annotation.plain:
Big’s rhetorical question was sampled on the hook of Consequence’s 2011 track “I’m In V.I.P.” featuring Mac Miller & Diggy Simmons.

It was also sampled on drum & bass producer Dave Owen’s 2010 track “Tru That.”

annotations.lyric_fragment: Choppin’ Os (Uh-huh), smokin’ la in Optimos

annotation.plain:
“Os” are ounces of cocaine. Drug dealers typically buy coke in rock form, and then “chop” them—break them down using a razor blade or other tool—into fine powder for distribution or crack production.

Big seems to be implying that cocaine is his business, while smoking “la"—marijuana—is his pleasure. He name checks Optimo, a classic brand of cheap cigar used for rolling blunts.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Still tote gats, strapped with infrared beams (That’s right) (What?)

annotation.plain:
Despite his life of luxury, violence is never far away.

“Gat” is old slang for gun, or more accurately “pistol.” Its use stretches at least back to the 1920s—the name of The Great Gatsby was chosen by author F. Scott Fitzgerald to hint at the character’s quasi-legal past.

“Infrared beams” are a laser sights. Rather than the small red dots we see in movies, an infrared laser sight is invisible to the naked eye (presumably to avoid alerting bystanders or the target). It can be viewed with infrared night-vision goggles.



Biggie also references infrared sights on “Ready to Die” and the outro skit on “Warning”.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Straight up, honey, really I’m askin’
 Most of these niggas think they be mackin’, but they be actin’
 Who they attractin’ with that line (What?), “What’s your name? What’s your sign?”

annotation.plain:
Big’s describing the average guy who has no game—a set up for him to brag about his own seduction skills in the following lines. In this context, “acting” means faking.

“What’s your sign?” is a cliché pickup line from the 1970s—only corny dudes were still using it in 1994 when this song was recorded. Zodiac “signs” are an aspect of astrology, and allegedly can determine personality attributes.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Throw your hands in the air if you’s a true player

annotation.plain:
Using a classic party anthem tactic, Big gives a shout out to both men and women in the song’s chorus. He highlights both sides in the war of the sexes: men who play women for sex, and women who play men for money.

He repeated the honeys/money/dummies rhyme on the opening lines of his 1995 hit “One More Chance (Remix)”:

First things first:
I, Poppa, freaks all the honeys
Dummies, Playboy bunnies
Those wanting money

He also referred to himself as a “true player” on the same song:

Don’t leave your girl around me
True player for real, ask Puff Daddy

Given that “One More Chance (Remix)” was a clear attempt to recreate the R&B crossover success of “Big Poppa"—he quotes the song’s main refrain too—it makes sense that Big would have had similar vocabulary on his mind.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You gon’ be here for a while? I’m gon’ go call my crew, you go call your crew
 We can rendezvous at the bar around 2 (Come on)

annotation.plain:
Big makes plans with his lady to meet up at the end of the night so they can leave together with their respective crews.

“Rendezvous” is a word borrowed from the French that means to discretely meet up at an agreed upon place and time. The use of a French word gives Big’s request a touch of class.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Forget the telly—we just go to the crib
 And watch a movie in the jacuzzi, smoke Ls while you do me

annotation.plain:
Big has second thoughts about his plans to take his girl to the “telly” (hotel). Instead, he decides to take her home, where they can smoke blunts, watch a movie, and have sex in his hot tub—an image that recalls the famous Scarface scene where Tony Montana watches TV in his tub.



“L’s” is a term for blunts that comes from the classic rolling cigar El Producto. The brand was once favored by Elvis and George Burns, and they later inspired the name of rapper El-P.

Freddie finally decides on a solution for his relationship dilemma – to stay calm, and run like hell to get away.



Notice that a motorbike is symbolic for isolation. A lone wolf rambling to free their mind, and perhaps gain a new perspective.

annotation.plain: Freddie has mixed feelings about getting into a deep relationship with his baby. The key words in this verse are “I ain’t ready.”; This fear of commitment is the main theme that runs through the rest of the song.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Take a back seat
 Hitch-hike (Ah hum, ah hum)
 And take a long ride on my motorbike

annotation.plain: “A back seat” is most likely acknowledgement of inevitable run-ins with police as the narrator attempts to find personal freedom. “Hitch-hiking” suggests relinquishing control and letting the road guide you where it will. A motorbike implies the meditative, lonely trek of an outlaw… and we all know who loves their “Bicycle”. These modes of transportation are all rich in providing life experience.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
She gives me hot and cold fever
 Then she leaves me in a cool, cool sweat

annotation.plain:
Comparing love to illness is a common trope in music, particularly in the 50s. One example is the Peggy Lee song, “Fever”.

You give me fever when you kiss me
Fever when you hold me tight
Fever in the morning
Fever all through the night

James Brown had a song called “Cold Sweat”, but this line must closely resembled one from “Get Up (I Feel Like Being A) Sex Machine”:

You said the feeling you got to get
You give me the fever ‘n’ a cold sweat

annotation.plain:
This is one of Queen’s three most successful songs in the US market; the other two were “Another One Bites the Dust” and “We Will Rock You”.

Queensongs discusses repetition in Queen’s songs – these three are the biggest culprits, and their success in the American Market.

In aspect of Queen chart hits the US market in the 1970s and 1980s seemed to prefer more repetitive compared to the UK market. Three of Queen’s more repetitive songs –  “We Will Rock You” (1977), “Another One Bites The Dust” (1980), and “Crazy Little Thing Called Love” (1980) – were their most successful songs in the US. Their much less repetitive worldwide hit “Bohemian Rhapsody” (1975), however, only reached a Number 9 position on the US charts in 1976 (No2 in 1992!), while more repetitive Number 1 disco hits  (“That’s The Way (I Like It)” (1975) by KC and the Sunshine Band and “Fly Robin Fly” (1975) by the Silver Convention ) set the trend at that time. “Under Pressure”, Queen’s collaboration with David Bowie, reached a low Number 29 on the US charts in 1982, while the record was a Number 1 hit in the UK.  “Innuendo” had similar story (No 1 vs. No chart appearance). These three songs show that the US single market was not ideal place for Queen’s non-repetitive songs. The famous riff of “Under Pressure” later on returned in a repetitive context as the sample hook in Vanilla Ice’s pop-rap hit “Ice Ice Baby”, an US Number 1 in 1990 and also a telling and extreme example of “less  is more” – on the charts at least.

annotations.lyric_fragment: It shakes all over like a jellyfish

annotation.plain: Love is often described as making you feel like your legs have turned to jelly, so feeling like a jellyfish is one step further, and at least to some, a unique and disturbing image of love.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Panty snatcher

annotation.plain: The official lyrics on Spotify and elsewhere are “penny snatcher,” likely a reference to Pink!’s experience growing up Jewish in Doylestown, Pennsylvania. “Penny snatcher” is an anti-Semitic taunt/slur. It seems many versions have changed the lyric to “panty snatcher,” which does not make sense in a song about “underdogs” and those who are “too school for cool.” A “panty snatcher” would seem to be the opposite: a bully? a harasser? “Penny snatcher” makes more sense in context.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Nitty

annotation.plain: The definition of “nitty-gritty” is “the essential substance or details of a matter; basics; crux”. The term has been misused in this song to mean simply “gritty”.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Why so serious?

annotation.plain: Possibly a reference to the movie The Dark Knight (2008) in which the Joker, played by Heath Ledger, says the line, “why so serious?”.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Wish you’d just freak out

annotation.plain: This could be a reference to Chic’s Le Freak which includes the words “Freak out”. Originally the song was supposed to say “Fuck off” instead of the well known “Freak out” but they had to keep it PG in order for the song to become the hit it is today. In this case P!nk really means “Fuck off” instead of “Freak out” similar to Chic.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Produced by Jim Jonsin & Deezle]

annotation.plain:
Via XXL:

Jim Jonsin: I originally made the track in a session for Danity Kane. They passed on the record, and I went over and played it for Static.
…
Deezle: We recorded it and we were listening back to it after. I looked at Wayne and he was like, “It’s cool.” I said, “Man, I can bring this song home.” I totally re-did the drums and changed the bass line that Jim had. All my drums are harder than most people’s drums. I gave it the bouncy feeling. It was more sedated before. That’s why the people dance like they do when the record comes on. I brought it back to Wayne and he jumped up on the speakers and was excited and started doing the same dances he’s doing in the video and was like, “That’s the next single. I know we’re supposed to do ‘Showtime,’1 but we’re going to do this one.”

1- “Showtime” presumably refers to “Action,” a bonus track also produced by Deezle that appeared on on some versions of the album. It never ended up being a single.

Blink 182’s biggest hit started out as a live letter to a girlfriend and four leather clad dudes. “I wanted to write a song with na-na’s, ‘cause i love the Ramones,” singer-guitarist Tom DeLonge has recalled. “I thought,'I’ll write this song about my chick, and it’ll be an ode to the Ramones too.” “All the Small Things” hit No.6 and inspired one of the cleverest videos ever: a spot-on send-up of boy-band dance moves.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Pierced through the heart, but never killed

annotation.plain:
This line references an imagery Swift has already wrote about throughout her albums where she feels as if she is being hunted. A clear example can be seen in her 2014 track, “I Know Places:”

They are the hunters, we are the foxes
And we run

As well as 2019’s “The Archer:”

I’ve been the archer
I’ve been the prey

This song’s connection “The Archer” is also solidified in the music video, where Swift gets pierced through the heart by an arrow but survives.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I should not be left to my own devices
 They come with prices and vices
 I end up in crisis

annotation.plain:
Swift acknowledges that her celebrated creativity comes with its downsides, and that she often finds herself spiraling due to her unrelenting imagination.

Swift previously expressed similar sentiments about the inexorability of her creative process during an Apple Music interview about the surprise releases of folklore and evermore during the pandemic:

[The pandemic] has changed everything about the way that I do what I do. When you’re taking music you’ve already made … and you’re choreographing and you’re setting up a live spectacle that is taking up so much emotional, creative and imagination-based bandwidth in your brain. So, if you take all of that away… I guess I learned that it’s very possible for me to write more music… [these albums] happened naturally.

Part of these lyrics were revealed on a Spotify billboard at midnight on October 17 in Times Square in the lead-up to the album release.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I wake up screaming from dreaming
 One day, I’ll watch as you’re leaving
 ’Cause you got tired of my scheming
 (For the last time)

annotation.plain:
These lines — and most of “Anti-Hero” — parallel Swift’s 2019 track, “The Archer,” on which she also sings about the anxiety she feels towards people leaving her:

I’ve been the archer
I’ve been the prey
Who could ever leave me, darling?
But who could stay?

On that same song, she also mentions waking up in the middle of the night:

I wake in the night, I pace like a ghost
The room is on fire, invisible smoke

Furthermore, these lyrics also connect with the 13th Midnights‘ track, “Mastermind,” on which Swift explains why she has become a master at scheming:

No one wanted to play with me as a little kid
So I’ve been scheming like a criminal ever since

annotations.lyric_fragment: I’ll stare directly at the sun, but never in the mirror

annotation.plain:
Staring at the sun is hard to do, but is also a self-destructive act: doing so can cause serious issues with one’s vision. Looking in the mirror is not, but doing so forces one to face their own problems: Swift is not able to look at herself and confront her weaknesses in the mirror, but can ironically hurt herself by ignoring them – with great strength.

In 2020, Taylor personified herself as a mirrorball, putting forth the idea that she has no real identity and can “change everything about [herself] to fit in” and conform to what everyone expects of her. If this is the case, looking in the mirror would be confusing – who would you see?

This is also a nod to “The Archer”:

And I cut off my nose just to spite my face
Then I hate my reflection for years and years

Swift could potentially be referring to the British tabloid newspapers, the “Sun” and the “Mirror”. As a double entendre, this would suggest she enjoys engaging with drama to an extent, but never takes it seriously.

annotations.lyric_fragment: At teatime, everybody agrees

annotation.plain:
“Teatime” could be a reference to the music video for Taylor’s 2017 single “Look What You Made Me Do”, which was largely panned by critics, one of whom described Taylor as “exhausting” for it – a word she uses to describe herself only a couple lines later. In the music video, Taylor sips tea on a throne in an apparent reference to a photo posted online by Kendall Jenner with the caption “tea time” after her half-sister Kim Kardashian shared a phone conversation between Taylor and Kanye West.



“Look What You Made Me Do” was also the first single from her 2017 album Reputation, where Taylor took the role of a sort of anti-hero and which spawned the term “Reputation era” online as a reference to one’s own real life “villain arc”. The “teatime” in question is likely referring to the ways people, both those Taylor knows and those she doesn’t, talk about her behind her back, and the fact that she has become so ubiquitous that idle chatter about her being the cause of her problems has become commonplace. Based on the fact that her “midnights became her afternoons”, which implies that she wakes up at around 4 p.m., and the fact that traditional English upper class teatime generally takes place at 11 a.m., those engaging in teatime are badmouthing her while she’s not even awake.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I have this thing where I get older, but just never wiser

annotation.plain:
This line seems to allude to a quote by Oscar Wilde, a famous writer from the 19th century, notably for his novel, The picture of Dorian Gray:

With age comes wisdom, but sometimes age comes alone

Swift has also previously discussed the correlation between aging and wisdom on her song “tolerate it,” from 2020’s evermore:

You’re so much older and wiser, and I
I wait by the door like I’m just a kid

She’s also mentioned feeling like aging hasn’t actually made her more mature on songs like “The Archer,” on which she sings:

I never grew up, it’s getting so old

Moreover, she similarly addresses the feeling that she’s lost wisdom over the years on “Nothing New,” by singing:

How can a person know everythin' at eighteen
But nothin' at twenty-two?

Lastly, over the years, the media in particular have occasionally called out Swift’s songwriting and behavior for seemingly becoming less mature with the passage of time.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Midnights become my afternoons
 When my depression works the graveyard shift

annotation.plain:
A “graveyard shift” is a shift that runs from the late hours of the night to the early hours of the morning, usually between midnight and eight a.m.

Taylor says that her “depression works the graveyard shift,” meaning that her depression takes over and is most prominent during the late hours of the night and early hours of the morning. This could refer to the previous line:

Midnights become my afternoons

which implies that her sleep schedule has become significantly out of whack.

“Works” also refers to someone physically working a graveyard shift. Her depression has almost become personified, as if it has its own job of visiting her every night.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I have this dream my daughter-in-law kills me for the money
 She thinks I left them in the will
 The family gathers ’round and reads it and then someone screams out
 “She’s laughing up at us from Hell”

annotation.plain:
Though not identical, this verse shares a number of similarities with a scene from the 2019 murder mystery film Knives Out. In it, the will of Harlan Thrombey, a wealthy mystery writer (who is later revealed to have been murdered by his grandson for his inheritance) is read aloud to his family and in-laws, who expect to hear what they received from him only to find out that all of his assets have instead been given to his nurse, Marta. Fans on Twitter and critics noted the similarities between the two as well.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xNwQyNMSUmg&ab_channel=Movieclips

According to the Forbes Celebrity 100, Taylor was the 25th-highest-paid celebrity in the world in 2020, earning $63,500,000 that year alone. Unfortunately, because of this, the idea of an in-law offing her for her money isn’t entirely farfetched, which is likely why she has recurring nightmares about it.

A scene from the music video expands on the specifics of this dream, with her imagined children Kimber, Chad, and Preston all fighting at her funeral over the 13¢ she left them after presumably being pushed off her balcony by Kimber. Each of her children exploits her legacy in a different way: Chad writes a book called Growing Up Swift and records a podcast called Life Comes at You Swiftly, Preston uses Taylor’s name to get entry into a country club, and Kimber wears Taylor’s outfit and hair from the Fearless Tour in 2009.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
It’s me, hi
 I’m the problem, it’s me

annotation.plain:
Taylor confesses that everything is always her fault, playing into the narrative that has been constructed for her in the tabloids and on social media or mostly in her relationship. She changes the rhythm of the lines at the bridge, sounding like she is exhausted and tired of admitting that she’s the problem.

Swift has numerously admitted fault in a relationship in most of her tracks, like her October 2010 track, “Back To December:”

So, this is me swallowing my pride
Standing in front of you saying, “I’m sorry for that night”

Her November 2017 track, “Call It What You Want” also sees her owing to her mistakes, but diverts with the information that she eventually chose the correct person, on the song’s second verse:

And I know I make the same mistakes every time
Bridges burn, I never learn
At least I did one thing right

This was also, later on, followed by Taylor assuming full responsibility for their relationship’s distance in her 2019 song, “Afterglow:”

Hey, it’s all me, in my head
I’m the one who burned us down

Taylor was also seen using this phrase during her TikTok series Midnights Mayhem with Me with the statement “It’s me, hi,” where she had also revealed the tracklist to her album, Midnights.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Did you hear my covert narcissism I disguise as altruism
 Like some kind of congressman?

annotation.plain:
In keeping with the track’s themes of self-loathing and self-criticism, Swift magnifies another flaw she sees within herself: inauthenticity.

The phrase “did you hear” is often associated with celebrity gossip and scandalous tabloids, which are known to capitalize on the less-flattering parts of people’s lives. In these lines, Swift may be assuming the role of the media to be self-critical and publicize her own faults and shortcomings.

Narcissism is the excessive interest in or admiration of oneself. Altruism is the belief in or practice of disinterested and selfless concern for the well-being of others. Here, Swift labels herself as a “covert narcissist,” which is a psychological designation for people with narcissistic personality disorder who display fewer external symptoms, or who “conceal” their narcissism (as opposed to an overt narcissist). A covert narcissist might try to make their self-serving behaviors seem “altruistic” in order to gain approval from others.

The comparison to a “congressman” in the following line serves a similar purpose, as politicians are infamous for being deceitful and hiding their true intentions from voters. Here, Swift is making a jab at both herself and political figures who ignore the will of the people to push their own agendas.

Aware of her sway as a major public figure, Swift was notably publicly apolitical for the majority of her career. 2018 marked a major turning point for Swift, who broke her political silence via Instagram shortly before the Tennessee midterm elections to endorse Democrats Phil Bredesen and Jim Cooper for Senate and House of Representatives, respectively.

In the post, Taylor wrote,

In the past I’ve been reluctant to publicly voice my political opinions, but due to several events in my life and in the world in the past two years, I feel very differently about that now…For a lot of us, we may never find a candidate or party with whom we agree 100% on every issue, but we have to vote anyway.

Swift also spoke about the idea of political deception during her Miss Americana documentary when talking about Tennessee senator Marsha Blackburn:

I can’t see another commercial and see her disguising these policies behind the words “Tennessee Christian values.” Those aren’t Tennessee Christian values. I live in Tennessee. I am Christian. That’s not what we stand for.

During a comedic bit at the end of Swift’s “Look What You Made Me Do” music video, Red Tour Taylor calls out Fearless Tour Taylor for similar inauthenticity:

Oh, stop acting like you’re all nice. You are so fake.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Here we go again, asking where I’ve been

annotation.plain: After talking some sense into his partner the narrator wonders if she would still mistrust him, bring up the scenario of an ex girlfriend stopping by.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Why can’t you see what you’re doin’ to me
 When you don’t believe a word I say?

annotation.plain: The narrator is asking the supposed lover to look at themselves and how they’re affecting him. Their lover is only focused on themselves and how they feel, but isn’t thinking about how they are affecting him by not trusting anything he says.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
We can’t go on together
 With suspicious minds (With suspicious minds)

annotation.plain:
Though the two are still deeply in love, they are unable to continue their relationship due to their mutual distrust of each other.

These lyrics are based on the personal experiences of songwriter Mark James, who loved his wife at the time but was simultaneously fond of his childhood sweetheart in Texas. This caused his wife to become extremely suspicious and skeptical of him, consequently inspiring the song.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
We’re caught in a trap, I can’t walk out
 Because I love you too much, baby

annotation.plain: They are sort of in limbo. Their relationship is unhealthy, yet they can’t walk away because they love each other too much. They have likely been married for quite a while and there’s a lot at stake. Joined accounts, their home, possibly children etc.

annotation.plain: Typically losing your virginity isn’t the greatest sexual experience you’ll have, and a lot of people regret the way they lost it, but Prince is saying he has no regrets and lost it to a beautiful girl, who made his first time great.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I was working part time in a five-and-dime

annotation.plain: “Five and Dime” stores were general stores that sold a wide variety of inexpensive items. They were the precursors to today’s 99 Cents and “Dollar stores.”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
That’s when I saw her, ooh, I saw her
 She walked in through the out door, out door
 
 [Chorus]
 She wore a

annotation.plain:
She was gorgeous. He was lost in her beauty. She  subverted cultural norms, carving her own path by going in through the out door. This is reinforced by the fact that she blends well with cloudy weather and isn’t much of a bright person. Seemingly to invoke stereotypes associated with people who are portrayed as wearing berets in America, those who are aware of social factors but attempt to deconstruct or subvert them

Interestingly, In Through The Out Door was the title of Led Zeppelin’s 1979 album release. Approximately 7 million copies have been sold worldwide, about the same amount of copies as Around The World In A Day.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You feel like a movie star

annotation.plain: The flashes of lightning from the previous line replicates the strobing of the flashbulbs from paparazzi – thus being a movie star.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Thunder drowns out what the lightning sees

annotation.plain:
The English producer Ian Broudie was inspired to name his band The Lightning Seeds  after mishearing this lyric.

This line also cleverly and indirectly suggests they are getting down! What the lightning sees is them getting it on. The thunder drowns out the screams of passion.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I put her on the back of my bike and, uh, we went riding
 Down by old man Johnson’s farm

annotation.plain:
This channels the infamous barn scene, a deleted scene from the film Purple Rain where Prince and Apollonia have sex, and it is apparently very explicit. Parts of it can be seen in the “When Doves Cry” music video, while lyrics from “Raspberry Beret” seem to suggest this scene, while the cartoon segments in its music video are also reminiscent of the scene.

According to Jesse Johnson (guitarist formerly of The Time), Prince told him “old man Johnson” is a reference to him.

annotations.lyric_fragment: And if it was warm, she wouldn’t wear much more

annotation.plain: She is a provocative dresser – on a hot day she would be nearly naked if it weren’t for the titular hat.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
My boss was Mr. McGee
 He told me several times that he didn’t like my kind
 ’Cause I was a bit too leisurely
 Seems that I was busy doing something close to nothing
 But different than the day before

annotation.plain: Mr. McGee was a racist, attributing Prince’s laziness to his skin color. However, Prince’s actions were fitting the stereotype; he was artfully finding ways to avoid his work.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Or am I a page in your history book?

annotation.plain: There is a quote by Marianne Williamson that describes life as a book with different chapters in it. For example, a long-term relationship with someone that eventually ends would be a chapter of your life that had its ups and downs, and eventually ended, but opened new doors. However, in this lyric, calling this love only a “page” in her man’s book elaborates on the topic of asking her lover if he really wants to be with her for a long time, because if he only means the relationship to last a page and not a chapter, she doesn’t want to be with him.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Younger than the mountains, growing like a breeze

annotation.plain:
The Appalachians are a very old mountain system, first formed approximately 480 million years ago and once reaching the heights of the Rocky Mountains and Alps before eroding to their present height.

There was undoubtedly life in modern West Virginia prior to the formation of the Appalachians, but it would have been unrecognizable compared to the modern flora and fauna which presently lives there. The habitat fostered by the Appalachian Mountains is largely responsible for fostering the extant biodiversity.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Almost Heaven, West Virginia

annotation.plain:
Even those that have never been to the state can appreciate its peaceful beauty from afar.



For a place to be so close to the Atlantic seaboard, yet have tens of thousands of acres of unspoiled beauty is in itself a modern day miracle. God’s mighty hand made so many treasures here, like the Lost river, Cheat river, Youghiogheny and Cacapon rivers just to name a few.  The remoteness of some locations made them unattractive for human development, but prime real estate for God’s footstool.



– Blackwater Falls; Davis, WV

annotations.lyric_fragment: West Virginia, mountain mama

annotation.plain:
Believe it or not, none of this song’s three co-writers had ever been to West Virginia before recording this song – which is surprising considering it has become the state’s de facto anthem. The inspiration to write a song about West Virginia came from beautiful postcards Bill Danoff’s friend sent him. The “mountain mama” part refers to the numerous mountains such as the Appalachians that run through the state.



Fun fact – Danoff almost replaced West Virginia with Massachusetts in the chorus, since he grew up in Springfield, MA.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Country roads, take me home
 To the place I belong

annotation.plain: The particular country road the song is talking about is Clopper Road, which originates in Gaithersburg, Maryland and leads into West Virginia. Part of this song was written by co-writers Bill Danoff and Taffy Nivert to kill time as they rode along Clopper towards a family reunion in Maryland. Ironically, Clopper was made into a busy four lane road years after this song was written.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Dark and dusty, painted on the sky
 Misty taste of moonshine, teardrop in my eye

annotation.plain: This could be an allusion to the moonshine alcohol commonly produced in Southern states such as WV, but given the peaceful and naturalistic tone of the rest of the song, it is probably just talking about about the beauty of the moon in the night sky.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
All my memories gather ’round her
 Miner’s lady, stranger to blue water

annotation.plain: It appears that the “miner’s lady” is actually West Virginia itself, as coal mining has always a huge component of the state’s economy and identity. WV is also land-locked from the Atlantic, and is thus a stranger to the ocean.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Shenandoah River

annotation.plain: The Shenandoah River runs through both Virginia and the eastern border of WV. It also runs along the edge of the Blue Ridge Mountains just mentioned.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Blue Ridge Mountains

annotation.plain: The Blue Ridge Mountains are a section of the much larger Appalachians. Only a small portion of the range is actually located in West Virginia, but since the song has more to do with non-specific southern nostalgia the line was included.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I hear her voice in the morning hour, she calls me
 The radio reminds me of my home far away

annotation.plain: Song’s co-writer Bill Danoff claims that even though he had never been to West Virginia when the song was recorded, he became fascinated with the state after listening to a West Virginian radio station (WWVA) while growing up in Massachusetts. Country music is rooted in the Appalachian area, so listening to it on the radio is bound to remind him of his home away from home.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Possibly

annotation.plain: On the album the lyric is “possibly” in the first chorus, while on the radio edit it is changed to “probably.”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Come on now, who do you
 Who do you, who do you, who do you think you are?

annotation.plain:
Cee-Lo poses the question directly to those lost in their minds or in the world. He is asking you to re-evaluate your current circumstances and what you’ve become.

He’s again talking to the sane person saying who do you think you are, because the crazy person has realized something the sane person hasn’t, and that’s that he doesn’t control himself, but that he’s being manipulated by other forces, just like the crazy person.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Does that make me crazy?
 Does that make me crazy?
 Does that make me crazy?

annotation.plain:
The establishing point of the song is basically saying we are either crazy, or we are being manipulated and we don’t even know it. And when anyone tells us whats actually going on, we brush them off as just another crazy person.

CeeLo has admitted that he is crazy in multiple interviews suggesting you’d have to be crazy to be a musician.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And it’s no coincidence I’ve come
 And I can die when I’m done

annotation.plain: His way of paying homage to the artists he drew inspiration from since he was little was to dare to follow his artistic vision and remain unique while still chasing success. It took a lifetime of work and perseverance, and thus it’s not magic that CeeLo is now living the same life as his idols: he planned for it, and he has no regrets. Now that he’s become like his heroes, he can die happy.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
My heroes had the heart to lose their lives out on the limb
 And all I remember is thinkin’ I wanna be like them, mhm
 Ever since I was little
 Ever since I was little, it looked like fun

annotation.plain:
These aren’t people he idolizes because of what they have, but because of what they’ve been willing to sacrifice: their selves, going out on a limb, continuously risking failure, because the only way to break new ground is to cross over to where no one else dares to tread.

So many people look at celebrities and other personalities and idolize them without ever developing their own ideas/personality.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You really think you’re in control?

annotation.plain:
He finds it funny because the person he is just speaking to believes they have full control of how they think and feel when his/her mind is probably manipulated into thinking everything’s fine

Here, Cee-Lo is basically saying; you are not in control. Much of the public’s beliefs and opinions are influenced by the news and entertainment media they consume. And those media sources are overwhelmingly owned and controlled by a small amount of wealthy businessmen.

In the music video, Cee-Lo appears with devil-like horns at this point in the song. This can suggest that the devil and/or demons are the ones in control

annotations.lyric_fragment: Ha, ha, ha, bless your soul

annotation.plain: Your answer to the question was terrible so Cee-Lo laughs at you. This is a southern colloquialism, where’s he’s actually being condescending to the person he’s speaking to. Bless your heart, or bless your soul is used in the south to mean, you’re stupid, or something similar. Cee-Lo is famously from Atlanta, Georgia, a city in a  southern state in the US.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And I hope that you are having the time of your life
 But think twice, that’s my only advice, mm

annotation.plain: He hopes that the brainwashed “sane” people are happy being that way. But he’s still trying to open their eyes and minds.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
But it wasn’t because I didn’t know enough
 I just knew too much, mm

annotation.plain:
He was ostracized because society thought he was ignorant. But in reality, he is actually enlightened beyond the general populace, and that is why they don’t understand him and think he’s “crazy”.

A genius will seem crazy to a fool.

annotations.lyric_fragment:

 Yeah, I was out of touch

annotation.plain: He’s been rejected by society for his opinions (or, considered “out of touch”), so now he’s on his own because they don’t care about him.
