annotations.lyric_fragment: Feeling like I matter too

annotation.plain:
At this point, there’s not much you can do except pity this man.

There is a thin line between being needy and emotionally manipulative.

Being told that someone “just wants to be with you, feeling like [they] matter too” leaves you with little room for rejection without looking like a terrible person. He is leaving her with little choice through his coercive word choices.

His self worth is almost entirely tied to the love interest. His mental health is very poor.

annotations.lyric_fragment: ’Cause all I really want is to be with you

annotation.plain:
This phrase follows the coercive nature of many of the lyrics.

It suggests codependence and lack of other aspirations- an extremely unhealthy mindset.

He probably doesn’t even want this, he wants the positive memories he had of being with her. He thinks that being with her will fix him.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Hey jealousy

annotation.plain:
If we consider the song to come from a hypothetical place, with the last line

“there’s only one thing that I couldn’t start”

suggesting that either he is imagining the conversation or is unable to start his recovery process, the line “Hey Jealousy” makes more sense.

Psych today suggests that

“Jealousy is a complex emotion that encompasses feelings ranging from suspicion to rage to fear to humiliation.”

Whilst Wiki notes feelings of “insecurity, fear, … anger, resentment, inadequacy, helplessness” with causes in “perceived threat to a valued relationship”.

Clearly, this song reeks of insecurity, humiliation, inadequacy, and helplessness- pinpointed by trying to reignite a threatened relationship.

So, in this case, “Hey jealousy” references a couple of things:


He is aware of the affect that his jealous feelings have on being able to move forward as a person, or even communicate his feelings in a healthy way.
He is jealous of the love interest coming out of their relationship better vs him struggling to function.
He is suggesting that not being with the love interest is causing these feelings, pointing out the “root cause” of his lyrical plea and essentially blaming her, as she is the object of his jealousy. By practically saying “its not really my fault” he is positioning himself better for when he makes basic promises (like not sleeping around) and asks her to keep the expectations low.
He wants to win her back, but his jealousy is affecting his speech and it is frustrating.



The line “Hey jealousy” contextualises the whole song- this is a man’s pathetic and frustrated attempt to try and pull back what he once had, being ruined by his own mental instability and negative thoughts.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
If I hadn’t blown the whole thing years ago
 I might be here with you

annotation.plain: He feels that if he hadn’t screwed up, their story might have ended with them never separating

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And you know, it might not be that bad
 You were the best I’d ever had

annotation.plain: Doug is admitting here that in retrospect, he really did enjoy the time he had with this person even though he “blew the whole thing years ago”, possibly out of wanting better. We don’t know if this person was abusive to him, him to her, or both.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Hey jealousy
 Hey jealousy
 Hey jealousy
 Hey jealousy

annotation.plain:
So for years I loved this song but was stumped by why he kept saying “jealousy”. Why is that the title? It sounds like he knows he did something wrong, he blew it, but nothing in the song really gives us a hint, just that he did something so bad that the relationship ended.  The best I could come up with is that the girl’s name is “Jealousy” and that she had Hippie parents. How many great songs about lost love the title is the other person’s name. But that’s not it.

See their other big hit off this album is a song about cheating “Found out about you”. He was totally into her, until he her whispers at the bus stop, found out about nights out at the schoolyard. Right? JEALOUSY. If you listen to that song alone, it’s the song of a jaded male who thought he was in love while the girl didn’t seem that interested in him.

But if the next song you hear is this one, it takes a new meaning. He was the jealous lover in the other song. Demeaning his love, but that was the action that drove her away, causing him to get drunk and show up on her doorstep to express this song.

“Hey jealousy” is him bemoaning the emotion of jealousy that screwed up his whole life, by screwing up this one relationship, by living “Found out about you”. Hence the wail on “jealousy,” it is his own jealousy he’s angry at.

Now if I can just figure out what the “one thing I couldn’t start” means.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Well, there’s only one thing that I couldn’t start

annotation.plain:
Okay, so this lyric is the greatest mystery I have in my entire music-listening life. I love this song, I’ve transcribed it and I’ve tried to annotate the parts that I’ve can. I’m still not sure why it’s called “Hey Jealousy”, there’s no real lyrics about jealousy and the other lyrics don’t sound like jealousy, I assume she just had weird parents who gave her a hippy name BUT:

What the hell couldn’t he start? I need to know this and I’m scared the answer died with the guitarist. He couldn’t start getting sober? He couldn’t start his relationship? What the hell couldn’t he start?!?!??!

Doug admitted to putting sugar in the gas tank of the tour van when he was really stressed out during a big tour.

annotations.lyric_fragment: It’s my party and I’ll cry if I want to

annotation.plain:
This line comes from the lyricist’s daugther. She was having a 15th birthday party and didn’t want her grandparents to come. Her dad (the one who wrote her song) told her to stop crying, which she responded “It’s my party and I’ll cry if I want to!”

It can be seen as something childish, to cry. But I think this line is quite empowering. She has a choice to cry and she does it if she wants to. Especially since crying is seen as something involuntary and in this line she makes it seem like a choice and protest

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Judy and Johnny just walked through the door (Walked through the door)
 Like a queen with her king
 Oh, what a birthday surprise
 Judy’s wearin’ his ring

annotation.plain: And Murphy’s law sets in… Things go from bad to worse and Johnny and Judy are getting hitched. In contrast to a pleasant birthday surprise like a pinata or a present, the narrator has to stare down her worst nightmare. Hope she got that pony she wanted…

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Nobody knows where my Johnny has gone (Johnny has gone)
 But Judy left the same time

annotation.plain:
Johhny seems to be the archetypal name for a handsome man in the 50s. Whereas, Judy was the name of Seymour Gottlieb’s daughter (The song’s author) who actually helped pen the song. (See the SLA)

He had given the lyrics to a friend named Herbert Wiener who in turn had passed them along to a composer. Gottlieb wasn’t even aware the song had been recorded until he heard it on the radio. Luckily he was able to cut a deal and share the royalties.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Try, cry, why try?

annotation.plain:
After going through the hell of self doubt, he comes to the conclusion, that trying to disclose his feelings will, most likely, bring him pain.

With the words “why try?” he puts in doubt, whether it’s worth speaking about it openly.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Like a hurt, lost and blinded fool, fool

annotation.plain: “Hurt” and “lost” evokes the sense of a child that is helpless, as it’s a common expression to describe a child experiencing or re-experiencing trauma.“Blinded fool” is meant to show how love can leave one blind to the things they have influence over in a breakup situation. “Fool” is then repeated to emphasize how much of a fool the singer is.

They could be about him and his love, and the various things he would love to do with them. This line could also speak about all the dark places that his mind goes during this difficult time

These lines relate back the lyrics of the  chorus. He now realizes the the “hints” he was seeing in his crush’s behavior were only in his head.



Tori Kelly also deals with this theme in her song “All In My Head”.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Every whisper
 Of every waking hour
 I’m choosin’ my confessions
 Tryin’ to keep an eye on you

annotation.plain:
Although Michael Stipe has never confirmed this, many read the lines  “choosing my confessions” and “hint of the century” as subtle statements about his struggles as closeted bi-sexual (He came out publicly in 2008) In an interview with Slate, Stipe said:

It was super complicated for me in the ’80s — I was totally open with the band and my family and my friends and certainly the people I was sleeping with. I thought it was pretty obvious.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Instrumental Intro]

annotation.plain:
In the book Reveal: The Story of R.E.M., guitarist Peter Buck shared how he wrote the memorable riff that drives the song. He decided to record his attempt to learn a new instrument (while also watching TV).

When I listened back to it the next day, there was a bunch of stuff that was really just me learning how to play mandolin, and then there’s what became ‘Losing My Religion,’ and then a whole bunch more of me learning to play mandolin.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Chorus]

annotation.plain:
Although the following lines are the functional chorus of the song, there is no musical hook, making it so forgettable that many people (including some reviewers) don’t even realize that this song has one.

R.E.M. bassist Mike Mills, when commenting on the song unexpected popularity, stated, “It’s a five-minute song with a mandolin and no chorus.”



Until this point, the song has revolved around minor chords, which have a musical connotation of sadness. However on the words, “I thought that I heard you laughing,” the song features its first sustained major chord, often characterized as having a “happy” sound.  However the singers happiness doesn’t last long; the happy major chord is simply a momentary wishful self-deception. By the end  of the chorus, the song once again returns to a somber dorian (similar to minor) modality.  This type of tonal change is called a “deceptive cadence,” and used by R.E.M.  to underscore the speaker’s self-deception

annotations.lyric_fragment:
The lengths that I will go to
 The distance in your eyes

annotation.plain:
Here is some wordplay, contrasting two terms of measurement (“length” and “distance”).

He is willing to do whatever it takes to make an emotional connection with the object of his obsession, even if they seem resistant.

The speaker is admitting (perhaps for the first time) that he has been desperately looking for clues (“the lengths that I will go to”) that the person he loves might possibly feel the same way. The following admission is crushing (“the distance in your eyes.”); he knows the person he loves doesn’t share these feelings.



A similar play on words is the central theme of Starset’s “Telescope”.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Tryin’ to keep up with you
 And I don’t know if I can do it
 Oh no, I’ve said too much
 I haven’t said enough

annotation.plain:
These lines are all about self-doubt. He wants to show that he is in love with this person, but he doesn’t want to come off as creepy. His obsession is making him doubt everything he says, and every move he makes.

These lyrics may also reflect Stipe’s difficulty in finding the balance for staying relevant to his fans while also staying true to his art.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I still go to Taco Bell
 Drive-through, raw as hell
I’m talking champagne wishes, caviar dreams

annotation.plain:
This is a reference to the TV Series “Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous”. The host, Robin Leach, ended each episode with his signature phrase “champagne wishes and caviar dreams.” The reference is a nuanced condemnation of that lifestyle. Ludacris mentions Robin Leach (the host) being jealous in the following lines right after to emphasize on their wealthy lifestyle.

This show has been mentioned before on songs such as Kanye West’s “So Appalled”, Kendrick Lamar “HiiiPower” and Kool G. Rap on “Fast Life”

annotations.lyric_fragment: I’m glad my daddy told me so, he let his daughter know

annotation.plain:
Fergie flips the meaning of the lyric here, originally she uses the sample to celebrate her success, and call her self a rich-bitch visa-ve rejecting those less successful.

But like parts off of “Glamorous,” Fergie shows how she’s as normal as anyone else, reflecting on a time before success. Her father telling her to come home if success never comes shows us a more human side of Fergie. She could have just as easily not been the success she is.

Ludacris lives such a “glamorous” and upscale life that it would make even Robin Leach

annotations.lyric_fragment: Yeah, you know me

annotation.plain:
This line may be referencing the song “O.P.P.” from Naughty by Nature, released in 1991 (Jump was released in 1992).
The chorus of O.P.P. has a line that goes “Yeah, you know me”, which is said in an identical tone in Jump.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Everything is to the back with a little slack

annotation.plain: This lyric is referring to Kris Kross wearing their pants backward and letting them fall a little bit.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
R&B rap is bullcrap is what I’m dumpin’
 Ain’t nuthin’ soft about Kris Kross, we all that
 So when they ask, “Do they rock?,” say, “Believe that!”

annotation.plain:
Right out of the gate, Kris Kross immediately established a rivalry with youngster-rappers ABC (aka Another Bad Creation), who were part of Bell Biv Devoe’s ‘East Coast Family’ – all known for their mix of R&B and rap that they called “mentally hip-hop, smoothed out on the R&B tip, with a pop feel appeal to it”.

Kris Kross makes it clear that they don’t do rap that is ‘smoothed out on the R&B tip’, calling that style ‘bullcrap’. Instead they rap with a rougher style, closer to the rock and roll attitude that groups like Run DMC established years earlier.

annotations.lyric_fragment: (Jump jump)

annotation.plain:
Producer Jermaine Dupri told Billboard Magazine how he got the idea for “Jump” while attending a concert:

I watched the crowd. I watched how people were just into jumping. Rappers had been doing it and I said ‘we should make a record like this’. I went home and wrote the song in an hour.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Cah you a di number one, gyal, wave yo’ hand
 Mek dem see yo’ weddin’ band

annotation.plain: Women are beautiful to me. I could be talking in this song to a single lady. I could be talking to my wife. And the lady who does have on her ring, she’s wilding out, and she’s showing her ring like, “Yeah that’s me, I got the ring.” There is a lot of competition out there, and she’s the one who wins. So it’s a point of pride for her. And for me, I’m talking to every woman that I could in this scenario. I think married people get to wild out too and party. And a husband can tell his wife she sexy: “Go ahead boo-boo.” That’s why the song is also able to play at weddings.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Gyal, run di program, jus gwaan pet it

annotation.plain: When I say “run the program,” I mean just let it happen. And when I say “gwaan pet it,” I’m telling her that… ladies can have this way of dancing in dancehall, where they show you their whole sexiness, and they pet their… I heard a word describing this stuff that ladies got. They call it ‘bits’ in England. Yeah, so pet your bits. Pet your stuff. It’s just saying you look sexy and it’s kind of empowering her, because it’s not like I’m telling her. She’s already doing it, and that’s why I noticed her. And I’m like “Whoa, she’s petting on her front there."And she’s really telling you it’s good, it’s clean, it’s tight. She got the good good. I’m saying, "Go ahead girl, do it.”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
From di day mi born, Jah ignite mi flame
 Gyal ah call mi name and it is mi fame

annotation.plain: When I said, “Girl a call me name and it is my fame,” I just remember being that 13-year-old and my cousin was like, “Girls at school! They digging you!” And I’m like “What did I do?” It just feels like it’s been that way ever since I was a little kid. But it’s hard to tell nowadays with fame who is there for whatever reason. They see that they can accomplish their goal around you. It’s easy to like something that you can see on the screen or a poster, but to personalize that thing, which is me, is another thing. Maybe they don’t like Chinese food and garlic like me. I don’t know.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Inna di club, dem waan flex wid us
 To get next to us, dem cyaan vex wid us

annotation.plain: I’m like, they want to come in to the club with us, they want to be around us, and they ain’t having no arguments. In other words, I got 99 problems, but my bitch ain’t one. It’s like she’s chilling with us. There are people who are in troubled relationships, that don’t got that. That’s what I’m saying in the song.

annotations.lyric_fragment: ’Pon di riddim when mi ride and mi lyrics ah provide electricity

annotation.plain:
In dancehall music, lyrics are very important. It’s a big part of the whole thing. At times, when people present me an EDM-type thing, and they want me to leave that space where it’s like all this noise going on, I understand, and I get it, but in the dancehall culture, we pay attention to the words a lot more. So, to stand out you need to have the best lyrics. Or you need to have lyrics that describes the situation perfectly. And also a great tone, which I had naturally.

But you have to worry about the lyrics in dancehall. When I say my lyrics provide electricity, what I mean is that she’s feeling the direct vibe of what I want to say to her and she agrees and feels the same way.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Get jiggy, get crunked up

annotation.plain: It’s a dope song, so I don’t feel no way about that part. I don’t feel no way about the oldness of the word. At the time, I was just using cliché rhymes: “Get crunked up, percolate.” That’s why I said “anything you want to call it.” It was like, “Whatever you want to say, you’re doing.” At that time, I was 20 something. Every 10 years, there’s this new flavor, new talk. So I was like, “Yo, anything you want to say.” So if I say “get busy” and “get jiggy,” that sounds old to you. Anything you want to call it. Just do your thing.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Woman, get busy, jus shake dat booty nonstop
 When di beat drop, jus keep swingin’ it
 Get jiggy, get crunked up

annotation.plain:
Hearing the rhythm, it was such a different type of rhythm, but it felt like something that you’ve heard all your life. Just the way it sounded was so different from what was playing, and also at the same point in time, you just felt it like you’ve known it forever. So I loved it from the beginning. I didn’t know what would come out of it. When I first did it, friends of mine were like, “Why did you flip the chorus like that?” So we were discussing and debating on how it would end up.

If the rhythm talks to me… sometimes it doesn’t end up having to be the biggest thing. But this rhythm did talk to me, and it did end up being the biggest thing. It just sparked a whole vibe on my career. It’s took me to new places. So what I was thinking about was basement parties and girls dancing and sweating and pressing up on, getting close. Loud music, banging on the banister and the rafters and just doing the thing.

I think those are some of the best times, even though when I’m writing a song, I can’t go back there. I can’t go back to when I was 14 or 15 years old, first going out to these kind of parties and getting busy. Those words just came. When you hear a dope beat, the rhythm tells you what to say.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Shake dat ting, miss Cana, Cana
 Shake dat ting, miss Annabella
 Shake dat ting, yo, Donna Donna
 Jodi and Rebecca

annotation.plain: Jodi is my wife. At the time, she wasn’t my wife. Her and Cana was chillin', and I was like, “I’m going to the studio now.” And they said, “Mention our name in the song.” And I was like, “Alright, cool.” I went in there, did the song, and I was trying to find an intro. And usually in Jamaica, we kind of talk an intro out and introduce the song. Well, this time I just decided to sing. I was like “I’m going to put their name in it and freak them out.” I did do it and to this day they’re still good friends. Big up, Cana!

annotation.plain: Sean doesn’t want his girl to let up or, “go easy,” because he is enjoying it so much.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Vanity, insecurity, ah

annotation.plain: This lyric is commonly misrendered as “vanity and security” in versions floating around the Internet. In fact, it refers to the twin flaws—vanity and insecurity—behind the defenses raised by the addressee of the song.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Won’t you come see about me?

annotation.plain: Reference to the immortal Come See About Me by The Supremes

annotations.lyric_fragment: When the light gets into your heart, baby

annotation.plain:
The theme of light & dark appears again. While love is “real in the dark”, the light will pull them apart. Taken rather literally, this completes the scenery of the dance and the evolving romance that happens in the dark, while at the end of the dance, when the lights come on, this transcendent and exuberant feeling of infatuation may disappear.

It also points to the theme of impermanence of romance throughout, as the lights could go on at any moment. Especially this fleeting feeling is what makes this song so beautiful.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Chorus]

annotation.plain:
As revealed in a 2019 Ringer piece:


The chorus was all G and C chords on a guitar tuned down a half-step, with the monosyllabic pithiness of Dr. Seuss. […]

Camp borrowed the chord shape—F#-B-Cdim-B, with that portentous C diminished chord—from the lurking danger of the James Bond theme.


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ii1tc493bZM

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Interlude]

annotation.plain:
As bassist Paul De Lisle told Rolling Stone in 2019:

I was deemed the best whistler in the band, so I got to be the whistler guy.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
My world’s on fire, how ’bout yours?
 That’s the way I like it and I’ll never get bored

annotation.plain:
This could use the first definition of “on fire”:
“in flames; burning.”, showing how his world (the earth) is getting hotter through global warming.
Or you could interpret this, taking “on fire” as
“in a state of excitement.”, showing how the narrator, though “taking the backstreets”, is living his life “for fun”.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Somebody once told me the world is gonna roll me
 I ain’t the sharpest tool in the shed

annotation.plain:
Someone who gets “rolled” is being fooled, taken advantage of, and/or being robbed. “Not the sharpest tool in the shed” is an idiom meaning he’s not so smart.

A 2019 Ringer article breaks down this opening line:


The song begins with vocals, barging in before the music does: one kick-starting syllable on the last unaccented beat of a nonexistent bar. It’s an impolite entrance, a skipping of preamble and niceties.

SomeBODY once told me the world was gonna roll me …

Both the record label and the radio stations hated it. “[Radio DJs] like to talk over the beginning of your song,” [songwriter Greg] Camp said. “Which made me fight for that even more. You know: ‘Well, they should shut up when our song plays.’”


The article also reveals Camp’s inspirations for this approach:

One track in particular stood out: Barenaked Ladies’ “One Week,” with its hyper-verbose verses and abrupt mood shifts, and the fact that the vocals kicked in before the music did. (The other group brazenly vocalizing right at top of songs that year was ’NSync. Smash Mouth would tour with them in 2002.)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cL2IZ6-QvjU

The opening is so iconic that Camp has said:

[Now vocalist Steve Harwell] just walks out on stage and says the word “Some,” and the crowd will finish the song for you. They’ll sing the entire song. My hair still stands up when that happens.

The line became a meme on TikTok where there was a trend of extending the time between “Some” and the rest of the verse to show funny videos and similar stuff.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You’ll never shine if you don’t glow

annotation.plain:
This lyric has been described as “vaguely koan-resembling but obviously tautological”. It turns out it was a temp lyric that Camp never updated:

I needed something to rhyme, and that’s all I had at the time. And all of a sudden it was on a record and I didn’t change it.

One interpretation: one does not rise to great success (to “shine”) unless one takes chances and puts in the effort to achieve more modest goals first (to “glow”). These terms fit well with the song’s star theme.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Bridge]

annotation.plain: The very fact that there’s a verse 3 here, after the bridge, solidifies the themes of rejecting the rules and doing your own thing. Very few people add a verse after the bridge, it’s usually reserved for the climax of the song, be it a guitar solo or a key modulation. This connects to the chorus line “Only shooting stars break the mold” because, as mentioned before, one-hit wonders change the game then disappear, and this is what Smash Mouth is trying to do here.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
She was looking kind of dumb with her finger and her thumb
 In the shape of an “L” on her forehead

annotation.plain:
This is referring to the symbol made when the thumb and the index finger of the right hand is held to the head, presenting an “L”, meaning loser, to the viewer.

http://zanesafrit.typepad.com/.a/6a00e55197a0e188330147e3c27ee6970b-800wi

Songwriter and guitarist Greg Camp told Rolling Stone:

The whole “L on the forehead” thing is actually a true story. I was in a relationship and I was playing in bands and stuff like that. Every morning this person that I was with would have to get up and go to work, and I would be able to just kind of stay in bed because I didn’t work until later. I was playing in bands that made money, like cover bands and wedding bands and things like that. I could sleep all day and, you know, drink at night and party and stay out and stuff like that, so there was a lot of jealousy happening, and it sort of came in the form of, “You’re a loser, dude. What are you going to do, sleep all day? This is going to end someday. You’re not going to do this the rest of your life. You’re gonna have to actually grow up and get a job.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Verse 2]

annotation.plain:
This verse is possibly Smash Mouth’s most sophisticated work of lyricism. It’s a gradual build-up from freezing (“It’s a cool place and they say it gets colder…”) to literally fiery hot (My world’s on fire…).

In a metaphorical sense, the character was being told that life gets only worse, but he refuses to suffer this fate and decides to live life the way he sees fit because “That’s the way I like it and I’ll never get bored”.

Apparently “boredom” plays a big part in the protagonist’s decision making, as he associates it with the academical standards pushed on him by media, his parents and in school, while he was young. He eventually realizes that the more you strive to achieve intellectually, the more you distance yourself from the “real world”.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Go for the moon

annotation.plain:
Per a 2019 Ringer article, “[Songwriter Greg] Camp took out a dusty old record of NASA air-to-ground voice communications, and pulled out a snippet that suggested a proverbial reaching for the stars: ‘Go for the moon.’”

This simple phrase—although at first it may sound scary—is a strong statement of encouragement, urging people to never give up and follow their dreams, no matter what they may be.

Obviously, going to the moon, is (and was), an extremely audacious task for anyone, which is why Steve uses it here. He is showing us that anything is possible.

However, the phrase is repeated, and not sung by Steve, possibly implying that the ability we have to do what we want has been over-drilled into our minds, and lost meaning.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Only shootin’ stars break the mold

annotation.plain:
A “shooting star” is someone who shines brightly all of a sudden but then drops off. Only those willing to take some risks in life will “break the mold” and put an end to a restrictive, dull pattern of events.

The original lyric here, per the handwritten lyrics tweeted out in 2017, was:

Wave bye bye to your soul

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I throw my hands up in the air sometimes
 Sayin’ “Ayo, gotta let go”

annotation.plain:
Bonnie Mckee revealed that she was facing personal hardships when she wrote that line and how there’s a deeper meaning to the song itself:

I was going through some shit, and it was actually about surrender, and for me ironically, it was about getting sober.

Mckee continued elaborating:

It was kind of one of those things where the sky was falling apart, and it was one of those things where you’d have to just sort of stir up your hands […] and it turned into this like absolute party anthem, which is really ironic.

She conclusively affirmed:

It’s really just like a cry to the heavens. It’s almost like a prayer.

Turning tribulation into celebration, the song peaked at #2 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart.

https://youtu.be/4QQNetwzKZk?si=bTK3wsingzDTR3MN&t=138
Bonnie Mckee performing “Dynamite”

annotation.plain:
New York Magazine writer Adam Sternbergh broke down songwriter and producer Dr. Luke’s lyrical style:

 “Dynamite” is exactly the track you’d want the D.J. to drop at the moment you enter the club. The lyrics, as with most Dr. Luke songs—“I came to dance / I hit the floor ’cause that’s my plans / I’m wearing all my favorite brands”—are basically about how fun it is to hear a Dr. Luke song.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
(Take me home)
 (Take me home)

annotation.plain:
The game of love is just as difficult as following the economy, it all comes down to timing.

Your chances of finding a true connection may rise when meeting someone new, but it can also fall when your emotional journey with that specific person may not turn out the way you want it to.

Lisa Lisa hints at some of the past emotional trauma that she has faced with people that she has been with in the past, and alludes to the possibility of initiating something she may or may not regret.

If you wanna see some real Texan asses, just watch Bey and Megan do their thing. Both known for their booty shaking ability. Yoncé is first shaking it to the left and the right, before dropping it los.

Swang has multiple meanings: it can be used as a dance move where Bey grinds on her man, or just living freely “living her best live”.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Always keep my words, no, I don’t do crosswords

annotation.plain: Crosswords are a popular word game where clues are given to fill in a linking grid of words—often they constitute random characters and places of culture, political figures, punny word play, slang terms, and more. Perhaps Beyoncé’s just swearing off the activity of doing crosswords, but she’s more likely employing word play on the idea of “cross words” — words that are disingenuous and conflicting. She’s adamant that she’s 100% honest and consistent when she makes a promise, like a real boss.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I’m comin’ straight up out that Third

annotation.plain:
The “third” is a reference to the Third Ward of Houston, Texas, where Beyoncé grew up. In 2013, Beyoncé notably created a nickname for herself and used it as a metaphor for her childhood and beauty standards in the opening lines of “Pretty Hurts,” the first track from her fifth studio album BEYONCÉ:

Ms. Third Ward, your first question:
What is your aspiration in life?
Oh, well my aspiration in life would be… to be happy

The proceeds from “Savage (Remix)” are to be donated to the Houston organization Bread of Life in support of Covid-19 relief.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I told that boy, “We gotta keep it low, leave me the room key” (Ooh-oh)

annotation.plain:
Megan prefers to keep her relationships private, which calls back to a reminiscent line in her 2018 hit “Big Ole Freak”:

Nobody know, I fuck with him on the low
We never show up together but I text him when I’m ready to go

annotations.lyric_fragment: If you don’t jump to put jeans on, baby, you don’t feel my pain (Hol’ up)

annotation.plain:
As a result of wide hips, Bey describes that having  a voluptuous body can be a struggle to put on her pants.

Bey used a similar lyric for this struggle in her 2018 track with Jay-Z, “BLACK EFFECT”:

Gotta hop into my jeans like I hop into my whip yeah

annotations.lyric_fragment: Like Beyoncé, like me (Like me)

annotation.plain:
Megan interpolates close lyrics, referencing the Southside rapper Webbie, with his 2005 track “Like That,” off his album Savage Life:

Like Beyonce, like Trina
Like a big booty ass black diva

Webbie acknowledged the slick nod via Twitter:

https://twitter.com/OfficialWebbie/status/1255595289496428555?s=20

annotations.lyric_fragment: I’m a boss, I’m a leader, I pull up in my two-seater

annotation.plain:
Fly is slang for cool. Beyoncé plays off the function of “fly” as both adjective and a verb (e.g. birds fly) to brag about her stylish coupe, which is a type of passenger car. She might also be making a reference to its speed: Beyoncé is driving hers so fast it’s practically flying. Moreover, its physical structure lend itself to the comparison: typically, a coupe also has just two doors. When opened, the car easily resembles the wings of a bird.

Coupe is also a homophone for coop, where chickens—a type of bird—are kept.

Bey’s made multiple references to coupes over the years, starting with 2011’s “Countdown”:

Me and my boo in my boo’s coupe riding
All up in that black with his chick right beside him
Ladies, if you love your man, show him you the fliest
Grind up on it, girl, show him how you ride it

Her featured appearance on DJ Khaled’s “Top Off” in 2018 also referenced the vehicle:

Top off the coupe and it look like Freaknik
In the hood, hollerin', “Free Meek”

annotations.lyric_fragment: Woodgrain, we swervin’, keepin’ his mind all on these curves (Uh)

annotation.plain:
Woodgrain is a finish of wood that resembles its natural character. Some classic woodgrain patterns are characterized by beautiful swirls—perhaps second only to Beyoncé’s body in curvaceousness.



Bey also famously used woodgrain to simulate sex on “Drunk In Love”:

Then ride it with my surfboard, surfboard, surfboard
Grainin' on that wood
Grainin'-grainin' on that wood
I’m swervin' on that, swervin'-swervin' on that
Big body been servin' all this
Swerve, surfin' all in this good-good

annotations.lyric_fragment: You’re a little late, I’m already torn

annotation.plain:
Anne Preven clarified on The Howard Stern Show what the line is really about:

I heard you guys dissecting it the other day. You guys got one thing wrong. You guys were saying that it’s like about a girl being dumped. He comes back; he wants her back. She’s done with him. She’s all disappointed.

Howard Stern exemplified:

Women do that all the time, though. You meet a guy, you start going out with him, and you start to project onto him what you want him to be. She does that?

“Yeah,” replied Anne.

Sung by Natalie Imbruglia, “Torn” topped the Billboard Hot 100 Airplay chart.


Anne Preven on The Howard Stern Show

annotations.lyric_fragment: I’m all out of faith

annotation.plain: Earlier, our narrator sang about seeing things in a “holy light,” but now she sees only cold stark reality. Faith is the ability to completely trust in someone or something even if you cannot see it; she is now utterly without faith and can no longer trust illusions or that which isn’t tangibly real.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Produced by Diplo & Skrillex]

annotation.plain: This song makes me think about a lot of stuff. When Justin sent us the a capella it was fashion week—a really magical week in New York for me. I played a bunch of really fun parties and got to meet a bunch of cool people. It was right when “Tuesday” by ILoveMakonnen and Drake came out. This song just reminds me of summer in New York, to be honest.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Produced by Diplo & Skrillex]

annotation.plain:
It’s funny how people find this song because it’s such a weird collaboration. Our fans are probably scared of it, pop fans probably thought it was weird, Bieber fans probably didn’t know about it. We needed to be able to define it in our own way. I am very excited that we got to make everything happen and that it became such a big record.

When I started working with Bieber he wasn’t the most popular artist. I think that things have changed a lot. He debuted as the number one single recently—that’s amazing. I think the song brought it all back together and it’s really helping him. Not that we was never likable, but he had so many things surrounding him that were negative. We’ve kind of made him cool again and made it so that he was likable again. I’ve seen him in clubs and he’s astounded that other adults can support and cheer for him. The song really meant something to him.

annotations.lyric_fragment: And I was on my knees when nobody else was prayin’, oh Lord

annotation.plain:
He says that he was the only one doing something good for her, believing in her and praying for her when no one else was.

It could also be that “Oh Lord” is intended to flow into the next hook, giving the rest of the song religious undertones.

I.e. “Oh Lord… where are you now that I need ya?”

annotations.lyric_fragment: I showed you the game everybody else was playin’, that’s for sure (That’s for sure)

annotation.plain: In the celebrity world there are lots of fake people. Most of them just want to stay around other famous folks, because they want to get attention as well. They’re playing the game when it comes to “who’s the most famous person, who hangs around with the most famous people, etc.”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I need you the, I need you, I need you the, I need you, I need you, where are you now that I need ya?
 I need you the, I need you, I need you, I need you the most

annotation.plain: Justin feels that he needs his ex lover (presumably Selena) more than anyone. He is the one person who needs her the most.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Tell me, where are you now that I need you?
 Where are you now? (Where are you now?)

annotation.plain:
Every time Selena needs major publicity, the pair seem to be together and seen out in public. If Selena needs Justin in any way, he is there immediately. Moreover he’s never bashed her in any form.

A week before the release of her single “Come and Get It,” they were spotted in Norway.

A month before the release of her album Stars Dance, they were seen together again.

Meanwhile, in his worst times, she is nowhere to be found. Through Justin’s rough patch in 2013-2014, Selena was never around every time he got in trouble. In fact, after his most notorious mess up–the DUI arrest–Selena went on Jimmy Fallon to bash Justin and claim him to be “ignorant” and “childish.”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Where are you now that I need ya?
 Where are you now that I need ya?

annotation.plain:
Continues to reference Justin’s previous notable romantic relationship with none other than Selena Gomez.

She has moved on and is now dating famous DJ Zedd (just take a look at her recent Instagram posts for evidence) while Justin has just left the hardest rough patch of his entire career and still needs her.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I gave you attention when nobody else was payin’
 I gave you the shirt off my back, what you sayin’? To keep you warm

annotation.plain:
Did Justin just give us a double? Not only did he carefully listen to her words and respect her thoughts, he probably bought her tons of stuff. Now that’s how you pay in attention.

While the shirt-giving was literal, figuratively he sacrificed everything to protect and take care of her.



Selena used to wear Justin’s clothes. Makes ya wonder…

annotations.lyric_fragment:
When you broke down, I didn’t leave ya (I didn’t leave ya)
 I was by your side
 So where are you now that I need ya? (Need ya)
 Where are you now that I need ya?

annotation.plain: This could be a reference to Selena Gomez’s stint in rehab during which Justin was there for her and supported her. However, when he went through a rough patch, she didn’t return the favor.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I gave you the key when the door wasn’t open, just admit it
 See, I gave you faith, turned your doubt into hoping, can’t deny it
 Now I’m all alone and my joys turned to moping

annotation.plain:
Justin gave a lover—or a close friend—the key to his heart, but he wasn’t really able to be vulnerable in the relationship. He never truly trusted the other person, which fractured the partnership, so much so that they broke up. Now that they are apart, his world is shattered, and in that loss he feels how much this person meant to him.

This can also mean that Justin allowed this lover into a place that he normally did not allow anyone else to enter.

The line “See, I gave you faith, turned your doubt into hoping” can refer to him helping heal this person who is his lover. In other words, the lyrics can be interpreted as Justin giving his lover support and helping them out, only to be left alone and in the cold once his lover left.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Oh, I’ll just keep on makin’ the same mistakes
 Hoping that you’ll understand

annotation.plain:
Ed isn’t alone. Psychology Today reports that we’re most likely to repeat mistakes when stressed (perhaps by a new relationship!):

Under stress, we tend to retreat to habits of emotion regulation formed in toddlerhood. Habits rule under stress and when the regulatory processes of the prefrontal cortex (the Adult brain) are overtaxed from physical or mental exhaustion.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And I’m thinkin’ ’bout how
 People fall in love in mysterious ways
 Maybe just the touch of a hand
 Well, me, I fall in love with you every single day
 And I just wanna tell you I am

annotation.plain: U2 famously sang about a woman who moved in “Mysterious Ways.” Sheeran sees that mystery in all relationships, and feels it in his own on a daily basis. Each day, he actively finds something else in her that makes him fall in love.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I’m thinkin’ ’bout how

annotation.plain:
Ed isn’t kidding here. Psychological studies have pinpointed 20 reasons people fall in love, and most of them are pretty mysterious. These include keeping your hand and torso open when you talk, offering your date hot drinks instead of cold drinks, and walking at the same pace as they do.

These seemingly random causes for love prove Ed’s point: if two people are meant to be together their love will be triggered one way or another.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
When my hair’s all but gone and my memory fades
 And the crowds don’t remember my name
 When my hands don’t play the strings the same way, mmm
 I know you will still love me the same

annotation.plain:
In this verse, Ed reveals his fears extends beyond simply getting old. He’s also worried that he may lose his appeal when his fame starts to fade.

But as he explores those fears in this verse, his confidence seems to grow. Instead of asking his love questions, he begins to describe their future with assurance.



Ed’s grandfather suffered from Alzheimer’s disease as he mentioned on “Afire Love”, making him especially nervous about the toll old age can take on your body and memory.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And darlin’, I will be lovin’ you till we’re seventy
 And baby, my heart could still fall as hard at twenty-three

annotation.plain:
Ed’s desire to grow old with a partner is inspired by his parents' love. As he told UK publication Mirror,

My parents are so in love it’s ridiculous. I kind of look at it like pressure. They’ve cracked it and my grandparents cracked it – but nowadays it’s harder to find that. I hope to have kids.



Ed with his mother, brother, and father

Ed only says he’ll love her “til we’re seventy” because seventy rhymes with twenty-three – he’s not actually going to call off the marriage on her 70th birthday! (we hope)

annotations.lyric_fragment:
So honey, now, take me into your lovin’ arms
 Kiss me under the light of a thousand stars
 And place your head on my beatin’ heart, I’m thinkin’ out loud

annotation.plain:
Ed often uses the stars as a symbol for romance, naming another cut from x “All of the Stars”, which appeared on the soundtrack for The Fault In Our Stars.



Ed’s desire for a night with a thousand stars in the sky recalls an old Jimi Hendrix line.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Maybe we found love right where we are

annotation.plain:
This line is strongly associated with this song, but Ed has used the lyrics “we found love” before. On “Sing,” the first single from x, they had to go to a rave to find romance; here Sheeran celebrates a more mundane but also more sustaining love.

Musically, this has a strong resemblance to Van Morrison’s “Crazy Love”
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oeE7BOLB8Jc#t=0m33s

When music journalist Mark Kemp noted a “Van Morrison-like vibe,” Sheeran enthusiastically agreed.

“That’s exactly what I wanted to capture,” he says. “I feel like everyone channels Jack Johnson, everyone channels Prince, everyone channels the Beatles, and there’s not really anyone in popular culture now that has gone and channeled a bit of Van.”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
’Cause, honey, your soul could never grow old, it’s evergreen
 And baby, your smile’s forever in my mind and memory

annotation.plain:
In case you couldn’t tell by the name, evergreen trees don’t turn brown and decrepit in the winter. Ed’s love for this girl and memory of her features won’t fade over time, it will remain as vivid as the color on an evergreen.

Ed also dwells on his love for the tree in the January 2011 song, “Nightmare”:

Right now it’s better than it’s ever been
Never fade like a plant that’s evergreen

annotations.lyric_fragment: And I’m thinkin’ ‘bout stickin’

annotation.plain:
Mix explained the story behind this line to Vulture in 2013:

There was one change (producer Rick Rubin) suggested: ‘On your punch line, I need you to hit mute, and drop the music out so that people can hear what you’re saying. That’s gonna drive the song.’ That’s where ‘my anaconda don’t want none” or 'I’m thinkin’ about stickin’’ came from. As soon as he heard the finished track, he said, ‘People are gonna be talking about this twenty years from now.’

Mix told Vulture who he wrote the song about:

I’m not talking about women who are shaped like me, with a gut, but women who ran five miles a day, with a washboard, six-pack stomach and a nice round, beautiful, supple ass

Sprung means “when that person comes close to you, your heart starts fluttering, beating faster and harder, and it feels like it might explode out of your chest … you feel almost obsessed with them”. It could be also referring to having an erection “spring up” when looking at a woman with a small waist and large rear.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I’m tired of magazines sayin’ flat butts are the thing

annotation.plain:
In the early 90s when “Baby Got Back” was written, the “heroin chic” look was becoming popular as a reaction against the idealised and airbrushed models used in fashion photography during the 80s and curvaceous models such as Cindy Crawford or Claudia Schiffer.

This look was characterized by pale skin and angular bone structure and was the basis of look of the 1993 advertising campaign of Calvin Klein, featuring Kate Moss. The super-skinny size zero figure became the benchmark not just for aspiring models but for many young women, sparking extreme dieting, eating disorders and even fatalities.




Kate Moss on a 1993 Calvin Klein Ad Campaign

annotation.plain: Sir Mix-a-Lot thinks plastic is better suited for playthings than inside the bodies of women featured in Playboy, a popular men’s magazine that, around the time of this song’s release in 1992, was full of women whose impressive mammary glands were due to silicone breast implants.

One of the few songs about masturbation written by a woman, “I Touch Myself” paved the way for open discussion about female sexuality. This song could be considered to be a feminist piece of work.

Lead singer, Chrissy Amphlett’s death also brought forth the I Touch Myself project. It aims to bring awareness to breast cancer screening, hoping to catch cancer at an earlier stage.

annotation.plain:
As with the end of the first verse, Eve subliminally mentions ghostwriting, which is a cause and effect in the media.

She was interpreted to have dissed Lil' Kim and of course, Foxy Brown, believing that they don’t write their own lyrics. Eve previously had issues with them before.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Intro: Eve]

annotation.plain: The sample sounds eerily similar to Dr. Dre’s last track “The Message” from the 2001 album featuring Mary J Blige. Interestingly enough, “The Message” was the only track NOT produced by Dre on the album. It was instead produced by Bronx native Lord Finesse. Did Dre bite Lord Finesse’s synth line? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m7PiursH1AU

annotations.lyric_fragment: Red from blonde, yeah, bitch, I’m drastic

Before in her first album, Ruff Ryders' First Lady her hair was dyed blond.

Sometime between then and the release of her her second album Scorpion, she dyed her hair red.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
A lot of y’all Hollywood, drama, casted
 Cut bitch, camera off, real shit, blast it

annotation.plain:
Eve insinuates that others in the rap game are playing a role that isn’t real—but Eve is, and she’s the one whose tracks are blasting on the stereo.

Some speculate that this may be a diss to rapper Lil Kim—as a followup to the lyric “Some of y'all ain’t writing well, too concerned with fashion”.



Kim was indeed getting involved in fashion, attending many high-end shows and modeling for Baby Phat, at the time her sophomore album was being scrutinized for not being on par, lyrically, with her classic debut Hardcore. Kim was also involved in TV and movie roles at this time, and plenty of drama—like the infamous Hot 97 shootout with her crew.

annotations.lyric_fragment:

annotation.plain: This is meant that she might want help to fix his “love bipolar”, which is a term used when you are fluctuating between loving and hating someone, often in a relationship. Where in this song it’s meant, that she wants the fluctuation to stop.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
We used to be

annotation.plain: Just like how twins stereotypical think and act similar, she and her boyfriend shared the same thoughts and desires. When one wanted something, the other wanted the same thing. When one did something, the other would be there in support.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You’re hot, then you’re cold

annotation.plain: In earlier periods male and female sexuality was understood to lie along a continuum from hot to cold (Laqueur 1990).

annotations.lyric_fragment:

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Yeah, you PMS
 Like a bitch, I would know

annotation.plain:
PMS stands for Premenstrual syndrome, which refers to the physical and emotional symptoms that women go through in the days leading up to their period.

These include mood swings, such as being angry (or, pejoratively, “acting like a total bitch”).

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Stuck on a roller coaster
 Can’t get off this ride

annotation.plain:
As Katy uses the metaphor of the roller coaster, we come to the climax of the song. We come to realize that Katy is stuck in her relationship, and doesn’t with to leave it (yet).

Katy could also be alluding to the fact that roller coasters go “up and down”, which certainly relates to her fluctuating relationship.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You change your mind
 Like a girl changes clothes

annotation.plain:
This is a simile to show off the extent that this person cannot make and stick with a decision.  It uses the stereotype that women are often not satisfied with the way they look.

Ironically, Katy herself enjoys changing her clothes, especially when she is performing live.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
’Cause you’re hot, then you’re cold
 You’re yes, then you’re no
 You’re in, then you’re out
 You’re up, then you’re down
 You’re wrong when it’s right
 It’s black and it’s white
 We fight, we break up
 We kiss, we make up

annotation.plain:
The boy Katy’s dating is a huge contradicting hypocrite, at least in her opinion. Changing your mind a lot doesn’t really let other people trust you, and Katy struggles to trust the guy.

Perhaps the set of and pairing of the expressions pre-dates the movie, but in Runaway Bride, part of the dialogue is:

Random man: They love you, they hate you, they’re hot, they’re cold, they’re high, they’re low…
Ike: … They’re up, they’re down.

Perhaps that served as inspiration for this hook, especially given the fact that the music video features a wedding and a runaway groom.

annotations.lyric_fragment: 99 percent of my life, I was lied to

annotation.plain: Eminem was 25 when the ‘Slim Shady LP’, so for 24 years Eminem was lied to. Most likely people to lie to Eminem was Debbie Mathers, Kim Mathers, his teachers and bullies, and his brother (cause brothers fight).

annotations.lyric_fragment: I just found out my mom does more dope than I do (Damn)

annotation.plain:
Eminem has accused his mom of being a drug addict on numerous occasions, including on songs such as “My Mom” and “Cleanin' Out My Closet.”

But put yourself in my position, just try to envision
Witnessin’ your mama poppin’ prescription pills in the kitchen

This line in particular is one of the lines that caused Eminem’s mom, Debbie, to sue him for $10 million in 1999. She settled for $25,000, but ended up only walking away with $1,600.

At this time, Eminem was also using drugs, only recreationally at the time, but still says that his mom uses more than him.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
This guy at White Castle asked for my autograph (Dude, can I get your autograph?)
 So I signed it, “Dear Dave, thanks for the support, asshole”

annotation.plain:
White Castle is a hamburger restaurant chain.



Eminem comedically suggests that he doesn’t care about his fans, even though he does. This is a classic example of an Eminem lyric that doesn’t necessarily mean what the words suggest. However, he does get on a more serious note in the track “The Way I Am” which was released on his next album The Marshall Mathers LP.

And I’m thankful for every fan that I get
But I can’t take a shit
In the bathroom without someone standing by it
No, I won’t sign you an autograph
You can call me an asshole, I’m glad

This lyric was later referenced in the skit interlude of “Asshole” on his 2013 album The Marshall Mathers LP2 and even later in the poster of his Kamikaze album.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Hi, my name is, what? (Excuse me) My name is, who?
 My name is, chka-chka, Slim Shady
 (Can I have the attention of the class for one second?)
 Hi, my name is, huh? My name is, what?
 My name is, chka-chka, Slim Shady

annotation.plain:
In a clip from HBO’s The Defiant Ones, Dr. Dre and Eminem recap the first time they met and also how “My Name Is” was born.

While Eminem admitted he was a little star struck meeting Dre for the first time, thinking to himself: “Dude, I see you on T.V. all the time—you’re one of my biggest influences ever, in life,” Dre thought Eminem’s “shit was fucking incredible.”

When Em showed up to the studio for his first session, Dre had a beat ready featuring a sample of Labi Siffre’s 1975 song “I Got The….” Dre recalls playing the beat and within a matter of seconds, watching the “My Name Is” lyrics come out of Em’s mouth:

I was like, ‘Listen, man, I put this sample together, tell me if you like it,’ and I hit the drum machine, and then maybe two or three seconds went by, and he just went, ‘Hi, my name is, what? My name is, who?’ I’m like, ‘Yo, stop. Shit’s hot.’

Watch the full clip here:

https://players.brightcove.net/4863540648001/default_default/index.html?videoId=5503026503001

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I smoke a fat pound of grass, and fall on my ass
 Faster than a fat bitch who sat down too fast
 Come here, slut; “Shady, wait a minute, that’s my girl, dawg”
 I don’t give a fuck, God sent me to piss the world off

annotation.plain:
Slim is not the most flattering person ever, and this is a prime example of his twisted mind: he points out an overweight woman in the rudest way possible and then proceeds to seduce her away from her man.

Note that in the clean version of this song, “God” is replaced with “Dre”, most likely due to the relative cultural insensitivity of saying God’s name in vain.

Also when he says “Come here, slut; “Shady, wait a minute, that’s my girl, dawg”“ the phrase "girl, dawg” is a play on the word Bitch. Like the guy is at the same time saying “Shady, wait a minute, that’s my bitch”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Wanna copy me and do exactly like I did? (Yeah, yeah)
 Try ’cid and get fucked up worse than my life is? (Huh?)

annotation.plain:
Slim is sarcastically prompting his younger audience to view him as a Role Model although he clearly has all of the traits that depict him as the exact opposite of one.

“‘cid” is short for “acid”, the common nickname given to LSD, a very powerful drug that induces strong and vivid hallucinations.

Also note that at this point in time, Eminem’s life was miles from good: it was so messed up that it could be compared to the effects of taking LSD. Examples of how difficult his life was is seen throughout The Slim Shady LP (see “If I Had”, “Brain Damage”, and “Rock Bottom”)

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Hi, my name is, what? My name is, who?
 My name is, chka-chka, Slim Shady
 Hi, my name is, huh? My name is, what?
 My name is, chka-chka, Slim Shady

annotation.plain:
Dre put on the Labi Siffre record, and I was just like “Hi! My name is!” That beat was talking to me. I was like, “Yo, this is it, this is my shot. If I don’t impress this guy, I’m going back home and I’m fucked.” I knew Dre wasn’t an easy person to please. I made sure that everything he had a beat for, I had a rhyme ready to go, or I came up with a rhyme on the spot.

“My Name Is” was the first thing that came out of my mouth that first day I was at Dre’s house. I don’t know if we released what I did the first day or if I re-did it, but it was basically the same. I didn’t understand punching, or believe in it. So I would just go from the top of the song all the way down. I was never flying in hooks. Everything was live, one take. If I got all the way to the fucking end, and messed up the last word, I’d be like “Run it back, let’s do it again.” I remember Dre was like “Yo, are you fucking crazy? Let’s just punch.” I didn’t like that concept because I wasn’t used to it. When we were recording here in Detroit, in the beginning, I was saving up my money to go in. We only had an hour, you know? I’m like “One take down, alright, let’s go to the next song. Fuck it.” That’s what I was used to.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Produced by Dr. Dre]

annotation.plain:
“My Name Is” was the first song we recorded. We recorded three or four that day, in like six hours. One song was called “Ghost Stories” and one was “When Hell Freezes Over.” I feel like there was one more but I can’t remember what it was. We always have this discussion, because Dre says it’s four.

Paul used to live in New Jersey, right across from Manhattan. He had an apartment he shared with three roommates. I was over, sleeping on the couch. We didn’t have money yet, really. We had already filmed the video, and we saw it for the first time on MTV. It came on really late at night. I was sleeping on the couch when Paul saw it for the first time.

That’s when it was like, “Okay, this isn’t a joke anymore.” We had kind of felt that, being in the studio with Dre and shit. But once that single came out, my life changed like that. Within a day. Just going outside. I couldn’t go outside anymore. In a day. It went from the day before, doing whatever the fuck I wanted to do, because nobody knew who the fuck I was, to holy shit, people are fucking following us. It was crazy. That’s when shit just got really — it was a lot to deal with at once.

Right after the first single came out, I did a signing at the Virgin Megastore in Times Square. While I was there, I got served by a court processor. They knew where I’d be, and they had to physically serve me. The guy got tackled. He was stupid. You don’t need to physically serve someone anymore, like in the movies. But the guy was being a cowboy. It was some lawsuit from my mother, I think.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Instrumental Intro]

annotation.plain:
“I’m Not in Love” begins with tape loops of hundreds of multi-tracked vocals done by band members Kevin Godley, Lol Creme, and Graham Gouldman to create an airy, ethereal-sounding choir that remains present throughout the song, backed with the soft, heartbeat-like thump of a programed Moog synthesizer emulating a kick drum, played by Godley.

Although ambient music had been pioneered as far back as the early 20th century with composer Erik Satie’s “furniture music” as well as in Jamaica with the emergence of dub in the 1960s, with the genre truly coming into form with the music of Brian Eno, “I’m Not in Love"—with its experimental, tranquil backing and ethereal soundscape of vocals not totally dissimilar from a modern day synth pad—may very well be one of the first truly "ambient” songs, and perhaps one of the few examples of the genre to achieve commercial pop success, which is very rare.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’m not in love, no, no
 (It’s because)

annotation.plain: He’s in denial and is trying to think of excuses and is trying to convince other people that he’s not hurting even though he clearly is.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Be quiet, big boys don’t cry
 Big boys don’t cry
 Big boys don’t cry
 Big boys don’t cry
 Big boys don’t cry
 Big boys don’t cry...

annotation.plain:
This female voice in the middle eight belongs to 10cc’s secretary, Kathy Redfern.



Eric Stewart recalls:

Lol remembered he had said something into the grand piano mics when he was laying down the solos. He’d said ‘Be quiet, big boys don’t cry’ — heaven knows why, but I soloed it and we all agreed that the idea sounded very interesting if we could just find the right voice to speak the words. Just at that point the door to the control room opened and our secretary Kathy [Redfern] looked in and whispered ‘Eric, sorry to bother you. There’s a telephone call for you.’ Lol jumped up and said ‘That’s the voice, her voice is perfect!

Redfern was at first unconvinced and had to be persuaded into recording the vocal.

annotations.lyric_fragment: It’s just a silly phase I’m going through

annotation.plain:
Being in denial, you tell yourself that you’re just in a “silly phase” because the feelings are strange to you, but the feelings are true and you’re simply in love.

You could also interpret it on the flip, as in the “silly phase” is a burst out, to the coming to terms with being in denial, and realising he actually is in love, and to deny it is a “silly phase”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I keep your picture upon the wall

annotation.plain: The excuses that the singer uses to try and cover up his lies make it obvious that despite all their denial, they truly are in love.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I’m not in love, so don’t forget it

annotation.plain: The singer is both talking to the person he  is falling in love with and himself at the same time. He struggles to convince himself that he is not in love (or trying to make himself not fall in love). ]] Everyone has had times where they would have rather not fall in love with someone knowing the pain it might cause them.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
So if I call you, don’t make a fuss

annotation.plain: Often times, a phone call from that one special person drives people to take it as a sign that the feeling is mutual, and they go tell all of their friends. He doesn’t want this to be the case, because the phone call doesn’t mean anything to him.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I know you know it doesn’t mean that much to me

annotation.plain: They’re both in denial about their feelings for each other

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I like to see you, but then again

annotation.plain: These words mean this guy is in denial; he does not want to admit to himself or his romantic interest that they are the one. He is trying to explain away the deep feelings he has for them by diminishing their importance but his love for them shines through.

annotation.plain:
Cory Rooney: Troy Oliver, who is a co-writer and producer with me, was working on little ideas as I walked into the studio, and it was the beginnings of “Jenny from the Block.” I was said, “What is that? He was like, “Oh, nothing actually. I’m gonna erase it and start something new.” I had to jump across the room to stop him from erasing it. I loved it and played it for my little daughter who was six years old. I asked her, “Pick the songs that you like for Jennifer.”  She picked that one and “I’m Real.” Originally, the song was called “Jenny from the Bronx” and I felt like that was a little too corny, so I changed the lyrics and I changed it to “Jenny from the Block” and changed a few things to make it fit her more specifically. She loved it as soon as she heard that song.

http://www.latina.com/entertainment/music/cory-rooney-jennifer-lopez-interview?page=1

annotations.lyric_fragment: Does she walk? Does she talk? Does she come complete?

annotation.plain: These are the kinds of questions one might ask about a doll. Old toy commercials would say that a doll “comes complete with everything you see here,” meaning you didn’t have to buy extra accessories. And there have been various dolls that walk and talk, making them seem more realistic.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Baby-blues

annotation.plain: The lady has beautiful blue eyes

annotations.lyric_fragment:
To see her in that négligée
 Is really just too much

annotation.plain:
Négligée is a light dressing gown made of a thin, translucent fabric. Justman describes the girl’s wear as “négligée” to highlight the sexual nature of the photograph he is looking at in the magazine.

He also uses this bridge to further develop the theme that memories are frozen in the past and not always reflective of the present (and by extension that nothing can last forever.) By juxtaposing the last two lines of the section with the first two, Justman highlights the contrast between how he perceived his “homeroom angel” in his original memory and how he perceived her after seeing the photograph, again setting up the chorus which directly validates the theme with the line “my memory has just been sold.”

annotations.lyric_fragment: Angel is the centerfold

annotation.plain: This line of the chorus, because it’s missing the article in the sentence, implies that the crush’s name is also “Angel.” This is further reinforced by the song, “Angel in Blue” (also featured on this album), which features a similar motif in that chorus.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I hope that when this issue’s gone
 I’ll see you when your clothes are on

annotation.plain:
This is another play on words – Issue, as in problem, and issue, as in the issue of the magazine that he saw her in.

He hopes that when both of these have passed, he’ll be able to do exactly what he has said.

annotations.lyric_fragment: My angel is the centerfold

annotation.plain:
A centerfold is a two-paged portrait, mostly nude or pin-up. The term was coined by Hugh Hefner, who was the founder of the popular adult magazine Playboy.

The concept is now mostly recognized as something erotic, although multiple non-erotic magazines, such as Time and National Geographic, also feature it.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Now, listen
 It’s okay, I understand
 This ain’t no never-never land

annotation.plain:
Neverland is a fairytale island (ever heard of Peter Pan?) where children go and never grow up.

When he says this is NOT Neverland, he means the sweet girl he once knew eventually had to grow up and take responsibility.

He understands this is a part of life and accepts her choices.

The added ‘H’ to make it a Nah Nah is probably because of the group’s Boston origin…

Hey, you know they’re all the same
 You know you’re doin’ better on your own (On your own)
 So don’t buy in
 Live right now
 Yeah, just be yourself
 It doesn’t matter if it’s good enough (Good enough)
 For someone else

annotation.plain:
The protagonist is telling himself to be free from people’s expectations and judgment and live for yourselves. Life has to be lived fully. Sure, other people’s opinions have some value, but it’s ultimately your decision to do what you feel is right.

In the context of the band, the record executives wanted them to sound like the other bands on the radio, which obviously they did not want to do. Ultimately, it paid off for them, as they have enjoyed a lot of success over the years.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Just do your best (Just do your best)
 Do everything you can (Do everything you can)
 And don’t you worry what their bitter hearts (Bitter hearts)
 Are gonna say

annotation.plain: In spite of your doubts, fears, and insecurities, it’s time to press on, to live life, to trust that things will work out. It’s always too early to quit, as the saying goes. If you try your best and trust, the path will appear. Just ask Indiana Jones. Remember how he had to take the first step into the abyss?

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Hey, don’t write yourself off yet
 It’s only in your head, you feel left out (Feel left out)
 Or looked down on

annotation.plain:
Often, we are our own worst enemies. It’s easy to think that everyone believes what our deepest fears tell us about ourselves. Most of the time, that’s complete crap–we are our harshest critics and give up on ourselves long before others give up on us.

This fits well with the theme of adolescence in this song–learn to trust yourself and not only those around you–as well as the context of Jimmy Eat World, as they had to recover from losing their record label.

annotations.lyric_fragment:

 It’s only in your head, you feel left out
 Or looked down on
 Just try your best
 Try everything you can
 And don’t you worry what they tell themselves
 When you’re away

annotation.plain:
The literal meaning of the phrase “to write off” is to discredit or to give up on this particular person or thing.
These lyrics mean don’t think that you don’t have a future, because you have a purpose.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
It just takes some time
 Little girl, you’re in the middle of the ride
 Everything, everything will be just fine
 Everything, everything will be alright, alright

annotation.plain:
The “middle of the ride” refers to adolescence, the period in “the middle” of childhood and adulthood.



Also, within the context of the song, it’s reminding you that you may have hit a few snags, but life isn’t over yet. Don’t write yourself off, because it’s only the middle, not the end. There’s still plenty of time to achieve (insert goal here).

annotation.plain:

https://twitter.com/TPAIN/status/377794577475702784

Reaffirmed in a since-deleted 2017 tweet as well:

annotations.lyric_fragment: My niggas call me loco, down for armed trafficking

annotation.plain:
Arms trafficking is selling guns without a Federal Firearms License as a commercial business. Generally associated with the criminal underworld that Ross constantly refers to being the boss of.
“Automatic weapons on the floor but who can you call?”

annotations.lyric_fragment: Hardaway, cross ’em up

annotation.plain: The crossover is a move used in basketball to outmaneuver the competition, just as Snoop is doing in his line of work. Tim Hardaway is credited for the “killer crossover” back in his Golden State Warrior days.

annotation.plain: Gwen wants to fight the girl who has been calling her out. But she wants to do it with no rules. After school, at the bleachers, with no supervision from superiors. Very “fight club-esque”.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Bridge]

annotation.plain:
During an interview with Howard Stern, Gwen went into depth about the bridge of the song:

https://youtu.be/CsiHlv8NxIg?t=184

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Both of us wanna be the winner
 But there can only be one

annotation.plain: Stefani compares herself and Love to fired-up schoolkids, further elaborating on the song’s high school metaphor. In school, there’s often a popular mean girl (Love), but now the outcast is coming for her throne.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Let me hear you say, this shit is bananas
 B-A-N-A-N-A-S
 This shit is bananas
 B-A-N-A-N-A-S
 Again, the shit is bananas
 B-A-N-A-N-A-S
 This shit is bananas
 B-A-N-A-N-A-S

annotation.plain:
Continuing the theme, this is the most cheerleadery part of the song, where the call and response cheer actually happens. Rather than a boast or pep talk, Gwen brings it out to point out just how absurd this entire thing is. It’s also arguably her most iconic lyric of all time, helping young children everywhere learn how to spell bananas – essentially, with this bridge, Gwen became the Aretha Franklin of the 00s.

The “cheerleader” comment by Courtney Love is maddening to anyone: how can a washed up former star critique someone absolutely smashing her lane?

annotations.lyric_fragment: Ooh, this my shit, this my shit

annotation.plain: In the radio edit, Gwen never actually says “shit,” instead mouthing the word or covering her mouth. The edit matches more closely the song’s theme: the “petite cheerleader” could obviously never swear, but she does not even have to. The track alone is brutal enough.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
So I’m ready to attack, gonna lead the pack
 Gonna get a touchdown, gonna take you out
 That’s right, put your pom-poms down
 Getting everybody fired up

annotation.plain: Playing off of the “cheerleader” insult, Gwen strings out football references. The players score touchdowns while pom-pom girls get the audience fired up, ready to take back the game. The catch? Gwen is both the cheerleader and the artist, simultaneously leading and cheering on the defeat of people like Love.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
That’s right, I’m the last one standing
 And another one bites the dust

annotation.plain: This is an obvious reference to the Queen song “Another One Bites The Dust”, emphasized by the horns in the instrumental playing the riff.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
’Cause I ain’t no Hollaback Girl
 I ain’t no Hollaback Girl

annotation.plain:
In cheerleading, the head cheerleader will “holler,” and the rest of the squad “hollers back.”

So in response to Courtney Love deriding Stefani as a “cheerleader,” Stefani has playfully adapted cheerleader lingo to state that if she’s a cheerleader, she runs this shit. To emphasize the point, this song has a lot of catchy call-and-response material (e.g. “B-A-N-A-N-A-S”)

annotations.lyric_fragment: I heard that you were talking shit

annotation.plain:
The “you” is C-Love, referring to the cheerleader comment and the other derogatory things she’s said about Gwen and Gavin.



Love specifically referred to Stefani as a one-off “cheerleader,” a true insult to the woman who penned rights anthem “Just a Girl.”

This is intentionally genius and proves his genius over and over. His genius will never be doubted after anyone hears how genius this genius lyric is. It also has references to his great-grandfather who invented the clock.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Won’t you tell me, is that healthy, baby?

annotation.plain: This line referencing the health of the situation is in reference to the rhino nose stew he used to drink with his father on Safari as well as all of the cocaine seal loved to enjoy over the course of the production of the Batman movie. On top of this, this line might be the most meaningful line all of seals discography because it references seals great-grandfather. Seals great grandfather was the founder of clocks he was the first man to ever design a clock. No other man had found out the concept of time until seals grandfather came along with a big idea and a whole lot of planning.

annotations.lyric_fragment: To me, you’re like a growing addiction that I can’t deny

annotation.plain: This line has to do with the way seal felt watching his dad patrol the beautiful parts of Africa trying to poach God’s beautiful creatures. Seal from a young age watched his dad run with a very dirty crowd of poachers and animal abusers. He saw his dad become addicted to killing lions and white nose rhinos.

annotation.plain: Seal may be describing his own life as a lighthouse. The dark side is the ocean, a vast expanse of turbulence and the unknown. Before meeting this woman, this “light”, he was basically useless, as a lighthouse without light isn’t very practical. She lights the way for him and helps him navigate tricky situations (like a pitch black ocean).
