annotations.lyric_fragment:
You could have told me yourself
 That you love someone else

annotation.plain: As betrayed as he feels from his girl cheating on him, it hurts that much more that she didn’t tell him herself.

annotations.lyric_fragment: End my life, you see

annotation.plain: As stated above, values associated with toxic masculinity dictate that the narrator should not cry, but his sadness here is so overwhelming that he even considers suicide.

annotations.lyric_fragment: ’Bout your plans to make me blue

annotation.plain: “Blue” means sadness since tears are often illustrated with the color blue.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
People say believe half of what you see
 Son, and none of what you hear

annotation.plain:
There are two sides to every story, Marvin sings. When you see something going down (in this case, his woman cheating on him) you might not be getting the full picture, so don’t take things at face value. But when you hear gossip, don’t believe a word of it. Or, at least, that’s the advice people give.

This popular phrase that Marvin quotes in the song is one that has many different variations, but it is generally credited to Edgar Allan Poe in his short story The System of Dr. Tarr and Prof. Fether which was published in November of 1845.

“Believe nothing you hear, and only one half that you see.”

annotations.lyric_fragment: Honey, honey, yeah (Heard it through the grapevine, not much longer would you be my baby)

annotation.plain: This part is one of the main contributors to the song’s success. In the Marvin Gaye version, the song at this point suddenly changes from a generic Motown style into a thrilling psychedelic soul sound.

annotations.lyric_fragment: But these tears, I can’t hold inside

annotation.plain: Hearing that his girlfriend had cheated on him by hearing other people talk about it, Gaye has become so distressed and heartbroken that he just can’t prevent the tears from leaking out.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I know a man ain’t supposed to cry

annotation.plain: Generally, a man is made fun of by his peers for crying, no matter the reason. But by the next line, it’s apparent that Gaye just wants to let a bawl out.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I heard it through the grapevine

annotation.plain:
Songwriter Barrett Strong came up with this line while in Chicago. To him, people were always saying “I heard it through the grapevine”. Associating the phrase with a telegraph slaves used to use: a human grapevine.

The line is used in this song to refer to Marvin, or someone he portrays, finding out his romantic partner betrayed on him through people gossiping (through the “grapevine”).

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Chorus: JAY-Z]

annotation.plain:
Jay’s A&R man Kyambo Joshua wrote the hook, as he revealed during his 2016 Rap Radar Podcast episode:

I Wanna Rock had a song called “Big Pimpin'…” I just liked the word, big pimpin'. Timbaland had the beat, and Jay, he wasn’t really blown away… If I like it, and he don’t like it, he’ll tell me to come up with something for it; to come up with an idea, or come up with a hook… With “Big Pimpin'” it was like, I mean I knew from day 1 we gotta get UGK on it… I think I got a hook… I originally say some girl names, but we eventually said, you know, Bun B, whatever.

annotations.lyric_fragment:

annotation.plain:
Jay would compare himself to assassins later on the record, yet here he compares only his heart to the lack of empathy a trained and hired killer possesses. Assassins are known to be incredibly patient, and waiting can be a huge part of their job.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You know I
 Thug ’em, fuck ’em, love ’em, leave ’em
 ‘Cause I don’t fuckin’ need ’em

annotation.plain:
From Decoded:

This is my take on a classic piece of pimpology, Pretty Tony’s riff in the movie The Mack: “Just like my hoes, I keep em broke. They wake up one morning with some money, they subject to go crazy. I keep em looking good, pretty and all that, but no dough.” These lines have been referred to a lot in hip hop, but it’s not meant to endorse actual pimping, that was never my thing. Pretty Tony’s delivery is so slick, the slang is so dead-on, the exaggeration so outrageous, and the sentiment so pure and distilled, that as riduclous as the words are, it still comes off real. It’s fucked up and mesmerizing, it’s also comedy. I was trying to get some of that feeling in this song.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Produced by Timbaland]

annotation.plain:
The song samples “Khusara” by Abdel Halim Hafez. The original track was produced by Egyption composer Baligh Hamdy.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4PmyTqM0xuE

In an interview with Drink Champs show, Timbaland revealed that even though he got the clearance for the sample from the composer hiers and paid them, they still tried to sue him and JAY-Z when the record proved to be a smash hit.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Verse 2: Bun B]

annotation.plain:
Bun B on his verse:

“In the South, I’m regarded as the guy who, quote unquote, out-rapped Jay-Z. A lot of Southern rappers would say that. Not saying that I’m a better rapper than Jay-Z, but I was able to out-rap Jay-Z on a track. The reality is that I probably took that song [“Big Pimpin’”] a whole lot more seriously than Jay-Z. Because that was a lackadaisical, laid-back party track, and I attacked it. You know, for me, I’m a rapper. And I’m on it with Jay-Z.”

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Verse 3: Pimp C, Bun B]

annotation.plain:
When ranking his own albums through 2013, Jay-Z specifically cited this verse as one of Vol. 3’s high points (along with “So Ghetto”).

But Pimp C was hardly eager to hop on this track! He feared fans wouldn’t like him working with a mainstream rapper and he even hated the beat at first, saying, “This got a lotta flutes man, I don’t know about them flutes, man.”

Bun B and Jay-Z eventually talked him into recording, but Pimp C agreed only on the condition that he would rap just eight bars. But what a memorable eight bars they were, with elements of this verse eventually used by:



Kenrick Lamar on “Blow My High (Members Only”) (2011)

Timbaland on “Triple Threat” (2012)

Isaiah Rashad on “Free Lunch” (2016)

Pimp C himself on “Pourin’ Up” (2006)

Wow! Oh, let me be your sledgehammer

annotation.plain: Suggests the idea of being a powerful force or advocate, incorporating courtroom and legal imagery, and plays on the old definition of “testimony,” which historically involved swearing an oath while holding one’s testes (the testicles).

annotations.lyric_fragment: If you bring your blue sky back

annotation.plain: A “blue sky” is usually seen as bright and cheerful. The singer wants the cheerfulness of the person he is trying to talk to.

He’s asking the girl to show him “the goods” and she’ll get to see his in return.

Probably a stretch, but show for also sounds like chauffeur, which plays into the car and driving foreplay. He could be offering her to drive his car…

annotations.lyric_fragment: I wanna be your sledgehammer

annotation.plain: A sledgehammer fits in with the other phallic metaphors used in the song, with the added implication that he’d be a particularly big shake-up to what she’s used to.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You could have an aeroplane flying

annotation.plain: The fuselage of most aircraft is generally phallic in shape, and those that fly via jet engines have their power measured in thrust. So this line is yet another potent metaphor for the act of coitus

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I get it right
 I kicked the habit (Kicked the habit, kicked the habit)
 Shed my skin (Shed my skin)
 This is the new stuff (This is the new stuff)
 I go dancing in (We can go dancing in)

annotation.plain:
One interpretation of this song is that it represented Peter Gabriel embracing pop music. When he was in Genesis, Peter Gabriel was writing intricate and progressive musical pieces, and performing elaborate shows with detailed costumes and over-the-top performances. His departure from the band ultimately stemmed from his opposition to the poppier, hit-oriented music the rest of the band was embracing.

Over the course of his solo career, Peter Gabriel eventually grew more into pop himself. He compares the simple, satisfying feeling of pop music to sex. By leaving behind prog, he “kicked the habit”, and “shed his skin”, reinventing his own identity as a musician.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Open up your fruit cage

annotation.plain: Although a “fruit cage” is not an especially common English language term, it refers to an agricultural cage in which fruit is grown, either on a large-scale commercial basis or in an individual’s garden. In this case it’s safe to say that he is referring to the place in which the fruit of man is grown (the female womb) and requesting that the entrance to said cage (the vulva) be opened for him

annotations.lyric_fragment: Put your mind at rest

annotation.plain: After orgasm, both men and women release the chemicals oxytocin, prolactin, gamma amino butyric acid (GABA), and endorphins that work to tell the body and mind to relax after sex. Peter is reassuring the subject of his wooing, that her post-coital disposition will be one of deep mindful relaxation

annotation.plain: While depicted usually (even here) as a romantic, great escape for lovers place, there may be a hint of exhibitionism here – “making love” with “people walking above”….

The song is a guy recounting an affair in a summer vacation – probably could have been told by millions with slight variations.

Still – a nice tribute to (probably Atlantic City, NJ).

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Intro]

annotation.plain:
Isaac Hayes said in 1994 that the famous hi-hat intro was inspired by his own arrangement on Otis Redding’s “Try a Little Tenderness”:

In the end [of Otis' song], Al Jackson was doing some stuff on the high-hat, some – you know, “You got to (vocalizing)”, you know. So I thought about that. I said, maybe if I just sustain that particular thing on the high-hat, that would give you a dramatic effect as something that’s relentless.

Regarding the wah-wah, he said:

I thought about the guitar lick. And I went and pulled it out, played it. And Charles Pitts – we call him Skip. He played the thing on the wah-wah. I said, hey. Play this line. And he started it. And I told Willie [Hall], the drummer … I said, give me that high-hat, man, some 16 notes, you know? (Vocalizing). And he did that. And it worked. I said, that’s the kind of dramatic effect I want. Then, I start putting the other things in – you know, the bass, the accents and all that stuff.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Black private dick

annotation.plain: Hayes plays with the slang term “private dick” (meaning private investigator) to play on Shaft’s sexual prowess

annotations.lyric_fragment: Who is the man that would risk his neck for his brother man?

annotation.plain:
Dectective"Shaft" film, is your most typical 70’s fiction icon from the Black Power movement in that era. More specifically Shaft should be placed under or as Blaxplotation, or the fiction and movies that exploits  Blackpower, Black dominance, but sometimes stereotypes (the fact he is basically named after a penis, I mean for real?) via characters like Shaft, who attract a  black demographic Hmmm, sounds familiar, Right?

However contrary to Madea, Shaft, almost, could be considered the first black superhero as he fought for justice on his terms, and stuck up for those without a voice. “Shaft ain’t the hero Gotham need, but the one it deserve.”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
A thousand miles seems pretty far
 But they’ve got planes, and trains, and cars

annotation.plain: This line possibly references the 1987 comedy film Planes, Trains and Automobiles which stars Steve Martin and John Candy. The film centers around the various mishaps that are faced during two men’s trip from New York City to Chicago, which are the very two cities this song is about.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Times Square can’t shine as bright as you

annotation.plain:
Times Square is well known for being strewn with lights and massive screens – it’s well-lit, to say the least. But in the singer’s eyes, even the excessive LEDs of the city cannot surpass Delilah’s beauty.



The comparison is particularly appropriate considering Times Square is located in New York City, where Delilah is said to be living.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Hey there, Delilah, you be good, and don’t you miss me
 Two more years and you’ll be done with school, and I’ll be making history
 Like I do

annotation.plain: He’s telling her not to miss him as best as she could since the separation is tough enough as it is. He’s saying this so she can be cheerful and optimistic that she will see him again really soon. In the meantime, until they are together permanently and in the same state, she is in school getting her life together so when they are living together, it’ll be easy for her to get a job and then they can start their life together. (He’ll be making history because he’s the lead singer of the band)

annotations.lyric_fragment: Hey there, Delilah, what’s it like in New York City?

annotation.plain: Delilah DiCrescenzo attended Columbia University in New York City on a sports scholarship.

annotation.plain:
https://youtu.be/bYaLqGD6Kr8?t=2m24s

Cherrelle revealed in the interview about that she disliked this song but did it because of Jimmy & Terry persuading her and made her aware that this hit could create a career for her.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
It’s been a long time
 I didn’t think I was going to see you again
 I see you haven’t changed
 It’s good to see you anyway

annotation.plain:
Cherrelle’s monologue here helps continue the loose narrative of being on-and-off lovers. This story stretches across her duets with Alexander O'Neal.

After two years passes between this and their next hit song together, “Never Knew Love LIke This,” Cherrelle adopts the same tone of voice to coo “and I’ve sure been missed.”

annotations.lyric_fragment: Let’s sing it together

annotation.plain:
Cherrelle would reprise this spoken line for another hit duet from this pair with “Never Knew Love Like This” from Alexander O'Neal’s 1987 album Hearsay.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday
 Thursday, Friday, Saturday love
 Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday
 Thursday, Friday, Saturday love

annotation.plain:
If you ever thought the chorus of this song was elementary, so did its songwriter Jimmy Jam:

I sat down and I came up with the chords and stuff… and then in my mind, I started thinking “Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturdayyy love” and I thought “Wow, this is cool. This is great!” So then I went to the studio later. Terry was there. I said, “Terry, I got this idea!” …and I instantly thought, “This is the dumbest idea ever… This is Sesame Street. This is so stupid.”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
So come on and give it to me anyway you can
 Anyway you wanna do it
 I’ll take it like a man

annotation.plain:
Renown music critic Robert Christgou famously wrote in his review of the song that “Mickey” made Basil “the only woman ever to offer to take it up the ass on Top 40 radio,” based on this lyric.

In 2012, Basil told Vulture:

People also think ‘Mickey’ is about butt-fucking! … NO! That’s ridiculous. Everyone reads shit into everything. It’s not about anything dirty. You change the name from boy to girl and they read anything they want into it! When it’s a guy singing about a girl, it’s a sweet line. But when a girl sings it, it must mean butt-fucking!"

annotations.lyric_fragment: Don’t wanna break your heart, wanna give your heart a break

annotation.plain: Demi is making a play on words here. To give someone a break means to stop putting pressure on them – to let them relax. To break someone’s heart, of course, is to make them sad with the downfall of a relationship. So Demi is telling their love interest that they have no interest in breaking his heart – what they really want is to let his heart be happy in a relationship with them.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
There’s just one life to live and there’s no time to wait, to waste
 So let me give your heart a break (Let me give your heart)

annotation.plain: Demi hearkens the famous sentiment “‘Tis better to have loved and lost / Than to never have loved at all” from Tennyson in these lines. Being that they only have one chance at life, she reasons that she can be the one to alleviate any pain previous caused by love, but he must act NOW!

annotations.lyric_fragment:
But now that I get you
 I know fear is what it really was

annotation.plain: Demi’s hopeful lover only scoffed at the thought of love because it’d been a painful experience for him in the past, and he wants to shield himself from that happening again.

annotations.lyric_fragment: For the price of a dime

annotation.plain: In the US, the ten cent coin is called a dime. In the early ‘80s, when “Jenny” was written, public payphones usually charged ten cents–a dime–to make a phone call.

annotation.plain: After failing to call Jenny, the singer attempted to play out a sexual encounter between them in his mind.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I know you think I’m like the others before
 Who saw your name and number on the wall

annotation.plain:
It is a typical occurrence to see someone’s phone number on a bathroom stall, especially if the stall is in a filthy gas station. This number will typically be accompanied by a message such as “for a good time call…” (as stated later in the song.)

Tommy has found this number, but wishes to express to Jenny that he is not some hot and bothered sleazeball like the other men who have seen her phone number in this bathroom. He is ready for a real relationship. This line also makes him sound quite desperate, trying for a relationship at every turn.
Jenny’s (now infamous) phone number, that continued to receive prank calls decades after the song was released.

 Like you was just another shorty I put the naughty on

annotation.plain:
“Frontin'” was released in 2003, which was coincidentally around the same time rumors of Jay-Z and Beyoncé’s relationship started to gain momentum. In April 2003, when asked in a Playboy interviewwhether Beyoncé was his love interest, Hov’s response was, “We’re just cool. We’re just friends."

In the same year Hov would not only play Beyoncé’s love interest in her “Crazy In Love” music video, but would also drop the famous “Hottest chick in the game wearin' my chain” line on his song “Public Service Announcement” on The Black Album that would release later that year in November 2003.

annotations.lyric_fragment: While you spottin’ and grinnin’ with a bunch of foxy women

annotation.plain: “Foxy Women” is a diss track towards the 90s/2000s female rapper “Foxy Brown”. Foxy Brown and Lil Kim went to the same high school and were on friendly terms, soon after their fame started to rise, and their popularity started to grow, their bond turned into beef.  They had many diss tracks toward each other, in Lil Kim’s album “Notorious K.I.M.” and Foxy brown had a verse in Capone-N-Noreaga’s “Bang Bang” that same year, her verse had some lines meant for Lil Kim. The photo shown down below was before their feud.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Want a cheap trick, better go down to FreakNik

annotation.plain:
Freaknik was an annual Spring Break bacchanalia where students from HBCUs would meet up in Atlanta, GA to party, have rap battles, dance-offs, and basketball tournaments.

Kim’s reference to Freaknik contrasts her status as a high-class player with multiple partners against the anonymous sleeping around of college students just out for a good time.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Little Kim the Queen Bee, so you best take heed

annotation.plain:
Lil' Kim is the original Queen Bee! Kim came in the rap game and quickly became one of the most successful female rappers of all time selling 20 million records and 30 million singles. She has hits all over the world and her run in Hip-Hop/Fashion and her crazy red carpet appearances influenced newer artists like Rihanna, Beyonce, Nicki Minaj, and Lady Gaga.

Kim is telling everyone who listens to pay their respect to her and honor her achievements because they are not easy to achieve.

annotation.plain: “Sea Breeze” is a bus station in Brooklyn, while “PV” is short for “MPV,” as in Mazda MPV, a van that was popular among street crews in the 90s. This comparison is intended to highlight Lil' Cease’s swagger: he’s cruising in his decked out PV while you’re running to catch the bus. See ya!

annotations.lyric_fragment: (True)

annotation.plain: Lil' Kim’s cooed “truuuue” in the call-and-response hook this song is as important and recognizable as the remainder of Biggie’s verse. However, many may not recognize that this hallmark was likely borrowed from triangle-afroed rapstress Bahamadia whose 1995 single “Uknowhowwedu” from her debut album Kollage featured the same playful feminine response to its male-spit hook.

Watching every motion in my foolish lover’s game

annotation.plain: This metaphor for longing might be quite literal in the context of Top Gun, where the protagonist is a Naval aviator deployed on the other side of the world from his home base – and in this song, from his lover, hanging her desire on her memories of him and his last words and (distant) known positions.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Through the hourglass, I saw you
 In time, you slipped away
 When the mirror crashed I called you
 And turned to hear you say
 “If only for today, I am unafraid”

annotation.plain:
In the context of Top Gun, this song is about the inherent tension of a military relationship. One partner may be deployed for many months out of the year, or for years at a time, affording precious little contact with family (especially in the 1980s).

This can take an exasperating psychological toll on the spouse of a warfighter, who is often forced to confront not only loneliness but profound fears of abandonment and jealousy.

But it can be just as difficult for the “away” partner, who may need to process these issues as well as the myriad traumas of military conflict.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Told you from the jump I’d only choose ya

annotation.plain: Basically, I’m the one to choose. When I’m right, I know I’m right. When I’m wrong, I know I’m wrong. It might take me a minute, but I know I’m wrong. But when I’m right, I’m right. So “Told you from the jump, I’d always choose you"—I told you I was going to be the one, basically. And here I am, the one.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And everything you want, you ain’t gotta ask for
 You got me boo’d up, boo’d up

annotation.plain: It’s like reassurance, but that’s also building trust. You have to definitely let the person know, and again, that’s communication as well. You have to reassure people and let them know, “I’m still here,” even if you’re not going through a bad situation. Even just telling someone, “I love you” before it’s too late. Even outside of a romantic relationship, like family. Just telling people you love them and showing your love for anyone you love is very important because you never know. It also feels good when someone says, “I love you,” or someone explains to you how they feel.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I wanna build this love

annotation.plain: Trust is definitely number one. Without trust, there’s no point; you can’t move forward. I think trusting, communication, being honest, which is, again, part of trusting; I think it’s definitely something you have to take one step at a time. I don’t think there is something that you can put in chronological order to say, “Right, this is what we do. And we’re going to take it off the checklist.” Every one situation is completely different, but trust, I would say, is the number one thing.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Head over heels in love
 Right in front of you, ain’t gotta look no more, baby (Hah)

annotation.plain: I’m a strong believer of when you go out searching for something, you don’t really find exactly what you’re searching for. Because I think you’re too concentrated on number one, number two, number three, number four—all these different things. That perfection doesn’t exist. So, if you go out searching for something that you have to take off all these different boxes, you’re not going to find someone that takes off every single box, because that just doesn’t exist, right? When you don’t look for it, and it just kind of comes out of nowhere and surprises you, it almost feels like all those boxes are ticked anyway, even if there’s something at the bottom of the list that isn’t it, but it’s just, again, the feeling of love. I think love in general can definitely sweep you off your feet, and that’s why I say, “Head over heels in love. Right in front of you. Ain’t gotta look no more.” It’s like you don’t have to search anymore. If you were searching, you don’t have to search anymore. And even if you don’t, you don’t have to search anymore because I’m not going anywhere.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Oh, how many ways can I say that I need you? Baby, it’s true
 I think I might die without you

annotation.plain: Obviously, if your heart stops beating, you die. You stop breathing, you die, and you no longer exist. I feel like sometimes you can be so in love with someone, or just infatuated with someone, that you feel like if they leave, what are you going to do? Like there’s nothing left for me to do. When, of course, there is, but that feeling again is, “If I don’t have you, then I don’t know how I’ll do with myself.” Especially when you get so used to a situation, as well, and you’re like, “This is what I’m used to. I’ve been with you for however many years, blah blah blah, I’m used to this.” Then all of a sudden, for argument’s sake again, they’re not there. Then you feel like you might as well not be there either. It can be very hard, but we’re sticking to the positive side of love here.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
That get me high like you do, yeah, yeah
 Ooh, no, I’ll never get over you until I find something new
 That get me high like you do

annotation.plain: I definitely think love is a drug. It’s something that you can be so caught up on for so long, and I think that’s also why people stay in good relationships, and that’s why people stay in bad relationships, because it’s almost like an addiction. You get addicted to the person, and you can’t let go of them, especially when you’ve been together for years and years and years. There’s just so much history and it’s hard to detach yourself. I feel like sometimes love overrides your mind: your brain and your thinking process.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Ooh, no, I’ll never get over you until I find something new

annotation.plain: It’s almost like you begin to believe that this is like a fairy talk, or it’s almost too good to be true. Then you start to think down the line of, “Wow, now I have this to compare everything else to. For argument’s sake, god forbid, it doesn’t work out in this situation, the next person I find, if they’re not showing me the same feelings, and I’m not feeling the same way about them as I feel about you, then I’m never going to get over you.”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Feelings, so deep in my feelings
 No, this ain’t really like me
 Can’t control my anxiety
 Feeling, like I’m touching the ceiling
 When I’m with you, I can’t breathe
 Boy, you do something to me

annotation.plain:
The line “This ain’t really like me” is because I don’t like to put myself in vulnerable situations. I don’t wear my heart on my sleeve. I’m very guarded and I’m an over-thinker. If I get into a situation and something doesn’t feel right, I’ll automatically close my doors. Which is a good and a bad thing in some situations, but the reason I said “No, this ain’t really like me” is because when you get into that first initial stage of really liking someone and falling for them, I think everyone, being human, has their doubts where they’re like, “Maybe I’m falling too fast, maybe the other person doesn’t feel the same way. I don’t know what it really is.”

I am still quite young; I’m 23, so I’ve only been in two real relationships. I can’t really explain it and I find it really hard to explain love as well and explain your feelings because I feel like it’s kind of better left unsaid; It’s just a feeling. If you know it and the person knows it; that’s what the whole song is, really. Just everything I haven’t had before and all the new experiences that I hadn’t experienced before in a relationship. I didn’t know what it was, so I couldn’t really say “Okay, it’s this, it’s that.” I just had this feeling, but I didn’t know what it was.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Pigeon from hell

annotation.plain:
A scathing indictment of the paparazzi, introduced in the previous line with the reference to the tabloid, “The News of the World.” As the comment to that reference suggests, the tabloid culture invaded the privacy—and embittered the lives of—the speaker and her companions (quite likely the band itself).

The image of a pigeon is surely intended to invoke the idea of a messenger pigeon—sent from a specific location to deliver a specific message. Of course, the speaker’s house isn’t the destination for the message. In this case, the goal is to get a story there—about the speaker and the band—and pass it along to the  masses. But the entire enterprise is evil. The pigeons who pass along the message are just part of a much more monstrous system of greed that preys on celebrities and the lust for scandal. They and everyone else who engineers this evil–those who finance the tabloids, the customers who pay to read them, etc.–are all part of hell.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homing_pigeon

annotations.lyric_fragment: Chain gang

annotation.plain:
A Chain Gang is a group of convicts who are chained together while they do manual labor, usually outside.
https://www.google.com/search?tbm=isch&q=Chain%20Gang

annotations.lyric_fragment:
The powers that be that force us to live like we do
 Bring me to my knees when I see what they’ve done to you

annotation.plain:
Drug addiction forces people to behave in ways they normally wouldn’t and changes personalities. Farndon was sacked because the drugs had made him aggressive and confrontational and he refused to get treatment. Two days after losing Farndon, Honeyman-Scott was dead from an overdose.

In her memoir Reckless, Hynde says that she “never got over losing Pete, never talking to him again” and that she coped with Honeyman-Scott’s death by imagining what he would do every time she had to make a decision.

annotations.lyric_fragment: News of the world

annotation.plain:
News of the World was a British tabloid newspaper, once very popular, that went out of business in 2011. It specialized in scandal, celebrity news, and splashy, provocative headlines. This line could have a double meaning: The world itself intruded in their lives with unwanted information – or paparazzi and nosy media intruded in their relationship.



Queen also used the name of this newspaper for their hit 1977 album.

songs.lyrics:

The glory that was Rome is of another day
I've been terribly alone and forgotten in Manhattan
I'm going home to my city by the Bay

I left my heart in San Francisco
High on a hill, it calls to me
To be where little cable cars climb halfway to the stars

annotations.lyric_fragment:
My love waits there in San Francisco
 Above the blue and windy sea
 When I come home to you, San Francisco
 Your golden sun will shine for me

annotation.plain:
This song was written by George Cory and Douglass Cross as they were longing for San Francisco upon moving to New York City.

Prior to Tony Bennett signing the song, it was pitched to [Tennessee Ernie Ford](



Bennett sang the song for the first time at The Fairmont Hotel atop Nob Hill in San Francisco. Mayor George Christopher and future mayor Joe Alioto were in attendance.

The 1962 record of the year Grammy winner is a timeless classic heard all over the world.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You won’t get no nookie or the cookies

annotation.plain:
In this line, Ciara is referencing the Limp Bizkit song “Nookie”.

Nookie and cookies are both slang terms for sexual intercourse.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
If you’re lookin’ for the goodies
 Keep on lookin’, ’cause they stay in the jar

annotation.plain:
In an interview with Genius, this song’s producer, Lil Jon, stated that the word “goodies” replaced the word “cookies” in this final version of this song. Ciara and fellow songwriter, Sean Garrett presented the original “cookies” version of the song to the producer and he and his friend voiced their dislike with the word choice of “cookies”, and advised that the writers change the word to another one and they came up with the word “goodies” instead.

The jar Ciara is speaking of is a cookie jar, which makes sense when she was talking about cookies in the original lyric, not so much in this final rendition of these lyrics.

annotation.plain: The song interpolates the 1968 song “(You) Got What I Need” recorded by Freddie Scott, whose basic chord and melody provided the base for the song’s chorus and made it famous.

annotation.plain:
Biz told EW:

I wasn’t supposed to sing the [chorus]. I asked people to sing the part, and nobody showed up at the studio, so I did it myself.

This hook was based on Freddie Scott’s “You Got What I Need”

annotations.lyric_fragment: I asked her her name, she said: “Blah-blah-blah”

annotation.plain: Biz Markie has said that “Just a Friend” is based on a real personal experience, but he wanted to censor the name of his past crush in order not to put her in trouble.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I started throwin’ bass, she started throwin’ back mid-range

annotation.plain: Biz Markie is punning on the phrase “throwing bass” (chatting up a girl), by using its literal meaning: he is speaking in a low tone, and the girl he’s speaking to is speaking in a higher tone.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Oh, snap!

annotation.plain:
This phrase of Biz Markie saying “Oh, snap!” was a big internet meme back in the day, so popular it was the premise of this radio shack ad:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h-n5W9exsOU

It has a history for multiple youtuber sound effects.

Know your meme says: ““Oh snap!” catchphrase is an indication of surprise or can be used to follow an insult. ”

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h8cN6wZFDA8

annotations.lyric_fragment: I’m a model, you know what I mean

annotation.plain:
Fred Fairbrass told The Guardian:

I came up with the “I’m a model, you know what I mean” stuff because I was dating a model. It was the start of the supermodel era, things were very hedonistic and I was thinking of big hair and dressing to impress.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’m too sexy for my shirt
 Too sexy for my shirt

annotation.plain:
This line was the genesis of “I’m Too Sexy”. While the group was looping a bass line at a friend’s studio, Richard Fairbrass spontaneously come up with the line:

…right out of the blue – I can’t tell you where it came from – I started singing ‘I’m too sexy for my shirt’ and we all fell about laughing.

annotations.lyric_fragment: ’Cause I know these niggas after where the bag at

annotation.plain: I think what he’s saying here might relate to the previous line. My idea is that Roddy Ricch got successful, but back in Compton he’s still got friends and family participating in gang activity, so he cruises in a bulletproof Cadillac because they are where the bag at, meaning they may rob him.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
The private I’m flyin’ in, I never wan’ fly again
 I’ll take my chances in traffic (Yeah)

annotation.plain:
Roddy Ricch highlights the drawbacks of fame and luxury. He feels that flying in a private jet, which many would see as a dream, has become burdensome or uncomfortable for him. By saying he’d rather “take my chances in traffic,” he implies that he prefers the unpredictability of everyday life over the pressures and isolation that come with his celebrity status. This reflects a deeper commentary on the costs of success and the desire for a more authentic experience.

Roddy often explores these themes in his other songs too. For instance, in “War Baby,” he talks about the pressure and the darker side of fame, mentioning feelings of loneliness and paranoia. In “Every Season,” he captures the transition from a difficult past to a more prosperous present while still grappling with the realities of his new life. These elements reinforce the sentiment in “The Box” about the complexities of fame and longing for authenticity amidst the glitz.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Yeah, come on
 Hey ladies
 Hey ma (Wassup?)

annotation.plain:
The lyrics are delivered antiphonally as call and response lines – “Hi” is followed by “Sup”?!

According to Wikipedia,

In Sub-Saharan African cultures, call and response is a pervasive pattern of democratic participation—in public gatherings in the discussion of civic affairs, in religious rituals, as well as in vocal and instrumental musical expression. It is this tradition that African bondsmen and women brought with them to the New World and which has been transmitted over the centuries in various forms of cultural expression—in religious observance; public gatherings; sporting events; even in children’s rhymes; and, most notably, in African-American music in its myriad forms and descendants including: gospel, blues, rhythm and blues, rock and roll, jazz and hip hop.

annotations.lyric_fragment: My boo be’s real (She’s real)

annotation.plain: Cam'ron is playing with a phrase from a few lines up, “boobies real”. These two phrases are homophones: they have the same pronunciations, but different meanings. The first time he says it, he means she doesn’t have breast implants. This time, he’s just saying she’s real in the more general sense of the term – she’s chill and authentic, she’s honest about her lifestyle, she keeps it real.

Since it was the 60’s, drugs and sex were on everybody’s name (aside from war, space and social injustice), and a few lines made some think about the song in a weird fashion.

Some thought that this line was to hint that the singer was pregnant…
As mentioned in the comment below – very unlikely since it was an all male band.

Another one that “stimulated” their conspiracy theories was “you’re such a sweet thing
Good enough to eat thing”.

‘nuff said.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Peaches and cream

annotation.plain:
In a song which is a collection of cliches, this one fits perfectly.

While peaches and cream is a great dessert, it usually means “Of facial complexion, smooth, unblemished, with attractive yellow-pink coloring”, and in the song, another superlative to describe this deep seated love.

It takes two to do “business.” This could mean anything from sex (between Rob Base and the ladies who love him) to hip-hop (between MC Rob Base and DJ E-Z Rock).

“Outta sight” isn’t literal here, it’s slang for “amazing”.

The hook is sampled from Lyn Collins' 1972 single “Think (About It)” as is the looped ‘Woo! Yeah’ refrain throughout.

annotations.lyric_fragment: That when she passes, each one she passes goes “ah!”

annotation.plain: Clever double meaning; People say “ah” when they are scared, but also when they want to express pleasure. So in this case, the girl from impanema is sneaking up on people (probably from behind) and startling them (grabbing their shoulders and/or yelling “boo)”. Victims experience a sense of fear, but, in realizing the beauty of the delinquent, are quickly overcome with a warm and gentle delight. Ah!

annotations.lyric_fragment: Tall and tan and young and lovely

annotation.plain: Stan sing about Heloísa Eneida Paes Pinto Mendes Pinheiro, who is now a model, which he saw go get cigarettes for her mother.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Oh, but he watches her sadly
 How can he tell her he loves her?
 Yes, he would give his heart gladly
 But each day when she walks to the sea
 She looks straight ahead not at he

annotation.plain:
This is the B section of the song, which is very noticable due to the chords being used and the lyrics.

Notice how in the verses the person singing is looking at a woman walking on the beach of Ipanema. However in this bridge section the lyrics become more reflexive and the singer starts comtemplating.

The chords being used in this section are strange to analyze when applying western music theory. This is very typically bossa nova, which makes is very distinguishable from other music styles.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Verso 1: João Gilberto]

annotation.plain:
Translated from Portuguese:

Look what a beautiful thing and full of grace
She, the girl who comes and who goes
On a sweet swing on the way to the sea
Golden body girl of the Ipanema sun
Your swing is more than a poem
It is the most beautiful thing I have ever seen.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And when she passes he smiles
 But she doesn’t see

annotation.plain:
The girl from Ipanema, although being quite a lovely girl, has no idea that the writers of the song admire her gorgeous appearance each day.

Composer Antônio Carlos Jobim and poet Vinícius de Moraes were hanging out in Rio de Janeiro in the early 60’s when they first laid eyes on Heloísa Eneida Menezes Paes Pinto Pinheiro (also known as Helô). Helô was probably one of the most beautiful women in all of Brazil, and did not care for any of the men (especially older ones) that stared at her all day while she was on the beach.

Having this as the last line in the single version really hammers home the tone of somber lonesomeness despite being in paradise. Although the girl is the most beautiful thing the songwriter has ever seen, he can’t do anything about it. He shows that even when we are at the beautiful beaches of Rio, we are still affected by loneliness.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Refrão: João Gilberto]

annotation.plain:
Translated from Portuguese:

Oh, why am I so alone?
Oh, why is everything so sad?
Ah, the beauty that exists
The beauty that is not just mine
That also goes alone

If only she knew
That when she passes
The smiling world is filled with grace
And it is more beautiful because of love

annotations.lyric_fragment: Moça do corpo dourado do sol de Ipanema

annotation.plain: Ipanema is well known as a beautiful beach in the southern zone of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. It’s known to be a beautiful, elegant beach as a very popular part of the neighborhood. Interestingly enough, it is ironic how the world “Ipanema” originally derives from the indigenous Tupi language and means “stinky lake”.

annotations.lyric_fragment: The girl from Ipanema goes walking

annotation.plain:
The girl that Jobim and Gilberto refer to is Heloísa Eneida Menezes Paes Pinto Pinheiro (also known as Helô), a native from Rio de Janeiro.

The fame she received from the song began her career as a model, to which she continues to be recognized for her beauty.

http://www.sfgate.com/travel/article/Girl-from-Ipanema-ages-gracefully-Still-tall-2537969.php

Since the identity of the “girl from Ipanema” is very vague, when the song was first released, there was widespread speculation as to who she was and inspired a line-up of “pretenders” who claimed to be the inspiration of the song. In 1965, the lyricist, Vinícius de Moraes, held a press conference to set the record straight.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
When she walks she’s like a samba that
 Swings so cool and sways so gently

annotation.plain: This lyric is suggestive of what the bossa nova artists were doing to Brazilian music. Samba is anything but gentle and cool. It does not sway or swing. It is energetic and powerful. The bossa nova artists moved away from the frenetic style of samba to a toned-down, minimalistic music for the more refined middle and upper classes. Thus, this description of the girl from Ipanema is a reflection of the changes that the bossa nova artists made to Brazilian music and culture.

annotation.plain:
Bobby is referring to Teddy Riley, member of the R&B groups Guy and Blackstreet, who wrote and produced the song. Although Riley remained uncredited as the writer, Bobby drops his name to acknowledge his contributions to the song.
Teddy Riley mentioned the song in Billboard Book of #1 R&B Hits:

When we came up with that song, we thought of it for Bobby Brown because of all the situations he’s been in – people saying he’s on drugs. I feel it’s Bobby’s prerogative to do what he wants to do."

annotation.plain:
„Promiskuität“ beschreibt Personen, die auf Beziehungs- und sexueller Ebene freizügig agieren.
Im Kontext des Songs soll die sexuelle Erfahrung der beiden Protagonisten noch mehr in den Vordergrund geraten, wodurch das Flirten in den Strophen mit mehr Spannung geladen und auch mit diesem, auf den ersten Blick, leichten Bild des verspielten und verführerischen Mädchens gespielt wird.
Nellys Person ist hier nicht konform mit der gesellschaftlichen Erwartung an das sexuelle Leben einer Frau und nutzt die Fremdbezeichnung, um sich über den Doppelstandard durchzusetzen. Im Gegensatz dazu ist Timbalands Person von dieser Bezeichnung nicht angetan und muss weder dafür noch für sein arrogantes Macho Verhalten Konsequenzen fürchten.

You only get what you give

annotation.plain:
Not only does this phrase express the sentiment that hard work, effort and kindness pay off in life – it also implies that people who are not kind, like the “bad rich” who hoard wealth while others starve, are also going to get what’s coming to them, when poor people get sick of it and start a revolution (hence the lines “every night we smash a Mercedes-Benz” and “we’ll kick your ass in!”).
Lead singer Gregg Alexander is implying that karma will reward people who do good things and treat others well – while also eventually coming back around to bite the people who do bad things and oppress others.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Chorus]

annotation.plain:
In an interview in 2024, Gregg Alexander said that this song came to him after a dream in which he’d heard music coming from a house.

“I walked in to hear, and Joni Mitchell was in baby blue pyjamas. She said, ‘Have a seat’ and we talked about music. I wrote ‘You Get What You Give’ the same day.”

In a strange cosmic coincidence, Joni Mitchell said that hearing the song on the radio stopped her from quitting music in 1999. She said it rose “from the swamp of ‘McMusic’ like a flower of hope” and was “the only thing I heard in many years that I thought had greatness in it”.

“At the time this song became popular, I no longer played my instruments and I had no desire to sing or to listen to music. I listened to public radio and changed the station if they played music. But music is everywhere – in stores, even in traffic with the window down – and so I managed to hear this song. It was the first thing I had heard in decades that seemed to be inspired by something greater than personal ambition. It was sassy and smart and had real emotions.”
-Joni Mitchell

In 2000, she also told Rolling Stone:

“That’s the first song since I was a teenager that I rushed to the radio to turn up. I like the harmony, I like the passion in his voice. I love that song, you know, ‘you got the music in you’,  and I love the punk irreverence of it. Now that’s my kind of punky white boy.”

Alexander recounted his experience meeting Mitchell, who approached him at a Grammy’s gala:

“After that, I met her. I told her about the dream and she said, ‘Oh wonderful’, like she has coincidences like that every day. She must be some kind of lightning rod for all these magical things.”

https://www.theguardian.com/music/2024/mar/04/murder-on-the-dancefloor-gregg-alexander-saltburn-obamas-joni-mitchell#:~:text=%E2%80%9CI%20almost%20flipped%20a%20coin,to%20say%20inside%20five%20minutes.%E2%80%9D

https://faroutmagazine.co.uk/britpop-hit-stopped-joni-mitchell-quitting-music/

annotation.plain:
In live versions of the song, lead singer Gregg Alexander would sometimes replace the celebrity names used in the studio version with the names of other celebrities, such as Richard Branson, Linda Tripp, and the lead singer of the band Garbage, Shirley Manson, whose name was likely included as a nod to her band’s 1996 cover of the song “Kick My Ass” by Vic Chesnutt.

annotation.plain: Beck’s last name is “Hansen”, which may be a play on words here.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Frenemies, who, when you’re down, ain’t your friend

annotation.plain: This is the first song known to use the portmanteau “frienemy”, a combination of ‘friend’ and ‘enemy’.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You’ve got the music in you
 Don’t let go, you’ve got the music in you

annotation.plain:
Anyone who can retain enough childlike innocence and hope, anyone who has tapped into their passions and discovered a “why” for this whole being-here-and-living conundrum we find ourselves in, essentially has the “music” in them. Music is an art of passion, passion is a strong fuel for living.

So, if you’re lucky enough to have it, the music within you:

DON’T. LET. GO.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Every night we smash a Mercedes-Benz

annotation.plain:
They’re pushed by society to the point of being vandals, destroying expensive cars that are symbolic of the massive divide between classes.

Or at least symbolically destroying them anyway, trying to eviscerate the fancy and overblown things that represent the oppressive system where the rich suck the poor dry for frivolous luxuries and we’re all expected to play along and keep supporting the system.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Verse 1: Tony Lewis]

annotation.plain: The song prior to “Your Love” takes an opposite take from the perspective that this song is delivering. In “Say It Isn’t So” the narrator sings from the point of view of a guy that is worried and paranoid of his lover being unfaithful to him. Whereas in this song the narrator sings from the perspective of a guy that is lonely while his lover is away and goes on in an attempt to persuade a separate love interest into spending a night with him so he can numb the pain of being alone. I wouldn’t go as far as saying the narrator is cheating in spite of his significant other but he is rather acting upon a feeling of loneliness or a loss of feeling love and has so decided that a night spent with whom he’s singing to, will solve his despair for the time being.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Josie’s on a vacation far away
 Come around and talk it over

annotation.plain: His girlfriend, Josie, is on vacation and he’s trying to have company with the girl he’s singing to while she’s away.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Try to stop my hands from shakin’

annotation.plain:
They were probably more than just friends, but that was fairly long ago. Being alone with her is re-stirring his feelings toward her. This is the first point in the song to give any indication that they had been alone together in the past (whether before or while dating Josie).

It’s also possible that this is his way of smooth talking the girl by playing into her emotions. He’s trying to convince her to sleep with him because he has feelings for her – even though he doesn’t.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You know I’d do anything for you

annotation.plain: Keep it under cover is a double entendre. He wants to keep it a secret but also get in bed with her.

annotations.lyric_fragment: As you’re leaving, please, would you close the door?

annotation.plain: Either the girl has rejected his advances and she’s leaving him or he is saying this to her after she came over and they had sex.  She sees how meaningless it was to him and is leaving.  Classy guy, he says: close the door behind you, and don’t forget what I said about keeping this quiet…  But then he adds (maybe to himself, as she slams the door):  Just because you were right to suspect this would lead nowhere, doesn’t mean I was wrong to need it – I just needed comfort, a shoulder to cry one for one night.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You know I like my girls a little bit older

annotation.plain:
There are two ways to interpret this line. The first is that the girl is actually too young for him, and that he’s trying to convince her that he isn’t going to try anything if she comes over to talk to him, or convincing himself that he shouldn’t try anything.

The second and probably more plausible interpretation is that he’s saying he likes girls older than either himself or Josie’s age.

In the context of the song the second interpretation makes more sense, but that doesn’t stop this song from being commonly listed among other creepy odes to loving underage girls.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I just wanna use your love tonight, oh
 I don’t wanna lose your love tonight

annotation.plain: The speaker only wants to be involved with her physically, however he does not want anything serious. After all, he’s still got Josie to deal with. He is flat out telling the girl that he’s only interested in a one night stand, but he’s going to make the most of it, should she accept.

annotations.lyric_fragment: So many things that I wanna say

annotation.plain: John’s desperate to get his point across. He doesn’t want a relationship with her, he just wants her to stay the night. As seen in later lines, he’s just so lonely, he’ll say whatever to get her on board.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I ain’t got many friends left to talk to
 Nowhere to run when I’m in trouble

annotation.plain: Those “friends” are not real friends, leaving him when he needs them most. That’s why he’s after this girl, because if nothing else, he believes she’ll at least listen to his problems.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I just wanna use your love tonight
 And I don’t wanna lose your love tonight

annotation.plain: They are very close to one another and he doesn’t want their relationship to sour. He touches on this again later in the song.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Got your grandma on my dick, haha

annotation.plain: What?

annotations.lyric_fragment: Mike, Mike Jackson, nigga, yeah, I’m Bad

annotation.plain:
Michael Jackson was a hugely iconic pop superstar who released many #1 hits and albums during his legendary career throughout the late 20th century. One of his biggest songs (and albums) is called “Bad,” where Jackson declares himself a bad boy of sorts. Tyga references this song and also claims to be bad on the level of Michael Jackson.



It is worth noting that Tyga’s real-life first name is also Michael.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Y-Young Money, Young Money, yeah, we gettin’ rich

annotation.plain:
Tyga was signed to the label formed by his founder, Lil Wayne at the time, called Young Money.

With club bangers like this song, Young money definitely went rich. The lable includes the 9th, the 20th and the 22th richest rappers on the planet.

Honcho is a Japanese name means leader of the squad..Since he is on the driver’s seat,he thinks he is big shot (boss).
Head Honcho is a trending South African clothing line,at one stage Tyga visited Cape Town where the brand originates.







Check out the making of BMF freestyle in South Africa on the video below

annotations.lyric_fragment: Mustard on the beat, ho

annotation.plain: This was the track that propelled Mustard’s signature style into the spotlight. Based on a three-note riff (A, G sharp, C sharp) and a clicking snare, the beat is occasionally complimented by offbeat chanting, claps on quavers and an 808 snare fill

annotations.lyric_fragment: Tell that bitch, “Hop out, walk the boulevard”

annotation.plain:
With this “walk the boulevard” language, Tyga consciously calls up the image of the ho stroll, and thus sets himself up as a pimp

Rappers' fascination with pimps and pimp imagery dates back to the beginning of the genre – the genre’s first hit, “Rapper’s Delight,” has Big Bank Hank calling himself “the ladies' pimp”

Wordplay on the NBA player Alonzo Mourning’s name



This is, ahem, very similar to a Pharell line in the song “Yes” Feat Lil Wayne:

Cause I got some supersize guys that’ll hit you with a combo
Pronto
You won’t see the morning like Alonzo

Also, both lines may be referring to the movie Training Day, in which Denzel Washington’s crooked cop character Alonzo must produce a sum of money for Russian gangsters by the morning otherwise he will be killed

annotations.lyric_fragment: Gloria, how’s it gonna go down?

annotation.plain:
The narrator is asking Gloria here what kind of encounter she’ll have with the man with whom she finally settles down, and what kind of life she’ll lead after.

As described later, the narrator’s view is pessimistic.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I think they got the alias (Gloria)
 That you’ve been living under

annotation.plain:
These lines may suggest that Gloria was well-known among the men in her past, so she changed her name and her number to try to start over in a new town.

Gloria is constantly afraid of her past being uncovered by the man she’s chasing after. She’s developed a paranoia that these men have figured her out. She’s manically pinning yarn threads on the corkboard in her mind.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Will you marry for the money?
 Take a lover in the afternoon?
 Feel your innocence slippin’ away
 Don’t believe it’s comin’ back soon

annotation.plain:
and once again continuing the theory that it’s about an aging performer trying to recapture their glory/fame/popularity, this could mean doing it for the money (aka “selling out”) and taking a lover in the afternoon could allude to the music she writes when not on stage that she loves, but it doesn’t sell.

obviously, in this scenario, her innocence is slipping away (likely already slipped away) as she sells out and she’s not really herself anymore.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
But you really don’t remember
 Was it something that they said?

annotation.plain:
Almost identical to the first line in the chorus with one very significant change – the “hesaid” changed to “they said”.

Earlier on it seems that Gloria’s problem were due to her ex(?) lover; now it is everybody – “they”, a classical symptom of paranoia.

Some believe that the forgetfulness and the desperation in Gloria’s actions may give another scenario for the song – addressing an aging performer trying to reclaim her popularity, looks and youth.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Gloria, don’t you think you’re fallin’?

annotation.plain:
A desperate attempt by the narrator to have Gloria help herself by realizing that she is, per Laura Branigan –

a girl that’s running too fast for her own steps

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Will you meet him on the main line?
 Or will you catch him on the rebound?

annotation.plain:
The narrator is taking a different tack. Rather than criticising or chiding, she agrees to go with Gloria’s flow. A smart tactic to get her point across.

“down the main line” – in a regular manner – “girl meets boy” style. However, recognizing Gloria’s obsessive behaviour and personality, she is afraid it will be a person on a rebound for whom any relation is acceptable, which assures that he will be less than an ideal partner.

Setting this scenario, she proceeds to draw even a bleaker picture.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Are the voices in your head calling, Gloria?

annotation.plain:
The questions is not “do you hear voices?”, but “are the voices calling?”. The narrator knows Gloria’s unstable history.

One can read it as it is (comma after “calling”), or as “Are the voices in your head calling Gloria?” (no comma) – an internal dialogue inside a schizophrenic mind.

Connects well to the assumption that running from herself is valid.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Outro]

annotation.plain:
The orchestral pieces bring forth the real power of the song – Laura Branigan’s distinctive voice.

Ahmet Ertegun, who first signed her for his Atlantic record label, described it after her death:

I immediately realized that she had a great pop voice, in the classical sense. Laura had an instinctive feel for music and melody, and her delivery was sensational. Everybody at Atlantic knew that we had a winner in this young lady, and she came through…

annotations.lyric_fragment:
You don’t have to answer
 Leave ‘em hangin’ on the line
 Oh-oh, calling Gloria

annotation.plain:
On the surface, the narrator contradicts the previous line’s statement (“why isn’t anybody calling?”) – simply don’t answer them

Perhaps she (Gloria) is conflating the “voices in your head calling” with phone calls, and her friend, the narrator, goes along with the metaphor to get her message across.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
If everybody wants you
 Why isn’t anybody callin’?

annotation.plain:
The hidden dialogue inside the monologue.
Gloria claims, through the narrator that “everybody wants me”. This goes together with the “voices in your head”, hinting of hallucinations, paranoia and schizophrenia.

The reply – “why isn’t anybody calling” does not exactly match the next lines' premise.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I’ll stop the world and melt with you

annotation.plain: to be repeated nearly a dozen times in the song “Let’s stop the world” shifts the tone from a white knight view (“I’ll stop the world”) to a collaborative tone that reflects the view that their love can stave off reality, and make the world better in its own insignificant way (which IS significant to their lives.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I made a pilgrimage
 To save this human’s race

annotation.plain: The pilgrimage he makes it the song is engagement with his lover. Love can and should save humanity in his romantic view. Which will butt up against his rational view in the next lines.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Never comprehending
 The race had long gone by

annotation.plain: A fool’s errand.   Nothing he could do that would be dramatic enough to save the world.

annotations.lyric_fragment: There’s nothing you and I won’t do

annotation.plain: This lends more to the pragmatic interpretation, since there is an “after,” as opposed to a nuclear holocaust.  When we become one, nothing can stop us.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I’ll stop the world and melt with you

annotation.plain:
Assuming “sex during nuclear war” is accurate, the couple will be in coitus when the blast hits them, melting their bodies into one.

On a more pragmatic level, the narrator is saying I will stop all of the chaos that bombards me and become one with you.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Mesh and lace

Flo Rida refers to two types of cars here: Cadillacs and Mercedes Maybachs. Both are known to be high in the price range and only affordable by very rich people (famous rappers, for example…), so here what Flo Rida might be saying is that he’s buying his partner all of these expensive things to win her love and affection.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You know I can’t afford to buy her pearls

annotation.plain: As a downtown man of working class, he cannot afford the luxuries the uptown girl is usually shown.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
She’s getting tired of her high class toys
 And all the presents from her uptown boys

annotation.plain: The uptown girl is so used to her daily luxuries; however, she’s getting bored. The other upperclassmen are probably treating her with respect because she’s also upper class. The uptown girl likely wants someone who will respect her out of love for her, and so she’s looking for a “downtown man” that will treat her differently than that. Luckily, the man narrating the song is just what she’s hoping for.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I’ll win

annotation.plain: Is Billy Joel winning the girl’s heart? Or is he winning in a competition he has with the rich guys who want her too? Or is it both?

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Uptown girl
 She’s been living in her white-bred world

annotation.plain: In this lyric, Billy Joel describes an “uptown girl” as a girl who has everything handed to her on a silver platter. Even though white bread is generally cheaper than other bread products, most people enjoy and delight in white bread. Therefore saying that she has things so many people want.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I bet she’s never had a backstreet guy

annotation.plain:
“Backstreet guy” refers to a man from a working class neighborhood which Billy Joel literally was.  The 90’s group, Backstreet Boys, did not portray the original meaning of “backstreet” so accurately.  Billy Joel portrays the working class in his music video by playing a mechanic.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hCuMWrfXG4E&feature=kp

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Uptown girl
 She’s been living in her uptown world

annotation.plain:
Uptown Girl – A girl who is rich and sophisticated. one who is used to the comforts and luxuries of life.  The name comes from New York’s Upper East Side which has been one of the city’s wealthiest neighborhoods for over a century.



This actually was inspired by not only Christie Brinkley, but by the type of girls that Billy Joel was going out with at the time as he became more famous—including another supermodel, Elle Macpherson, with whom the song was originally written in mind.  He originally intended it to be plural, “Uptown Girls.”

She wants with her tie-yie-yie-m
And when she wakes up
And makes up her mie-yie-yie-nd

The accentuation on the last words are very derivative of Frankie Valli and the Four Seasons, which this song credits as an homage. Take a listen to this song to see the connection:

http://youtu.be/BMYZBVbifh8

annotations.lyric_fragment: I never eat a pig ’cause a pig is a cop

annotation.plain:
Foreshadowing his later conversion to being a Muslim in 1996, This is one of the two references Everlast makes on the album about not eating pork, as Pork is forbidden and unclean in Islam and other Abrahamic religions.

The name given to the police itself is lifted from the book Animal Farm, in which pigs are seen as authoritative figures in power.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I got more rhymes than there’s cops at a Dunkin’ donuts shop

annotation.plain:
Dunkin' Donuts (now known as Dunkin') is an American fast food chain that specializes in coffee and donuts.



Police officers love donuts. It’s a popular stereotype.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I’m the cream of the crop, I rise to the top

annotation.plain:
This is likely a reference to a now infamous interview with WWF pro-wrestler Macho Man Randy Savage, who was interviewed by Mean Gene Okerlund on May 11th, 1987, in which Savage repeately pulls out coffee creamer seemingly out of thin air as he declares himself the “cream of the crop”, further stating “the cream will rise to the top”.

In the interview, Savage was asked about Wrestlemania III, which took place on March 29th, 1987, in which he lost the Intercontinental Championship title to his opponent Ricky Steamboat. He went on to blame then WWF president Jack Tunney for losing the title due to “outside interference” in the form of sabotage by sending George “The Animal” Steele to help Steamboat during the match.

In a similar vein, it can be argued that House of Pain was “sabotaged” by Ruffhouse Records CEO Joe Nicolo (who was called out during the outro of Jump Around) for rejecting their demo of the song, then turning around and playing it for Jermaine Dupri who went on to produce Jump for Kris Kross upon his request to produce something similar to the demo.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8C4lK41SX-Q

annotations.lyric_fragment: Get up, stand up,

annotation.plain: The decision to use the phrase “Get Up, Stand Up,” is intentional, as it is a reference to Bob Marley and The Wailers' 1973 hit of the same name.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I’m comin’ to get ya, I’m comin’ to get ya

annotation.plain: “They’re coming to get you, Barbara” is a famous line from the film Night of the Living Dead, which Dawn of the Dead is a direct sequel of.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Tryin’ to play me out like as if my name was Sega

annotation.plain: Playing something out is to make something that’s popular repetitive and he references Sega , a video game company known for making Sonic The Hedgehog.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Jump around (Jump around)
 Jump around (Jump around)
 Jump around (Jump around)

annotation.plain:
When interviewed for Talib Kweli, Everlast started the chorus of this song was heavily inspired by ragga and reggae influences, in which he would shout “Jump around if you love freedom”.  Muggs later told Everlast to just say the word “jump around” as he and Cypress Hill had recently come off tour with Leaders of The New School, who although didn’t have a record with the words “jump around,” their energetic style of rapping often incited audiences to jump around at their show.

https://youtu.be/JF2eC0RW2aY?t=55

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Outro: Everlast]

annotation.plain:
Also missing from the outro of this song, not only did Joe “The Biter” Nicole allegedly steal the song JUMP from House Of Pain demo, but rapper Treach from Naughty By Nature was a enlisted writer of the number one song JUMP by Kriss Kross. Treach was not paid by Jermaine Dupree for his penmanship at the time of N.B.N. hit song “Craziest” in the 1995. Three years after Kriss Kross’ 1992 hit song “JUMP”.

“If you ain’t jumpin then don’t pump it
I’m hittin Jermaine in Atlanta cause he owe me loot for that JUMP shit.”

https://external-content.duckduckgo.com/iu/?u=https%3A%2F%2Ftse1.mm.bing.net%2Fth%3Fid%3DOIP.l0YN2SMar1QqndAJ31kdqgHaHa%26pid%3DApi&f=1

annotations.lyric_fragment: And then you wake up in the Dawn of the Dead

annotation.plain: Dawn of the Dead is a 1978 zombie movie directed by George A. Romero. It was an instant classic, and is often referenced as one of the best horror films of all time.

annotations.lyric_fragment: And just like the Prodigal Son, I’ve returned

annotation.plain:
Continuing his allusion to the Bible, Everlast makes a reference to one of Jesus' parables.

In the Parable of the Prodigal Son, the younger of two sons asks their father for his share of their inheritance. The father splits the inheritance between them, and, with his share, the younger son parties it up in another country, only to run out of wealth just as a famine hits. He returns to the father, and the father cooks up the fattest calf they have in celebration of his return.

annotation.plain: Ironic verbal “sample” of the lyrics of the Stranglers' “Peaches,” released the year before. Both songs are about a man looking at women, but the man in “Peaches” has an overconfident swagger in contrast to the lonely longing depicted in this song.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Pretty women out walking with gorillas down my street

annotation.plain:
The opening line of “Is She Really Going Out With Him?” immediately sets the stage for the song. The narrator is in disbelief that he sees pretty women going out with “gorillas”, which is meant to convey that these men are ugly and brutish compared to their partner. Jackson described this song as a “funny song about gorgeous girls going out with monsters”.

In an interview with Calgary Herald, Jackson discussed criticism he had received for the racial overtones some listeners perceived in this line.

I was approached on the street in London many years ago by a black guy who accused me of being a racist. And I said, “What the hell are you talking about?” And he quoted the first line of Is She Really Going Out With Him — “Pretty women out walking with gorillas down my street” — which he thought was about black guys with white girls, that I was a racist. And no matter what I said he wouldn’t believe me, and as far as he was concerned that was what it was. So, I mean, really, what can you do? (Laughs) I always feel like my lyrics are very clear, but what can I say?

annotation.plain:
When asked about these specific lines from Verses 2 and 3 in an interview with Rolling Stone, Levine said:

Yep, that’s sexual, all right. I was so sick of typical lyrics like ‘Ooh, baby’ and ‘I love you’ and all this vague shit. I thought the more explicit I got without being totally explicit was a nice approach. The little girls would enjoy them, and it would go right over my grandparents' heads. But it would hit my ex-girlfriend like a ton of bricks. It was perfect.

“Coming” has clear sexual connotations with its homophone.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Intro]

annotation.plain:
Nile Rodgers said he wanted this intro to sound like Diana Ross' “fanfare”, given she was the “queen of pop/R&B”.

We [told Motown], “She’s the queen, it’s a fanfare.” “What do you mean it’s a fanfare?” And my exact words were, “Alright, you’ve got the President of the United States. When the President of the United States walks into the room, they go, ‘Ladies and gentleman, the president of the United States.’ (sings “Hail to the Chief”) That’s the President of the United States. How about the queen of R&B/pop/soul? ‘Ladies and gentlemen, Diana Ross.’ (Sings riff) Yeah! Here she comes!’” Is that hard? Nobody got it.

annotation.plain: Nile Rodgers has went on numerous of interviews of himself about those who were gay secretly becoming comfortable in their own skin. The song is to support the LGBT community.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Trombone solo: Meco Monardo]

annotation.plain:
In a 2000 interview on DiscoMusic.com, Monardo elaborates on his contribution to the song:

I played on countless hit records as a trombonist, the most notable being Diana Ross' Diana produced by Nile Rodgers of Chic in 1980. I play the only jazz trombone solo that I am aware of featured on any pop record of the last 50 years. That was me playing on I’m Coming Out. Diana hated the album so much and was so pissed at Nile that she did not give any of the musicians credit. (from DiscoMusic.com, May 25, 2000)

annotations.lyric_fragment:

 I’m comin’
 I’m ... comin’ ... out
 I’m comin’ out
 
 I’m comin’ ... out
 I’m ... comin’ ... out

annotation.plain:
While the disco/club roots are obvious in the song’s theme and arrangement, it is not widely known that the origins of this song concern songwriter Nile Rodgers' experience at a gay club:


Rodgers got the idea to write “I’m Coming Out” while hanging out at a gay club in New York called the GG Barnum Room. The gay clubs in New York had the best underground music, so Rodgers frequented them to find out what the next big thing music would be. After seeing three different drag queens dressed as Diana Ross, Rodgers imagined what it would be like if Ross were to come out of the closet…

‘Diana Ross is not gay, so her singing “I’m Coming Out” was not about coming out of the closet,’ said Rodgers. ‘But it was like she was coming out of another form of the closet because she was leaving Motown and she had been under the thumb of Berry Gordy her whole life and this was the one thing she had done on her own.’


–Express Gay News (1993)

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Harmony and understanding
 Sympathy and trust abounding

annotation.plain: The age of Aquarius is often that of kindness and good nature, along with knowledge and development, thus these fitting adjectives.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Mystic crystal revelation

annotation.plain:
People have believed forever that crystals whose structure and metaphysical grid have the property and capacity to enhance body and soul healing.



Crystals, specifically crystal balls are the cornerstone of foretelling the future.

Both aspects were probably in the lyricists' minds when this line was written.

The song is after all about the coming future, with all its “New age” changes and social healing, so needed in and after the 60’s.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Golden living dreams of visions

annotation.plain:
Beautiful words strung together creating an illogical situation. Perhaps a combinations of daydreams and hallucinations?

This being “the” musical of psychedelia, the weird mixture of scenarios could be a symptom of one or many trips.

And “living”? changing the order to “‘Visions’ of ‘dreams’ of ‘living, or 'living’ things” might make more sense.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Aquarius
 Aquarius

annotation.plain:
A now defunct website (“Aquariuswater.com”) had a description of the ideal “age of Aquarius” per this site –

Aquarius is the age of self-realization (Kundalini Awakening). Aquarius is the true age of knowledge. In this age, dogmatic types of religion will cease to be taught, and all dogmatic forms will disappear. Science and religion will merge and people will begin to comprehend that spirit and matter are derived from the same source, and are only modifications of the One Universal Energy. It is the desire to pool and merge the time, efforts, and resources of the individual with those of the larger society in order to create something new for the benefit of everyone. Enhancement of the polity overwhelms the desire for self-aggrandizement, and the wall of Ego come tumbling down and the individual communes with the totality of the species.

Also per the aforementioned site – the essence of the change in ages is –

If Pisces can be described as the age of revelation versus reason, then the Aquarius age will be the age of collective integrity versus individual dignity.  In the Piscean Age, we looked to have our minds and souls revealed to us, either through our imaginations or interpretations of Divinity. Reason was the counterfoil to that impulse.  In the Aquarian Age, I believe we will strive more to condition our minds to be better integrated into the collective.  In the Piscean age, the key question was, “What do you believe?”  In the Aquarian age, the question will be, “How are we connected?”



It is a utopian view, and all preceding ages and the current one (Age of Pisces) had less than 5% days with no wars and mayhem. Unlikely that the coming Age of Aquarius will be any different.

Astrologically, we are towards the end of Age Pisces – around 6% left, which computes to a few hundred years, therefore we are in a long transition period…

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Then peace will guide the planets
 And love will steer the stars

annotation.plain:
The same year (1969) the song was released, another song topped the chart for 6 weeks, and it also had some future predictions, albeit totally opposite to the hopeful ones in “Aquarius”.

Zager and Evans “In the Year 2525”, the outlook was grim:

In the year 2525
If man is still alive
If woman can survive
They may find

This was the end of the revolutionary and turmoil laden 60’s, and it’s not surprising that the feelings and predictions were as diverse as the opinions of that era’s populace.

What is absolutely mind blowing was that in a year that yielded such mega classics as “Aquarius”, “Hey Jude”, “2525” and many others, the song of the year turned out to be … “Sugar Sugar”…
