How can one not be inspired by the lyrics, singers and the outfits?



“Let the Sunshine In” is one of the most crowd pleasing and “sing-a-long” songs from the musical, with not one spectator staying in his/her seat.

annotations.lyric_fragment: No more falsehoods or derisions

annotation.plain:
The only “No” line in this list of the positive aspects of The Age of Aquarius.

It stresses that together with the positive thoughts and deeds, truth and respect, the negative ones should vanish, allowing “The sun to shine in”.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Let the sunshine
 Let the sunshine in

annotation.plain:
Perhaps on purpose, the major sky’s object, the sun, dominates this part of the song, after the stars and the planets inspired the first segment.

It creates a contrast of light and dark, though the darkness in the Aquarius part also hinted strongly of the coming light – “The DAWN of the Age of Aquarius”. Therefore – the sun coming in is a natural progress.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Let the sunshine
 Let the sunshine in
 The sunshine in

annotation.plain:
“Let the Sunshine In” was not a song standing on its own.

In the musical, it was the last segment of the song “The Flesh Failures” – lyrics, a very strong anti-war song including forceful dark lyrics like

We starve-look
At one another
Short of breath
Walking proudly in our winter coats
Wearing smells from laboratories
Facing a dying nation
Of moving paper fantasy
Listening for the new told lies
With supreme visions of lonely tunes

in this song, the ending is a song of hope. In Aquarius – complementing the message of “we are almost there”, and in “The Flesh Failures”, a stark contrast to its dreary picture.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a56-TcPQMow

Per “bones” Howe, The song’s producer:

I listened to the cast album, and I thought ‘This isn’t a complete song. It’s an introduction.’ There was so much talk about that show at the time because people were naked on stage, and ‘Aquarius’ was just part of the opening routine. Well, I went to see the show, and about four-fifths of the way through there was a song called ‘The Flesh Failures’, which was a typical ‘60s downer — you know, the world is falling apart, we’re all killing each other with poison, and so on. A total environmental downer. But at the end of the song there were three bars just repeating 'Let the sunshine in, let the sunshine in, the sunshine in,’ over and over and over again.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
This is the dawning of the age of Aquarius
 Age of Aquarius
 Aquarius
 Aquarius

annotation.plain:
Astrologically, the “Age of Aquarius”, at least according to one source, started in 2009:

Meanwhile on February 14th (the day dedicated to the patron Saint of love) just a few minutes after dawn GMT the final pieces of the celestial jigsaw fall into place as the Moon moves into the 7th house in the 7th house sign of Libra while Jupiter is aligned to Mars in Aquarius.

There are numerous other sources who point to different times when the “age” started, or will start.

more important is the metaphorical meaning of the date, so well put in the previous two lines –

Then peace will guide the planets
And love will steer the stars

When men can make it happen (and compel the stars and planets to comply) in bringing all that is promised in the next verse.

This line was based on an actual event:

We didn’t have a chorus and we didn’t have a subject or a lyric. So over the next weekend, I went to this awesome party they have at The Echo in Echo Park, Los Angeles, called Funky Sole Saturday… this girl actually told me to shut up and dance with her. – Nick Petricca

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Oh, we were bound to get together
 Bound to get together

annotation.plain:
Throughout the song, the narrator falls back on common tropes of falling in “love at first sight”: the relationship as “destiny,” prolonged eye contact (“deep in her eyes…”), a comparison to Romeo and Juliet, and allusions to increased heart rate.

Kanye West similarly explored the inevitability of falling in love with his significant other in “Bound 2”.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Pre-Chorus]

annotation.plain:
Walk The Moon was looking to emulate the feel of the early 80’s pop-rock.

The band had been listening to songs like “Jessie’s Girl” and “Just What I Needed” and “Hit Me With Your Best Shot” – these super quirky rock anthems. They’re simple and beautiful and in-your-face rock songs, and that’s the vibe we were looking for.

For comparison, here is the pre-chorus of “Jessie’s Girl”:

https://youtu.be/qYkbTyHXwbs?t=59s

annotations.lyric_fragment: A backless dress and some beat-up sneaks

annotation.plain:
According to Nick, his girlfriend actually was wearing a “backless dress and beat up red Chucks” at the time.



Those beat-up shoes were  Chuck Taylor All-Stars, one of the most popular shoes in the world. First produced in 1917, Converse has sold over 800 million pairs of the shoe since. Nearly 100 years later, they are still a fashion staple thanks to  hipster fashion trends, and celebrity adoption (see: Wiz Khalifa).

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Chorus]

annotation.plain: The guitar intro uses a fast repeating digital delay and reverb in a manner popularized by U2 (listen to the intro of “In God’s Country”.)

annotation.plain:
Nick explained to American Songwriter that he was thinking of his awkward high school years:

I started picturing myself in high school because that’s what it really reminded me of. Being this incredibly uncomfortable, awkward adolescent dude, so it sort of became this anthem for the dork who is 100 percent me.

annotations.lyric_fragment: My discothèque Juliet, teenage dream

annotation.plain:
A “discotheque” is another word for a nightclub. He compares meeting this girl to the teenage meeting of Romeo and Juliet at a ball in William Shakespeare’s iconic play.



He marks his infatuation with her through a reference to Katy Perry’s hit “Teenage Dream”, a song that says “We can dance, until we die.” “Teenage Dream” might very well have been playing at the party where they are dancing together.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
We were victims of the night
 The chemical, physical kryptonite
 Helpless to the bass and the fading light

annotation.plain:
Kryponite is the radioactive element that weakens Superman, leaving him powerless. The music, lights, and this girl have a similar effect on the narrator’s inhibitions, allowing him to have a good night on the dance floor.

In real life, they were struggling with writer’s block,  unable to come up with the chorus of what became “Shut Up and Dance.”



The fictional element previously hit the musical charts in 2000, when “Kryptonite” by 3 Doors Down peaked at #4 on the Billboard US Hot 100.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Get me on the court and I’m trouble

annotation.plain: Ice Cube has often expressed his love for basketball through interviews. Because of this love for the game, he signifies that when he in on the basketball court, he dominates the court and is hard to play against.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Lookin’ in my mirror, not a jacker in sight

annotation.plain: A jacker is a common nickname for carjackers, hence the name “Jacker,” and because of the quality of Ice Cube’s whip, it would be the #1 target for car thieves.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Two in the mornin’, got the Fatburger

annotation.plain: Fatburger is a fast food chain, known for its fat burgers. Since there is only one Fatburger in all of Europe, Europeans may not me familiar with the chain.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Just wakin’ up in the mornin’, gotta thank God

annotation.plain:
One thing that people might miss is that Ice Cube is actually religious. Therefore the gotta thank God just for waking up arguably has a dimension many miss.


‘Cause me and Allah go back like cronies I ain't gotta be fake, ‘cause he is my homie― Ice Cube – Gangsta Rap Made Me Do It

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I gotta go ’cause I got me a drop-top
 And if I hit the switch, I can make the ass drop

annotation.plain: In the music video for “It Was a Good Day,” Ice Cube is seen cruising the streets of Los Angeles in a green 1964 Chevrolet Impala drop-top convertible lowrider with a hydraulic kit on it that can make the car drop and rise or bounce up and down with the flip of a switch.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Seven, even back door Little Joe

annotation.plain: Little Joe is a hard 4 (two 2s) in craps. “Back door” refers to rolling the dice out of the back of your hand. The odds of rolling any 4 in craps are 1 in 12 (8.333%), while the odds of a hard 4 are 1 in 36 (2.778%), so Ice was definitely on his game that day.

annotations.lyric_fragment: It’s ironic, I had the brew, she had the chronic

annotation.plain:
When Ice Cube went over to this girl’s house, he was prepared to have a good time and had liquor in his possession. He is surprised to see that she had the chronic, which is another word for marijuana. On the West Coast of the United States, chronic is known as weed of the highest quality.

This line is not a reference to Dr. Dre’s landmark 1992 album The Chronic. The Predator was released roughly one month before The Chronic was.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Didn’t even see a berry flashin’ those high beams

annotation.plain: ‘Berry’ is a reference to the flashing lights on top of a police vehicle. When a police vehicle flashes its light, it is highly possible that it will pull you over. Luckily for Ice Cube, the police vehicle didn’t flash the beams.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Plus nobody I know got killed in South Central L.A.​
 Today was a good day

annotation.plain:
In 1992, the year of the making of the song, South Central Los Angeles experienced record crime rates. That year, the LAPD reported 403 slayings in the area (partly due to the 1992 LA Riots).

Given these high numbers of deaths, a day without having a person close to you killed already constitutes a good day.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Freakin’ niggas every way like MJ

annotation.plain:
MJ is basketballer Magic Johnson, a former player for Cube’s home team Los Angeles Lakers who’s commonly included among the best players of all time.

In a 2008 interview with ESPN, Cube mentioned Magic is his favorite basketball player:


Interviewer: Your famous line from “Today Was a Good Day” is “…(bleeped) around and got a triple-double.” Who did you have in mind when you wrote that?
Ice Cube: Come on. Magic Johnson!

Just making sure it wasn’t Pooh Richardson.
Magic Johnson was and is my favorite basketball player of all time.

Is he the basis for Ice Cube as a Lakers fan?
It was all Magic. By the time he’s drafted into the league, I’m just starting to understand what basketball was all about, and then he came and won a championship his first year.


On the censored version, Ice Cube says

Freakin' brothers every way, like MJ

A Slurpee is a frozen, flavored ice drink from 7-Eleven.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Keeping versed and on my feet

annotations.lyric_fragment: Making sure I’m not in too deep

annotation.plain: He’s making sure that he’s not putting a lot of weight on himself and only takes on things that he can handle.

annotations.lyric_fragment: (If you steal my sunshine)

annotation.plain: Sharon backs him up, stating if anyone should come steal their happiness, they will become depressed. However, Marc’s lines show that they’re mentally trying to prevent this from happening.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I know it’s up for me

annotation.plain: Marc feels that he doesn’t have much of a chance to prove himself to the people that have misinterpreted who he really is.

annotations.lyric_fragment: If I should die before I wake

annotation.plain:
Not everybody knows but this quite popular line (which has been used by the likes of Kid Cudi, Metallica, Christina Aguilerra and more) is taken directly from children’s bedtime prayer from the 18th century – “Now I Lay Me Down to Sleep”.

The prayer itself has many different versions but the line appears in most of them. Here is the one printed by The New England Primer:

Now I lay me down to sleep,
I pray the Lord my soul to keep,
If I shall die before I wake,
I pray the Lord my soul to take. Amen.

Here, this line basically serves as a reference before it ties in with the next line.

He released the song Love Sosa after the death of rival Chicago rapper Lil JoJo, who was killed the same day he exchanged threats and insults via Twitter with Chief Keef and affiliates.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Thirsty-ass bitches, shit that we don’t like

annotation.plain:
Nobody enjoys a woman who is desperate for some action, unless you’re desperate as well. Apparently Lil Reese isn’t.

“Thirsty ass bitches” is another term for gold diggers. Lil Reese doesn’t like gold diggers and Chief Keef doesn’t like “Pop bitches.” Women who are “thirsty bitches” are desperate; for action and/or for money."

annotations.lyric_fragment: Fredo in the cut, that’s a scary sight (Man down)

annotation.plain:
Referring to GBE recording artist Fredo Santana who is most likely one of Keef’s shooters.





When it says “Fredo in the cut” it could be Lil Reese saying that Fredo is off to the side not being vied in the public eye, or it could mean Fredo is doing great and making money.

Many people think that when Lil Reese says “that’s a scary sight” is a derogatory notion towards Fredo’s position. It is probably referencing to Fredo Santana’s mixtape “It’s a Scary Site”, which describes the horrors of the streets in Chicago or “Chiraq.”

The line as a whole is most likely saying that Fredo’s position or activity can be related to some of the songs on his mix tape.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Floatin’ off at flat, I might take flight

annotation.plain: “Flats” are slang for a type of pill, most likely Xanax pills which are flatly shaped. Lil Reese likes to get high off of them. .

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Roll you like you were dice
 Until you come up blue

annotation.plain: It means that the character is difficult at relationships: she will “play with your heart”.

annotations.lyric_fragment: When she snows you

annotation.plain: The original by Jackie DeShannon is “She’ll expose you / When she blows you / Off your feet with the crumbs that she throws you”.  The cleaned-up “when she snows you” (with “snows” meaning “fools” or “tricks”) makes much less sense.

annotations.lyric_fragment: All the boys think she’s a spy

annotation.plain: Just a hint that the girl is mysterious and hard to figure out.

annotations.lyric_fragment: She’s ferocious

annotation.plain: Ferocious means to mark by extreme and violent energy. Obviously a slight exaggeration.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Off your feet with the crumbs she throws you

annotation.plain: The speaker is saying that the girl can (not literally) throw you off your feet with her trickiness. (hence the comparison to the famous folktale “Hansel and Gretel” with the breadcrumbs that make you follow them until the person gets you exactly where they want you.)

annotations.lyric_fragment: She’ll let you take her home

annotation.plain: Whether the guy is “taking her home” to have sex with her or just to be with her more, some girls don’t allow guys to take them home just because they like taking things slow and don’t want guys taking advantage of them. This girl wants to keep playing the game.

annotations.lyric_fragment: It whets her appetite

annotation.plain: “Whet” means ‘make keen or eager; stimulate’. So her appetite (for sex) can be made more intense if you take her home (aforementioned in the previous line).

annotations.lyric_fragment: She got Greta Garbo stand off sighs

annotation.plain:
Greta Garbo was a Swedish actress who lived from 1905-1990.  Her most famous line was “I want to be alone,” in the movie “Grand Hotel.”
https://youtu.be/tojjWQvlPN8?t=27

The speaker is saying that the girl whom they are speaking of wants to be alone sometimes. this line is similar to the line “she’ll unease you” because most of the lines in this song are positive characteristics but these two are not. it’s again, a change of mood from the speaker’s perspective.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And she knows just
 What it takes to make a pro blush

annotation.plain:
The term “making a pro blush” refers to being better at one’s own game. For example, if you are a comedian and you are making fun of someone in your audience and then all of a sudden the audience member says something that makes you shut up and move on, then that person has made a pro blush.

While commonly misheard as “to make a crow blush”, the lyric sheet confirms that it is “to make a pro blush”. Jackie DeShannon’s original version also used “pro” according to New Arrangement’s lyric sheet, despite rumors that she sang “crow” in her version and Carnes changed it.

annotations.lyric_fragment: She’s precocious

annotation.plain: “Precocious” means having or showing the qualities or abilities of an adult at an unusually early age. meaning she is mature, basically. obviously a good thing but sometimes being around a person who is too mature can be exasperating.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
What’s the sense in sharing this one and only life
 Ending up just another lost and lonely wife
 You count up the years
 And they will be filled with tears

annotation.plain:
The paradox of being in love and falling in love. The first is filled with promise and benefit while the latter leads to pain and regret.

The singer could also be arguing against falling in love in the first place, knowing the inevitability that the one she loves will pass away via breakup, divorce, or death.

This perspective is in stark contrast to Victorian-era English poet Alfred, Lord Tennyson who wrote in Canto XXVII of his poem In Memoriam: “’Tis better to have loved and lost / Than never to have loved at all.”

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I keep asking myself, wondering how
 I keep closing my eyes, but I can’t block you out

annotation.plain: The speaker is confused and distraught by the realization that she’s in love with another girl. “I keep closing my eyes” references the previous lyric where she claims this girl has “opened [the speaker’s] eyes”. As soon as she becomes aware of how she feels, she wants to shut those feelings out; but she’s too infatuated with this girl to ignore them.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Wanna fly to a place where it’s just you and me
 Nobody else, so we can be free
 (Nobody else, so we can be free)

annotation.plain:
She wants the two of them to escape to another country where love between two women (or, indeed, two men) isn’t a crime and they don’t have to hide who they are.

According to the Human Dignity Trust, there are still more than 70 countries where being gay is illegal. Russia isn’t technically one of them, but in 2013 it passed a law banning “propaganda of homosexuality among minors”. Furthermore, in 2020, same-sex marriage was banned with a bill which defined marriage as between a woman and a man.

annotation.plain:
PROPOSED SUGGESTION:

In the original Russian version of the song the hook sounds like “Ya soshla s uma, mne nujna ona” which means “I’ve gone crazy, I need her”. This song is not about problems in the relationship between partners. The main message of this song is falling for someone in a crazy way, forgetting about everything else except your crush, trying to escape this feeling (unsuccessfully) and mainly about homophobia. And this version is still about it. The singer can’t stop thinking about the words her crush said. Probably her feelings are mutual and her crush confessed her love to her, so she can’t stop thinking about it and the main problem is homophobia from everyone around including her family.

annotations.lyric_fragment:

 This is not enough (All the things she said, all the things she said)

annotation.plain: Between theese lines the Russian line is heard “Я сошла с ума” (/Ya soshla s uma/ – I’ve lost my mind) – that is the title of Russian song and the line corresponding “All the things she said” in there

annotations.lyric_fragment:
If I’m asking for help, it’s only because
 Being with you has opened my eyes
 Could I ever believe such a perfect surprise?

annotation.plain:
Being with another girl has opened up her eyes: she never thought that it was possible to actually feel this way about another girl.

But, at the same time, they live in one of the most homophobic countries in the world, and she needs help with realising that her sexuality is real.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I’m in serious shit, I feel totally lost

annotation.plain:
Homophobia is rampant in Russia (where t.A.T.u. are from); the two girls would be in “serious shit” if they came out because of the all the backlash they would face from their family. They feel lost: how could they feel this way? Is it normal to find other girls attractive?

Also, interestingly enough, the word “shit” is censored in the original album and the video, but not during live performances or on the tenth anniversary edition of the album.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I can try to pretend, I can try to forget

annotation.plain: You can try to pretend to be straight, you can try to forget you are gay. But it would drive you crazy in the end.

annotation.plain: She wants to escape with her partner to a place where she can’t be shamed by the community for being in a relationship with another woman.

annotation.plain: Now she sings to her dad. “Will I ever be free” (from this torture of not knowing my sexuality). Have I crossed the line of being out of control and going too far with this?

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Some people need three dozen roses
 And that’s the only way to prove you love them

annotation.plain: In her interview on Jada Pinkett’s, “Red Table Talk,” Keys shared that the song was partly inspired by the death of R&B’s princess, Aaliyah. She stated, “I think being on a plane and knowing she passed away after a plane crash, there was just this sentiment of being present in the moment and really nothing else matters but those that you love. I think that feeling was really present in my life at that time and really right in my face.” The lyric, “Some people need three dozen roses, And that’s the only way to prove you love them” stands to mean that people care more about the physical and materialistic things and three dozen roses should be enough to express your love to someone, but that shouldn’t be the case. On top of Aaliyah’s death, 9/11 had also occurred which had a huge impact on everyone. These lyrics remind us all to not wait until it is too late to actually make time and show those we love them that we’re here and that we do in fact love them without the materialistic things.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Hand me the world on a silver platter
 And what good would it be?
 With no one to share
 With no one who truly cares for me

annotation.plain:
To hand someone something on a silver platter means to give someone an extremely valuable possession for nothing in return.
She’s taking this phrase a step further to show how much this person means to her. If someone were to offer her the world on a silver platter, she still wouldn’t take it.



This says a lot about her uncaring attitude toward superficiality, and her strong desire to be with the one she loves instead. Even if she could have the world and all its riches, it would mean nothing if she didn’t have this person in her life.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Some people search for a fountain
 That promises forever young (Ya know)

annotation.plain:
‘The Fountain Of Youth' is a fictional thing which makes one young forever. People seem to desire to find a device that stops them losing their youth, when really they’re wasting it by trying to stop it.

Alicia doesn’t need to be young forever however. She doesn’t care how old she gets, as long as she grows old with him.

Even her friend Jay Z wants to be “Young Forever”!

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Some people want it all
 But I don’t want nothin’ at all
 If it ain’t you, baby
 If I ain’t got you, baby

annotation.plain:
In comparison to the rest of the world, Alicia isn’t asking for much.

She feels that love is all she needs and that all other materialistic aspects of life are surplus. Even the prospect of losing her love is impossibly painful to her.



On a technical note: The hook starts in a similar way to the chorus of “(You Make Me Feel Like A) Natural Woman” by Carole King. The two songs, in a way, are quite similar in meaning.

annotations.lyric_fragment: They think we’re lovers kept under cover

annotation.plain: This line is a classic example of a double entendre. When something is “kept under cover”, it’s kept a secret. Here, the narrator is saying that  the coworkers think they’re secretly lovers, but also that they’re having an affair, as the ‘covers’ mentioned allude to bedsheets and blankets.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I feel so foolish, I never noticed
 You’d act so nervous, could you be falling for me?
 It took the rumor to make me wonder
 Now I’m convinced I’m going under
 Thinkin’ ’bout you every day
 Dream ’bout you every night
 I’m hoping that you feel the same way
 Now that we know it, let’s really show it, darling

annotation.plain:
Sometimes it’s like this; the two of you become such close friends you don’t even notice the relationship has grown to love.  There’s a con-nection here to another song on the subject. Go next to listen to and read Jackson Browne’s “Just Say Yeah”.

If you’ve never had this experience, just wait around a while.  Raitt’s material is definitely not aimed at the youth market. She’s been on the scene for five decades, just waiting for her audience to gain the experience that provides the background to her songs.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Later’s better than never

annotation.plain:
Despite the fact that Lana didn’t try to catch up to him immediately, she is trying now and that’s all that matters from her point of view.

As stated in “Burning Desire”:

I’m driving fast, flash! Everyone knows it

Lana drives as an act of desperation in order to catch up to him. Yet she knows that she will never be able to drive fast enough in order to turn back time.



Even though Lana’s lover is gone she is just gonna keep driving. She could be driving to forget him. Or that even though he’s not here she’s gonna keep driving like normal, finally starting to let go of him.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Think I’ll miss you forever
 Like the stars miss the sun in the morning sky

annotation.plain:
Lana will always love her, so she will ultimately always miss her, too.

She compares this to the sky and the stars. The stars are never out at the same time as the sun so they never see each other, they are always too late to see the sun. This connects to Lana as now that she is gone from her life, she will always be too late to catch her.



Also note the homophones – morning and mourning, which reflects Lana’s grief over her lover.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Cruisin’ down the coast, goin’ ’bout 99

annotation.plain:
Her feeling of electricity translates into the speed at which she is driving.

Lana is extremely fond of driving fast. It seems almost as if Lana is trying to drive away from her past and her memory of this person. However, the past will always catch up with you.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Got my bad baby by my heavenly side
 I know, if I go, I’ll die happy tonight

annotation.plain:
Lana feels like her lover is there in spirit with her tonight.

Despite the fact that Lana has turned her back on god, she still feels like he has allowed her lover to be there with her.

She feels as if it doesn’t matter if she lives or dies, as she effectively was killed when her lover left her. If dying meant joining him she would be more than happy to go to heaven with him.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I’m feelin’ electric tonight

annotation.plain:
Similar to the telephone lines Lana feels like there is electricity flowing through her.

This implies Lana’s pure energy as electricity is, ultimately, a form of energy. Lana feels unnaturally charged, this contrasts to her usual feelings of loneliness.

This also acts as a reference to ‘Body Electric’, where Lana feels similarly hyped up.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Honey, I’m on fire, I feel it everywhere

annotation.plain:
Lana has become fearless due to the fact that her lover has left her.

When she was with her lover, she was afraid of death because she had someone to live for. Now that she’s gone Lana feels her life is pointless, therefore she’s going to go out and make the most of it.

The fire suggests that Lana is going to go out in a flourish. Fires are fast burning and are inevitably extinguished at some point, just as Lana knows that she can’t keep live forever.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Oh my God, I feel it in the air
 Telephone wires above are sizzlin’ like a snare

annotation.plain:
Lana is fully aware that something special is going to happen tonight.

Telephone lines hiss when they are wet. This makes a similar noise to a snare on a drum kit when it is played. This comparison suggest Lana’s slightly confused temperament – even things as normal as the telephone lines seem to be in rhythm. As a ‘self-styled gangsta Nancy Sinatra’ Del Rey clearly uses this aural metaphor to contextually place herself in this era in the song.

Most of all though this line shows Lana Del Rey’s acutely self-referential lyrics – The snare that she used to describe the telephone wires transcends from the figurative to the literal as after Del Rey invokes the snare it begins to play in the backing track.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Summertime sadness

annotation.plain:
Lana lost a dear friend one summer when her friend committed suicide by jumping off of a bridge, hence the title. The lyrics and music video both tell this story about how Lana loved her friend, and now she’s gone.  She gets sad in summer time because that’s when it happened.

https://www.quora.com/What-is-the-Summertime-Sadness-video-about

annotations.lyric_fragment: High heels off, I’m feelin’ alive

annotation.plain:
You take your heels off when you’re at the end of a party event, and ready to feel free. Girls often do this before they go on the dance floor.

However, Lana seems to be forcing this happiness. She attempts to ignore her summertime sadness as she feels it does nothing but detract from her enjoyment of life. Parties are the only place where Lana can have a release from her melancholy.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I got my red dress on tonight

annotation.plain:
Simply put, Lana loves wearing red dresses. She has mentioned them in numerous songs of hers, including “Cruel World” and “Yes to Heaven”.

She finds it ironic that it’s a beautiful summery day, and she is all dressed up to party, yet she just cannot get all of her memories of her lover out of her head.

This is extremely similar to Body Electric:

Dancing and grinding in the pale moonlight

annotations.lyric_fragment: But boy you’ve got a prayer in Memphis

annotation.plain:
That is to say: “There’s hope for you in Memphis.”

It is as though the lyrics suggest: When it seems there’s not a hope or prayer for you in the world, Memphis has a hope or prayer for you, mostly in from the sense of a church or religious non-segregation standpoint. This lyrics is Reverend Green’s offering, as a sentiment for the traveling narrator, as reminder for his journey ahead of him, on this visit and the next.

It’s a welcoming expression and delivers a sense of communal friendliness, also known as southern hospitality. It would likely comfort someone from out of town, like the song’s narrator, who appears to be interacting with people from different origins.

If Reverend Green were black, for example, Marc Cohn, as the song’s narrator, delivers the lyrical message of this lyric being a turning point.

After this lyric, the song’s narrator begins to further understand that the nuances of Memphis are what the streets can’t fully offer. Despite the rich culture   and landmark attractions, the lyrics and arrangements offer a sense of pondering beyond city’s “Main Street” attractions.

From my perspective as the listener, I feel there is a crescendo of abandon by Marc Cohn himself, as he realizes the unprejudiced facets of Memphis' many accepting cultural offerings, including unprejudiced people, the increased spiritualization of him having realized what he realized about Memphis, is felt by me from both the lyric and delivery standpoint, in addition to the overall emotional progression of the song.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
But there’s a pretty little thing
 Waiting for The King
 Down in the Jungle Room

annotation.plain:
In the middle of the 60s, Elvis furnished the “Jungle Room” (including a waterfall) in Graceland in a style that reminded him of Hawaii
https://www.atlasobscura.com/places/the-jungle-room-at-graceland-memphis-tennessee

annotations.lyric_fragment:
She said
 “Tell me are you a Christian child?”
 And I said
 “Ma’am I am tonight”

annotation.plain:
Cohn is a Jew immersed in the culture of the heavily Protestant Deep South (aka “Bible Belt”), at least for the evening.  This line is sung almost tongue-in-cheek, as in this experience is so good that it might convert me!

Traditionally, citizens of the Deep South place a lot of emphasis on enjoying the little things in life, appreciating what you have, and redemption for past sins. Although he is not Christian, Marc obviously connects with this on many levels during his visit.

Cohn spoke about this line directly in an interview for the Chicago Tribune

It’s so funny — people often think that I’m Christian or born-again, from not only that song, but others. In a way, I like that. There’s nothing clear about what I’m writing, in terms of spirituality. But to me, that line could have only been written by a Jew. It’s such a Jewish line, and I love that.

annotations.lyric_fragment: And they brought me down to see her

annotation.plain:
They didn’t actually bring Cohn down to meet Muriel. Cohn and his companions were simply on Highway 61 when they stopped in the Hollywood Cafe to get some food.

Perhaps “they” refers to fate.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Now Muriel plays piano
 Every Friday at the Hollywood

annotation.plain:
Muriel was an elderly African-American woman who would play the piano at the Hollywood Cafe. She also happened to have a great impact on Marc Cohn’s life. He described their meeting as thus:

She was real curious, she seemed to have some kind of intuition about me, and I ended up telling her about my family, my parents, how I was a musician looking for a record deal, the whole thing. Then, it must have been about two in the morning, she asks me up to sing with her and we do about an hour, me and this lady I’d never met before, hardly a song I knew so she’s yelling the words at me. Then at the end, as the applause is rising up, she leans over and whispers in my ear, she’s whispering, You’ve got to let go of your mother, child, she didn’t mean to die, she’s where she’s got to be and you’re where you have to be, child, it’s time to move on.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And Reverend Green be glad to see you
 When you haven’t got a prayer

annotation.plain:
Cohn made sure to see the famous Reverend Al Green when he went to Memphis. Al Green is an ordained Baptist minister who bought a church in Memphis back in 1976.

Yet another indication of the important cohesion of Gospel and Blues.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Saw the ghost of Elvis
 On Union Avenue
 Followed him up to the gates of Graceland
 Then I watched him walk right through

annotation.plain:
The journey from Union Avenue to Graceland is symbolic of the journey leading to success and fame. Following this path is akin to following Elvis from his origins to his eventual epic success.

Union Avenue is likely mentioned because Sam Phillips' studios, called Memphis Recording Service, were located at 706 Union Avenue. Elvis' start on his journey to fame and fortune is usually attributed to the success of “Blues Suede Shoes” and “Heartbreak Hotel,” the latter of which was originally recorded at Sam Phillips' studio when Elvis was signed to Sun Records.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Walking in Memphis
 But do I really feel the way I feel?

annotation.plain: The feelings Cohn has are too surreal at this point. He went to Memphis for one purpose, but seems to be having new revelations with every corner he turns.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Then I’m walking in Memphis
 I was walking with my feet ten feet off of Beale

annotation.plain:
Beale Street is a famous street in Memphis. There is a statue of W.C. Handy on Beale and B.B. King was known as the “Beale Street Blues Boy.”

“Walking with my feet ten feet off” could imply that he was, in effect, “walking on air” which would indicate a certain kind of excitement for being there, present in the land of blues in search of inspiration.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Yeah I’ve got a first class ticket
 But I’m as blue as a boy can be

annotation.plain:
“Being blue” could refer to the genre of Blues, but it can also infer that one is feeling down or sad. Cohn lost his mother at the age of 2 and father at the age of 12. This trip – however enjoyable it may be – doesn’t mean as much as family does to Cohn. He is searching for something very deep during his travels.

“Blue” could also be interpreted as blue-collar, asserting that though he was able to buy in a first class flight, he’s working class at heart, like all his idols in Memphis.

 Things I can’t understand

annotation.plain: In the music video, Dallin, Fahey, and Woodward are walking down a street, when they pass by two Americans discussing something, without paying an extra glance at them. To the three European-based singers, American English might sound foreign and “strange,” but they just don’t care.

annotations.lyric_fragment: But the air is so heavy and dry

annotation.plain:
As weird as this sounds, dry air is actually heavier than humid air:

In very hot, humid weather you might feel the air is heavier because moving around seems to take more energy than on dry days. Sticky days probably feel “heavier” because heat and high humidity slows the evaporation of perspiration, your body grows hotter and this saps your strength.

annotations.lyric_fragment: She’s gone, she’s gone

annotation.plain:
The specific series of events that the song is based on is unclear.

According to a 1985 article in Rolling Stone, the song is about Daryl Hall’s divorce to his then-wife Bryna Lublin. Alternatively, VH1’s Behind the Music explains the song as being written by John Oates after his girlfriend stood him up on New Year’s.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Let the carbon and monoxide choke my thoughts away, yeah

annotation.plain: “Carbon and monoxide” for carbon monoxide is an instance of hendiadys, a figure of speech in which a single idea is expressed by means of two words linked by a conjunction. The same phrase  was used by Paul Simon two years earlier, in Papa Hobo.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Sorry, Charlie

annotation.plain: In the 1960s Starkist Tuna started an ad campaign with a hipster, jive talking, cartoon character named Charlie the Tuna. He wore sunglasses and a beret and always talked about having “Good taste”. He wanted, for some reason, to be caught and turned into tuna fish by Starkist, but always got told “Sorry, Charlie”. Starkist didn’t want tuna that had good taste, it wanted tuna that tastes good. The commercials ran into the 1980s and he’s still their mascot on the labels.  As an aside, it might be possible that the origins of the idea for Sorry, Charlie came from the old Charlie Chan films. Charlie was a Chinese detective who was famous for saying things like “So sorry…” before he called people on lies, etc.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I roll the best weed

annotation.plain:
Snoop Dogg here makes the claim that he rolls the best weed.
15 years after the song’s release, in October 2019 on the Howard Stern Show it was unearthed that Snoop Dogg pays someone $40,000 – $50,000 a year to roll blunts.
Snoop was asked why he required a blunt roller, to which he simply replied: “I don’t have time.”
He has also stated that he smokes 81 blunts a day.
This song takes us back to a simpler time.

annotations.lyric_fragment: I got the Rollie on my arm and I’m pourin’ Chandon

annotation.plain:
A Rollie is short hand for saying Rolex.
Rolex and Chandon are expensive products.
Rolex is a the most famous brand of luxury Swiss watches.
Moët & Chandon is a brand of champagne, since it is being paired with Rolex it is most likely that Snoop is referring to the champagne and not the sparkling wine (from Napa Valley).

annotations.lyric_fragment: Living his grey flannel life

annotation.plain: In the 1950s, the image of “The Man in the Grey Flannel Suit” was coined, to indicate a young businessman who worked for a large corporation, followed its rules, did what was expected of him, wore non-flashy clothes, lived in the suburbs, didn’t make waves, and hoped to rise no higher than Vice President of his corporate division. In other words, a very dull person who no longer has adventures in New Orleans with sex workers.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Voulez-vous coucher avec moi ce soir?
 Voulez-vous coucher avec moi?

annotation.plain:
This translates in English to “Do you want to go to bed with me tonight?”

Vous is the formal or plural version of “you”. So either she’s proposing group sex, or is addressing a stranger or someone she considers her superior, which fits since the song is about a prostitute. The formal tense is used to address someone formally, namely a stranger or superior; you don’t have to be an expensive lay or prestigious person to speak with the formal tense.

 Though you call yourself by a different name (Different names)

annotation.plain:
Although Donna Summer wrote “Bad Girls” after being mad at a police officer for mistaking her friend for a prostitute, she realised that at the end of the day, everyone was the same. She later said:

Who am I to throw stones? We’re all the same really: whether she’s getting paid and I’m giving it away, we’re all out doing it. Who is a bad girl? In some ways aren’t we all even if it’s only in our minds?

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Toot toot, hey, beep beep
 Toot toot, hey, beep beep
 Toot toot, hey, beep beep
 Toot toot, hey, beep beep

annotation.plain:
The “toot-toot” “beep-beep” mimics a car trying to get a prostitute’s attention in Sunset Boulevard.

It can also be interpreted to represent police whistles and car horns on the busy streets of the night. Donna was inspired to write the song after
a police officer mistook her assistant for a prostitute.



The original demo did not have “toot-toot, hey, beep-beep.” Donna wrote in her memoir, Ordinary Girl:


We worked on it for days, but as much as I liked what [Giorgio Moroder] had done with it, I still felt there was something missing. I couldn’t put my finger on what it was, but it sounded incomplete.

Finally, after repeated listenings, a light bulb went off in my head. ‘You know what, Giorgio? I want to throw a little cherry on the top of this cake.’

How do you get the attention of a hooker? Especially if you’re in a car on Sunset? Let’s go back into the studio.‘ He cued up the tape and I added the toot-toot … ahh … beep beeps to the final mix.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
I’m going insane
 Starting the hurricane, releasing pain

annotation.plain:
Considering the other references this song makes to boxing, this line may be paying homage to middle-weight boxing champion, Rubin Carter, also known as “the Hurricane”.



His career lasted from 1961 to 1966, and he won 27 matches with 19 knock-outs, lost 12 matches and was knocked out once, and had 1 draw. His stellar career ended suddenly in June 1966 when he was arrested and later charged along with being convicted for murder. The trial was widely publicized and many believed he was innocent. The conviction of Carter sparked nationwide protests. According to the book, Damn Good Advice (For People With Talent), famous advertiser George Lois one night convinced Bob Dylan to bring awareness to the situation. The outcome was “Hurricane”, one of Dylan’s most recognizable tracks.

annotation.plain: He has made a news site and pretended to be a journalist on it, writing about his own comeback.

annotation.plain: Gotta mean the same as “pushing someone’s buttons,” just flipped in a way that suggests a similar mechanic, only pulling someone’s lever. In short, don’t aggravate LL or, as the bars follow, he’ll shoot you.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You to get with, Mr. Smith, don’t riff

annotation.plain: LL Cool J’s birth name is James Todd Smith

annotations.lyric_fragment:
The man of the hour, tower of power
 I’ll devour

annotation.plain:
Your typical bragaddocio from a rapper, but he throws in a references to

1) 60’s-70’s R&B band Tower of Power who have been sampled by many rappers

2) The tower is a classic symbol from Tarot, representing danger, crisis, destruction, and power.

The Tower signifies darkness and destruction on a physical scale.

All themes LL invokes here.

annotations.lyric_fragment: It ain’t no country club, either

annotation.plain: A line taken from Jean Harris’ book Stranger in Two Worlds. Having been convicted of murder and sent to Bedford Hills prison, the guard remarked to her on her arrival ‘this ain’t no country club, Jean.’

annotations.lyric_fragment: The bartender looks up from his want ads, but

annotation.plain: Plenty of people go to Los Angeles in search of a “big break,” but before they can get it, they usually work in a service industry job. Prior to the Internet, the best place to look for jobs, casting calls, etc. was in the Classifieds section of a newspaper.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
The good people of the world
 Are washing their cars on their lunch break
 Hosin’ and scrubbin’ as best they can in skirts and suits

annotation.plain: Washing a car is messy business, but these people are so intent on maintaining appearances that they’re trying to get their cars cleaned up not only while they should be eating and taking a break, but while they’re still in formal work clothes.

annotations.lyric_fragment: We are drinking beer at noon on Tuesday

annotation.plain: This is a day when most people (the “good people of the world”) would be working, but Sheryl and Billy are drinking in a bar.

annotations.lyric_fragment: It’s apropos of nothing

annotation.plain: “Apropos of nothing” means “without any particular significance or reason to be brought up, "out of nowhere.”  This applies to his previous line, and to his subsequent introduction.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And he’s plain ugly to me
 And I wonder if he’s ever had a day of fun in his whole life

annotation.plain: William is a victim of corporate America.

annotations.lyric_fragment: From his bottles of Bud

annotation.plain: Budweiser (or BudLight) alludes to one of William’s possible names.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Until the sun comes up over Santa Monica Boulevard

annotation.plain: Santa Monica Boulevard is a major west-east thoroughfare in Los Angeles County. It breaks off of Sunset Boulevard at Sunset Junction and ends at Ocean Avenue in Santa Monica near the Pacific Ocean, and passes through West Hollywood and Beverly Hills.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
They drive their shiny Datsuns and Buicks
 Back to the phone company, the record store, too
 Well, they’re nothing like Billy and me, ’cause

annotation.plain:
Datsun



and Buick
http://s3.amazonaws.com/filepicker-images-rapgenius/FwwKanfyQCySgOuK4ByN_buick.jpgare two different high-end cars. The “good people of the world” think they’re better than people like Billy or Sheryl because they have well paying jobs. But unlike Billy or Sheryl they don’t know how to have fun!

annotations.lyric_fragment:
He says his name is William
 But I’m sure he’s Bill or Billy or Mac or Buddy

annotation.plain: It sounds like this man was trying to make himself seem more respectable by using the formal name William, but Crow thinks he most likely goes by one of the name’s informal forms in his day-to-day life.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
No one opens the door
 For a native New Yorker

annotation.plain: New Yorkers are often stereotyped as rude or impatient.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Love could really be like a Broadway show

annotation.plain: Broadway is the musical theater quarter of New York. When something is “like on Broadway”, or “like a Broadway show”, it is the idealized, picture-perfect version of something. The girl used to believe that love could be perfect and easy, how it is often portrayed in Broadway shows.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Up in Harlem, down on Broadway

annotation.plain: Harlem and Broadway are two different neighborhoods in New York. The song says that the girl knows the city well, and she often is in various different parts of it.

annotations.lyric_fragment: You grew up ridin’ the subways

annotation.plain:
The New York subway is the main mass transportation system in the city, often referred to as the backbone of New York. It spans across the boroughs of Manhattan, Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens and the girl in the song, like so many others in New York, grew up a frequent user of the system.

New York is a big city, and often the easiest and most convenient way of moving from one part of it to another is by the subways.

annotations.lyric_fragment:
It’s your world and I’m just a squirrel
 Tryna get a nut to move your butt

annotation.plain:
The “just a squirrel tryin' to get a nut” is a verbatim reference to a line spoken by Oran ‘Juice’ Jones on his legendary track The Rain; toward the end of the song at approximately the 5:00 mark, when Oran delivers his monologue to his cheating girlfriend, he states “this is my world, you’re just a squirrel tryin' to get a nut.” In a similar vein, Freedom Williams in this case is telling the listener that he is now in their world, and he’s attempting to be successful at making the listener dance (i.e. that is the “nut”).

Oran ‘Juice’ Jones – The Rain:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9BjUtZLmYGw

annotation.plain: Another classic phrase taken from “La Di Da Di” by Doug E. Fresh and Slick Rick (1985). This is also a legendary sample in hip-hop canon.

annotation.plain: Stacy has crush but gets rejected????????

annotations.lyric_fragment:
And I know that you think it’s just a fantasy
 But since your dad walked out, your mom could use a guy like me

annotation.plain: These lyrics say that our protagonist has PROBABLY been WAITING for Stacy’s father to divorce with her mother so that he could fill in the spot

annotations.lyric_fragment: Is she there, or is she trying to give me the slip? (Give me the slip)

annotation.plain: “Giving the slip' to somebody means escaping from someone or someTHING

annotations.lyric_fragment: And the way she said, “You missed a spot over there” (Spot over there)

annotation.plain: In the song she is most likely refering to the boy missing a spot of grass somewhere, but in the music video she is likely talking to the massuer (massage giver) telling him that he missed a spot somewhere on her body, likely her back.

annotations.lyric_fragment: Your mom came out with just a towel on (Towel on)

annotation.plain: Similarly to how people don’t go outside with their pyjamas on, towels are not exactly public wear. Most likely Stacy’s mom doesn’t care how he sees her because in her mind, he’s still a child. Possibly though, she actually is trying to be appealing to him in some way. Evidently, this is what the protagonist hopes for.

annotations.lyric_fragment: [Intro]

annotation.plain:
After listening to the staccatoed guitar riff, you can identify a similarity with The Cars‘ intro to “Just What I Needed”.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z5-rdr0qhWk

(Fountains of Wayne’s bassist Adam Schlesinger paid homage to them while discussing the song, as well.)

annotations.lyric_fragment:
Stacy’s mom has got it goin’ on
 Stacy’s mom has got it goin’ on
 Stacy’s mom has got it goin’ on
 Stacy’s mom has got it goin’ on

annotation.plain:
Stacy’s mom is as smokin' as Sports Illustrated model Rachel Hunter was in the song’s music video.



Side note: Hunter has personally been on both ends of the generation gap Fountains of Wayne is expressing in this song. She was married to rock star Rod Stewart, who is 24 years her senior. A few years after they divorced, Hunter became engaged to NHL hockey player Jarret Stoll, who is 13 years her junior. That relationship ended in heartbreak too, however, as Stoll called their wedding off just seven weeks before the big day.

Hunter and Stewart also have two kids together: Renee and Liam; inconveniently, neither one of those names is ‘Stacy’.
